In this verse, K·πõ·π£·πáa delivers His concluding message - that He alone, the one and only real and eternal, is to be attained by means of the temporary mate- rial body. The attainment of Him is possible only by bhakti and not by any other means. By this instruction to Uddhava, Krsna advocates the practice of bhakti for all human beings, since in this context Uddhava is representative of humanity in general. From K·πõ·π£·πáa’s statement, it is understood that intelligence (buddhi) is not measured by the extent of a person’s wealth, power, status, worldly knowledge, or familial and social prominence. From the everyday point of view, if a person invests one dollar and earns a thousand, people will consider him to be smart. If another person is able to gain a pound of gold from a dollar’s investment, he will be thought of as smarter still. If, however, with the same investment, a person can procure a 1000 carat diamond, he will be known as the smartest of the lot. Beyond even this, if a person were to acquire the mythic philosopher’s stone (i.e., touchstone) by spending a single dollar, his intelligence would be estimated as limitless. This application of the intelligence in everyday affairs is, how- ever, far from being the hallmark of the intellective capacity (buddhi). The true function of buddhi is “discernment” (viveka), which refers to the ability to distinguish between the eternal and the perishable. In this respect, a person who is firmly resolved to the path of bhakti is the most highly discerning individual. How so? Because by engaging his essentially unreal (asat) and perish- able ears, tongue, and other senses in direct acts of devotion, he obtains in return the transcendental, eternal, supremely blissful Bhagavan. Unlike the investment of a dollar, the devotee’s engagement of the senses in such devotional acts does not even require him to part with his senses. He retains them and still obtains the most precious object possible. These senses are all material and temporary. They 436 85 K·πõ·π£·πáa’s Concluding Instruction Is in Bhakti will fade away of their own accord in due course of time. There can- not be a more discriminating use of the material body and senses than to engage them in bhakti. But such discerning individuals are exceedingly rare on earth. This caliber of discernment is virtually unknown to most people, especially outside India. In the next anuccheda, ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´ draws from the Twelfth Canto, citing the concluding instructions of ≈örƒ´ Sukadeva, the prime speaker of Srimad Bhagavata. 437 17 Suka Instructs King Parik·π£it Anuccheda 86 Anuccheda 86 ≈öuka’s Concluding Instruction Is in Hearing Lila-kathƒÅ ‡•Æ‡•¨ ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•® ‡•§‡•™‡•§‡•™‡•¶ ) - AT THE Conclusion of his instructions as well, ≈örƒ´ Suka recom- mended bhakti [as the abhidheya] by way of reference to the process of hearing ( ≈õravana ) : ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡•§ ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§µ‡§£‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡•• ‡•ß‡•©‡•Ø ‡•• For a person tormented by the forest fire of manifold miseries and aspiring to cross the insurmountable ocean of material exis- tence (samsara), there is no vessel other than absorption in the aesthetic rapture (rasa) of the narrations of the divine play of BhagavƒÅn Purusottama [ Sri Krsna ] . ( SB 12.4.40 ) 1 ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ö - " ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ- ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ | ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi comments: “The clause na anya·∏• plava·∏•, ’there is no other vessel,’ means, ’there is no other method (sadhana) to cross,’ because of the impossibility of doing so by any other 1 samsara-sindhum ati-dustaram uttitirsor nanya·∏• plavo bhagavata·∏• purusottamasya lilƒÅ katha-rasa-nisevanam antarena pumso bhaved vividha-du·∏•kha-davƒÅrditasya 441I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya means (upaya). Consequently, hearing the narrations (katha) of Bhagavan is alone that which is to be enacted, as per one’s capacity.” [Here ends Sridhara Svami’s comment.] Because the predilection (prav·πõtti) for all other limbs of bhakti is necessarily preceded by hearing, it is rightly said [by Sridhara SvƒÅmi] that it is impossible by any means other than this. ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•ß) - ≈örƒ´ Suka’s beginning and concluding statements from the next chapter of Srimad Bhagavata are in correspondence with his latter remark. He opens with the following words: ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§ú‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§É || ‡•ß‡•™‡•¶ || Continuously being depicted here [in this Srimad Bhagavata MahƒÅpurana] is ≈örƒ´ Hari, who is immanent as the Self of the cosmos and transcendent as Bhagavan. It is from His benevo- lence that Brahma is born and from His fury that Rudra [≈öiva] is brought forth into being. (SB 12.5.1)2 ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•ß‡•© ) - ≈öuka then ends the chapter with these words: 2 —ç ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡•É‡§™ ‡•§ ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∏‡§ø ‡•• ‡•ß‡•™‡•ß ‡•• I have narrated all this to you, dear child, in response to your inquiry regarding the divine acts of Bhagavan Hari, the Imma- nent Self of the cosmos. O King, what more do you wish to hear? (SB 12.5.13)3 ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§ ‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞- ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡•ã‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á “‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å atr√¢nuvar·πáyate’bhik·π£·πáam vi≈õvƒÅtmƒÅ bhagavan hari·∏• yasya prasadajo brahma rudra·∏• krodha-samudbhavah etat te kathitam tata yad ƒÅtmƒÅ prstav√§n n·πõpa harer vi≈õvƒÅtmanas cestam kim bh≈´yah srotum icchasi 442 86 Suka’s Concluding Instruction Is in Hearing Lƒ´lƒÅ-kathƒÅ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•® ‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø- ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§è‡§µ ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§≠‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ Because the previously mentioned process of hearing Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa’s lƒ´lƒÅ-kathƒÅ possesses the type of glory indicated in these two statements, it alone is established as preeminent. On this basis, because hearing is thus recommended [as the means to be undertaken] in both the opening and closing statements of this chapter, bhakti itself, characterized by hearing (≈õravana), is established as preeminent here as well. In between the opening and concluding statements, we find instructions on j√±ana, such as those found in this verse: “O King, cast aside the foolish notion that you will die” (SB 12.5.2).* This instruction was given just to bring forth at the crucial moment of death the fixity of the king’s faith (ni·π£·π≠hƒÅ) in bhakti, which Suka had observed in him earlier. Suka’s offering such an instruction is comparable to Bhagavan’s enticing His unalloyed devotees to accept the boon of liberation. This is understood because from the very outset, King Parik·π£it had already aban- doned the fear of death of his own volition due to his resolute faith in bhakti. Additionally, even after hearing the instruc- tions on j√±ƒÅna, he himself showed that his fixity was in bhakti alone. ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡•á ‚Äú‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•Ø‡•§‡•´) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø “‡§¶‡§ß‡•å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•Ø‡•§‡•≠) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ In this regard, the king’s prior faith in bhakti is shown in the First Canto: “Recognizing the sacred service (seva) of the feet of ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa as the highest possible attainment, the king sat down on the bank of the ‘River of the Immortals’ [the Ganga], having calmly resolved to embrace his imminent death while fasting” (SB 1.19.5).5 4 tvam tu rajan mari≈üyeti pasu-buddhim imƒÅm jahi 5 k·πõ·π£·πáanghri-sevam adhimanyamana upavisat prayam amartya-nadyam 443 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya And in this statement as well: “Being of one-pointed devo- tional regard (ananya-bhƒÅvah), observing the vow of sage-like tranquility (muni- vratah), and having abandoned all attach- ments, this descendant of the Pandavas [Parƒ´k·π£it] fixed his mind meditatively on the lotus feet of Sri Mukunda [Krsna]” (SB 1.19.7). ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‚Äú‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§π‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ó‡§æ‡§•‡§æ: " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß | ‡•ß‡•Ø / ‡•ß‡•´ ) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The king gave up the fear of death exclusively on the basis of his resolute faith (nistha) in bhakti, as shown by his own statement: “Let the treachery conjured by the brƒÅhma·πáa consume me, or let the snake Tak·π£aka bite me, just go on singing the glories of BhagavƒÅn Visnu” (SB 1.19.15 ) ? ‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø - ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•¨‡•§‡•®-‡•™ ) - Even after hearing Suka’s instructions on j√±ana, the king showed the firmness of his faith in bhakti, as in the follow- ing three verses. Without attributing much importance to the instructions he received on j√±ƒÅna, he pointed out that the perfec- tion he had attained was due only to bhakti, consisting primarily of hearing: ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§®‡•ã ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•ß‡•™‡•® ‡•• ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É ‡•• ‡•ß‡•™‡•© ‡•• ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•ß‡•™‡•™ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ I stand perfected and blessed by you, the very embodiment of grace, because you have made it possible for me to hear about SƒÅk·π£ƒÅt Bhagavan Hari, who is without beginning or end. I am ‚óè dadhau mukund√§nghrim ananya-bhavo muni-vrato mukta-samasta-sargah dvijopas·πõstah kuhakas tak·π£ako va dasatv alam gayata vi·π£nu-gƒÅthƒÅ·∏• 7 444 86 Suka’s Concluding Instruction Is in Hearing Lila-katha not at all surprised that magnanimous souls whose regard is exclusively intent upon Bhagavan Acyuta bestow their grace on the ignorant who are tormented by material miseries. It is from you that we have heard this Purana Samhita, in which the most glorious Bhagavan has been continuously described. (SB 12.6.2-4) ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å- ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ú ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•¨‡•§‡•´-‡•¨ ) - In the first of the next two verses, just to honor Suka’s words, the king affirmed the brahma-j√±ƒÅna he received from Suka as the cause of his casting off the fear of the snake Tak·π£aka. In spite of this, in the ensuing verse he then prayed for the blessing that his speech and mind be absorbed in singing and meditating upon the names of Bhagavan Adhok·π£aja [≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa], who is con- stitutionally beyond the direct intuition of Brahman (brahma- j√±ƒÅna): ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§® ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•• ‡•ß‡•™‡•´ ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ú‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç || ‡•ß‡•™‡•¨ ‡•§‡•§ O Venerable Master, I fear neither Taksaka nor any other form of death since I have become established in the fearless liberated state of immediate Brahman-realization (brahma-nirvƒÅ·πáam), revealed by you. Grant me your blessing, O sage, that while restraining my speech and fixing my mind, free from all predis- positions toward desire, on Bhagavan Adhok·π£aja [K·πõ·π£·πáa], I may give up my vital life force. (SB 12.6.5-6) siddho’smy anugrhito’smi bhavata karu·πáƒÅtmanƒÅ ≈õravito yac ca me s√§k·π£ad anadi-nidhano harih naty-adbhutam aham manye mahatam acyut√§tmanƒÅm aj√±e·π£u tƒÅpa-tapte≈üu bh√ºtesu yad anugrahah purƒÅ·πáa-samhitam etam asrau≈üma bhavato vayam yasyam khaluttama·∏•-sloko bhagavan anuvar·πáyate bhagavams tak·π£akadibhyo m·πõtyubhyo na bibhemy aham‚Üí 445 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç- ‡§§‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•¨‡•§‡•≠ ) - Thereafter, in one verse, the king makes evident the truth directly self-disclosed to him, that the perfection of knowl- edge ( j√±ƒÅna) and realization (vij√±ƒÅna), which dispels all igno- rance, is indeed implicit in the bliss of beholding the lotus feet of BhagavƒÅn: ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•™‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Because you have revealed to me Bhagavan’s supreme feet, which are the source of all auspiciousness, my nescience has been completely eradicated through fixity in knowledge and immediate realization. ( SB 12.6.7) 10 ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§¶‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‚Äú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•à‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡•á‡§ú‡•á ‡§ñ‡§ó‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú- ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß|‡•ß‡•Æ ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•¨) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ In this verse, to tender the meaning of the word pada as “lotus feet” is validated by the following statement from the First Canto: ‚ÄúBy virtue of the awareness ( jnƒÅna) disclosed by Suka, the son of Vyasa, King Parƒ´k·π£it attained the feet of Bhagavan Krsna, whose flag bears the emblem of Garuda‚Äù (SB 1.18.16). ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•Æ‡•§‡•®-‡•™) ‚Äì The import of the topic under discussion is clarified by Sri Suta’s following statements from that same chapter: ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡•ã‡§∞‡•Å‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•ß‡•™‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Å‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•™‡•Ø ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ pravisto brahma-nirvanam abhayam darsitam tvaya anujanihi mam brahman vacam yacchamy adhoksaje mukta-kƒÅmƒÅ≈õayam ceta·∏• prave≈õya vis·πõjƒÅmy asun 10 aj√±ƒÅnarn ca nirastar me jnana-vijnana-nisthaya 11 bhavata darsitam k·π£emam param bhagavatah padam j√±anena vaiyƒÅsaki sabditena bheje khagendra dhvaja-pada-mulam 446 86 Suka’s Concluding Instruction Is in Hearing Lila-kathƒÅ O Saunaka, the king was not at all bewildered by the dread- ful fear of death from Tak·π£aka, occasioned by the wrath of the brƒÅhma·πáa boy, because he had offered the very root of his attention (ƒÅ≈õayah) to Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa. (SB 1.18.2)12 For those whose discussions are exclusively intent upon the most glorious Bhagavan, who thus drink the nectar of the nar- rations of His divine acts, and who are constantly absorbed in remembrance of His lotus feet, there is no delusion even at the time of death. (SB 1.18.4)13 ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•ß‡•Ø ‡•§ ‡•©‡•≠ ) - Additionally, at the end of the First Canto, King Parik·π£it had previously submitted the following inquiry: ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§π ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•´‡•¶ ‡•§‡•§ Therefore, I request you, O supreme teacher of the yogis, to delin- eate that engagement which is imperative to be undertaken by a person about to die and by which one can attain complete perfection in this world. (SB 1.19.37)14 ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•á ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•® ‡•§ ‡•© ‡•§ ‡•™‡•Ø-‡•´‡•ß ) - The response to this earlier question of the king is given in the third chapter of the Twelfth Canto itself. By way of reply, ≈örƒ´ Suka personally instructed him specifically to meditate upon and glorify Bhagavan: 13 ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•´‡•ß ‡•• ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ 12 brahma-kopotthitad yas tu tak·π£akƒÅt prƒÅ·πáa-viplavat na sammumohorubhayad bhagavaty arpitƒÅ≈õayah nottamasloka-v√§rtt√§nam jusatƒÅm tat-katham·πõtam syat sambhramo’nta-kale’pi smaratam tat-padambujam 14 ata·∏• prechami samsiddhim yoginam paramam gurum purusasyeha yat karyam mriyama·πáasya sarvatha 447 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§É ‡•• ‡•ß‡•´‡•® ‡•• ‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•´‡•© ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ Therefore, O King, with the totality of your being, install Bhaga- van Kesava [K·πõ·π£·πáa] in your heart. By thus focusing your mind on Him with resolute attention while quitting the body, you will attain the supreme destination. Those on the verge of death should meditate upon Bhagavan, who is the Almighty Supreme Regulator (Parame≈õvara). By virtue of such meditation, my dear King, the Supreme Self of all living beings, who is the ground and refuge of everything, leads them to the state of divine love for Him (atma-bhavam) [which is identical to His own Self (parama-prematma-tulyatƒÅm)]. O King, Kaliyuga is indeed a storehouse of all vice, yet it has one great virtue. Merely by singing the names of Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa, one is freed from all bondage and attains the supreme destination. (SB 12.3.49-51)15 ‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ- ‡§∏‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ In the first of these three verses, the word tata·∏•, “thus,” means, “as a consequence of focusing the mind in this regard (tatra), i.e., on Bhagavan Kesava.” The word avahita·∏• means, “with res- olute attention” (k·πõta-avadhƒÅna·∏•). In the second verse, the com- pound atma-bhƒÅvam, “the state of divine love for Him,” means, “that bhakti which is intrinsic to His own Self” (atmano bhaktim). The meaning of these three verses as a whole may be summed- up as follows: “Forget about meditation, which is perfected with great endeavor, because one can attain the supreme destination simply by kirtana, which is easy to perform.” 15 tasmat sarvƒÅtmana rajan hrdi-stham kuru kesavam mriyamano hy avahitas tato yasi parƒÅ·πÅ gatim mriyamanair abhidhyeyo bhagavan parame≈õvara·∏• atma-bhavam nayaty anga sarvƒÅtmƒÅ sarva-sambhava·∏• kaler dosa-nidhe rajann asti hy eko mahan gunah kirtanƒÅd eva k·πõ·π£·πáasya mukta-bandhah param vrajet 448 86 Suka’s Concluding Instruction Is in Hearing Lila-kathƒÅ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø " ‡§® ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§É ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•® | ‡•®|‡•©‡•© ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ " ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•©‡•§‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‚Äú‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•©‡•≠) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ | In the Second Canto as well, Suka replied to King Parik·π£it’s ques- tion about the duty of one about to die [SB 1.19.37, cited above], beginning with this verse: For human beings entangled in this world of repeated birth and death, there is no other path more auspicious than that by which bhakti-yoga for Bhagavan Vasudeva can come into being. (SB 2.2.33)16 ≈öuka’s explanation continued up to the first verse of the next chapter: “O King, I have given this reply to your question as to what a discerning human being should do, and especially for one on the verge of death” (SB 2.3.1). Thus from this group of verses, pure bhakti-yoga, consisting of various limbs, is understood to be the response to the king’s question. In the midst of this series, we find the following statement: Those who drink from the filled cups of their ears the ambrosia of the stories of Bhagavan, the beloved Self of the devotees, purify their hearts, which were adulterated with sense impressions, and attain the lotus feet of Bhagavan. (SB 2.2.37)18 By verses such as this, hearing the lilƒÅ-katha of Bhagavan is understood to be the supreme conclusion. Here we may again refer to the verse cited earlier in this anuccheda: “O King, cast aside the foolish notion that you will die” (SB 12.5.2). On the 16 na hy ato’nyah sivah pantha visata·∏• sams·πõtƒÅv iha 17 18 vasudeve bhagavati bhakti-yogo yato bhavet evam etan nigaditam prstavan yad bhavan mama n·πõ·πáƒÅm yan mriyamananam manusyesu manisinƒÅm pibanti ye bhagavata atmana·∏• satƒÅm kathamrtam sravana-putesu sambh·πõtam punanti te visaya-vidusitƒÅ≈õayam vrajanti tac-carana-saroruhantikam 19 tvam tu rajan mari≈üyeti pasu-buddhim imam jahi 449 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya basis of the above analysis, it was thus rightly asserted that this statement was made just to make evident the king’s reso- lute faith (ni·π£·π≠ha) in bhakti, because bhakti alone is the import (tƒÅtparya) of Suka’s teachings. ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç “‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç” ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•ß‡•Æ‡•ß‡•©) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç “‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•®|‡•´|‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø || ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡§É ‡•• Therefore, the intent of the king’s prayer in the eighth chapter of the Second Canto is also nothing other than bhakti: “Let my mind be fixed on ≈örƒ´ Krsna, free of all attachments, as I cast away this mortal coil” (SB 2.8.3).20 In conclusion, it can be said that the point made in SB 12.4.40, cited at the very beginning of this anuccheda, that there is no means to cross the ocean of material existence other than absorption in hearing Bhagavan’s lila-katha has been rightly established by verses such as SB 12.5.1 [in which hearing lƒ´lƒÅ-kathƒÅ is understood as the preeminent process]. Commentary ≈öRI SUKADEVA began his reply to King Parik·π£it’s question about the essential engagement for a person about to die in the first chap- ter of the Second Canto. His very first recommendation was to immerse oneself directly in bhakti: Therefore, O descendant of Bharata, a person seeking ultimate release from all fear should hear about, glorify, and remember Bhagavan Hari [K·πõ·π£·πáa], who is the Supreme Master (Isvara) and the Immanent Self of all beings. (SB 2.1.5)21 20 krsne nivesya ni·∏•sangam manas tyaksye kalevaram 21 tasmad bharata sarvƒÅtmƒÅ bhagavan isvaro harih ≈õrotavyah kirtitavya≈õ ca smartavyas cecchatabhayam 450 86 Suka’s Concluding Instruction Is in Hearing Lila-katha Later, at the conclusion of Suka’s instructions to the king, he again recommends bhakti in the form of hearing ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa’s lƒ´lƒÅ- katha (SB 12.4.40). From this analysis of Suka’s opening and con- cluding statements, it is unmistakably evident that he advocates bhakti alone as the answer to the king’s question. This is further supported by his numerous other statements about bhakti during his lengthy discourse. Some of these statements are spoken by him directly and some by other sages whom he quotes. These were illustrated beginning from Anuccheda 26 onward. An objection may be raised in this regard. The fifth chapter of the Twelfth Canto is the final chapter spoken by Sukadeva. There- after, he departs from the assembly of King Parik·π£it and the sages, who had gathered on the bank of the Ganga River. In his conclud- ing words, he speaks on j√±ƒÅna-yoga, or the teachings that pertain to Advaitavada, in statements such as the following: O King, cast aside the bestial notion that you will die. It is not the case that like the body, you did not exist previously and have now come into being, nor in the future will you ever cease to be. (SB 12.5.2) 22 Just as when a clay pot is broken, the space that was enclosed within the pot becomes simply open space, exactly as it was prior to delimitation, so too when the body perishes, the jiva again becomes Brahman. (SB 12.5.5)23 “I am Brahman, the supreme refuge. Indeed, Brahman I am, the supreme destination.” Directly intuiting the self in this manner and investing the individual self into the indivisible Absolute Self, you will perceive neither the Taksaka snake, who is biting and lick- ing your feet with its poisonous fangs, nor your own body, nor the universe, as separate from the Self. (SB 12.5.11-12)24 22 tvam tu rajan mari≈üyeti pasu-buddhim imam jahi 23 na j√§ta·∏• prag abh≈´todya deha-vat tvam na nark·π£yasi ghate bhinne gha·π≠ƒÅkƒÅ≈õa akasa·∏• syad yatha pura evam dehe m·πõte jivo brahma sampadyate punah 24 aham brahma param dhama brahmaha·πÅ paramam padam evam samiksya catmƒÅnam ƒÅtmany adhaya niskale dasantam tak·π£akam pade lelihƒÅnam visƒÅnanai·∏• na drak·π£yasi ≈õarƒ´ram ca visva·πÅ ca prthag √§tmanah 451I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya These statements are in direct opposition to the fundamental principle of bhakti. So how can it be legitimately maintained that ≈örƒ´ Suka’s intention lies in bhakti alone? ≈öri Jiva GosvƒÅmi provides a penetrating response to this ques- tion. His analysis proceeds along the following lines. First, he examines the faith of King Parƒ´k·π£it, whose ni·π£·π≠hƒÅ, or resolute fix- ity, was not in j√±ƒÅna but in bhakti. This is perfectly clear from his own statements and from those of others spoken about him. His attainment of the state of fearlessness was specifically because his mind was fixed on ≈öri Krsna alone. Then, even after hearing the above-mentioned instructions on j√±ƒÅna, Parik·π£it demonstrated that his fixity was in bhakti alone. He did not transfer his internal allegiance to j√±ƒÅna. This is clear from the king’s final words to his teacher Suka in which he expressed his profound gratitude for having been blessed with the opportunity to hear about SƒÅk·π£ƒÅt Bhagavan Hari (SB 12.6.2-4).25 With the exception of a few verses pertaining to j√±ƒÅna that are submitted intermittently throughout Srimad Bhagavata, ≈örƒ´ ≈öuka glorified and recommended bhakti alone to the king. A few of these statements are cited in this anuccheda. Yet, in response to the king’s question regarding the essential engagement for a person on the verge of death, ≈örƒ´ ≈öuka recommended only bhakti (SB 2.1.11, 2.2.33- 2.3.1, and 12.3.49-51). rec- Although in the fifth chapter of the Twelfth Canto, ≈örƒ´ Suka ommended j√±ƒÅna to King Parƒ´k·π£it, his intention was rooted ulti- mately in bhakti. This is understood from the first and last verses of this chapter (SB 12.5.1 and SB 12.5.13), both cited in this anuccheda. In these two verses, the preeminence of bhakti characterized by hearing is clearly evident. In this regard, SB 12.5.13 is the final verse spoken by ≈öri Suka. 25 siddho’smy anugrhito’smi bhavata karunƒÅtmanƒÅ ≈õravito yac ca me sƒÅk·π£ad anadi-nidhano hari·∏• natyadbhutam aham manye mahatƒÉm acyutƒÅtmanƒÅm aj√±e·π£u tƒÅpa-tapte≈üu bh√ºte≈üu yad anugrahah purana-samhitam etam asrausma bhavato vayam yasyam khaluttama-sloko bhagavan anuvar·πáyate 452 86 Suka’s Concluding Instruction Is in Hearing Lila-kathƒÅ It is to be noted that King Parik·π£it was born in the family of great devotees of Krsna. He was the grandson of Arjuna, a friend and devotee of K·πõ·π£·πáa, and the son of Abhimanyu, whose maternal uncle was K·πõ·π£·πáa. Being born and brought up in such an illustrious family of K·πõ·π£·πáa’s intimate associates, it was naturally expected that he himself would be a great devotee. Indeed, he was an extraordi- narily rare individual, who got the opportunity to see Krsna while still in his mother’s womb. He was named Parƒ´k·π£it (lit., “the exam- iner”), because after birth he was constantly searching for that all- attractive person, ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa, whom he first saw in the womb. As a consequence, it would have been completely out of character if later in life, he would have given up his attraction for K·πõ·π£·πáa and adopted the path of j√±ƒÅna. An additional consideration is that the speaker of the BhƒÅga- vata, ≈örƒ´ Sukadeva, had previously set aside his fixity in j√±ƒÅna sub- sequent to his transformation and the onset of his absorption in bhakti. As such, it would have been highly incongruent with his own experience to recommend j√±ƒÅna-yoga to the king. Accordingly, S≈´ta GosvƒÅmƒ´ makes the following statement in regard to ≈örƒ´ Suka in his concluding prayers: I offer my obeisances unto ≈örƒ´la Vyasadeva’s son, ≈örƒ´ ≈öuka, who destroys all sins. Although his consciousness was completely filled with the bliss of the self, and though he had consequently cast off all other feelings and thoughts, his essence (sara) was irresistibly drawn by the enchanting lil√§s of Bhagavan Ajita, K·πõ·π£·πáa. Out of compassion, he thus delineated this Purana, which illumines reality. (SB 12.12.69)26 From the above analysis, it is concluded that Sri Suka could not possibly have advocated the path of j√±ƒÅna to Parik·π£it as the answer to his question. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ comments that these statements of Suka in regard to j√±ƒÅna-yoga were made only to make evident the king’s resolute and steadfast commitment to bhakti. He wanted 26 sva-sukha-nibh·πõta-cetas tad-vyudastanya-bhƒÅvo ‘py ajita-rucira-lilak·πõ·π£·π≠a-sƒÅras tadƒ´yam vyatanuta k·πõpaya yas tattva-dipam puranam tam akhila-v·πõjina-ghna·πÅ vyƒÅsa-s≈´num nato’smi 453 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya to demonstrate to the great sages sitting in the assembly that even after hearing instructions on j√±ƒÅna from his teacher, the king did not deviate from his nistha in devotion. In this way, he showed the king’s fixity as well as bhakti’s superiority over j√±ana, since the teachings on j√±ƒÅna could not unsettle him. Bhagavan Himself occasionally behaves in a similar manner. When He appears to a devotee, He may first offer him mukti. A true devotee, however, rejects such a boon, because his interest is in bhakti alone and not in mukti. Bhagavan Nrsimha tried to seduce the great devotee Prahlada in this way but was unsuccessful, as expressed in the following statement: Although Prahlada, the best of the asuras, was enticed in this manner [as described in the previous verses] by boons that are extremely tempting to people in general, he did not desire any of them, because he was exclusively devoted to Bhagavan. (SB 7.9.55)27 Next, ≈örƒ´ Jiva refers to the concluding words of S≈´ta GosvƒÅmi. 27 454 evam pralobhyamano’pi varair loka-pralobhanai·∏• ekƒÅntitvad bhagavati naicchat tan asurottama·∏• 18 Suta Instructs Saunaka Anucchedas 87-91 Anuccheda 87 S≈´ta’s Concluding Instruction Is in Bhakti ‡•Æ‡•≠ ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§É (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•´‡•® ) - AT THE END of ≈örƒ´ S≈´ta’s instructions as well, [bhakti is estab- lished as the abhidheya] in five verses, beginning with the following statement: ‡§®‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§§‡•á ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§∂‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á ‡§® ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•´‡•™ ‡•• Even the awareness (j√±ƒÅna) that is disclosive of Brahman (nai≈ükarmyam), by virtue of its being free from all taints (nira- njanam), is inadequately illuminating (alam na sobhate)’ if devoid of devotional affect (bhava) for Bhagavan Acyuta [≈örƒ´ The predicate “is inadequately illuminating,” which is stated of nai≈ükarmya-j√±ƒÅna, is a translation of the words alam na sobhate, lit., “it does not illuminate or beautify adequately (alam).” ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi glosses the phrase in question as naparoksa-paryantam bhavati, meaning that (if devoid of bhakti) even naiskarmya-j√±ana cannot directly disclose Brahman. This verse is almost identical to SB 1.5.12, discussed in Anuccheda 23. The translation here, which is in accordance with Sridhara Svami’s comment, differs only slightly from that of SB 1.5.12, which was also based on his comment in that regard. The essential meaning of both verses is, however, one and the same. 457 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya K·πõ·π£·πáa]. What then can be said of motivated action [kamya- karma], which is always inauspicious, or even of the incompa- rable [unmotivated] action (anuttamam), when not offered to Bhagavan? (SB 12.12.52)2 ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ö - ‚Äú‡§á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‡§®‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡•ç ‡§® ‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡•• ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi comments as follows: “S√ºta spoke this verse to indicate that the devotional acts, such as the glorification (kirtana) of Bhagavan, are to be esteemed even more greatly than the practices of j√±ƒÅna and karma. The word naiskarmyam, ‘free from bondage to action,’ means, ‘Brahman,’ and the word j√±ƒÅnam, ‘awareness,’ means, ’that which is disclosive of Brah- man.’ The reason why such awareness is disclosive of Brahman, is indicated by the word niranjanam, meaning that it dispels all limiting adjuncts (upƒÅdhis). Yet, even awareness freed of upƒÉdhis, if devoid of bhakti to Bhagavan Acyuta, is inadequately illuminating (alam na ≈õobhate), meaning that its disclosive power cannot culminate in unmediated cognition of the Truth that lies beyond all perception (n√§parok·π£a-paryantam bhavati).” Commentary S≈™TA GOSVƒÄMƒ™ is the first speaker in Srimad Bhagavata. In the very first chapter of the First Canto, Saunaka raised six questions, which S≈´ta GosvƒÅmƒ´ began to answer in the second chapter of the First Canto. From the very outset, he spoke of bhakti as the means of attainment (abhidheya). This topic was analyzed in the first 21 anucchedas of this book. Now, in the penultimate chapter of ≈örimad Bhagavata, Suta concludes his teachings by again emphasiz- ing bhakti as the abhidheya. The verse cited here (SB 12.12.52) is of great importance, because it is one of the few verses in the BhƒÅga- vata that has been repeated. It was also spoken by Narada to Vyasa 2 458 nai≈ükarmyam apy acyuta-bhava-varjitam na ≈õobhate j√±ƒÅnam alam niranjanam kutah punah sasvad abhadram isvare na hy arpitam karma yad apy anuttamam 87 Suta’s Concluding Instruction Is in Bhakti (SB 1.5.12) and discussed earlier in Anuccheda 23. ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmƒ´’s comment in this regard makes it clear that the independent cul- tivation of j√±ƒÅna without the support of bhakti is inefficacious in granting the unmediated cognition of Brahman. 459 Anuccheda 88 Bhakti Bestows Unbroken Remembrance of BhagavƒÅn ‡•Æ‡•Æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•ß‡•® ‡•§‡•´‡•© ) - ≈öRI S≈™TA continues:1 ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§™‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§É || ‡•ß‡•´‡•´ || The immense labor expended in discharging prescribed duties pertaining to one’s varna and a≈õrama, and in undergoing penance, study of the Vedas, and other similar practices, cul- minates only in wealth accompanied by fame. But by hearing and repeating the glories of ≈örƒ´ Hari, one attains unbroken remembrance of the lotus feet of Bhagavan, who is the support of the Goddess of Fortune. (SB 12.12.53)2 ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ö - " ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã- ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡•• ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi comments: “Moreover, the immense labor expended in executing one’s prescribed duties in var·πáƒÅ≈õrama and in other practices culminates only in wealth accompanied by fame, or in one of these two alone, but not in the supreme *This is the second of the five verses cited from Suta’s concluding instructions. 2 ya≈õa·∏•-≈õriyƒÅm eva pari≈õramah paro varnasramacara-tapa·∏•-≈õrutadisu avismrti·∏• ≈õridhara-pada-padmayor gunanuvada-≈õravanadirbhir hareh 460 88 Bhakti Bestows Unbroken Remembrance of Bhagavan object of attainment (parama-puru≈üƒÉrtha). This is the intended sense. But by devotional acts, such as repeating the glories of ≈öri Hari, one attains continuous remembrance of the lotus feet of Bhagavan ≈örƒ´dhara, the husband of the Goddess of Fortune.” Commentary IN THIS verse, ≈örƒ´ S≈´ta demonstrates that the parama-dharma of pure devotion is the abhidheya by contrasting it with var·πáƒÅ≈õrama- dharma. The latter requires a tremendous expenditure of labor, but the result attained is merely temporary and insignificant. On the other hand, bhakti is executed joyfully and bestows the eter- nal blissful fruit of unbroken remembrance of Bhagavan ≈örƒ´dhara. From this, it is clear that bhakti is the abhidheya and not var·πáƒÅ≈õrama- dharma. 461Anuccheda 89 Concomitant Effects of Remembrance ‡•Æ‡•Ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•® ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•® ‡•§‡•´‡•™ ) - ≈öRI S≈™TA said:1 ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§§‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•´‡•¨ ‡•• Continuous remembrance of the lotus feet of Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa destroys all inauspiciousness, extends tranquility, purifies the heart, awards bhakti for the Supreme Self, and bestows knowledge accompanied by immediate realization and detachment. (SB 12.12.54)2 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• 1 The meaning is self-evident. Commentary THIS verse describes the effects that naturally ensue as a conse- quence of the uninterrupted remembrance of the feet of Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa. Certainly, the process that is ascertained as the abhi- dheya, or the means to the ultimate attainment, should establish one in an internal state of purity, all-auspiciousness, tranquility, This is the third of the five verses cited from Suta’s concluding instructions. avism·πõtih k·πõ·π£·πáa-padaravindayoh k·π£inoty abhadrani ca sam tanoti sattvasya suddhim paramƒÅtma-bhakti·πÅ j√±ƒÅna·πÅ ca vij√±ƒÅna-virƒÅga-yuktam 462 89 Concomitant Effects of Remembrance and immediate realization of the Truth accompanied by the total absence of material hankering. Here, S≈´ta confirms that bhakti is precisely just such a means. 463 Anuccheda 90 Bhakti Is the Supreme State of Blessedness ‡•Ø‡•¶ | ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•® ‡•ß‡•®/‡•´‡•´ ) - ≈öRI S≈™TA Continues:1 ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§§ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡§Æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡•• ‡•ß‡•´‡•≠ ‡•• O chief among the twice-born, all of you are indeed exceed- ingly fortunate, because, having permanently installed Bha- gavƒÅn NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa in the inner core of your being (√§tmani), and being perpetually endowed with loving devotion to Him, you are engaged in worshiping Him, the Immanent Self of all liv- ing beings (akhilƒÅtma-bh≈´tam ), the supreme worshipful Deity (Devam), and the Omnipotent Regulator (Isam), who is without any other sovereign Lord or superior (adevam ). ( SB 12.12.55 ) 2 ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ö - " ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•Ñ‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§π ‘‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§π‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ! ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ú‡§§ ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ü‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ? ‡§Ö‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã- ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§É ? ‡§à‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§- ‡§™‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§É” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡•§ I 2 ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmƒ´ comments: “In this manner, delighting the hearts of his listeners as well as his own self, ≈örƒ´ S≈´ta speaks This is the fourth of the five verses cited from Suta’s concluding instructions. yuyam dvijƒÅgryƒÅ bata bh≈´ri-bhƒÅga yac chasvad √§tmany akhilƒÅtma-bh≈´tam nƒÅrƒÅya·πáam devam adevam isam ajasra-bhƒÅvƒÅ bhajatƒÅvive≈õya 464 90 Bhakti Is the Supreme State of Blessedness two verses, beginning with the present one. He says, ‘O chief among the twice-born, because all of you have installed Bha- gavƒÅn ≈örƒ´ NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa in the inner core of your being (ƒÅtmani, i.e., anta·∏•-karane), you may worship Him constantly, and hence you are exceedingly fortunate (bh≈´ri-bhƒÅgah), meaning that you are highly virtuous (bahu-punya·∏•).’ The verb bhajata, ‘all of you may worship,’ although belonging to the verbal classification known as lo·π≠-lakƒÅra, the imperative mood, is used here to indi- cate possibility (sambhavana). What is ≈örƒ´ NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa’s essential nature as depicted in the verse? He is ’the Immanent Self of all living beings’ (akhilƒÅtma-bh≈´tam, i.e., sarvƒÅntaryƒÅminam), and as such He is ’the supreme worshipful Deity of everyone’ (Devam, i.e., sarvopƒÅsyam). He is ‘without any other sovereign Lord or superior’ (adevam). And why is that? Because He is ’the Omnipotent Supreme Regulator’ (Isam). “An alternate meaning to the verse is as follows: ‘Because all of you are exceedingly fortunate, being generously endowed with austerity and other virtues, you should worship Bhagavan NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa.’ In this alternate interpretation, the verb bhajata carries the sense of an injunction (vidhi) [rather than the idea of possibility, referred to above].” [Here ends ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi’s comment.] ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§™‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§É || The import of Sridhara SvƒÅmi’s comment is that the perfection of wealth in the form of austerity and other virtues comes about only by the worshipful service of Bhagavan NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa. Commentary IN THE above verse, S≈´ta GosvƒÅmƒ´ points out that the highest for- tune is to engage in bhakti to Bhagavan, because that is the source of all auspiciousness. It is for this reason that even the celestial beings (devas) marvel at the fortune of those who have taken birth in the land of Bharata (India) because of the opportunity that it readily 465 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya affords to take to the path of bhakti. This is directly stated by them in the following verse: Oh, what virtuous acts must have been performed [in a past life] by these people, or it might be that Bhagavan Hari of His own accord became pleased with them, who have taken birth as human beings in the land of Bharata, a birth which is suitable for the service of Bhagavan Mukunda [≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa]. Such a birth is desired even by us but [not actually attained]. (SB 5.19.21) If, however, in spite of obtaining the fortune of being born in India, one neglects to take to bhakti, then such a person is the most unfortunate. This indeed is the case with the majority of Indians at present. On the other hand, even if one is not born in India but engages in bhakti, he or she is highly fortunate. 466 aho ami·π£ƒÅm kim akari sobhanam prasanna e≈üƒÅm svid uta svayam harih yair janma labdham nrsu bhƒÅratƒÅjire mukunda-sevaupayikam sprhƒÅ hi nah Anuccheda 91 Bhakti in the Form of Remembrance Is the Abhidheya ‡•Ø‡•ß | ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•® ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•® ‡•§‡•´‡•¨ ) - ≈öRI S≈™TA further said:1 ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•´‡•Æ ‡•• I too have been reminded [by all of you] of the Supreme Imma- nent Self of all beings, whom I had heard of earlier from the mouth of the foremost seer, ≈öri Suka, in the assembly of sages and illustrious beings who were also attentively listening to the discussion while King Parik·π£it sat with a vow to fast until death. (SB 12.12.56)2 ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É- ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§É ‡•• 1 The sense of the verse is as follows: “By the context of this dis- cussion, I too have been reminded of ’the essential Self’ (ƒÅtma- tattvam), meaning ’the Supreme Immanent Self of all beings’ (akhilƒÅtma-bh≈´tam), Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa. At present, I have become supremely exhilarated in regard to that essential Self (atma-tattvam), whom I heard of from the mouth of the foremost sage [≈örƒ´ ≈öuka].” This is the fifth of the five verses cited from Suta’s concluding instructions. 2 aham ca sa·πÅsmƒÅrita ƒÅtma-tattvam ≈õrutam pura me paramarsi-vaktrat prayopavese nrpateh pariksitah sadasy r·π£inam mahatam ca ≈õ·πõnvatam 467 468 Commentary I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya WHEN S≈™TA GOSVƒÄMI appeared in the assembly of sages at Nai- mi·π£ƒÅranya, ≈öaunaka ·πösi posed six questions to ≈örƒ´ S≈´ta. By way of response, S≈´ta related what he had heard from his teacher, ≈örƒ´ ≈öuka. This prompted him to become deeply absorbed in remem- brance of Bhagavan. From this, it is clearly understood that the essence of all the questions and replies reported throughout the text was focused exclusively on Bhagavan. This implies that the abhidheya described in ≈örƒ´mad Bhagavata is nothing other than bhakti, characterized by hearing, glorification, and remembrance of Bhagavan. 19 Other Dialogues Anucchedas 92-94 Anuccheda 92 Bhakti Is the Essential Teaching throughout ≈örƒ´mad BhƒÅgavata ‡•Ø‡•® ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•¨‡•§‡•¨ ) - ‚Äî THUS, in this beautiful MahƒÅpurƒÅ·πáa, in the statements of both tutelage and apprenticeship that are exchanged in the rela- tion between teacher and student, bhakti alone has been estab- lished as the abhidheya, or the prescribed means of ultimate attainment. This is again indicated in the following verse: ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§•‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•´‡•Ø ‡•• O greatly fortunate one [S≈´ta GosvƒÅmi], please narrate these incidents if they pertain to Bhagavan Krsna or His devotees, who lick the honey from His lotus feet. (SB 1.16.6)1 ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§≠‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø- ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•¨‡•§‡•©‡•§‡•®‡•®) - According to this verse, the import of all the accounts found throughout Srimad Bhagavata is understood to be concerned with this subject alone [i.e., Bhagavan and His devotees, because all discussions are narrated in response to the above request]. 1 tat kathyatƒÅm mahabhaga yadi k·πõ·π£·πáa-kathƒÅ≈õrayam athavasya padambhoja-makaranda-lihƒÅm satam 471I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya As this topic alone would extensively increase the size of this book, I will not elaborate on it. The point that bhakti alone is the abhidheya in ≈örimad BhƒÅgavata is evidenced in other dialogues as well. In this regard, we will now examine a number of verses where this is pointed out by anvaya, or positive concomitance. Yama informed his servants: ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡•§‡•§ ‡•ß‡•¨‡•¶ ‡•• In this world, this alone is asserted to be the supreme essential duty (para-dharma) of humanity, namely, to engage in bhakti- yoga to Bhagavan by uttering His names and other such direct acts of devotion. (SB 6.3.22)2 ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•å‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§®‡•à‡§§‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§É ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§µ- ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‚Äì‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•É- ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‚Äì ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å- ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§´‡§≤‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• The word pu·πÅsƒÅm, “of humanity,” means, “of all living beings” (jƒ´va-mƒÅtrƒÅ·πáƒÅm), and para-dharma·∏•, “the supreme essential duty,” means, “the universal duty” (sarvabhauma-dharma·∏•). The clause, “this limit, or extent (etƒÅvƒÅn), has been asserted (smrtah) as the supreme essential duty of humanity,” indicates that there is no higher dharma beyond this. The para-dharma·∏• being referred to by the words et√§v√§n eva, “this extent alone,” is direct (sƒÅk·π£ƒÅt) bhakti-yoga, consisting of devotional acts such as uttering the names of Bhagavan. By the emphatic particle eva, “only,” used to qualify the pronoun et√§v√§n, “this extent,” Yama denies the possibility of any other dharma being admitted as supreme. He clarifies this by the word bhagavati, “to Bha- gavan.” [In other words, the supreme dharma involves those devotional acts that are meant exclusively for the pleasure of Bhagavan.] 2 et√§v√§n eva loke’smin pumsam dharmah parah sm·πõtah bhakti-yogo bhagavati tan-nama-graha·πáƒÅdibhi·∏• 472 92 Bhakti Is the Essential Teaching throughout Srimad Bhagavata If the uttering of Bhagavan’s names and the other acts of devo- tion are applied in regard to karma, [j√±ƒÅna,] or other practices, in order to bring them to fruition, they can no longer be con- sidered as supreme (para). Rather, when these acts are applied in this way, it is considered an offense to bhakti, because they are then utilized in pursuit of insignificant fruits. In such a case, these devotional practices are relegated to the bestowal of ephemeral fruits. This is the import. Commentary THE THREE principal topics of discussion in the Six Sandarbhas are sambandha, “a discursive analysis of the Reality denoted by the text of Srimad BhƒÅgavata,” abhidheya, “the means of attainment of that Reality,” and prayojana, “the end state to be attained in regard to that Reality.” The topic of sambandha was examined in great detail in the first four volumes. The present book, Bhakti Sandarbha, is concerned with an exposition of the means (abhidheya). In the first volume, Tattva Sandarbha, ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´ first dealt with the topic of epistemology (pramƒÅna), establishing ≈örimad Bhagavata as the supreme authority for deriving valid conclusions regarding the three primary topics with which the anthology is concerned. On this foundation, ≈örƒ´ Jiva began in this book to analyze the dialogues between the principal teachers and students described in ≈örimad BhƒÅgavata in order to objectively ascertain the abhidheya. In doing so, he surveyed the entire book, canto by canto, begin- ning with the first. The unmistakable conclusion made evident through this investigation is that all the major teachers, who are renowned sages within the Puranic tradition, recommend bhakti as the abhidheya. ≈örƒ´ Jiva undertook this elaborate study, which is continued in the upcoming anucchedas, because before his time most of the ear- lier scholars and philosophers across the spectrum of Indian reli- gion thought of bhakti only as a means to mukti. This view is still prevalent. Even among the Vaisnava Schools, there are many who consider bhakti primarily as a means to attain mukti in the form of 473 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya eternal residence in the transphenomenal abode of Vaikuntha. As a consequence of this predetermined bias in view, it was exceed- ingly rare for someone to recognize bhakti as an end unto itself. To uproot this misconception and to establish bhakti in its own right, ≈örƒ´ Jiva initiated an extensive analysis of Srimad Bhagavata, the sup- reme pramƒÅ≈Üa, or authority, in the matter of the self-disclosure of Ultimate Reality as Bhagavan. A list of the significant dialogues examined up to this point in the text is given below:
  5. Suta GosvƒÅmi offers instruction to Sage Saunaka in Anucchedas 3-22.
  6. ≈örƒ´ Narada instructs Vyasa in Anuccheda 23.
  7. Sri Suka instructs King Parƒ´k·π£it in Anucchedas 24-32.
  8. ≈örƒ´ Saunaka responds to Suta’s teachings in Anucchedas 33-40. 5. Brahma instructs Narada in Anucchedas 41-42.
  9. Vidura inquires from Maitreya in Anuccheda 43-
  10. Maitreya cites the prayers of the devas known as Aja and Anaja to KƒÅranodaka≈õayi Vi·π£·πáu in Anuccheda 44.
  11. Maitreya addresses Vidura in Anuccheda 45.
  12. Bhagavan Kapila instructs Devahuti in Anucchedas 46-47. 10. Sanat-kumƒÅra instructs King Prthu in Anuccheda 48.
  13. Maitreya instructs Vidura in Anuccheda 49.
  14. Rudra instructs the Pracetas in Anuccheda 50.
  15. Narada instructs the Pracetas in Anucchedas 51-52.
  16. R·π£abhadeva instructs His sons in Anuccheda 53.
  17. Jada Bharata instructs King Rahugana in Anuccheda 53.
  18. Rahugana responds to Jada Bharata in Anuccheda 54.
  19. Bhagavan Sankar·π£a·πáa instructs King Citraketu in Anuccheda 55. 18. Prahlada instructs his classmates in Anucchedas 55-57.
  20. NƒÅrada instructs King Yudhisthira in Anuccheda 58.
  21. The Nava-yogendras instruct King Nimi in Anucchedas 59-65. 21. ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa instructs Uddhava in Anucchedas 66-85.
  22. ≈örƒ´ Suka instructs King Parik·π£it in Anuccheda 86. 23. ≈örƒ´ S≈´ta instructs Saunaka in Anucchedas 87-91. In this analysis, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ did not refer to the Eighth, Ninth, and Tenth Cantos of Srimad Bhagavata. In this regard, he did not want to further extend the scope of the book, as he mentions in 474 92 Bhakti Is the Essential Teaching throughout Srimad Bhagavata this anuccheda. In summing up this survey of the major dialogues between teacher and student, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va cites a verse spoken by Sau- naka in which the latter requests S≈´ta GosvƒÅmƒ´ to relate the story of Kali’s chastisement by King Parik·π£it. In making this request, how- ever, he stipulates that he is interested to hear only if the narration is related to Krsna or His devotees. This suggests that not only this specific episode but all the other stories recounted by Suta GosvƒÅmƒ´ would be required to meet this same criterion; otherwise, his audi- ence would become indifferent to his speech. From this guiding principle, it is concluded that because the entire BhƒÅgavata is con- cerned with nothing other than the accounts pertaining to K·πõ·π£·πáa and His devotees, its purpose is clearly devotion to Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ Krsna. After concluding this extensive analysis of the message of the BhƒÅgavata’s preeminent teachers, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va refers to other dialogues, such as that of YamarƒÅja to his servants, in which bhakti is again identified as the abhidheya. In the verse cited here (SB 6.3.22), the indeclinable emphatic particle eva, “only,” is highly significant. Its function in Yamaraja’s statement is to exclude anything other than bhakti to Bhagavan as the supreme essential duty (para-dharma) for all human beings (pumsƒÅm). ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va remarks that if bhakti in the form of uttering the names of Bhagavan is applied in regard to practices such as karma, then such bhakti cannot be classified as para-dharma, because in this case, bhakti would be relegated to an inferior purpose. Indeed, such a secondary application of bhakti is not pleasing to Bhakti Devi. As a consequence, she would award only the results of karma, which are temporary, but not the eternal fruit of prema for Bhagavan. 3 The indeclinable eva can have three different applications: (1) specifying the object itself, anya-yoga-vyavaccheda, in which case its function is to exclude any other object from the reference in question; (2) specifying the object’s qualifier, ayoga-vyavaccheda, in which case it excludes the non-application of the qualifier to the object in question; and (3) specifying the action of the verb as it applies to the object, atyanta-ayoga-vyavaccheda, in which case it excludes the possibility of the non-application of the verb’s action to the object in question (Kiranavali commentary on NyƒÅya-siddhƒÅnta-muktƒÅvalƒ´, p. 299). In the present verse (SB 6.3.22), ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmi takes the first meaning of eva, specifying that nothing other than this limit (et√§v√§n eva) can be the para-dharma. 475 476 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya In the upcoming anucchedas, ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmi continues to cite other positive affirmations (anvaya) of bhakti as the abhidheya. Anuccheda 93 Bhakti Is the Most Appropriate Path ‡•Ø‡•© | ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•¨‡•§‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•≠ ) - ≈öRƒ™ SUKA said: ‡§∏‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡•Ä‡§®‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§≠‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•ß‡•¨‡•ß ‡•• In this world, this path [of bhakti] is certainly most appropri ate, because it is the source of all auspiciousness and altogether free of fear [from impediments of any kind]. Those who tread this path are of ideal character (susilah), established in virtue (sadhava·∏•), and exclusively devoted to Bhagavan NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa. (SB 6.1.17)1 ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡§É || The words ayam pantha·∏•, “this path,” refer to the path of bhakti to Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa. Commentary BHAKTI is the most auspicious path, because it is altogether free of fear from obstacles. Moreover, Bhagavan personally helps His devotees, as confirmed by ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa Himself: 1 sadhricino hy ayam loke pantha·∏• k·π£emo’kuto-bhaya·∏• susilah sadhavo yatra nƒÅrƒÅya·πáa-parƒÅya·πáa·∏• 477 2 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya But those who have dedicated all actions to Me, who are attached to Me, and who worship Me, meditating on Me through the yoga of exclusive devotion alone - O Partha, I quickly uplift such individ- uals, whose minds are absorbed in Me, from the ocean of deathly material existence. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 12.6-7)2 There is no such help on other paths. On the path of j√±ƒÅna, which is based on isolationism, there is an absence of compassion, while on the path of karma, in which action is motivated by desire for the fruit, envy of others’ attainments is prominent. But on the path of bhakti, there is cooperation and love. This is indicated in the verse by the words susila·∏•, “those on this path are of ideal or gracious character,” and sadhava·∏•, “they are established in virtue.” 478 ye tu sarvƒÅ≈Üi karmani mayi sannyasya mat-parah ananyenaiva yogena mam dhyƒÅyanta upƒÉsate te·π£ƒÅm aham samuddharta m·πõtyu-samsara-sƒÅgarƒÅt bhavami nacirƒÅt pƒÅrtha mayy √§vesita-cetasƒÅm Anuccheda 94 Bhakti Is the Fruit of All Scriptural Study ‡•Ø‡•™ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§´‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ï‡•à‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•© | ‡•ß‡•© |‡•™) - AGAIN, by positive concomitance, ≈örƒ´ Vidura establishes bhakti as the fruit of hearing, or studying, all scriptures with reference to the a fortiori argument (kaimutya) [lit., the principle of ‚Äúhow much more‚Äù]:’ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç || ‡•ß‡•¨‡•® || To repeatedly hear the virtues of those in whose hearts the lotus feet of Mukunda perpetually reside has been rightly esteemed by the wise as the true aim of the extensive effort undertaken by human beings in studying the scriptures. (SB 3.13.4) 2 ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ò‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•å ? ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶- ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç “‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§É " (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•®‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ ‚Äú‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•©‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ 1 2 Kaimutya-nyaya is a type of logic used to establish a point of far-reaching significance by comparison with a truth of lesser significance, i.e., “If that is true, how much more true must this be?” In the verse quoted above, simply hearing about the virtues of those who keep Bhagavan Mukunda in their hearts is said to be the true aim of studying the scriptures. If this is the case, how much more beneficial must it be to directly hear about the virtues of Bhagavan Himself? Thus, bhakti to Bhagavan is established here as the genuine purpose of studying the scriptures through the kaimutya principle. ≈õrutasya pumsam sucira-sramasya nany anjasa suribhir idito’rthah tat-tad-gunanusravanam mukunda-padaravindam h·πõdaye≈üu ye≈üƒÉm 479 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya

This alone (ayam eva) has been esteemed (idita·∏•, i.e., slaghita·∏•) as the true aim (artha·∏•), meaning the genuine purpose (prayo- janam), of scriptural study (≈õrutasya), or in other words, of the effort to ascertain the meaning of the Vedas (veda-artha- avagate·∏•), undertaken by human beings (pumsƒÉm). What has been thus esteemed? To repeatedly hear about the distinct virtues - one in essential nature with bhakti to Bhagavan ‚Äì of those in whose hearts the lotus feet of Mukunda perpetually reside. From this statement, it is all the more self-evident that hearing directly about the virtues of ≈örƒ´ Mukunda is certainly esteemed as the genuine purpose of studying the Vedas. This indeed was stated earlier - vasudeva-parƒÅ vedƒÅ·∏•, “The Vedas have as their exclusive aim ≈örƒ´ Vasudeva” (SB 1.2.28). This is further confirmed in the following verse as well: After thrice studying and deliberating upon the entire corpus of the Vedas, the venerable Brahma, who was of one-pointed intel- lectual resolve, ascertained through his faculty of discernment that by which love for the Self [≈öri Hari] is evoked. (SB 2.2.34)3 ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø - The same conclusion is expressed in the B·πõhat-sahasra-nƒÅma- stotra found in the Padma PurƒÅ·πáa: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•ß‡•¨‡•© ‡•• One should remember Bhagavan Vi·π£·πáu always and never forget Him even for a moment. All the rules and prohibitions of scrip- ture are servants of these two principles alone. (Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda 71.100)* ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§ö- 3 bhagavan brahma kartsnyena trir anviksya mani·π£ayƒÅ tad-adhyavasyat ku·π≠astho ratir atman yato bhavet smartavya·∏• satatam visnur vismartavyo na jƒÅtucit sarve vidhi-ni·π£edhah syur etayor eva kinkarƒÅ·∏• 480 94 Bhakti Is the Fruit of All Scriptural Study In the Prabhasa-khanda of the Skanda PurƒÅ≈Üa and in the Linga Purana also, it is said: ‡§Ü‡§≤‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡•• ‡•ß‡•¨‡•™ ‡•• After churning all the scriptures and deliberating on them again and again, this conclusion alone has clearly come to the fore-that one should continuously meditate on Bhagavan NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa. (Skanda Purana 4.25.35, Linga Purana 2.7.11)5 ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ - Therefore, in the mantra that is offered to undertake the study of the Vedas, it is said: ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§É || ‡•ß‡•¨‡•´ || ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§É || Thus, Bhagavan Vi·π£·πáu is praised as the sourceless ground of all knowledge and penance. May the worshipful Bhagavan Janar- dana, for whom the knowers of the Vedas undergo penance, be pleased with me.” Commentary IN THIS ANUCCHEDA, ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´ demonstrates that it is not only ≈örƒ´mad Bhagavata that recommends bhakti as the abhi- dheya but that all scriptures do so. In establishing this conclusion, he first supplies evidence from Srimad Bhagavata and then from other PurƒÅ≈Üas. The fact that all scriptures advocate bhakti certainly 2 alo·∏çya sarva-sastrani vicarya ca puna·∏• punah idam eva sunispannam dhyeyo naraya·πáa·∏• sadƒÅ This verse is also found in Garuda Purana (229.1). iti vidya-tapo-yonir ayoni vi≈ünur iditah brahma-j√±as tapate deva·∏• priyata·πÅ me janardana·∏• Source unknown 481482 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya stands to reason, because Bhagavan is the source of all scriptures, and He manifested them simply to disclose the means by which He Himself can be known to humanity. The root cause of the jivas’ suf- fering is their beginningless ignorance of Bhagavan. Consequently, the sole remedy for this condition is the knowledge and immediate awareness of Bhagavan. The scriptures are the authentic source of this knowledge, and so the means that they advocate - namely, bhakti - is the real purpose of all scriptures, of all paths, and of all rules and regulations. In the next anuccheda, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi shows that even those scriptures or passages that propound varnasrama have bhakti alone as their ultimate purpose. Bhakti Is the Culmination of All Methods Anucchedas 95-98 Anuccheda 95 Bhakti Is the Fruit of All Dharma ‡•Ø‡•´ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•™‡•≠‡•§‡•®‡•™ ) - ‚Äî THEREFORE, bhakti alone is the unparalleled authenticated fruit even of the conduct prescribed in scripture for the varnas and ƒÅ≈õramas, as ≈örƒ´ Uddhava informed the Vraja-devis: ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§π‡•ã‡§Æ‡§ú‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•à‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•á ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•ß‡•¨‡•¨ ‡•• Bhakti to Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa is indeed to be aimed at through charity, vows, penances, fire sacrifices, uttering mantras, study of the Vedas, self-control, and various other auspicious practices. (sB 10.47.24 ) 1 ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ In this verse, it is to be understood that practices such as offer- ing charity are meant to be performed for the satisfaction of Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa. 1 ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç “‡§§‡§ú‡•ç ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ö‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•™ ‡•§ ‡•©‡•ß ‡•§‡•Ø) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ The same idea was also expressed by ≈örƒ´ NƒÅrada: dana vrata-tapo-homa-japa-svadhyaya-saryamaih ≈õreyobhir vividhais canyaih k·πõ·π£·πáe bhaktir hi s√§dhyate 485 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya [In this world,] a human being’s birth, actions, lifespan, mind, and speech are successful only if applied in the service of Bhaga- van Hari, who is the Supreme Regulator and the Immanent Self of the cosmos. (SB 4.31.9)2 ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á- And in the B·πõhan-nƒÅradƒ´ya PurƒÅ·πáa, it is said: ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•á ‡•• ‡•ß‡•¨‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Pure bhakti to Bhagavan Janardana, who is the worshipful God of all the gods, is attained by those who have accumulated piety over thousands of millions of births. (BNP 1.39.51)3 ‡§Ö‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç- And in the Agastya-sa·πÅhitƒÅ: ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ‡•á ‡•• ‡•ß‡•¨‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ By perfectly executing vows, fasts, scriptural rules, and vari- ous types of sacrifices for millions of lives, one attains bhakti to Bhagavan Madhava. (Agastya-samhita)+ ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§£‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç “‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•®‡•ß‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡•§ “‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ- ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•® | ‡•ß‡•® | ‡•´‡•© ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§ö ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§É || The same point is made by negative concomitance in the following verses: 2 3 4 If the conventional dharma prescribed for human beings is meticulously carried out and yet does not induce attraction for taj-janma tani karmƒÅ≈Üi tad-ayus tan-mano vaca·∏• n·πõ·πáƒÅm yena hi vi≈õvƒÅtmƒÅ sevyate harir isvarah janma-koti-sahasresu punyam yai·∏• samupƒÅrjitam te≈üƒÉm bhaktir bhavec chuddha deva-deve janardane vratopavasa-niyamair janma-kotyapy anusthitaih yaj√±ais ca vividhai·∏• samyag bhaktir bhavati madhave 486 95 Bhakti Is the Fruit of All Dharma the narrations of Bhagavan Vasudeva, such dharma is decidedly only fruitless labor indeed. (SB 1.2.8)5 And: The immense labor expended in discharging prescribed duties pertaining to one’s varna and a≈õrama, and in undergoing penance, study of the Vedas, and other similar practices, cul- minates only in wealth accompanied by fame. But by hearing and repeating the glories of Sri Hari, one attains unbroken remembrance of the lotus feet of Bhagavan, who is the support of the Goddess of Fortune. (SB 12.12.53) Commentary THE purpose of var·πáƒÅ≈õrama is devotion to ≈örƒ´ Krsna. It is a social system designed specifically to lead all of its members to the path of bhakti. A doubt may be raised in this regard. It has been estab- lished earlier that bhakti ensues only from bhakti itself.
