Such being the case, how can conventional moral acts, such as charity, give rise to bhakti? ≈öri Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´ explains that the var·πáƒÅ≈õrama principles can be practiced in two ways. They may be undertaken indepen- dent of Bhagavan, or they may be performed for His satisfaction. In the first case, if the var·πáƒÅ≈õrama duties are meticulously per- formed, they will yield the aspired for material benefit. This too ultimately occurs only through the grace of bhakti, since the per- former must adhere to the scriptural injunctions, which are the orders of Bhagavan. On this account, Bhakti Devi rewards the per- former for their obedience to the divine ordinance. If, however, one carries out these prescribed acts without faith, and thus with- out authentic adherence to the requisite process, he or she will not obtain even the material result, as attested to by ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa: 6 5 dharma·∏• svanusthita·∏• pumsƒÅm visvaksena-kathƒÅsu ya·∏• notpadayed yadi ratim srama eva hi kevalam yasa·∏•-≈õriyƒÅm eva parisramah paro varnasramacara-tapah-≈õrutadi·π£u avismrti·∏• ≈õridhara-pada-padmayor gu·πáƒÅnuvada-≈õrava·πáƒÅdirbhir hare·∏• 487 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya O son of Prtha, whatever is offered in the sacrificial fire, whatever is given in charity, whatever austerity is undertaken, and what- ever other auspicious actions are performed without faith, are all termed asat, or worthless, because they bear no fruit, neither here nor after death. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 17.28)’ The alternate and superior manner of carrying out var·πáƒÅ≈õrama duties is to do so for the satisfaction of Bhagavan. If conducted with this intent, then by the grace of a devotee, these sanctified acts will give rise to a taste for hearing about K·πõ·π£·πáa. This in turn will impel the performer to take to pure bhakti. Only this type of execution of var·πáƒÅ≈õrama principles is truly praiseworthy. This is the intended meaning of Uddhava’s statement. In the next anuccheda, it will be demonstrated that true j√±ƒÅna ensues only from bhakti. 7 asraddhaya hutam dattam tapas taptam krtam ca yat asad ity ucyate partha na ca tat pretya no iha 488 Anuccheda 96 Authentic J√±ƒÅna Ensues Only from Bhakti ‡•Ø‡•¨ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§§‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶‡•§‡•ß‡•™‡•§‡•´ ) - EVEN the j√±ƒÅna that is prescribed in ≈örƒ´mad Bhagavata is to be understood as included within bhakti alone. An example of this is seen in the following prayer of Brahma to Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa: ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§π ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡§π‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§π‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡§•‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§Ω‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§ ‡§§‡•á ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•¨‡•Ø ‡•• O Unlimited, Infallible Lord, in the past, many yogis in this world offered their prescribed practices and even their worldly actions unto you. As a consequence of thus surrendering their actions unto You, they obtained bhakti in the form of hearing and recounting Your narrations. Then, having directly realized the self by such bhakti alone, they easily attained Your supreme destination. (sB 10.14.5) 1 ‡§π‡•á ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç ! ‡§á‡§π ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø- ‡§§‡•á‡§π‡§æ ‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø- ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡§•‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§™‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§•‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ 1 pureha bhuman bahavo’pi yoginas tvad-arpiteh√§ nija-karma-labdhaya vibudhya bhaktyaiva kathopanitaya prapedire ‘fijo’cyuta te gatim param 489 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya The sense of the verse is as follows: “O Unlimited Lord (bhuman), previously there were indeed many yogis in this world. Hav- ing failed to attain realized knowledge (j√±ƒÅna) through their practice of yoga, they later offered their prescribed practices and even their worldly actions unto You [the word ihƒÅ, ’effort or exertion,’ implies both types of action]. As a consequence of thus surrendering their actions unto You, they obtained bhakti in the form of the taste (ruci) for hearing Your narra- tions (katha). Furthermore, on account of the contact (sami- pam, lit., proximity’) with such katha, they were led to attain bhakti in the form of a liking (ruci) for You directly, the subject of such narrations (kathaniya).? By this bhakti alone [consisting of these two types of taste], they easily realized the Absolute, beginning from atma-tattva, ’the immediate intuition of the self,’ up to bhagavat-tattva, ’the immediate intuition of Bha- gav√§n.’ Having done so, they attained Your supreme intrinsic [i.e., supramundane] destination (paramantarangƒÅ·πÅ gatim).” ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ö ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§É " (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•¶‡•§‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡§ø- ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•¶ | ‡•ß‡•ß ) - In Bhagavad GitƒÅ as well, K·πõ·π£·πáa imparted teachings on pure devotion, beginning with this verse: aham sarvasya prabha- va·∏•, “I am the source of everything” (Gƒ™TƒÄ 10.8). Thereafter, Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa said: 2 The compound kathopanita can be broken down into two words: kathƒÅ, “narrations,” and upanita, “brought near.” The compound appears in the instrumental case and acts as an adjective qualifying bhakti. Thus, kathopanitaya bhaktya means, “by devotion brought about by hearing katha.” Jiva GosvƒÅmi has explained this in two ways. First, one obtains bhakti in the form of the taste (ruci) for hearing the narrations of Bhagavan, then as a consequence of this, one obtains bhakti in the form of attraction for Bhagavan Himself, the subject of such kathƒÅ. 490 96 Authentic J√±ana Ensues Only from Bhakti ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§• ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡•• ‡•ß‡•≠‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç || Just to bless them, I, situated in their consciousness, destroy the darkness born of ignorance with the shining lamp of wisdom. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 10.11)3 Commentary IN THE previous anuccheda, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi made the point that the practices that constitute the path of dharma, or “sanctified action,” bear real fruit only if performed for the satisfaction of Bhagavan. Now he goes a step further to assert that any attempt to cultivate j√±ƒÅna, or “immediate awareness of the self,” without bhakti will also end in failure. In the main verse of this anuccheda (SB 10.14.5), BrahmƒÅ himself admits that in the past many yogis were unsuccessful in their attempts to attain such realization through their practice of yoga. Being thus frustrated, they later offered all of their actions and aspirations to Bhagavan. This attestation serves as a lesson for modern-day practitioners. By offering one’s actions to Bhagavan, and by the association of a devotee, a person will obtain faith in the process of hearing about K·πõ·π£·πáa. This will lead to constancy in hearing from realized devo- tees and engagement in sadhana-bhakti. This in turn will purify the heart of all unwanted predispositions and desires (vƒÅsanƒÅs). Then, by the grace of bhakti, the practitioner will be blessed with direct experience of Bhagavan. Thus, true j√±ƒÅna ensues only from bhakti. This is confirmed by Krsna in the verse cited here (Gƒ™TƒÄ 10.11). Any practice devoid of bhakti is termed as ignorance (aj√±ƒÅnam) by K·πõ·π£·πáa in the following pair of verses: 3 te·π£ƒÅm evƒÅnukampƒÅrtham aham aj√±ƒÅna-jam tama·∏• nƒÅ≈õayƒÅmy atma-bhava-stho j√±ƒÅna-dipena bhƒÅsvatƒÅ 491492 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya Undeviating pure devotion unto Me with exclusive absorption, res- idence in a secluded place, nonattachment to the association of worldly people, constancy in the culture of knowledge pertaining to the Self, and deliberation on the goal of knowledge regarding the Absolute - all this is declared to be knowledge. Whatever is different from this is ignorance. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 13.10-11)* mayi cananya-yogena bhaktir avyabhicƒÅri≈Üi vivikta-de≈õa-sevitvam aratir jana-samsadi adhyatma-jnana-nityatvam tattva-j√±ƒÅnƒÅrtha-dar≈õanam etaj j√±ƒÅnam iti proktam aj√±ƒÅnam yad ato’nyatha Anuccheda 97 Bhakti Is the Source of All Perfection ‡•Ø‡•≠ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡•Æ‡•ß ‡•§‡•ß‡•Ø ) - ALL other practices (sƒÅdhanas) that are described in ≈örƒ´mad BhƒÅgavata as productive of the ultimate good (puru·π£ƒÅrtha) are similarly rooted only in bhakti, as expressed in these words of ≈örƒ´dƒÅmƒÅ Vipra: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç || ‡•ß‡•≠‡•ß || Worship of Your lotus feet is the root of all perfections and opu- lences that human beings can attain in heaven, in liberation, on earth, or in the subterrestrial realms. (SB 10.81.19 ) 1 ‚Äú‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•Æ‡•§‡•®‡•©‡•§‡•ß‡•¨ ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® “‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á- 1 [In undertaking the ritual process associated with motivated action (kƒÅmya-karma), many errors can arise in regard to mantra and sadhana.] In this respect, the following principle is enunciated [about bhakti]: svargƒÅpavargayo·∏• pumsƒÅm rasayam bhuvi sampadam sarvƒÅsƒÅm api siddhƒ´nƒÅm m≈´lam tac-cara·πáƒÅrcanam 493 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya Defects pertaining to the pronunciation of mantras, the proce- dure to be followed, the time and location of the ritual, the eli- gibility of the persons involved, and the items employed are all made flawless by chanting Your names. (SB 8.23.16)2 Additionally, bhakti’s perpetuity (nityatva), meaning, its regular compulsory nature, is expressed in this pair of verses: From the mouth, arms, thighs, and feet of the Purusa appeared the four respective vocational classifications (varnas) along with the four stages of life (asramas). The varnas were distinc- tively divided into vipra, ksatriya, vaisya, and s≈´dra accord- ing to the corresponding gunas that determine their natures. Among human beings belonging to these divisions, those who [naively] neglect to worship the Puru»ôa, who is directly the primordial ground of being of all individual beings (atma- prabhavam) and the Supreme Immanent Regulator of all being (I≈õvara), or who [knowingly] show Him contempt, are deprived of their status and fall into degradation. (SB 11.5.2-3)3 Thus, by virtue of the principle that bhakti rectifies all defects as well as by its necessity (nityatva) - shown respectively in the above two verses - it is understood that those whose regard is directed away from Bhagavan (tad-bahirmukhƒÅnƒÅm), certainly cannot attain their respective aspired for goals, as stated in Skanda PurƒÅ·πáa: 2 3 4 ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•å‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§É ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•≠‡•® ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The actions performed according to ≈öruti and Smrti of those who are devoid of bhakti to Vi≈ü≈Üu result only in bodily misery, like the illicit affairs of a prostitute. (Skanda PurƒÅ·πáa)* mantratas tantratas chidram desa-kalarha-vastuta·∏• sarvam karoti nischidram anusarkirtanam tava mukha-bƒÅhuru-pƒÅdebhyah puru·π£asyasramai·∏• saha catvƒÅro jajnire var·πáƒÅ gunair vipradayah prthak ya e≈üƒÅm puru·π£am sƒÅk·π£ƒÅd atma-prabhavam isvaram na bhajanty avajƒÅnanti sthƒÅnƒÅd bhra·π£·π≠a·∏• patanty adhah visnu-bhakti-vihƒ´nƒÅnƒÅm ≈õrautƒÅ·∏• smartƒÅ≈õ ca ya·∏• kriyƒÅ·∏• kaya-kle≈õa·∏• phalam tƒÅsƒÅm svairi≈Üi vyabhicƒÅravat 494 97 Bhakti Is the Source of All Perfection ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§£ (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•§‡•≠‡•®‡•§‡•™) - Accordingly, ≈öri Yudhisthira MahƒÅrƒÅja said: ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡§∂‡§®‡•á ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡•É‡§£‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§®‡§æ‡§≠ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑ ‡§à‡§∂ ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡•• ‡•ß‡•≠‡•© ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ O lotus-navelled Lord, Your foot sandals destroy all inauspi- ciousness. Those who constantly render [bodily] service to them, who meditate upon them with pure minds, and who praise them [through speech], obtain freedom from bondage to the material world. And if they should so desire, they can attain even material boons. Others, however, cannot attain such things. (SB 10.72.4)5 ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á - Therefore, it is said in the B·πõhan-nƒÅradƒ´ya PurƒÅ·πáa: ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•ß‡•≠‡•™ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡•• Just as water is said to be the life of all living beings, so too bhakti is acknowledged as the life of all perfections. (BNP 1.4.4) Commentary BHAKTI is the basis of success in all undertakings, be it karma- yoga, j√±ƒÅna-yoga, or a·π£·π≠anga-yoga. Even in worldly dealings, peo- ple attain success by polite and humble behavior, not by arrogance or indifference. Even politicians have to make a show of devotion and promise public service to win votes. People support a leader 0 tvat-paduke aviratam pari ye caranti dhyayanty abhadra-nasane sucayo grnanti vindanti te kamala-nƒÅbha bhavapavargam a≈õ√§sate yadi ta ƒÉ≈ùisa isa n√§nye yathƒÅ samasta-lokƒÅnƒÅ·πÅ jƒ´vana·πÅ salila·πÅ sm·πõtam tatha samasta-siddhƒ´nƒÅm jƒ´vana·πÅ bhaktir isyate 495 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya whom they think will provide services that will be of value to them and their community. If even material success is reliant on a devo- tional disposition, how much more must this be the case in regard to spiritual endeavors? Bhagavan is the Supreme Master and Regulator of everything. We have the capacity to act, but the result is not in our control. This is clearly expressed by Sri Krsna in the Gita: “Your eligibil- ity pertains exclusively to the fulfillment of action but never to the fruits thereof” (GITA 2.47)? There are many factors involved in the outcome of actions, such as time and place. Beyond all other material considerations, there is the overseership of the Supreme Immanent Self, ParamƒÅtmƒÅ. Everything functions under His supervision. Therefore, no result can come about without His consent. Sudama thus concludes that all perfections are rooted in the worship of K·πõ·π£·πáa’s feet (SB 10.81.19). ≈örƒ´ Jiva then cites three verses to show that bhakti is a compul- sory duty, without which all other prescribed duties are flawed. The first verse (SB 8.23.16) is spoken by SukrƒÅcƒÅrya, the guru of Bali, who was the king of the asuras. Bali’s yaj√±a was interrupted by Vamanadeva when He went there to beg land from Bali. Bha- gavan Vamanadeva had requested SukracƒÅrya to complete any deficiency that might occur in the yaj√±a. In response to this pro- posal, ≈†ukrƒÅcƒÅrya spoke this verse. SukrƒÅcƒÅrya declared that all perfection comes about merely by chanting the name of Bhaga- van. Those seeking material rewards alone can obtain the results of their respective undertakings by the grace of bhakti, but if one performs the same actions as an offering to Bhagavan, one will also attain bhakti in course of time. The next pair of verses cited by ≈örƒ´ Jiva (SB 11.5.2-3) is spoken by the sage Camasa. He makes it emphatically clear that without devo- tion to the Supreme Self, who is the very source of all being, nobody can succeed in any endeavor. Indeed, even if one has attained a high position, he will lose it. This is further confirmed by King Yudhisthira (SB 10.72.4). In this manner, because bhakti is shown 7 karmany evƒÅdhikƒÅras te ma phale≈üu kadƒÅcana mƒÅ karma-phala-hetur bhur ma te sangostv akarmani 496 97 Bhakti Is the Source of All Perfection to be the root of all practices and compulsory for their success, it is thus concluded to be the abhidheya. Next, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi makes the point that bhakti is the life of all other paths, and as such it is not dependent on anything. 497 Anuccheda 98 Bhakti Is Independent of All Methods ‡•Ø‡•Æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‚Äú ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•©‡•§‡•ß‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡•§ 1 IT IS THUS evidenced that because bhakti is the life of all these different practices (sadhanas), bhakti alone has been proclaimed everywhere as the abhidheya. It is moreover observed that the aspired for ends of these various practices are brought to fruition by bhakti alone, even without recourse to these practices themselves. This is expressed in the following statement: A person of evolved discernment, whether desireless, desiring all, or seeking liberation, should worship the Supreme Puru≈üa with resolute bhakti-yoga. (SB 2.3.10)1 ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡§π‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§µ‡§ø‡•¶ ‡§™‡•Å‡•¶ ‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•™‡•¨ ) - As the sage Pulaha says in the Vi·π£·πáu PurƒÅ·πáa: ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•á ‡•• ‡•ß‡•≠‡•´ ‡•• If Bhagavan Janardana, who is known as “the Lord of Sacrifice” (yaj√±a-puru≈üa) in the domain of sacrificial action and as “the akƒÅma·∏• sarva-kƒÅmo vƒÅ mok·π£a-kƒÅma udara-dhih tivrena bhakti-yogena yajeta puru≈üam param 498 98 Bhakti Is Independent of All Methods Supreme Immanent Self” (parama·∏• puman) in the practice of yoga, is pleased, what remains unattainable ? (VP 1.11.46 ) 2 ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á- Therefore, it is said in the Mok≈üa-dharma of the Mahabharata: ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É || ‡•ß‡•≠‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ By taking shelter of Bhagavan NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, a human being attains the four human goals even without recourse to any of the vari- ous practices that are meant for obtaining them. (Mahabharata, Moksa dharma ) " ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§´‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§¶‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç “‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß | ‡•ß‡•™ | ‡•© ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ Therefore, it was rightly said that bhakti is the abhidheya, because it is the fruit of studying all scriptures. For this rea- son, in the beginning of an evolutionary cycle, bhakti alone was brought forth into being by Bhagavan Himself, as was said: In due course of time, this speech of Mine, known as the Veda, remained undisclosed during the period of dissolution. In it, the dharma that is entailed is constituted of the very essence of My Being (mad-ƒÅtmaka·∏•). It was spoken by Me once again to BrahmƒÅ, at the beginning of a new creational cycle. ( SB 11.14.3 ) + ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§- ‡§¶‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§´‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§´‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§´‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ 2 3 4 yo yaj√±a-puruso yajne yoge ya·∏• parama·∏• puman fasmims tuste yad-aprapyam kim tad asti janardane yƒÅ vai sadhana-sampattih purusƒÅrtha catustaye tayƒÉ vinƒÉ tad-√¢pnoti naro narayanasrayah k√§lena na≈üta pralaye vaniyam veda-safijfitƒÉ mayadau brahmane prokta dharmo yasyam mad-atmaka·∏• 499 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya As bhakti is so much emphasized, even those who are not overly discerning worship Bhagavan Sri Vis≈Üu, yet they do so only as a part of karma, or as part of whatever path they are following, in order to achieve the results of their respective practice. This, however, is an offense to bhakti. As a result, bhakti awards them only with the fruit of their respective desires, and of that also there is no assurance. But, if bhakti is performed independent of those practices, even if only to attain the results proclaimed by those paths, bhakti certainly awards those results. Moreover, bhakti is not limited merely to offering those particular fruits, rather in the end it bestows the supreme fruit as well. ‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•´‡•§‡•ß‡•Ø‡•§‡•®‡•≠) - Therefore, bhakti alone is the abhidheya, because it grants the ultimate good. This is affirmed by the devas: ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§¶‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•≠‡•≠ ‡•• It is true that Bhagavan, when prayed to by human beings, awards the results that they seek. [Yet by doing so,] He does not offer anything of genuine value, because [after the petitioners have enjoyed their rewards,] they again pray for something new. [Recognizing this pattern,] Bhagavan personally offers His own lotus feet to those who worship Him, even though they don’t aspire for them, and this brings an end to their material desires. (SB 5.19.27) 5 ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø- ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§¶‡•ã ‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ- ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•Ø ‡•ß‡•Ø ‡•ß‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ- ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§ï ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡•§ 5 satyam disaty arthitam arthito n·πõnam naivarthado yat punar arthita yata·∏• svayam vidhatte bhajatƒÅm anicchatam iccha-pidhƒÅnam nija-pƒÅda-pallavam 500 98 Bhakti Is Independent of All Methods Being prayed to by human beings, Bhagavan truly indeed (satyam eva) awards the results that they seek. The word satyam, “it is true,” indicates that this cannot ever be otherwise. Yet, by doing so, He does not offer anything of genuine value, because even after awarding such boons, He is not relieved from their solicitations. The reason for this is that the worshiper remains unfulfilled by obtaining his desired object, and when his enjoy- ment is exhausted, he again prays to Bhagavan for some new object. This pattern is illustrated in the following statement: “The craving for sensual gratification is never extinguished by enjoyment of the sense objects” (SB 9.19.14). Recognizing this pattern, the most merciful Bhagavan awards His own lotus feet, which are here described as iccha-pidhƒÅnam, that which brings an end to all desires. This means that He offers His lotus feet to the worshiper even though the person doesn’t desire them due to ignorance of their sweetness. This is com- parable to a mother’s action of removing a chewed piece of clay from the mouth of her child and offering a sweet in its place. ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•©‡•§‡•ß‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§°‡•á- For this reason also, the resoluteness (tivratvam) of bhakti was emphasized in SB 2.3.10, quoted at the beginning of this anuccheda. A similar statement [to that of the devas in SB 5.19.27], is found in the Garuda Purana: 6 7 ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§® ‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∏‡•Ç‡§¶‡§®‡§É ‡•• ‡•ß‡•≠‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ When meditated upon, Bhagavan Madhusudana [≈öri Krsna] awards even that which was not requested, which is exceed- ingly rare, unattainable, and beyond what the mind can conceive. (Garuda Purana 2.234.12) na jƒÅtu kama·∏• kamƒÅnam upabhogena samyati yad-durlabham yad aprƒÅpyam manaso yan na gocaram tad apy aprarthitam dhyƒÅto dadƒÅti madhusudana·∏• 501I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•• ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• Accordingly, it is to be understood that even ≈örƒ´ Sanaka and the other KumƒÅra brothers, who were established in the imme- diate realization of Brahman (brahma-j√±ƒÅnƒ´s), attained Bhaga- van’s lotus feet by their adherence to bhakti [even though they originally did so only to attain Brahman realization]. Commentary IN THIS ANUCCHEDA, ≈örƒ´ Jiva clearly demonstrates that bhakti is supremely independent in awarding its results, whereas all other processes are impotent without bhakti. From this, it is under- stood that one should engage only in bhakti, no matter what one’s aspired for end might be. This is the import of the akƒÅma verse (SB 2.3.10) spoken by Sukadeva and already discussed earlier (in Anuccheda 31). There are three ways to proceed in the attempt to fulfill one’s aspiration within the jurisdiction of sastra. The first is to follow some particular process, such as karma, without recourse to bhakti. This strategy will not be successful, because, of its own accord, karma lacks the power of Bhagavan’s intrinsic potency, of which bhakti is constituted, and which alone is capable of effecting the result. The second is to follow the process in question while also taking support from bhakti. In this case, the practitioner consid- ers bhakti as subordinate to his chosen path. This approach may, however, yield the desired result, because it draws support from the internal potency through the performer’s indirect participa- tion in bhakti. In the case of the karma-marga, bhakti awards the result of the prescribed action so that the performer does not lose faith in sastra. In this approach, however, making bhakti secondary to karma is disrespectful to bhakti. Since bhakti’s pleasure is not invoked by such an attitude, she offers only that which is desired by the performer and nothing more. 502 98 Bhakti Is Independent of All Methods The third and optimal method is to take to bhakti alone, even if one still has material desires. The person who does so does not undermine the value of bhakti, although his seeking of material boons reflects a lack of acumen. K·πõ·π£·πáa not only awards such per- sons the fruit that they desire but He also gives them the experience of Himself. This engenders a sense of detachment from material pleasures, whereupon such a worshiper desists from petitioning for further material boons. This is the meaning of the statement that bhakti gives rise to vairagya as a concomitant effect (SB 1.2.7), cited in Anuccheda 4. In SB 5.19.27, the devas refer to Bhagavan’s feet as iccha-pidhƒÅ- nam - “that which shuts down or places a lid on desires.” If it were not so, the devotee would keep on petitioning for one boon after another; material desires are never satiated merely through indul- gence. Bhakti, however, does bring an end to desire, because the bliss derived from bhakti is superior to any material pleasure. This was seen in the case of Dhruva, who worshiped Vis≈Üu with the desire to obtain a kingdom greater than that of his father. When, however, Bhagavan Vis≈Üu personally appeared before him, Dhruva became fully satisfied and no longer wished for anything else. His testimony submitted at that time to Bhagavan Vi·π£·πáu is reported in Hari-bhakti-sudhodaya: Being desirous of a position of great worldly importance, I took to the performance of penance. Though I was searching for broken glass, I have attained You, a divine jewel, who are unobtainable even by the gods and great sages. O Lord! I am now completely fulfilled and ask for no other boon. (Hari-bhakti-sudhodaya 7.28) ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmi then points out an important connection between the devas’ statement in SB 5.19.27 and that of ≈örƒ´ Suka- deva in SB 2.3.10, with which he began the anuccheda. He writes that the resoluteness (tƒ´vratvam) of bhakti has been emphasized in SB 2.3.10 specifically because of the conclusion drawn by the devas that Bhagavan awards His own lotus feet even to the worshiper sthƒÅnabhila≈üi tapasi sthito ham tvƒÅm pr√§ptavƒÅn deva-munindra-guhyam 8 kacam vicinvann api divya-ratnam svamin k·πõtƒÅrtho’smi varam na yace 503 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya with desires. The word tivrena in SB 2.3.10 thus signifies that one should wholeheartedly engage in bhakti alone, without depending upon any other process. In other words, one should not think of bhakti as secondary to any other process. Making it secondary is comparable to the sun’s brilliance being covered with clouds. By doing so, one will not experience the true potency of bhakti. Dhruva is an example of a person with an extravagant material desire who performed resolute (tivra) bhakti. The KumƒÅra broth- ers are mentioned as an example of brahma-j√±ƒÅnƒ´s who desired liberation. They too engaged in bhakti and by so doing attained not only mukti but also bhakti. Taking all of this into consideration, one should not engage in karma devoid of bhakti, nor in bhakti subordinated to karma, nor even in bhakti alone undertaken to fulfill material objectives. Rather, one should engage exclusively in bhakti and for the sake of the pleasure of Bhagavan alone. At present, the majority of peo- ple do not fit in any of these four categories. They are primarily interested in earning money and enjoying their senses without fol- lowing any sort of spiritual process. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ does not even bother to speak about them. Next, ≈öri Jiva establishes bhakti as the abhidheya by vyatireka, or negative concomitance. 504 Bhakti Established through Negative Inference - Vyatireka Anucchedas 99-105 Anuccheda 99 Bhakti Contrasted with Karma ‡•Ø‡•Ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§£ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§π - ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§´‡§≤‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•ß‡•Æ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•® ) - NOW BHAKTI is established as the abhidheya through negative concomitance (vyatireka), by expressing disregard for the path of karma. There is both uncertainty and misery involved in attaining the results of karma. But in the case of bhakti, suc- cess is assured and the devotee experiences joy even in the stage of practice. These conclusions are summed up in the following statement of the sage Saunaka to S≈´ta GosvƒÅmi: ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•á ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å || ‡•ß‡•≠‡•Ø ‡•§‡•§ We have been engaged in the performance of this sacrifice, the fruits of which are uncertain, until our bodies were blackened by smoke. Now you have come and revived us by causing us to drink the ambrosial nectar flowing from ≈örƒ´ Govinda’s lotus feet. (SB 1.18.12)1 ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§Ω‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡•à‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ- ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§® ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•å ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§∑‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Ä ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ 1 | karmany asminn anƒÅ≈õv√§se dhuma-dhumratmanƒÅm bhavan apayayati govinda-pada-padmƒÅsavam madhu 507 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya In this endeavor (asmin karmani), meaning “in this sacrifice” (asmin satre), the outcome is “unassured” (anƒÅ≈õvƒÅse), or “unre- liable” (avi≈õvasaniya). Because of the possibility of many dis- crepancies (vaigunya-bahulyena) in the performance of sacri- fice, there is a want of certainty in regard to the result (phala- ni≈õcayƒÅbhƒÅvƒÅt), as is the case with farming. By this statement, the reliability (vi≈õvasanƒ´yatvam) of bhakti is indirectly implied. In the compound dhuma-dhumratmanƒÅm, the word ƒÅtmanƒÅm refers to “the body and mind” (sarira-citte), dhumra means “dispirited” (vira√±jita) and “discolored” (vivarna), and dhuma means “by the smoke” (dh≈´mena). Thus, the compound as a whole means “to us, who have become dispirited and discol- ored in mind and body due to the smoke.” Although ƒÅtmanƒÅm appears in the sixth case [the possessive case], it is used in the sense of the accusative, [indicating that the sages are the direct object of the verb ƒÅpƒÅyayati, ‚ÄúYou are causing us to drink”]. In the compound pada-padmƒÅsavam, the word asavam means, “the intoxicating nectar of a flower” (makarandam), which flows from the lotus feet (pada-padma) of ≈örƒ´ Govinda in the form of His fame (yaso-rupam). This nectar, or fame, is “honey-like” or “ambrosial” (madhu). In this statement, it is to be understood that the uncertainty and hardship that is specifically pointed out in regard to the satra sacrifice actually applies to all other forms of karma. Similarly, the certainty and pleasure attributed to hearing the glories of Bhagavan applies to all other types of bhakti. Thus, by negative concomitance (vyatireka), it is understood from Saunaka’s state- ment that by the execution of karma alone devoid of bhakti, the performers experienced only misery. ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç “‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§É " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•ß‡•® | ‡•ß‡•® | ‡•´‡•© ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‚Äú ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à ‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•®‡•® ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ This same idea was expressed by S≈´ta GosvƒÅmƒ´: The immense labor expended in discharging prescribed duties pertaining to one’s varna and a≈õrama, and in undergoing 508 99 Bhakti Contrasted with Karma penance, study of the Vedas, and other similar practices, cul- minates only in wealth accompanied by fame. But by hearing and repeating the glories of Sri Hari, one attains unbroken remembrance of the lotus feet of Bhagavan, who is the support of the Goddess of Fortune. (SB 12.12.53)2 And: For this reason indeed, the enlightened sages, out of supreme delight, continuously engage in bhakti to Bhagavan Vasudeva, which is utterly fulfilling to the self. (SB 1.2.22)3 ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡•à‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç- In the Brahma-vaivarta Purana as well, Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ Vi·π£·πáu makes a similar statement to ≈öiva: ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§≤‡•å ‡§ï‡§≤‡•Å‡§∑‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• If anyone seeks to attain Me, they certainly do attain Me. This cannot be otherwise. In the age of Kali, the life and other char- acteristics of the impure-hearted who adhere to var·πáƒÅ≈õrama are all futile, but this is not the case for those who have taken shelter of Me. (Brahma-vaivarta Purana)* Commentary AFTER demonstrating through positive affirmations (anvaya) that bhakti is independent in awarding its result and that other paths 2 ya≈õa·∏•-≈õriyam eva pari≈õramah paro var·πáƒÅ≈õramƒÅcƒÅra-tapa·∏•-≈õrutƒÅdi·π£u 3 4 avism·πõti·∏• ≈õridhara-pada-padmayor gu·πáanuvada-≈õrava·πáƒÅdirbhir hare·∏• ato vai kavayo nityam bhaktim paramaya muda vasudeve bhagavati kurvanty atma-prasƒÅdanim yadi mam pr√§ptum icchanti pr√§pnuvanty eva nanyathƒÅ kalau kalu·π£a-cittƒÅnƒÅm v·πõthƒÅyuh prabh·πõtini ca bhavanti varnasraminam na tu mac-chara·πáƒÅrthinam 509 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya depend upon it, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va now establishes the same conclusion through disaffirmation (vyatireka), by showing the inefficacy of other paths. In this anuccheda, he shows the futility of karma devoid of bhakti. Thousands of sages headed by Saunaka had assembled at Nai- mi·π£ƒÅranya to participate in a long-enduring yaj√±a, specified by the name satra. According to Vyasa’s statement in the beginning of Srimad BhƒÅgavata, it was meant to last for a thousand years (SB 1.1.4). The sages, however, were unsure that they would obtain the desired result. On this account, they referred to the sacrifice by the word anƒÅ≈õvƒÅse, or “uncertain.” They also found the whole endeavor to be quite troublesome, and thus they admitted that their minds and bodies had become covered in soot from the smoke of the sacrificial fire. It is understandable that their bodies became covered in soot, but how could such a thing be said of their minds? This indicates that they were feeling mental dissatisfaction and uncertainty in regard to the result. In this connection, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va glosses the word dh√ºmra, lit., “smoke-colored,” with the two words. viranjita and vivarna. Although both of these words mean “dis- colored,” the first word in particular can also carry the sense of “dispirited” or “disheartened,” which is perhaps what ≈örƒ´ Jiva had in mind in supplying two otherwise perfectly synonymous terms. The path of sacrificial action (karma-marga) is so precise that if the ritual is not executed exactly as prescribed down to the last detail, it will not yield the desired result. A slight deviation even in the intonation of a single phoneme in a mantra may even bring to bear the exact opposite of what was intended. The story of the demon V·πõtrƒÅsura, who was generated from a dark tantrika ritual, and that of Diti, who contrived to conceive a son who would be able to kill Indra, are glaring examples of the fallibility of karma. In con- trast, bhakti is pleasurable even during the stage of practice, and its result is assured because of the supreme independent power with which it is intrinsically endowed. If there is any imperfection in the course of the performance of bhakti, Bhagavan personally brings about its completion, as confirmed by the sage KarabhƒÅjana: 510 99 Bhakti Contrasted with Karma If a beloved devotee of Bhagavan, who is engaged in rendering ser- vice to the soles of His feet, having given up all other objects of affection, somehow becomes involved in a forbidden act, then the Supreme Master Hari, situated in the devotee’s heart, destroys all reactions to such an act. (SB 11.5.42) 5 sva-pada-mulam bhajatah priyasya tyaktanya-bhavasya hari·∏• paresah vikarma yac cotpatitam kathancid dhunoti sarvam hrdi sannivistah 511Anuccheda 100 The Worthlessness of Vedic Karma Devoid of Bhakti - I ‡•ß‡•¶‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‚Äú‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•ß‡•≠ ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø- ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã- ‡§ö‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡•à‡§´‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø- ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ [IN REGARD to bhakti’s being established as the abhidheya through disregard for the path of karma,] here is another statement that should be examined: Has inauspiciousness (abhadram) ever befallen a person, in whatever circumstance he might find himself (yatra kva vƒÅ), who, having abandoned his prescribed socio-religious duty (sva-dharma), takes to the sacred service (bhajana) of the lotus feet of Bhagavan Hari, even if, thereafter, while still in an imma- ture state, he should meet with death or somehow fall away from such bhajana? On the other hand, what value (artha) is gained through adherence to prescribed duty by those who fail to worship Bhagavan? (SB 1.5.17)1 In this manner, it is understood from examining the various statements in scripture that by karma, which is both costly and 1 tyaktva sva-dharmam cara·πáƒÅmbujam harer bhajann apakvo’tha patet tato yadi yatra kva vabhadram abh≈´d amu·π£ya kim ko vartha apto bhajatƒÅm sva-dharmata·∏• 512 100 The Worthlessness of Vedic Karma Devoid of Bhakti - I laborious to perform, one obtains only petty fruit, like pro- motion to the celestial planets, whereas by bhakti, which is accomplished with very little effort and expense, one attains the supreme transcendental fruit. In fact, such a result may be obtained even by a semblance (abhƒÅsa) of bhakti. From this, it is to be concluded that the import of all scripture is in bhakti alone. Therefore, it should also be understood that because all other scriptures also advocate bhakti in a roundabout manner by promoting various other processes, they are not futile. ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•≠‡•§‡•Ø‡•§‡•ß‡•¶) - Furthermore, ≈öri Prahlada said to Bhagavan Sri Nrsimha: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§£‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•ß ‡•• In my opinion, a dog-eater, who has offered his mind, speech, actions, wealth, and life to Bhagavan, is superior to a brƒÅhma·πáa who, although endowed with twelve exalted qualities, is not devoted to the lotus feet of Bhagavan, whose navel is shaped like a lotus. Such a dog-eater purifies his whole family and not the overly proud brƒÅhma·πáa. (SB 7.9.10)2 ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ö - “‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‘‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡§™‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•å‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§¨‡§≤- ‡§™‡•å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§É’ (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•≠/‡•Ø/‡•Ø) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§°‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§ 2 ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi comments as follows: “It was said that it is pos- sible to please Bhagavan Hari only by unalloyed (kevala) bhakti. Now in this verse, Prahlada asserts that there is nothing other than bhakti that can be a cause for Bhagavan’s satisfaction. The viprad dvi-sad-gu·πáa-yutad aravinda-nƒÅbha- pƒÅdƒÅravinda-vimukhat svapacam varistham manye tad-arpita-mano-vacanehitartha- prƒÅnam punati sa kulam na tu bh≈´rimƒÅna·∏• 513 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya immediately preceding verse [SB 7.9.9]3 enumerated the twelve qualities referred to here as follows: wealth, birth in a cultured family, beauty, austerity, erudition, sensory prowess, physi- cal power, influence, bodily strength, industriousness, intelli- gence, and the culture of yoga. Prahlada says that he considers a dog-eater [who is fully devoted to Bhagavan] superior even to a vipra possessing these twelve qualities [but who is not devoted to Bhagavan]. ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É (‡§Æ‡•¶ ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•©‡•§‡•™‡•©‡•§‡•®‡•¶ ) - “Alternatively, the twelve qualities may refer to those mentioned by the sage Sanat Sujata in the Mahabharata: ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§¶‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•® ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The twelve vows of a brahmana are moral integrity, truthful- ness, sensual regulation, austerity, nonenvy, modesty, toler- ance, freedom from jealousy, sacrifice, charity, fortitude, and erudition. (Mahabharata, Udyoga-parva 43.20) ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ? ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ö‡§Æ‡•ç ? ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®- ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡•á‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§® ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§à‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ö‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ? ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§§‡•á ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡•Ä‡§® ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡•§ “What type of vipra does Prahlada consider to be inferior to a dog-eater? He replies that it is a brahmana who is not devoted to the lotus feet of the lotus-navelled Bhagavan. And what type of dog-eater does he speak of? One who has offered his mind, speech, and so on to the lotus-navelled Bhagavan. The word ihitam means ‘actions.’ What is the reason behind the dog- eater’s superiority? Such a dog-eater purifies his entire dynasty, 3 4 manye dhanabhijana-rupa-tapa·∏•-≈õrutaujas- teja·∏•-prabhava-bala-paurusa-buddhi-yoga·∏• n√§rƒÅdhanaya hi bhavanti parasya pu·πÅso bhakty√§ tuto≈üa bhagavan gaja-yutha-pƒÅya dharmam ca satyam ca damas-tapas ca amƒÅtsaryam hris titik·π£ƒÅnasuyƒÅh yajna≈õ ca danam ca dh·πõti·∏• ≈õrutam ca vratani vai dvƒÅdasa brƒÅhma·πáasya 514 100 The Worthlessness of Vedic Karma Devoid of Bhakti ‚Äî I whereas the vipra, being excessively proud, cannot even purify himself, to say nothing of his family. The import is that for a person devoid of bhakti, all these qualities are simply a source of pride and not of purification. For this reason, such a person is inferior.” [Here ends ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi’s comment.] ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§´‡§≤‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö - “‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§°‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§æ- In his Mukta-phala commentary (16.26), Vopadeva also says: “The twelve qualities are those referred to in the previous verse [SB 7.9.9], such as wealth and birth in a cultured family. Alter- natively, they may refer to the qualities mentioned in this verse: ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§¶‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§É ‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§£‡§æ‡§É || ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•© ‡•• The twelve qualities are control of the mind, control of the senses, austerity, cleanliness, tolerance, simplicity, detach- ment, knowledge, realization, satisfaction, truthfulness, and theism.5 ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ | This is the end of Vopadeva’s comment. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç- In the Skanda PurƒÅ·πáa, ≈örƒ´ Narada makes the following statement: 5 ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•É‡§¢‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§É ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•™ ‡•• Although bereft of noble birth and civility, a person endowed with resolute bhakti, who has subdued his senses, is praised by all people, but not a dvija who is devoid of bhakti, even if he has samo damas tapa·∏• saucam k·π£anty arjava-viraktaya·∏• j√±ana-vij√±ana-santo·π£a·∏• satyastikye dvi-sad-gunah 515 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya studied all eighteen branches of Vedic knowledge and is peace- ful, highborn, and attentive to his prescribed duties. (Skanda Purana) ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§ö- In the Ka≈õi-khanda also, it is said: ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É || ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•´ || Whether one is a brƒÅhmana, a ksatriya, a vai≈õya, a ≈õ≈´dra, or any- thing else, if he is fully endowed with Visnu-bhakti, he is to be understood as the best of all the best. ( Kasi khanda) 7 ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á - And in the Brhad - naradiya PurƒÅna: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•¨ ‡•• Those who are devoid of Vi≈ünu-bhakti, whoever they may be, are proclaimed as candƒÅlas, or outcastes, but those who are exclu- sively fixed in bhakti to Bhagavan Hari are the greatest, even if they are cƒÅndƒÅlas (Brhad - naradiya Purana 1.37.12 ) s ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á‡§ö- In the Narada Purana also: T ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ö‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§É || ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•≠ || kulƒÅcƒÅra-vihƒ´no’pi drdha-bhakti-jitendriyah prasasta·∏• sarva-lokƒÅnƒÅ·πÅ na tv a·π£·π≠ƒÅdasa-vidyaka·∏• bhakti-hino dvija·∏• santa·∏• saj-jatir dharmikas tatha brahmana·∏• ksatriyo vaisyah sudro va yadi vetara·∏• vis≈Üu-bhakti-samayukto j√±eya·∏• sarvottamottama·∏• vi≈ünu-bhakti-vihina ye cand√§l√§·∏• parikƒ´rtitƒÅ·∏• candƒÅlƒÅ api te ≈õrestha hari-bhakti-parƒÅya·πáa·∏• 516 100 The Worthlessness of Vedic Karma Devoid of Bhakti ‚Äî I O King, a devotee of Visnu is better than a dvija, even if he is a dog-eater, but a dvija devoid of Visnu-bhakti is worse than a dog-eater. (Narada Purana 2.10.37b-38a)” ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á “‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•™‡•§‡•ß‡•Æ) - In the original verse under discussion, it is said that a dog-eater who has offered his entire being to Bhagavan, purifies his entire dynasty. This of necessity means that he purifies himself as well, as it is said: ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§π‡•Ç‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§∂‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ï‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§ñ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•á ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• The Kiratas, H≈´≈Üas, Andhras, Pulindas, Pukkasas, Abhiras, Kankas, Yavanas, Khasas, and all other races of sinful peo- ple become purified simply by taking shelter of those who have taken shelter of that Omnipotent Lord unto whom I offer obeisance. (SB 2.4.18) 10 Commentary DIFFERENT paths have different criteria of eligibility for their respective practitioners. The path of ritual or sacrificial action (karma-marga) requires a psycho-physical standard of purity that depends upon birth as well as the character and conduct of the practitioner. A person not born in var·πáƒÅ≈õrama is disqualified to participate in the path of karma. This is so because the path of karma is related to the mind and body, which are products of mat- ter. It aims at securing material boons by appeasing different deities in charge of universal material affairs. Its ultimate purpose, 9 svapaco’pi mahipala vi≈ünor bhakto dvijƒÅdhika·∏• visnu-bhakti-vihino yo dvijati·∏• svapacƒÅdhikah 10 kirata-h≈´·πáƒÅndhra-pulinda-pukka≈°ƒÅ ƒÅbhira-kankƒÅ yavanƒÅ·∏• khasƒÅdaya·∏• ye’nye ca papa yad-apa≈õrayasraya·∏• ≈õudhyanti tasmai prabhavisnave nama·∏• 517 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya however, is to purify the heart of the practitioners, so that they become gradually freed of their material attachments. Bhakti, on the other hand, is a purely spiritual path, directly related to Bhagavan, who is beyond all contact with matter. It is the way of the heart, the path of divine love. Birth and social sta- tus play no role on this path; transcendental devotion and love are the only things that are of any importance here. It is on this basis that an exalted being such as Brahma, the original teacher of the four Vedas, expressed his longing to be born in Vrindavana even if only as a creeper so that the dust from the feet of its resi- dents, who were primarily vaisyas, would be sprinkled on his head (SB 10.14.34).

≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´ cites a statement of Prahlada to illustrate the unique power of bhakti. In the var·πáƒÅ≈õrama system, a vipra is regarded as the purest or the most highly evolved human being, whereas a ≈õvapaca, or a dog-eater, is considered to be the lowest, or the most impure. A person born from brahmana parents is classified in a general sense as a brahmana. After coming of age and undergoing the preparatory ritual known as the upanayana- samskƒÅra, he is addressed as a dvija and becomes eligible to begin his study of the Veda. Then, after completing his studies, he becomes a vipra in earnest and is characterized as a ≈õrotriya, or one who is learned in the three Vedas11 In Prahlada’s opinion, however, although such a vipra may be endowed with all good qualities, if he is not devoted to Bhagavan, he is inferior to an outcaste dog-eater (svapaca) who is a devotee. This means that by the intrinsic power of bhakti, the lowest per- son in the var·πáƒÅ≈õrama system surpasses even the highest person, a vipra, who is devoid of bhakti. Such a vipra would be proud of his noble birth and education and thus would never be able to recog- nize the lower caste or outcaste devotee. He would think himself to be superior, which in an absolute, transcendental sense is a mis- take - the devotee is always dearer to God than the nondevotee, no “janmanƒÅ brƒÅhma·πáa·∏• j√±eya·∏• samskaraih dvija ucyate vidyaya yati vipratvam tribhi·∏• ≈õrotriya-lak·π£a·πáam Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda 148.129 518 100 The Worthlessness of Vedic Karma Devoid of Bhakti - I matter how materially or spiritually qualified. One who harbors such pride in his material birth and achievements cannot purify even himself because of this disqualification. On the other hand, a ≈õvapaca devotee will naturally be humble for two reasons. He has nothing to be proud of from the material or external point of view, and bhakti itself endows the devotee with humility, no matter how qualified. In fact, ≈örƒ´ Suka, citing the prayers of Prahlada to Bhagavan Nrsimha on Hari-varsa, affirms that all good qualities become manifested in a devotee: The celestial beings along with all their virtues become firmly established in one who has unmotivated devotion for Bhagavan: On the other hand, where are noble qualities to be found in a per- son bereft of devotion for Sri Hari? Such a person rushes about in outward pursuit of impermanent sense objects led by the chariot of desire. (SB 5.18.12)12 The conclusion is that bhakti is the basis of all good qualities and that without bhakti even so-called good qualities are only a source of tribulation. There are examples of people like RƒÅvana, who was a brahmana and learned in the Vedas but antagonistic to Bhagavan. Although he even wrote commentaries on the Vedas and was exceptionally powerful, having acquired many metanor- mal powers through his mastery of yoga, he was recognized as an asura because of his animosity to Bhagavan Rama. On the other hand, there was a female devotee named Sabari, who was born in a very low caste family and was uneducated, yet Bhagavan RƒÅma personally visited her hut and happily ate the food offered by her. From the var·πáƒÅ≈õrama point of view, food prepared by her would be unacceptable by a person of the upper castes. This incident clearly shows that Bhagavan is pleased only by bhakti and not by anything else. It is with this understanding that the Narada Purana declares that a ≈õvapaca who is a devotee is superior to a dvija, and that a nondevotee dvija is inferior to a svapaca. 12 yasyasti bhaktir bhagavaty aki√±canƒÅ sarvair gunais tatra samƒÅsate surah harav abhaktasya kuto mahad-guna manorathenasati dhƒÅvato bahih 519 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya A doubt may be raised here in regard to bhakti’s being estab- lished as the sole means of ultimate attainment. If bhakti, which is supremely potent by its own intrinsic nature, is the only abhi- dheya, and if all other paths are inefficacious without the support of bhakti, then why do different sastras recommend paths other than bhakti? The answer is that people in general do not develop ≈õraddha in bhakti unless they obtain the association of a devotee, which is very rare. A person’s ≈õraddha is naturally in accord with their psycho-physical constitution, as explained by ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa (Gƒ™TƒÄ 17.3). Consequently, unless one comes into contact with a devotee, one’s natural orientation would be toward worldly ends or at best mukti. If such people are not engaged in some particular process by sastra, they would remain undisciplined and frivolous, as is the case at present. For this reason, sastra recommends various paths. While engaged in these practices, if a person happens to meet a devotee, they may take to bhakti. Otherwise, such a person at least remains faithful to sastra, follows a certain regimen, and gradually evolves in consciousness. 520 Anuccheda 101 The Worthlessness of Vedic Karma Devoid of Bhakti ‚Äî II

‡•ß‡•¶‡•ß ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ | ‡•®‡•© | ‡•©‡•Ø ) - THEREFORE, the yƒÅjnika-brƒÅhma·πáas repented: ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ú‡•á ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•Ø ‡•• Shame upon our three auspicious births, shame upon our vows, and shame upon our extensive learning! Shame upon our noble heritage, and shame upon our proficiency in performing ritu- als, for we have diverted our attention away from Bhagavan Adhok·π£aja. (SB 10.23.39)1 ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ö - “‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡•§ ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi comments: “The words triv·πõt janma mean ’three types of birth,’ namely, ≈õaukra, ‘seminal,’ savitra, ‘initiation into the chanting of the s√§vitri-mantra and being invested with the sacred thread,’ and daik·π£am [or yƒÅjnika], ‘initiation into the performance of Vedic sacrifice.’ The word vrata means ’the vow of celibacy’ (brahmacaryam), and kriyƒÅ-dƒÅk·π£yam means ‘dexter- ity in the execution of ritual or sacrificial acts.”” [Here ends ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi’s comment.] 1 dhig janma nas triv·πõd yat tad dhig vratam dhig bahu-j√±atƒÅm dhik kulam dhik kriya-daksyam vimukha ye tv adhoksaje 521I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§§‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•™‡•§‡•©‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•• ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡•• A similar statement was made by ≈örƒ´ NƒÅrada:

What is the value of a human being’s three births in this world ‚Äî ≈õaukra (seminal), sƒÉvitra (initiation into the chanting of the sƒÉvitri-mantra and being invested with the sacred thread), and yajnika (initiation into the performance of Vedic sacrifice)? What is the use of the ritual acts prescribed by the three Vedas? Of what value even is a lifespan as long as that of the gods? What is the point of hearing the Vedas, of asceticism, eloquence of speech, focused mental attention, acute intelligence, power, sensual dexterity, yoga, sankhya, mendicancy, study of the Vedas, and other auspicious practices, if by these Bhagavan Hari is not self-disclosed as the revealer of the Self (atma-prada·∏•)? (SB 4.31.10-12)2 Commentary ≈öRI JIVA GOSVƒÄMƒ™ continues to stress the singular importance of bhakti and the futility of all other practices if devoid of bhakti. Bhakti is comparable to the ƒÅtmƒÅ itself, and all other practices are akin to the physical body. Just as the physical body is worthless without the presence of the ƒÅtmƒÅ, so too all other processes and paths are impotent without bhakti. The principal verse of this anuccheda (SB 10.23.39) is spoken by the brahmanas of Mathura, who had assembled near V·πõndƒÅvana to perform a yaj√±a. Meanwhile, K·πõ·π£·πáa was tending the cows nearby along with His friends. In the midst of their play, K·πõ·π£·πáa’s friends suddenly became overwhelmed with hunger and requested K·πõ·π£·πáa to arrange for some food. Krsna directed them to the brahmanas, who were engaged in their yaj√±a nearby. When, however, the 2 kim janmabhis tribhir veha saukra-savitra-yajnikai·∏• karmabhir vƒÉ trayi-proktai·∏• pumso’pi vibudhayu·π£ƒÅ srutena tapasƒÅ vƒÅ kim vacobhi≈õ citta-vrttibhih buddhyƒÅ vƒÅ kim nipunaya balenendriya-rƒÅdhasƒÉ kim va yogena sƒÅnkhyena nyasa-sv√§dhyƒÅyayor api kim va sreyobhir anyais ca na yatratma-prado harih 522 101 The Worthlessness of Vedic Karma Devoid of Bhakti - II brƒÅhma·πáas were approached by the boys, they would not give them any food, not wanting to be diverted from their rituals. So the boys returned without success. Krsna then advised them to approach the wives of the very same brahmanas. When the boys went to the wives and asked for food, the wives were delighted. They person- ally carried sumptuous offerings of cooked preparations to K·πõ·π£·πáa and fed everyone. At this point, the brahmanas realized their mis- take by the grace of their wives. They spoke the present verse while repenting for not having served K·πõ·π£·πáa and His friends when they first had the chance. After demonstrating the futility of karma devoid of bhakti, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi next explains that even karma offered to Bhagavan is inferior to pure bhakti. 523 Anuccheda 102 Disdain for the Practices of Karma and Yoga ‡•ß‡•¶‡•® ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç " ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•ß‡•ß‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•®‡•ß‡•Æ-‡•ß‡•ß ) - EARLIER, by way of the disregard expressed even for the practice of offering one’s prescribed duties to Sri BhagavƒÅn [in SB1.2.8- 10], bhakti was shown to be the abhidheya, as concluded in this verse: Consequently, with one-pointed mental attention, one should continuously hear about, glorify, meditate on, and worship BhagavƒÅn ≈örƒ´ Krsna, the guardian of His devotees. ( SB 1.2.14 ) 1 In Bhagavad GitƒÅ also, offering one’s actions to Bhagavan is prescribed only if one is incapable of direct engagement in bhakti: 1 ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§® ‡§Ü‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§Ø ‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•ß ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•® ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§•‡•à‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§´‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•© ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ tasmad ekena manasa bhagavan satvatƒÅ·πÅ pati·∏• ≈õrotavya·∏• kirtitavya≈õ ca dhyeyah pujya≈õ ca nityadƒÅ 524 102 Disdain for the Practices of Karma and Yoga Fix your mind exclusively on Me, and let your intelligence be absorbed in Me. Thereafter, you will reside only in Me. Of this there is no doubt. If, however, you are unable to fix your mind steadily on Me, O Dhananjaya, then seek to attain Me by repeated practice. If you are unable even to practice steadily in this manner, then be devoted to working for Me. Even by engagement in actions for My satisfaction, you will attain per- fection. But if you cannot do even this, then take shelter of My yoga, and being self-controlled, offer the fruits of all your actions to Me. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 12.8-11)2 ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ In this regard, we may examine the following narrative from the KƒÅrtika-mƒÅhƒÅtmya of the Padma PurƒÅ≈Üa: ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‚Äî‚Äú‡§ö‡•ã‡§≤‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§π‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ß‡§§‡•ã ‡§® ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‚Äî “There was a brƒÅhma·πáa named Vi·π£·πáudƒÅsa in the kingdom of Chola, who was purely engaged in the worship of Bhagavan. The king of Chola challenged him to a competition to see who would attain Bhagavan first. Although the king meticulously performed many sacrifices and offered them to Bhagavan, he could not attain Bhagavan. But, seeing that the brƒÅhma·πáa had already attained Bhagavan, he gave up the sacrifices and spoke to Mudgala, his priest: 2 ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ß‡•É‡§ó‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•™ ‡•• mayy eva mana adhatsva mayi buddhim nivesaya nivasisyasi mayy eva ata urdhva·πÅ na samsaya·∏• atha cittam samƒÅdhƒÅtum na ≈õakno·π£i mayi sthiram abhyasa-yogena tato mam icchaptum dhananjaya abhyase’py asamartho’si mat-karma-paramo bhava mad-artham api karmani kurvan siddhim avapsyasi athaitad apy asakto’si kartum mad-yogam asrita·∏• sarva-karma-phala-tyagam tatah kuru yatatmav√§n 525 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§£‡•á ‡§Æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•´ ‡•• ‘It was I who performed all these acts of sacrifice, charity, and so on in competition with this brahmana, yet it is he who has obtained a form like Vis≈Üu and is ascending to the abode of Vaikuntha. Therefore, I have concluded that Bhagavan Vi·π£·πáu is certainly not pleased merely by sacrifices and acts of char- ity. Bhakti alone is the supreme cause of His pleasure.’ (Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda 109.22, 25) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•å ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§π‡•ã‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•à‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•ã‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ- ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ “After admitting this to Mudgala, he stood in front of the sac- rificial fire pit and resoundingly uttered the following words three times, ‘Kindly bestow resolute devotion to Vis≈Üu upon me through my actions of mind, speech, and body’ (Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda 109.29) Saying this and taking exclu- sive shelter of pure devotion, he at once gathered complete humility, gave up his body in the sacrificial pit, and immedi- ately thereupon attained bhakti.” [Here ends the narrative from the KƒÅrtika-mƒÅhƒÅtmya of the Padma PurƒÅ·πáa.] ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§π (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•§‡•´‡•ß‡•§‡•¨‡•ß) ‚Äî Next, [bhakti is established as the abhidheya], by the expression of disregard for the path of yoga, as in the following statement of Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa to King Mucukunda: 3 4 yat-spardhaya maya caitad yaj√±a-dƒÅnƒÅdikam k·πõtam sa vi≈ünu-rupa-dhrg vipro yati vaikuntha-mandiram tasmad danais ca yaj√±ais ca naiva vi≈ünu·∏• prasidati bhaktir eva para·πÅ tasya nidanam tosane matam visnau bhaktim sthiram dehi mano-vƒÅk kƒÅya-karma·πáƒÅ trir uccair vyƒÅjahƒÅrƒÅsau homa-ku·πá·∏çƒÅgrata·∏• sthita·∏• 526 102 Disdain for the Practices of Karma and Yoga ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•≠ || O King, the mind of those who are engaged in the formal prac- tices of mental discipline [i.e., the yogis], yet who are bereft of devotion, does not abandon its predisposition for sense plea- sure through the practice of breath restraint (pranayama) and other such methods. Consequently, it is sometimes seen to revert to its focus on the sense objects. (SB 10.51.61) ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• The word utthitam, [the mind is seen to have again] “risen up,” means, “to have become focused on the sense objects” (vi≈üayabhimukham). Commentary AFTER showing that karma is ineffective without bhakti, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va now makes the point that even karma offered to K·πõ·π£·πáa is not pure bhakti. It is for this reason that in the very beginning of Srimad BhƒÅgavata (SB 1.2.14), ≈örƒ´ S≈´ta advocates pure bhakti alone, and not karma even when offered to Bhagavan. The recommendation to offer one’s prescribed and worldly actions is for people who are unable to take to pure bhakti. This inability occurs when the mind is overly preoccupied with material desires and when one is igno- rant of his true identity as a spiritual self distinct from the mind and body. It is therefore said that j√±ƒÅna and vairƒÅgya have some utility only in assisting a person’s entry into bhakti but can impede its progress later (BRS 1.2.248) The story of King of Chola mentioned here is found in chap- ters 108-109 of the Uttara-khanda of Padma Purana. There was a king named Chola who ruled in South India. He was very pious and 5 6 yu√±jƒÅnƒÅnƒÅm abhaktƒÅnƒÅm prƒÅ·πáƒÅyƒÅmƒÅdibhir mana·∏• ak·π£ina-vasanam rajan drsyate kvacid utthitam jnana-vairagyayor bhakti-pravesayapayogita isat prathamam eveti nangatvam ucitam tayoh 527 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya devoted to Bhagavan Vi·π£·πáu. He performed an immense yaj√±a on the banks of the Tamrapar·πáƒ´ River for the pleasure of Vi·π£≈Üu. One day, he visited the temple of Bhagavan Ananta, where the deity is lying down in the yogic sleep of supraconscious absorption (yoga- nidrƒÅ). He worshiped this form of Bhagavan with great opulence, offering Him various gems, ornaments, and golden flowers. Just then, a brƒÅhma·πáa named Visnudasa arrived there and wor- shiped the deity with tulasi leaves while chanting Vedic hymns. The king noticed that the tulasi leaves offered by the brƒÅhma·πáa were covering the beautiful ornaments he had offered. This infuriated him, and he rebuked the brƒÅhma·πáa for doing so. The brƒÅhma·πáa, not caring for the king, replied tauntingly, pointing out the king’s igno- rance of devotion. The king was outraged at this, and he ridiculed the brahmana by asking, “What makes a poor fellow like you think you could serve Bhagavan?” The brahmana replied that Bhagavan is pleased only by bhakti and not by opulent offerings. The king laughed sarcastically and questioned how this pitiable fellow could possibly be a devotee. Then he proudly boasted of his many acts of charity, building of temples, and the elaborate and opulent yaj√±as he had performed for the satisfaction of Visnu. He claimed that the brahmana had nothing of value to offer that could please Bhagavan Vi≈ü≈Üu. It is often the case that rich people, who are proud of their wealth, think that only they can serve Bhaga- van. They arrange for enormous celebrations, such as the recita- tion of Bhagavata Purana for seven days with much pomp and cir- cumstance, with 108 brahmanas engaged in recitation. At the con- clusion of the recitation, a tremendous yaj√±a is performed followed by a huge feast. This type of undertaking is more about ostentation than devotion. Being of such a mindset, king of Chola threw down a challenge that whoever of the two could attain Bhagavan first would prove his supremacy. The brƒÅhma·πáa Vi·π£·πáudƒÅsa accepted the challenge. The king then began an elaborate yaj√±a, while the brƒÅhma·πáa chanted Vedic hymns and worshiped the deity with tulasi leaves. A long time passed in this manner. One day, the brƒÅhma·πáa pre- pared a dish of eatables, but before he could offer it to his deity, 528 102 Disdain for the Practices of Karma and Yoga someone stole the food.
