He did not cook again that day, because he had to complete his evening chanting and worship. The next day, the same thing happened again, and this episode was repeated for seven consecutive days. At this point, the brahmana had not eaten for seven days, because he would not eat without first offering the food to Bhagavan, and he had no time to cook again. Feeling some- what frustrated, he considered leaving the place altogether, since he was afraid that he would be unable to survive if this scenario continued. On the eighth day, he cooked again and then hid himself to see who was stealing the offerings. What he saw was that an extremely emaciated person of low birth was entering the kitchen and steal- ing the food. When the thief ran away, the brƒÅhma·πáa came out from his hiding place and chased after him. The brƒÅhma·πáa, who was carrying a pot of ghee in his hands, compassionately shouted after him, “Please stop and take some ghee. How can you eat this dry food?” When the brƒÅhma·πáa was chasing him, the thief, who was severely emaciated due to starvation, tripped and fell uncon- scious on the ground. The brahmana attempted to revive him by sprinkling water on his face and fanning him with his upper gar- ment. Suddenly, he watched as the thief stood up and assumed the four-handed form of Visnu. The brahmana was overwhelmed by seeing his worshipable Bhagavan standing directly in front of him. Then, a celestial vehicle descended from the sky, and Bhaga- van Vi·π£·πáu carried the brahmana to His abode. The brahmana also obtained a four-handed transcendental form just like that of Vis≈Üu. The king witnessed the brahmana ascending to Vaikuntha and spoke the verses cited in this anuccheda (109.22, 25) to his priest Mudgala. Thereupon, he installed his sister’s son on the throne and leaped into the sacrificial fire while praying for pure devo- tion. Without delay, he too attained Vaikuntha. The moral of the story is that Bhagavan is pleased only by bhakti and not by anything external. The king had been ceremoniously engaged in performing opulent yaj√±as, offering charity, and conducting other such acts as duties within var·πáƒÅ≈õrama and then offering them to Vis≈Üu, but all this was not equal to the simple devotion of the brƒÅhma·πáa. 529 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya After establishing bhakti as the abhidheya by the comparative disregard shown for the path of karma, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va next begins to demonstrate bhakti’s preeminence in contrast to the path of yoga. In this connection, he cites a statement spoken by ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa to King Mucukunda. In this verse (SB 10.51.61), Krsna clearly states that the yogis who are engaged in various forms of mind training (yunj√§nƒÅnƒÅm), yet who are bereft of devotion, can be allured again by the sense objects. A classic example of this is seen in the life of the sage Saubhari, whose story is related in the sixth chapter of the Ninth Canto of the Bhagavata. He was a great yogi, who was meditating under water inside the Yamuna River for a long time. One day, he saw fish mating, and this revived his sublatent sexual impressions, inciting within him the desire for a marital relation. Subsequently, he abandoned his meditation, restored his body to a youthful state through yogic power, and married fifty princesses. In contrast to this, there is the story in Mahabharata of Arjuna, who journeyed to Indraloka to help Indra fight with the Kalakeya asuras. While residing there, he was approached at night in private by Urvasi, the most beautiful and famous apsarƒÉ of heaven. Arjuna could easily have enjoyed her company, but he turned down her request. Being a devotee, he was not allured even by the most beau- tiful heavenly courtesan in the dead of night, whereas Saubhari became agitated merely by the sight of fish mating. In the next anuccheda, ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmi offers further evidence of yoga’s inferiority in comparison to bhakti. 530 Anuccheda 103 Bhakti Contrasted with Yoga ‡•ß‡•¶‡•© | ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•¨‡•§‡•©‡•¨ ) - IN THE same vein, ≈örƒ´ NƒÅrada instructed ≈örƒ´ VyƒÅsa: ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§™‡§•‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§≠‡§π‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§® ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§‡•§ ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•Æ ‡•§‡•§ The mind, which is repeatedly overwhelmed by lust and greed, is not as directly established in tranquility by the path of yoga, beginning with the practice of moral restraint (yama), as it is by the sacred service of Bhagavan Mukunda, “the very embodiment of liberation.” (SB 1.6.36)1 ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ " ‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•™ ‡•§‡•®‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ- ‡§∞‡§¶‡•ã ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• 1 Consequently, the following assertion is all the more self- evident: 2 O Uddhava, neither the practice of yoga, nor Sankhya, nor atten- tion to prescribed religious duties (dharma), nor the study of the Vedas, nor penance, nor renunciation can subdue Me as does all-powerful devotion rendered unto Me. (SB 11.14.20)2 yamadibhir yoga-pathai·∏• kama-lobha-hato muhu·∏• mukunda-sevaya yad vat tathaddhƒÅtmƒÅ na samyati na sadhayati mam yogo na sankhyam dharma uddhava na svadhyayas tapas tyago yatha bhaktir mamorjitƒÅ 531Commentary 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya THE mind (manas) is a product of prak·πõti, which is constituted of the three gunas. The three gunas exist and interact in a state of invariable entanglement. It is not possible to separate any one of them from the other two, as they are integrally present in every- thing material. It is only their ratios that are subject to variation. Some things contain a higher preponderance of sattva, others of rajas, and yet others of tamas. Since the mind is also a product of these three gunas, it can never be permanently established in sattva alone, free from any influence of rajas and tamas, by any method that is itself at best a product of sattva-guna. Consequently, the attempt to control the mind by the practice of yoga, which is born of sattva-guna, can be successful only up to a certain point. When rajas exerts its influence, the mind will again be thrown out of the equilibrated state. Bhakti, however, being the intrinsic potency of Bhagavan, is completely beyond the gunas. By engagement in bhakti, a devotee’s mind becomes imbued with this potency and functions directly under its influence. When this occurs, the mind is established in the state of unwavering tranquility, known as sama. Narada confirms to Vyasa that the mind is “directly tranquilized‚Äù (addhƒÅ ≈õƒÅmyati) by sevƒÅ to ≈örƒ´ Mukunda, “the very embodiment of liber- ation.” As a consequence of this transmutation of its fundamental nature, the mind is no longer subject to the fluctuations of the mate- rial gunas, and hence there is no possibility of its straying away from Bhagavan. No sense object born of the gunas has the power to pull away the “nirguna-essentialized” (i.e., nirguna-ƒÅtmaka) mind of a devotee. In Narada’s statement (SB 1.6.36), the sense of saying that “the mind is not ‘as’ directly established in tranquility by the path of yoga” is that if one combines yoga with bhakti, then the mind can be partially equilibrated due to the slight infusion of the nirguna intrinsic potency. Even this partial tranquilization, however, is not accomplished as effectively as is the case when one engages in pure nirguna devotion. If, on the other hand, one practices yoga devoid of 532 103 Bhakti Contrasted with Yoga bhakti, then because the mind remains under the influence of the gu≈Üas, it can never transcend its own nature and become directly established in “unwavering peace” (sama). For this reason, even Patanjali in his Yoga-sutras has included “surrender to God” (isvara-pranidhana) in all three types of yoga outlined by him. In the first chapter, he describes rƒÅja-yoga and advocates isvara-pra·πáidhƒÅna in sutra 1.23. In the second chapter, he discusses kriya-yoga (2.1) and a·π£·π≠ƒÅrga-yoga (2.29). Surrender to God is compulsory for the latter two disciplines. Within the context of the Yoga-sutras, bhakti in the form of isvara-pra·πáidhƒÅna is taken as secondary to yoga, and it is understood as assisting in bringing forth the results of yoga. Having established bhakti as the abhidheya by showing the infe- rior status of karma and yoga, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ next applies the same strategy of disaffirmative inference (vyatireka) in regard to the path of j√±ƒÅna. 533 Anuccheda 104 Bhakti Contrasted with J√±ƒÅna ‡•ß‡•¶‡•™ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‚Äú‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•©‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•™‡•´) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ NOW, BHAKTI is illustrated as the abhidheya by virtue of the disregard expressed even for the path of j√±ƒÅna. In this regard, numerous verses have already been cited that exhibit disdain for the path of j√±ƒÅna because of the difficulty involved in effect- ing its completed state of realization. This is exemplified in the following pair of verses: O Bhagavan, those whose hearts have been purified by con- summate bhakti, drinking the nectar of Your stories, attain to immediate realization (bodham) permeated with the essence of detachment (vairagya-sƒÅram) and easily attain Vaikuntha as a matter of course. Whereas others, the j√±ƒÅnis (dhƒ´rƒÅ·∏•), after surmounting the powerful material nature on the strength of their transcognitive absorption in the Self, enter in You only, the Supreme Immanent Being (Purusa). They undergo a great deal of hardship but not those who attain You through divine service (seva). (SB 3.5.45-46)1 ‡§§‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‚Äú‡§ï‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•™‡•§‡•®‡•®‡•§‡•™‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ p√§nena te deva katha-sudhayah prav·πõddha-bhaktyƒÅ visadƒÅsaya ye vairagya-saram pratilabhya bodham yathanjasƒÅnviyur akuntha-dhisnyam tathapare catma-samadhi-yoga-balena jitvƒÅ prak·πõtim balisthƒÅm tvam eva dhirah purusam visanti te·π£ƒÅm ≈õramah syan na tu sevaya te 534 104 Bhakti Contrasted with Jnana The same idea is reiterated in the KumƒÅra’s instructions to King Prthu: Those who desire to cross the ocean of birth and death, which is infested with the crocodiles of the mind and five senses, yet who are without a boat in the form of the shelter of Isvara, undergo great tribulation in this attempt by undertaking diffi- cult means, such as jnana. Consequently, you should adopt the worshipable feet of Bhagavan Hari as your boat and cross over this insurmountable ocean of misery. ( SB 4.22.40 ) 2 ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ö (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•ß-‡•´) - In Bhagavad Gita also, the same conclusion is affirmed in Krsna’s response to this question of Arjuna: 2 ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§® ‡§â‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö - ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•Ø ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö- ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•¶‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§ö‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•¶‡•ß ‡•• ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§É || ‡•®‡•¶‡•® || ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•®‡•¶‡•© ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Arjuna inquired: Between those devotees who are ever united with you in the manner previously described and who worship You in the fullness of being, and those who worship the imper- ishable and unmanifest [Brahman], who have better realized the nature of yoga? Bhagavan replied: Those whose minds are absorbed in Me, who k·πõcchro mah√§n iha bhavar·πáavam aplave≈õƒÅ·πÅ sad-varga-nakram asukhena titirsanti tat tvam harer bhagavato bhajaniyam anghrim krtvo·∏çupam vyasanam uttara dustara·πõ·πáam 535 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya are ever united with Me, and who worship Me, being endowed with transcendental faith, I regard as the topmost realizers of yoga. But those who have regulated their senses, who are established in the vision of equality toward all phenomenal uprisings, who are engaged in the welfare of all living beings, and who worship the ineffable, unmanifest, all-pervading, inconceivable, immutable, immovable, eternal, and imper- ishable Reality [Brahman], attain Me alone. The hardship of those whose minds are attached to the unmanifest is greater, because the goal of the unmanifest is attained with difficulty by embodied beings. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 12.1-5)3 ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•™‡•§‡•©) - On the path of bhakti, however, there is no hardship (≈õramah). Furthermore, bhakti yields an unprecedented fruit (ap≈´rvam phalam), being that Bhagavan comes under the control of His devotee. This is affirmed in this statement of Brahma: ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ú‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§§‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç || ‡•®‡•¶‡•™ || O Bhagavan, although as a general rule You are invincible (ajitah) throughout the three worlds, even You become con- quered (jitah) by those who, having abandoned all striving for j√±ƒÅna, live their lives solely by venerating through body, speech, and mind the sacred narrations of Your lilƒÅs. Such nar- rations enter their ears of their own accord, flowing from the . arjuna uvƒÅca - evam satata-yukta ye bhaktas tvam paryupasate ye capy aksaram avyaktam te·π£am ke yoga-vittamƒÅ·∏• sri bhagavan uvƒÅca ‚Äî mayy avesya mano ye mam nitya-yukta upƒÅsate sraddhaya parayopetas te me yuktatamƒÅ matƒÅ·∏• ye tv aksaram anirdesyam avyaktam paryupasate sarvatra-gam acintyam ca kuta-stham acalam dhruvam sanniyamyendriya-gramam sarvatra sama-i a-buddhaya·∏• te pr√§pnuvanti mam eva sarva-bh≈´ta-hite ratƒÅ·∏• kleso’dhikataras te·π£ƒÅm avyaktasakta-cetasƒÅm avyakta hi gatir du·∏•kham dehavadbhir avapyate 536 104 Bhakti Contrasted with J√±ana mouths of sages, while they remain situated in a fixed location. (SB 10.14.3)* ‡§â‡§¶‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§à‡§∑‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ- ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡§ø ‡•§ In this verse, the word udapasya, “having abandoned,” is an indeclinable past participle meaning, “not striving even a little bit [for j√±ƒÅna].” The words sthane sthita·∏•, “situated in a fixed location or position,” mean, “while staying at the residence of those who have realized the truth (satƒÅm).” The narrations of Bhagavan’s lƒ´lƒÅs (bhavadƒ´ya-vƒÅrtƒÅm) perpetually issue forth of their own independent will (svata·∏• eva) from the mouths of those sages (san-mukharitam). Such narrations enter the ears of their own accord (svatah eva), simply by proximity to those realized beings. The word praya≈õa·∏• means “for the most part.” So, although Bhagavan is generally (praya≈õa·∏•) invincible (ajitah) by all others throughout the three worlds, He becomes conquered (jitah) by those who live their lives solely by ven- erating through body, speech, and mind His sacred narrations, even though such people don’t undertake anything else [i.e., any other form of sadhana]. This means that He comes under their control. 4 ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á - Therefore, it is stated in the Nrsimha PurƒÅ·πáa: 5 j√±ƒÅne prayƒÅsam udapasya namanta eva jivanti san-mukharitam bhavadƒ´ya-vƒÅrtƒÅm sthƒÅne sthita·∏• ≈õruti-gatam tanu-van-manobhir ye prayaso jita jito’py asi tais tri-lokyƒÅm In his Vaisnava-to≈üani commentary, ≈öri Sanatana GosvƒÅmƒ´ glosses the words sthane sthit√§h, “situated in a fixed location or position,” as follows: satam nivasa evavyagrataya sthita·∏• na tu tirtha-parya·π≠anadi kle≈°√§n kurvanta·∏•, “while residing exclusively at the hermitage of sages and being thus steadily situated, rather than troubling themselves by wandering to many holy places.” Sridhara SvƒÅmƒ´ glosses the same two words as, “while they remain situated in their own! respective positions” (sva-sthana eva sthita·∏•). 537 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§´‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§¶‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•¶‡•´ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ When leaves, flowers, fruits, and water are readily available free of cost, and when the Primordial Being, Bhagavan, is eas- ily attainable by bhakti, why would anyone endeavor for mukti? (Nrsimha Purana 62.19) Commentary AS IS THE case with the practices of karma and yoga, the path of j√±ƒÅna devoid of bhakti is also rooted in and functions under the influence of the gunas of prak·πõti. On this path, one has to renounce all attachments to possessions and relations. Moreover, one has to apply one’s own intelligence (buddhi), or the mechanism of ascer- tainment, to control one’s mind and senses. But intelligence itself is materially constituted and operates under the influence of one’s previous sa·πÅskƒÅras. By means of such conditioned intelligence, one cannot transcend the limits of materiality. The senses are exceedingly powerful and can mislead even a person of knowledge (balavan indriya-grƒÅmo vidvƒÅ·πÅsam api kar·π£ati, SB 9.19.17). K·πõ·π£·πáa also confirms the same thing: O son of Kunti, certainly the turbulent senses forcibly snatch away the mind even of a wise person who is striving for liberation. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 2.60)” Unless one takes support from nirgu·πáƒÅ-bhakti and Bhagavan, any independent effort to liberate awareness is bound to be a failure. This is why Krsna concludes that those who are endeav- oring through the path of j√±ƒÅna have to undergo much hardship (Gƒ™TƒÄ 12.5). In the verse previous to this, Krsna states that the j√±ƒÅnis ultimately attain Him alone. By this, it is to be understood that they attain only Brahman, which is but the unqualified aspect 6 patresu puspesu phalesu toye·π£v akrita-labhyesu sadaiva satsu bhakty√§ sulabhye puruse purane muktau kim artham kriyate prayatnah 7 yatato hy api kaunteya purusasya vipascita·∏• indriyani pramathini haranti prasabha·πÅ mana·∏• 538 104 Bhakti Contrasted with J√±ƒÅna of Him. They do not attain Him as He is in His own unconcealed or utterly complete fullness of being, as disclosed to the devotees. But even to attain Brahman, they have to become permanently estab- lished in the vision of equality toward all phenomenal uprisings (sarvatra sama-buddhaya·∏•, GITA 12.4). This is not possible without the support of nirgu·πáa-bhakti, as emphatically stated by ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa Himself: A person who serves Me alone through unswerving bhakti- yoga, completely transcends these gunas of primordial nature and becomes eligible for the immediate realization of Brahman. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 14.26)9 For those, however, who disregard bhakti and who are predis- posed toward the unmanifest, there is only hardship: avyaktƒÅ hi gatir du·∏•kham (Gƒ™TƒÄ 12.5). Being bereft of contact with the trans- mutational power of the intrinsic potency, such people do not even attain Brahman. Devotees, on the other hand, do not have to make much effort, as confirmed by Brahma in the verse cited here (SB 10.14.3). Simply by hearing and venerating the narrations of K·πõ·π£·πáa’s lilƒÅs that naturally flow from the mouths of pure devo- tees, a person pleases K·πõ·π£·πáa, who then becomes conquered by him. ≈örƒ´ Jiva comments that this occurs even without undertaking any other form of sadhana (yadyapi nanyat kurvanti). Accordingly, it is said in the very beginning of Srimad Bhagavata that Krsna becomes at once captured in the heart of the virtuous in the precise moment that they merely desire to hear the Bhagavata (SB 1.1.2). In reality, undertaking the practice of j√±ana devoid of bhakti results only in suffering. This is clearly stated in the following anuccheda. 8 mam ca yo vyabhicarena bhakti-yogena sevate sa gunan samatityaitan brahma-bh≈´yaya kalpate 539 Anuccheda 105 J√±ƒÅna Is Ineffective without Bhakti 1 ‡•ß‡•¶‡•´ | ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ | ‡•ß‡•™ |‡•™) - THE TRUTH of the matter is stated by BrahmƒÅ: ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§É‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§≤ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§µ‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç || ‡•®‡•¶‡•¨ || O Omnipotent, Omnipresent Lord (vibho), those who discard bhakti unto You, which is the means to supreme blessedness, and strive instead to attain realization of the radically unqual- ified Absolute, are left in the end with nothing more than their own labor, like those engaged in threshing coarse husks devoid of grain. (SB 10.14.4) 1 ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö - " ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‘‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§É’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏ ‡§á‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ù‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§µ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§≤‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É - ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§ï‡§£‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§µ‡§ò‡•ç‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø " ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡•§ ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi comments: “Brahma speaks this verse to affirm that j√±ƒÅna cannot be accomplished without bhakti. The compound ≈õreyah-s·πõtim [qualifying the word bhakti] means that ‘bhakti is a dynamic fluid reservoir (srtih, i.e., saranam) from which flow spontaneously arising forms of well-being, Sreyah-s·πõtim bhaktim udasya te vibho klisyanti ye kevala-bodha-labdhaye te·π£ƒÅm asau klesala eva sisyate nanyad yatha sthula-tu·π£ƒÅvaghƒÅtinƒÅm 540 105 J√±ana Is Ineffective without Bhakti epitomized by liberation (≈õreyasƒÅm, i.e., abhyudayƒÅpavarga- lak·π£a·πáƒÅnƒÅm),’ like an immense mountain lake from which many cascading streams flow. Alternatively, ≈õreya·∏•-s·πõtim means ’the path (srtim, i.e., mƒÅrga-bh≈´tƒÅm) of all forms of well-being (≈õreya- sƒÅm).’ For those who discard bhakti unto You, which is the path of all blessedness, only misery remains. The import of the verse is as follows: Those who reject quantitatively small paddy and thresh bulky husks, which resemble paddy but are devoid of grain, derive absolutely no benefit from their labor. In the same manner, those who minimize bhakti and strive instead to attain realization of the radically unqualified Abso- lute (kevala-boddha) also gain nothing.” [Here ends ≈örƒ´dhara Svami’s comment.] I ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‚Äú‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•å ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§≤‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ- ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ In this verse, the word kevala, “the radically unqualified Abso- lute,” or “the Absolute as consciousness only,” can be used instead as an invocation for Bhagavan, like the word vibho, “O Omnipotent, Omnipresent Lord.” In that case, it would mean: “O pure One” (suddha) [i.e., “O You who are completely transcen- dental to, and hence absolutely untouched by, prak·πõti”]. The pronoun asau, “this,”” is used here to qualify the word klesala·∏•, “misery.” From this, it is understood that in the practices that constitute the path of j√±ƒÅna, such as sannyasa, the misery one experiences is directly before the eyes. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ö ‚Äú ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö - ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•© ‡•§ ‡•≠) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®- ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á “‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä” (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•© ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø- ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‚Äú‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•© ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‚Äú‡§è‡§§‡§ú‡•ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•© ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø- ef: 1 2 The pronoun asau, “this,” is used in Sanskrit grammar to refer to objects that are both proximate and immediately visible to the subject. 541I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya In Bhagavad GitƒÅ as well, Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa imparted instruc- tions on what constitutes j√±ƒÅna, “realized knowledge, imme- diate awareness, or wisdom,” in Chapter 13, verses 7-113 He begins this instruction related to the path of j√±ƒÅna-yoga with the words, amƒÅnitvam adambhitvam, “Wisdom involves prideless- ness, absence of deceit, and so on.” In the middle of this group of verses (13.10), K·πõ·π£·πáa says, mayi cƒÉnanya-yogena bhaktir avya- bhicƒÉri·πáƒ´, “Wisdom entails unswerving bhakti unto Me unmixed with any other type of sadhana.” In the first line of the last verse in this group (13.11), He says, tattva-j√±ƒÅnƒÅrtha-dar≈õanam, “wis- dom is to reflect on the ultimate aim of the immediate realiza- tion of the Absolute.” Then, in the final line of this verse, He concludes, etaj j√±ƒÅnam iti proktam aj√±ƒÅna·πÅ yad ato’nyathƒÅ, ‚ÄúAll this is declared to be wisdom, and whatever is apart from this is called ignorance.” From this analysis, it follows that realized knowledge (j√±ƒÅna) does not come about without bhakti-yoga. ‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç “‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á” (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•© ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ 3 4 Consequently, at the end of this topic as well, BhagavƒÅn ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa declared: “On realizing this, My devotee becomes eligible to attain divine love for Me” (Gƒ™TƒÄ 13.18).* ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Ø ‡•§ ‡•© ) - Elsewhere in the Gƒ´tƒÅ, Bhagavan said: ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø ‡•• ‡•®‡•¶‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ amanitvam adambhitvam ahimsa k·π£antir ƒÅrjavam ƒÅcƒÅryopƒÅsana·πÅ saucam sthairyam atma-vinigraha·∏• indriyƒÅrthe≈üu vairagyam anahankara eva ca janma-m·πõtyu-jarƒÅ-vyƒÅdhi-du·∏•kha-dosanudarsanam asaktir anabhi≈üvangah putra-dara-grhƒÅdi·π£u nityam ca sama-cittatvam istanistopapattisu mayi c√¢nanya-yogena bhaktir avyabhicƒÅri≈Üƒ´ vivikta-desa-sevitvam aratir jana-samsadi adhyatma-j√±ƒÅna-nityatvam tattva-j√±ƒÅnartha-darsanam etaj j√±ƒÅnam iti proktam aj√±ƒÅnam yad ato’nyatha mad-bhakta etad-vij√±ƒÅya mad-bhƒÅvƒÅyopapadyate 542 105 Jnana Is Ineffective without Bhakti Those who do not have faith in this dharma [of supremely confi- dential devotion intrinsically endowed with j√±ƒÅna], O scorcher of enemies, being unable to attain Me, return to the path of cyclic existence rooted in death. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.3)5 ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‚Äú‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§¶‡•É‡§¢‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§É‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Ø‡•ß‡•ß‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á- ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ In the above verse, the pronoun asya, ‚Äúthis,” qualifying the word dharma, refers to that constitutional manner of being whose characteristics are defined in the following verse of the same chapter: Such devotees of firm vows, who are always engaged in glo- rifying Me, who are perseverant in their practice, and who bow down to Me - they, being ever united with Me [through meditative absorption], worship Me with devotion. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.14) ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§ü‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ö‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ || ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó- ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• Therefore, even in the case of those whose devotion was not explicitly evident, such as the sage Mudgala, it is to be understood that they performed s√§dhana-bhakti previously. Commentary THE influence of the teachings of j√±ana-yoga is exceedingly widespread. Spiritual aspirants of all description consider it to be the ultimate teaching of the Vedas. In particular, the core ideas of Sankara Vedanta are so pervasive that they have filtered down into virtually all modern paths of spirituality, such that the majority of spiritual practitioners embrace these ideas as pre- given truths even without any formal acquaintance with Vedanta. 5 asraddadhana·∏• puru·π£a dharmasyasya parantapa aprƒÉpya mam nivartante m·πõtyu-samsƒÅra-vartmani satatam kirtayanto mam yatantas ca drdha-vratah namasyanta≈õ ca mam bhakty√§ nitya-yukta upasate 543 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya Except among Vedantic scholars, it is virtually unknown that there are at least five other major schools of Vedanta apart from Sankara Vedanta. One reason for the emphasis on j√±ƒÅna-yoga and the prevalence of Sankara Vedanta is that the Upanisads primarily speak of Brah- man. Rarely do they use words like Isvara, ParamƒÅtmƒÅ, or Bhaga- v√§n, or the personal names of Bhagavan. Thus the students of the Upanisads conclude that these scriptures propound unqualified Brahman as the highest Reality and the ultimate goal. But the truth is far from this idea, as can be understood by anyone who studies the Upanisads objectively without being predisposed to favor the impersonal interpretation. The wider view of Vedanta, which entails a synthesis of the Upanisads as a whole and which is the consensus outlook of the five Vedantic schools other than that of Sankara, is that the Absolute qualified with Its own intrinsic potencies is the most complete self- disclosure of Reality and the substratum of unqualified Brahman. This perspective accommodates distinction within unity (bheda- abheda), while upholding the core doctrine of nonduality that is so fundamental to the Vedic revelation of truth. This view is fur- ther confirmed by an impartial study of the Vedanta-sutra, which provides the essence of all the Upanisads in codified form. The same understanding is all the more self-evidently disclosed in Srimad Bhagavata, which is referred to as the divinely descended mature fruit of the wish-fulfilling tree of all the Vedas, nigama- kalpa-taror galitam phalam (SB 1.1.3). The unique status of ≈örƒ´mad Bhagavata as being the highest authority in the matter of Vedantic truth is further understood from its being described as “equal to the Vedas,” brahma-sammitam (SB 1.3.40 and SB 2.8.28), “the con- densed essence extracted from all the Vedas and Itihasas,” sarva- vedetihƒÅsƒÅnƒÅ·πÅ sƒÅram saram samuddh·πõtam (SB 1.3.42), “the ≈öruti or Veda of the supremely liberated devotees,” satvati ≈õruti·∏• (SB 1.4.7), and “the very essence of all Vedanta,” sarva-vedanta-saram hi (SB 12.13.15). 544 105 Jnana Is Ineffective without Bhakti Returning to our original point of discussion, there is an even more telling reason for the prevalence of j√±ana-yoga in the mod- ern “Me Generation,” which is dominated by rational doubt and scientific materialism. Since j√±ƒÅna-yoga doesn’t depend on belief in a personal God, it evades the question of surrender to a higher authority - a prospect that is abhorrent to the materially condi- tioned ego. The fundamental characteristic of the material ego is that it functions so as to hold in place its artificial supremacy and autonomy. As such, it is resistant to bhakti, which involves the recognition of one’s dependence on God. This egoic defiance is a symptom of ignorance, avidya or maya, which is the root of suffering. Related to this idea is the fact that the ego thrives upon chal- lenges so that it can face opposition, emerge victorious, and assert its feeling of supremacy. In bhakti, there is no such challenge for the ego to overcome. Bhakti is the path of cooperation, surrender, and love. In this respect, bhakti is very easy. One does not have to undertake severe penance or hardship, after accomplishing which, the ego is surreptitiously reinforced all the more. Consequently, bhakti does not appeal to the ego. The fact remains, however, that it is bhakti that dissolves the empirical ego altogether, allowing the authentic liberated “I”- consciousness to emerge. On all other paths that depend upon individual striving, the ego persists, at least in a subtle form. This is evident from the story of the KumƒÅras, who held to the subtle ego of being great j√±ƒÅnis, as discussed in Bhagavat Sanda- rbha (Anuccheda 79). In his famous ten verses known as Da≈õasloki, ≈örƒ´ NimbƒÅrkƒÅcƒÅrya makes the point that Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa’s mercy manifests in a person endowed with humility, as a conse- quence of which he attains unalloyed bhakti in the form of prema, k·πõpasya dainyƒÅdi-yuji prajayate yaya bhavet prema-vi≈°e·π£a-lak·π£a·πáƒÅ bhaktir hy ananya (Da≈õaslokƒ´ 9). ≈örƒ´ Caitanya Mahaprabhu there- fore firmly emphasizes the importance of humility for a sincere devotee (Sik·π£ƒÅ·π£·π≠akam 3). Because people are unable to invest their faith in bhakti, they endeavor on other paths instead, including j√±ƒÅna. In the Gita verse 545 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya cited by ≈örƒ´ Jiva, Krsna states that those who do not have faith in the dharma of supremely confidential devotion continue to remain in bondage (Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.3). In this regard, it may be objected that there are many examples of people who attained mukti without any appar- ent involvement in bhakti. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va replies that in such cases, it is to be understood that they must have executed bhakti in their past life but were somehow compelled to take another birth due to an offense or some misgiving. When the reaction to the offense comes to an end, they are transported to the abode of Bhagavan. As an example of this, ≈örƒ´ Jiva refers to the story of the sage Mudgala, found in the Mahabharata, Vana-parva, chapters 260-261. Although Mudgala was a highly religious man, it is not explicitly mentioned that he was engaged in direct bhakti. Yet, when the time of his death arrived, he rejected the offer to go to heaven or even to the topmost planet of Brahma but chose instead to go to Vaikun- tha, the abode of Bhagavan, which is attained only by bhakti. Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´ therefore concludes that he must have performed bhakti in the past to have attained such perfection. The same should be understood for others like him. In this manner, ≈örƒ´ Jiva has shown that the paths of karma, yoga, and j√±ƒÅna are impotent without bhakti, and that bhakti is therefore the only true abhidheya. In this regard, it should be understood that bhakti can be performed in three different attitudes, namely, pure or unmixed (kevala-bhakti), predominant (pradhana-bhakti), or secondary (gu·πáƒ´bh≈´ta-bhakti). Kevala-bhakti is the most power- ful of all, because it results in divine love (prema) for Bhagavan. In pradhana-bhakti, although bhakti is predominant, it is mixed with some other influence, such as karma, j√±ƒÅna, or yoga, and its result is primarily mukti. If, however, a devotee who is engaged in this cate- gory of devotion obtains the association of a pure devotee, then he too may be promoted to the level of kevala-bhakti. When bhakti is undertaken as secondary to karma, j√±ƒÅna, or yoga, it bestows only the result that is specific to those respective paths. This type of enactment is not really bhakti in the legitimate sense but karma, j√±ƒÅna, or yoga mixed with bhakti. So truly speaking, bhakti is only of two types, kevala and pradhana. Of these, it is kevala-bhakti 546 105 J√±ƒÅna Is Ineffective without Bhakti alone that is the abhidheya. This pure unadulterated bhakti, along with its two major divisions known as vaidhi and rƒÅgƒÅnugƒÅ, will be examined in great detail from Anuccheda 234 onward. In the next anuccheda, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va reasons that just as there is no need to resort to any path other than bhakti, so too there is no need to seek the shelter of any deva other than Bhagavan. 547 Bhakti Is for Bhagavan Alone Anucchedas 106-107 Anuccheda 106 Respect All, but Worship Only BhagavƒÅn 106.1 Bhagavan Alone Is Worthy of Shelter ‡•ß‡•¶‡•¨ ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§π ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•¨‡•§‡•Ø‡•§‡•®‡•® ) - THE DEVAS stress the necessity of bhakti to Bhagavan by express- ing disregard for independently taking shelter of any other entity: 1 ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç || ‡•®‡•¶‡•Æ || That person who takes shelter of someone other than Him [Bha- gavan] - for whom there is nothing that could be the cause of His astonishment (avismitam), whose will is utterly fulfilled by virtue of the self-actualizing power that is intrinsic to His own being (svenaiva l√§bhena parip≈´r·πáa-kƒÅmam), who is established in perfect equanimity (samam), and whose consciousness is unerringly stable (pra≈õƒÅntam ) ‚Äì is surely as foolish as some- one who wishes to cross the ocean by holding the tail of a dog. (SB 6.9.22 ) 1

‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂ ‡§à‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ avismitam tam paripurna-kamam svenaiva labhena samam pra≈°antam vinopasarpaty aparam hi balisa·∏• ≈õva-l√§ngulen√§tititarti sindhum 551I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya The word avismitam, lit., “unastonished,” signifies that because of the nonexistence (asad-bhava) of any other object or entity (vastu) that is “without precedent” (apurva) in relation to Bha- gavƒÅn, He is therefore devoid of the possibility of astonishment (vismaya-rahitam)? Alternatively, if the word smitam is taken to mean “a smile,” then a-vi-smitam would mean that, “Bhaga- van is never without a smile.” Consequently, He is that entity whose will is utterly fulfilled (paripur·πáa-kƒÅmam) by virtue of the self-actualizing power that is intrinsic to His own being (svenaiva l√§bhena, i.e., svƒ´yenaiva kriyƒÅbh≈´tena), and not due to anyone else’s efforts. As a result, He is “perfectly equipoised” (samam) in regard to all possible circumstances (sarvatra). It therefore follows that He is “of unerringly stable conscious- ness” (pra≈õƒÅntam), meaning that His consciousness (citta) is absolutely free from all misgivings (dosa-rahitam). The word bali≈õa·∏•, “foolish,” means “one whose disposition is disagreeable to Isa” (i≈õasya apriyah). Although the verse uses the verb atitita- rti, which literally means, “he crosses over,” the actual meaning is “he wishes to cross. “3 ‡§§‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç " ‡§∞‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•®‡•≠) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ Accordingly, it is said [in reference to those who take shelter of anyone other than Bhagavan]: 2 In the fields of Indian philosophy and aesthetics, astonishment (vismaya, or more technically, camatkara) is defined as an internal state of being that is brought about through the sudden contact with something never previously experienced (apurvatƒÅ). According to this theory, without the inducement of an unprecedented event, astonishment is an impossibility. Since there is nothing unprecedented (apurva) in relation to Bhagavan - meaning that there is nothing that could precede His experience and cognition either temporally or in terms of the order of being - He is therefore devoid of the possibility of astonishment (avismitam). All of this is to say that “astonishment” (vismaya) is the effect, whereas “unprecedentedness” (apurvata) is its cause. In his gloss, ≈örƒ´ Jiva is explaining that because Bhagavan is devoid of the cause of astonishment ‚Äî namely, apurvatƒÉ - He is therefore devoid of astonishment (avismitam). 3 The correct form of the verb would be atititirsati. Since it is impossible for anyone to cross the ocean by holding the tail of a dog, the use of the present tense here is understood as figurative and not literal. 552 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan Those whose natures are of the qualitative essence of rajas and tamas and whose character is thus accordant [with those whom they regard] worship only the forefathers, the spirit entities, the progenitors, and so on, being covetous of wealth, power, and progeny. (SB 1.2.27 ) 4 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á ‡§ö- There is a similar reference in the Skanda Purana, in a dialogue between ≈öri Brahma and Sri Narada: ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ö‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•¶‡•Ø ‡•• One who discards Bhagavan Vasudeva and worships some other deva instead is indeed comparable to a person who abandons his own mother and venerates an outcaste woman who cooks dog meat. (Skanda PurƒÅna ) s ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö - Elsewhere in the same Purana, it is said: ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡§≤‡§æ‡§π‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç || ‡•®‡•ß‡•¶ || One who discards Bhagavan Vasudeva and worships some other deva instead is deranged, like a person who rejects immortal nectar and drinks the deadly halahala poison. (Skanda PurƒÅ·πáa) ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á - In the Mahabharata it is said: 4 5 6 ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ò‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡•®‡•ß‡•ß ‡•• rajas-tamah-prak·πõtaya·∏• sama-sila bhajanti vai pitr-bhuta-prajesadtn sriyai≈õvarya-prajepsavah vasudevam parityajya yonya-devam upƒÅsate sva-mataram parityajya sva-pacƒ´m vandate hi sah vasudevam parityajya yo’nya-devam upƒÉsate tyaktv√§m·πõtam sa mudhatma bhunkte halƒÅhalam visam 553 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya One who out of delusion gives up Bhagavan Vi·π£≈Üu and worships some other entity is comparable to a person who forsakes a stock of gold to acquire a heap of dust. (Mahabharata)’ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•á‡§® ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•Æ‡•§‡•®‡•™ ‡•§ ‡•™‡•Ø ) - Therefore, ≈öri Satyavrata said: ‡§® ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§® ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡•• ‡•®‡•ß‡•® ‡•• I take shelter of You, the Supreme Immanent Regulator (I≈õvara), even a fraction of one ten-thousandth’s part of whose divine grace, all other devas, spiritual preceptors, and people in general, are unable to extend, whether they strive to do so individually or collectively. (SB 8.24.49) Commentary

ONCE BHAKTI alone has been established as the true abhidheya, the question naturally arises as to whom such bhakti is meant to be directed. This is a highly controversial subject within Indian culture and religion. People of widely diverse religious denom- inations uphold many different deities as worshipable. Promi- nent among them are Visnu and His numerous avataras, Siva, Hanuman, Ga·πáe≈õa, Durga in her various manifestations such as KƒÅli - Kartikeya, Sarasvati, Hari-hara-putra or SvƒÅmi Ayappa, the Navagrahas, and the Sun. Besides these, there are numerous minor deities, such as Manasa Devƒ´, ≈†ƒ´talƒÅ MƒÅtƒÅ, KhƒÅtu ≈öyƒÅma, vil- lage deities, family deities, the forefathers (pitr-devas), rivers such as the Ganga, Gayatri, ghosts (bh≈´tas), snakes (nagas), forest spirits (yaksas), and so on. B Why do people worship different deities? This question was answered earlier by Suta GosvƒÅmi (SB 1.2.27, Anuccheda 20), and his yas tu visnum parityajya mohad anyam upasate sa hema-rƒÅsim uts·πõjya pam≈õu-rƒÅsim jighrk·π£ati na yat-prasadayuta-bhaga-lesam anye ca deva guravo jana·∏• svayam kartum sameta·∏• prabhavanti pumsas tam isvaram tvƒÅm saranam prapadye 554 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan reply is cited here again by ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´. Those whose discrim- ination is not refined and illuminated through the study of scrip- ture from an authentic guru are attracted to deities that accord with their own nature. Or it may simply be the case that people worship a particular deity because of social convention or long- standing local tradition. In the past, some illustrious person ini- tiated the worship of a particular deity, and after him the trend is continued. In S≈´ta GosvƒÅmi’s teachings to the sages of Naimi·π£ƒÅ- ranya, however, he points out that the true benefits for humanity ensue from the worship of Visnu alone, because He is the direct embodiment of unalloyed being (visuddha-sattva, SB 1.2.23). There- fore, on the authority of scripture, ≈örƒ´ Jiva Prabhu shows that it is only Bhagavan who is the intended object of bhakti or worship. The original form of Bhagavan is ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa. He has innumerable manifestations, or avataras, such as Rama, Narasimha, Visnu, and NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa. Other supernal entities, such as ≈†iva, Ga·πáe≈õa, DurgƒÅ, and the Sun are called devas, or gods. They are all very power- ful beings and devotees of Visnu. They are entrusted with spe- cific responsibilities in regard to the management of universal affairs and are endowed with corresponding powers to perform their duties. None of them, however, are independently powerful. Visnu or Krsna is the source of their power; hence, whatever boons they are able to grant can also be bestowed directly by Him. On this basis, it was asserted earlier that a devotee can obtain any blessing that may be desired through bhakti to Krsna. Furthermore, the devas can award only material boons. They do not have the power to grant liberation or immediate apprehension of the Absolute. In the principal verse of this anuccheda (SB 6.9.22), they themselves declare that anyone seeking life’s ultimate goal who takes shelter of the devas, disregarding Bhagavan, is like a per- son who attempts to cross the ocean by catching hold of the tail of a dog. Such a foolish person is bound to drown. In India, there is a popular notion that the devas respond quickly to prayers. This is a misconception. The devas have no power to offer boons inde- pendent of Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa. Even the boons they award ultimately proceed from Him alone, labhate ca tata·∏• kƒÅmƒÅn mayaiva vihitan hi 555 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya tƒÅn (Gƒ™TƒÄ 7.22). Moreover, what the devas can offer is inconsequen- tial in comparison with Sri K·πõ·π£·πáa’s all-exceeding divine grace. This is the sense of Satyavrata’s prayer (SB 8.24.49) cited here. There is another unforeseen advantage of worshiping K·πõ·π£·πáa. K·πõ·π£·πáa may not grant the wishes of a devotee if He recognizes that the desired boon will be detrimental to the devotee’s ultimate well- being. The devas, on the other hand, do not take into considera- tion what sort of impact the boons they offer will have on the wor- shiper. Sometimes they can even endanger themselves by grant- ing devastating powers to those with ill intent, as occurred in the case of ≈öiva. He consented to award a boon to BakƒÅsura that if the latter placed his hand on someone’s head that person would imme- diately drop dead. As soon as the cunning Bakasura secured the boon, he attempted to test it on ≈öiva himself, much to the god’s consternation. On the basis of all this reasoning, scripture recommends the worship of K·πõ·π£·πáa alone. K·πõ·π£·πáa Himself also expressed this conclusion to Arjuna: Hear again My supreme instruction, the foremost of all secrets. Because you are extremely dear to Me, I shall disclose this bene- ficial teaching to you. Fix your mind on Me, become My devotee, worship Me, and bow down to Me. By doing so, you will come to Me. I promise this to you truly, because you are dear to Me. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 18.64-65)9 This is a perfectly unambiguous and explicit instruction given by Bhagavan Himself. Thus, there should be no doubt about it. 556 sarva-guhyatamam bh≈´yah ≈õrnu me paramam vaca·∏• isto’si me drdham iti tato vaksyƒÅmi te hitam man-mana bhava mad-bhakto mad-yaji mƒÅm namaskuru mƒÅm evaisyasi satyam te pratij√±ƒÅne priyo’si me 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan 106.2 The Devas Can Be Worshiped As Vaisnavas ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§≠‡§ú‡•á‡§§ ‚Äú‡§∏ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•®/‡•Ø/‡•´) “‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§É” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•ß‡•©‡•§‡•ß‡•¨) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ Even ≈öri BrahmƒÅ and ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva are to be worshiped exclusively as Vai·π£·πáavas, as confirmed in the following two statements: While seated on his lotus pedestal, Brahma, the first of the gods (ƒÅdi-deva·∏•) and the supreme preceptor of the world (jagatƒÅm paro guruh), reflected with the intent to bring forth the creation. Yet, in this regard, he was unable to arrive at a consistent vision of the process by which the world’s unfolding could take place. (SB 2.9.5)10 And: “As ≈öiva is supreme among the Vai·π£·πáavas” (SB 12.13.16).11 ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•©‡•™ ) - Therefore, in the Twelfth Canto, ≈örƒ´ MƒÅrka·πá·∏çeya spoke the following words to ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva: 10 11 ‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§£‡•á‡§Ω‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø || ‡•®‡•ß‡•© ‡•• I do, however, request one boon from you, who are complete in yourself and who shower benedictions upon your devotees - that I may have unfailing devotion unto Bhagavan Hari, unto those who are exclusively devoted to Him, and unto you as well. (SB 12.10.34)12 sa adi-devo jagatƒÅm paro guruh svadhi≈ünyam asthaya sis·πõk·π£ayaik·π£ata tam nadhyagacchad d·πõ≈õam atra sammatƒÅm prapanca-nirmana-vidhir yaya bhavet Here, ≈örƒ´dhara Svami glosses the words paro guruh, “the supreme preceptor,” referring to Brahma, as bhakti-rahasyopade·π£·π≠a, “the teacher of the mystery of devotion.” From this and the fact that Brahma, being subordinate to Bhagavan, desired to bring forth the creation in service to Him, it is evident that he is to be venerated not as an independent god but as a great Vaisnava. vai·π£·πáavƒÅnƒÅ·πÅ yatha sambhu·∏• 12 varam ekam v·πõ·πáe’thapi p≈´rnƒÅt kƒÅmabhivar·π£a·πáƒÅt bhagavaty acyutƒÅm bhaktim tat-pare≈üu tatha tvayi 557 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•å ‚Äú‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø- ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•Æ‡•§‡•≠‡•§‡•©‡•©) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The words tathƒÅ tvayi, ‚Äú and unto you as well,‚Äù should be under- stood to mean, “and unto you, who are also exclusively devoted to Him (tat-para). ‚Äù Thus, in the Eighth Canto, Prajapati offered this eulogy to ≈öiva: “Your feet are meditated upon within the heart by the gurus of those who delight in the self alone (ƒÅtmƒÅ- rƒÅmas), and you wander about engaged in severe penances along with Uma” (SB 8.7.33).13 ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡§ø “‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•á‡§®” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•™ ‡•§ ‡•©‡•¶ ‡•§‡•©‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ In the Fourth Canto, the Pracetas also referred to ≈öiva in a similar manner while speaking to the eight-handed form of BhagavƒÅn: O Bhagavan, by a moment’s association with Your dear friend ≈öiva, we have directly attained You as our ultimate destination and as the topmost physician for treating the virtually incur- able disease of repeated birth and death in material existence. (SB 4.30.38)14 ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§® ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á-

Siva is a Vaisnava. Those, however, who regard him as abso- lutely equal to Vis≈Üu, cannot obtain bhakti; rather, such an attitude is offensive, as stated in Vaisnava Tantra: 13 14 ‡§® ‡§≤‡§≠‡•á‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§°‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡§É || ‡•®‡•ß‡•™ || ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§ ‡§∏ ‡§™‡§æ‡§∑‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•ß‡•´ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ye tv ƒÅtma-rama-gurubhir hrdi cintit√§nghri- dvandvam carantam umaya tapasƒÅbhitaptam vayam tu sƒÅk·π£ad bhagavan bhavasya priyasya sakhyuh k·π£ana-sangamena sudu≈õcikitsyasya bhavasya m·πõtyor bhi·π£aktama·πÅ tvadya gatim gata·∏• sma 558 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan Those bereft of all sense, who equate ≈öiva with Vi·π£·πáu, cannot obtain unalloyed devotion to Bhagavan Hari, even if they wor- ship Him with one-pointed attention. One who regards the devas, such as Brahma and ≈öiva, as equal to Bhagavan NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa certainly becomes a heretic. (Vaisnava Tantra)15 ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•®‡•¶-‡•®‡•® ) - Therefore, scriptural statements that advocate the vision of non- difference (abheda-drsti) [between Vi·π£·πáu and ≈öiva or Brahma] are meant specifically for devotees who are established in the vision of equality (sama-bhaktas, i.e., santa-bhaktas), or those whose bhakti is predominated by j√±ƒÅna, as referred to in this statement of ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva from the story of ≈örƒ´ MƒÅrka·πá·∏çeya in the Twelfth Canto: 15 16 ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•ß‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§∏‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•ß‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§® ‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§ú‡•á ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø ‡•• ‡•®‡•ß‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The guardians of the planets along with their residents, and even I [≈öiva], the venerable BrahmƒÅ, and ≈örƒ´ Hari, who is directly God Himself (Svayam Isvara), all venerate, worship, and wait upon those brahmanas who are saintly, tranquil, detached, affectionate toward all beings, one-pointedly devoted to us, free from animosity, and established in the vision of equality (sama-darsinah). Those brƒÅhma·πáas do not perceive even an iota of difference between me, Bhagavan Acyuta [≈örƒ´ Hari], and the birthless Brahma, nor indeed between themselves and other living beings. Consequently, we honor brƒÅhma·πáas like you. (SB 12.10.20-22)16 na labheyuh punar-bhaktim harer aikƒÅntikim jadah ekƒÅgra-manasas capi vis≈Üu-samanya-darsina·∏• yas tu nƒÅrƒÅyanam devam brahma-rudradi-daivataih samatvenaiva vik·π£eta sa pƒÅ·π£andi bhaved-dhruvan brahmanah sadhava·∏• s√§nt√§ ni·∏•sargƒÅ bh≈´ta-vatsala·∏• ‚Üí 559 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ú‡•á‡§Æ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø- 2f: 1 The word tad [in the third verse of this group] stands for the pronoun tato’pi, meaning, “even more than them.””” When tad is taken in this sense, the meaning of the final quarter of the verse is as follows: “We honor you, MƒÅrka·πá·∏çeya and other pure Vai·π£·πáavas, even more than them” [i.e., “even more than the brƒÅhma·πáas who are established in the vision of nondifference”]. ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•™‡•§‡•®‡•™‡•§‡•©‡•¶ ) - As ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva himself informed the Pracetas: ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§• ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•ß‡•Ø ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Therefore, great devotees (bhƒÅgavatas) like you are just as dear to me as Bhagavan Himself. And for the devotees as well, there is never anyone dearer than me. (SB 4.24.30)18 ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö “‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡§∞‡•å ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•Æ‡•§‡•≠‡•§‡•™‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ Elsewhere ≈öiva said: “When Bhagavan Hari is pleased, I also become pleased along with all mobile and stationary beings” (SB 8.7.40).19 ekanta-bhakta asmƒÅsu nirvairƒÅ·∏• sama-darsina·∏• sa-lokƒÅ loka-p√§l√§s t√§n vandanty arcanty upƒÉsate aham ca bhagavan brahma svayam ca harir isvarah na te mayy acyute’je ca bhidam anv api cak·π£ate nƒÅtmana≈õ ca parasyƒÅpi tad yusman vayam imahi “The word tad, appearing in the final quarter of SB 12.10.22, can be interpreted either as an adverb of reason, conveying the sense of “consequently,” or as a pronoun, standing for “them,” i.e., “the brahmanas who are established in the vision of nondifference.” The former interpretation, as given by ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi, is the standard way of rendering the word tad in the final quarter of the verse. Sri Jiva, however, brings out a unique meaning by interpreting tad as a pronoun in the ablative case taking the form of tatas, meaning, “[even more] than them.” 15 atha bhagavata yuyam priya·∏• stha bhagavan yathƒÅ 19 na mad-bhƒÅgavatƒÅnƒÅ·πÅ ca preyƒÅn anyo’sti karhicit prite harau bhagavati priye’ham sacarƒÅcara·∏• 560 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•® ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡•¨) – And just prior to the group of three verses from the Twelfth Canto quoted above, M√§rkandeya was described as a pure (suddha) Vaisnava: ‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§ ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á‡§Ω‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•á ‡•• ‡•®‡•®‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ This brƒÅhma·πáa sage [M√§rkandeya] certainly does not desire any benedictions even up to the point of liberation, because he has attained paramount devotion to Bhagavan, the imperishable Supreme Being. (SB 12.10.6)20 ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§ö ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ " ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§É ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•® ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•©) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva made this statement in reference to the sage MƒÅrka·πá- deya. Additionally, [the fact that M√§rkandeya was a suddha Vaisnava and not a sama-bhakta, here meaning that he recog- nized a distinction between ≈öiva and Bhagavan Hari] is verily indicated by the fact that M√§rkandeya’s state of transcogni- tive absorption (samadhi) on Bhagavan Hari was broken when ≈öiva suddenly appeared within his consciousness (cetas),21 as attested to by Marka·πá·∏çeya himself in the following words: “The sage, whose samadhi had been broken, thought to himself, ‘Who is this? And from where has he come?” (SB 12.10.13)22 20 naivecchaty asi·π£a·∏• kvapi brahmar·π£ir mok·π£am apy uta 21 bhaktim parƒÅ·πÅ bhagavati labdhavan puru≈üe’vyaye M√§rkandeya was absorbed in samadhi on Bhagavan Hari. If Hari and Siva were one in all respects, Siva’s appearing in the place of Hari in Markandeya’s samadhi would not have broken his trance. The fact that M√§rkandeya recognized such a distinction is further evidence of his being a suddha Vai·π£·πáava meaning one exclusively devoted to Bhagavan Hari - and not a sama-bhakta, or one whose devotion is depersonalized and hence diluted by the attitude of indiscriminate equality. This is what ≈örƒ´ Jiva is pointing out here. 22 kim idam kuta eveti samƒÅdher virato munih 561I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö “‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•® ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•®‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‚Äú‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä- ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•ß‡•¶‡•§‡•®‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç “‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•®‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ Moreover, although in ≈örimad Bhagavata (12.10.20, quoted above), there is a reference to the [brahmanas’] vision of non- difference (abheda-drsti) [by describing them as sama-dar≈õina·∏•, or “established in the vision of equality”], the supremacy of ≈örƒ´ Hari alone is expressed in the very next verse (SB 12.10.21) in the words svayam ca harir isvara·∏•, “and even ≈örƒ´ Hari, who is directly God Himself (Svayam Isvara).” That Bhagavan Hari alone is Svayam Isvara is implied in the following statement: Just as smoke is superior to firewood, which is a product of the earth, and as fire, which is intimately connected with the rit- ual acts of the three Vedas, is superior to smoke, so too, the universal qualitative principle of dynamism (rajas) is superior to stasis (tamas), yet superior even to dynamism is luminosity (sattva), because it conduces to the immediate realization of the Absolute. (SB 1.2.24)23 ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ- In the Brahma PurƒÅ·πáa, ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva also makes a similar statement: 23 24 ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§§ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•®‡•ß ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The omnipotent Bhagavan Vasudeva is certainly to be seen by anyone who aspires to see me or Brahma, the grandsire of all beings. (Brahma Purana 226.46)24 parthivad daruno dhumas tasmad agnis trayƒ´maya·∏• tamasas tu rajas tasmat sattvam yad brahma-dar≈õanam ≈öri Jiva’s point in quoting this verse here is that because ≈örƒ´ Vis≈Üu is the direct embodiment of pure sattva, He is Bhagavan Himself (Svayam Isvara), whereas Brahma and Siva, who predominate over the gunas of rajas and tamas respectively, are somewhat removed from the status of direct Godhood (svayam-isvaratvam). yo hi mƒÅm drastum iccheta brahmanam vƒÅ pitamaham drastavyas tena bhagavan vasudeva·∏• pratƒÅpavƒÅn 562 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•å‡§Æ‡•à‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É- The import is that by the immediate realization of Him, every- thing else becomes directly known. Therefore, Sarvabhauma ≈örƒ´ Cintamani Dik·π£ita also said: ‡§µ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§ô‡•ç ‡§® ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§® ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Å‡§∞‡•á ‡•• ‡•®‡•®‡•® ‡•• ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ü‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§°‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∂‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡•á‡§ò‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡•• ‡•®‡•®‡•© ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ My heart is not captivated in the same manner on seeing ≈öiva decorated with a garland of skulls as it is on beholding K·πõ·π£·πáa, who sports a garland of forest flowers. A peacock does not expe- rience the same delight on seeing a bank of white clouds as it does on glimpsing a mass of dark clouds. The goddesses are like rivers, the gods like ponds, and Visvesvara ≈öiva is like the ocean, the husband of the rivers. But for Cintamani Dik·π£ita, who is like the cataka bird that lives by the pure water falling from the clouds, nothing can quench his thirst other than the monsoon cloud known as Bhagavan Sri Krsna.25 ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ Thus, it is rightly concluded that ≈öiva should be worshiped only as a Vai·π£·πáava. Commentary Since it has been established that bhakti is meant to be directed exclusively toward Bhagavan, it may then be asked how a devotee of Visnu or Krsna should regard devas, such as ≈öiva. There are some Vai·π£·πáavas who will not even enter a temple of Siva. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va rec- ommends, however, that the devas should be respected as devotees 25 vana-malini yƒÅd·πõ≈õasayo mama tad·πõni na kapƒÅla-malini asite mudire yatha sikhi mudam abhyeti tatha na pandure devyas ta·π≠inyas tri-dasƒÅs tadagƒÅ visvesvaro’yam saritam adhi≈õa·∏• trsna-harah ko’pi na krsna-megham vihaya cintamani-cƒÅtakasya 563 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya of Vis≈Üu. They should never be disrespected; otherwise, one will become implicated in an offense. ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva in particular occupies a place of unique prominence among the devas. This was stated by S≈´ta GosvƒÅmi (SB 12.13.16) and the Pracetas (SB 4.30.38), as cited here. The same intention was also expressed by ≈örƒ´ M√§rkandeya (in SB 12.10.34), when he prayed to ≈öiva that he may be blessed with undeviating devotion unto Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ Krsna, unto the Vaisnavas who are exclusively devoted to Him, and unto ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva as well. If MƒÅrka·πá·∏çeya had thought of ≈öiva as identical to Bhagavan, there would have been no sense in making a separate request for devo- tion to ≈öiva, since this would imply a difference between the two. This clearly indicates that he considered Siva to be a Vaisnava and not Bhagavan Himself. Even though by the entreaty for devotion to the Vaisnavas, devotion to ≈öiva would thus be included, Markan- deya still made a separate request to show special respect to ≈öiva, who was standing right in front of him, and to convey to others that ≈öiva is particularly distinguished among the Vaisnavas. In this context, the following question may be raised: It is learned from scripture that bhakti is to be directed to Bhagavan Vi·π£·πáu alone, so why then did M√§rkandeya pray for devotion to the Vai·π£·πáavas? The answer is that the Vaisnavas are as worshipable as Visnu Himself. ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva personally informed his wife of this confidential truth: O Devi, among all varieties of worship of different deities, the wor- ship of Visnu is supreme. Superior even to that, however, is the worship of His devotees. (Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda 253.176)26 The English saying, “Love me, love my dog,” is relevant in this regard. Bhagavan dearly loves His devotees, and thus respect shown to them is especially pleasing to Him. But they are not to be worshiped independently. The devas may also be worshiped as Vai·π£·πáavas but not directly as Bhagavan. To do so would please nei- ther Bhagavan nor the devas, since the latter are naturally endowed 26 √§rƒÅdhanƒÅnƒÅm sarve·π£ƒÅm vi≈ünor √§r√§dhanam param tasmat parataram devi tadiyƒÅnƒÅ·πÅ samarcanam 564 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan with the mood of servitorship to Bhagavan. Taking this into consid- eration, ≈örƒ´ Jiva comments that to worship Siva as the Supreme God will not award bhakti to the practitioner but will instead amount to an offense that will block his progress on the path. The devotee who worships ≈öiva independently is called a Saiva and is different from a Vaisnava. A further doubt may be raised in regard to the above discus- sion. There are statements in the sastra that suggest that there is no difference between Visnu and ≈öiva, and that anyone who regards them as different is implicated in an offense. For example, ≈öiva tells M√§rkandeya, “The brƒÅhma·πáas who are established in the vision of equality (sama-darsinah) do not perceive even an iota of difference between me, Bhagavan Vi·π£·πáu, and Brahma” (SB 12.10.22). ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi points out that such statements are meant specifically for devotees who cherish the vision of equality toward all beings, sama-bhaktas or sama-darsƒ´s. The fact that the above statement was made in express reference to devotees of this dispo- sition is clear from the verses preceding this one, which are cited along with it in the anuccheda (i.e., SB 12.10.20-21). The import of such statements is that ≈öiva, or any other deva, is not independent of Vi·π£·πáu. Alternatively, the oneness that exists between Vis≈Üu and ≈öiva is understood to be out of love. Otherwise, if Siva is accepted as equal to Vis≈Üu, then the other verses that describe ≈öiva as a Vaisnava would need to be reconciled in some other manner. If there were no difference whatsoever between Siva and Visnu, then M√§rkandeya’s meditation would not have been interrupted when ≈öiva entered his heart. When M√§rkandeya was meditat- ing on Bhagavan Visnu, ≈öiva appeared in his heart just to bless him. When, however, M√§rkandeya’s internal vision of Visnu was suddenly lost, he became perturbed and his meditation broke (SB 12.10.13). In this connection, ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva personally referred to Vis≈Üu as “God Himself” (Svayam Isvara, SB 12.10.21); so the conclu- sion is that ≈öiva should be worshiped as a great Vaisnava and not as the Supreme God. ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmi refers to SB 1.2.24 to illustrate Vis≈Üu’s suprem- acy over Brahma and ≈öiva. This verse was discussed in Anuccheda 18. 565 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya The sense of this verse is that just as fire is superior to smoke and wood, so too sattva is superior to rajas and tamas. By extension of meaning, Vis≈Üu, who oversees the qualitative state of sattva, is superior to Brahma and ≈öiva, who oversee the qualitative states of rajas and tamas, respectively. 106.3 The Devas Can Be Worshiped As Existential Seats of Visnu ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§- ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§É- Some Vaisnavas, however, on being faced with an emergency sit- uation in which the worship of ≈öiva is unavoidable, will then worship ≈örƒ´ Bhagavan alone as present within His existential seat (adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅna) in the form of the deity of ≈öiva. In this regard, we may refer to the following historical anecdote found in the concluding portion of the Vi≈ünu-dharmottara PurƒÅ·πáa: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§ï ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§â‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§• ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö ‚Äú‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡§ø ?‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö “‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§Ø” ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•§ “There was a brƒÅhma·πáa named Visvaksena, who was exclusively devoted to Bhagavan and who traveled throughout the land. Once, he was sitting alone in a secluded forest. Soon after, the son of the village chief of that place came there and asked the brƒÅhma·πáa, ‘Who are you?’ The brƒÅhma·πáa introduced himself, after which the son of the chieftain again spoke, ‘Today, I have a headache, and I am unable to worship my deity, ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva. So kindly worship him on my behalf.”” ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç- After this, the following one and a half verses are cited from the above PurƒÅ≈Üa: 566 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•®‡•™ ‡•• ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§•‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•®‡•´ ‡•• Hearing this request, the brƒÅhmana replied, ‚ÄúYoung man, we are known to be unalloyed devotees of Bhagavan. For us, only Bhagavan Hari, who manifests in the four forms of Vasudeva, Sankarsana, Pradyumna and Aniruddha, or in the forms of His avatƒÅras, is worshipable, and we worship no one else. Therefore, be on your way without delay.” (Visnu-dharmottara PurƒÅna 3.354.12-13 ) 27 ‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§ñ‡§°‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß- ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡§≠‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç " ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É” ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ “When the brƒÅhma·πáa thus refused his proposal, the son of the village chief raised his sword to behead the brahmana.
