The brƒÅhma·πáa was stunned by this threat, and not willing to meet with death at the hand of the boy, he deliberated and said, ‘Very well, I shall go and perform the worship. ’ I ‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç " ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä- ‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§¶‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§≠‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§µ ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§≠‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø " ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ | “While on his way to the temple, he reflected as follows, ‘Being instrumental in the dissolution of the cosmos, Rudra is respon- sible for increasing darkness (tamas), and thus he embodies the qualitative state of tamas. On the other hand, Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ Nrsimhadeva is the dispeller of tamas, because He tears apart the tƒÅmasika demons. On this account, I pray that He may mani- fest there to destroy the darkness of ignorance, just as the sun dispels darkness. Therefore, I will worship only Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ Nrsimhadeva even in this deity of Rudra so that He may destroy the ignorance of these worshipers of ≈öiva.’ 27 etad ukta·∏• praty uvƒÅca vayam ekantina·∏• ≈õrutƒÅ·∏• caturatma hari·∏• pujya·∏• pradurbhava-gato’thava pujayƒÅma≈õ ca naivƒÅnya tasmat tvam gaccha mƒÅciram 567 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§Ö‡§•‚Äú‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡•å ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§ñ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•ã‡§ü‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ò‡§æ‡§® ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•ã‡§ü‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúAs the brƒÅhmana uttered the mantra, ‘Obeisance to ≈örƒ´ Nrsimha- deva,’ holding flowers in his cupped palms, the son of the chief- tain became enraged and again lifted his sword. Just then, Bha- gavan Nrsimhadeva suddenly appeared in person, bursting out from that very ≈öiva-linga, and killed the son of the village chief along with his retinue. In South India, Bhagavan Nrsimha is personally situated in a deity form, which is celebrated by the name Linga-spho»õa, ‘He who appeared by bursting forth from the cylindrical (linga) form of ≈öiva.”” [Here ends the anecdote.] ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Therefore, unalloyed devotees regard even ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva as a Vai·π£·πáava. ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•á- Alternatively, some devotees may at times regard ≈öiva as the existential seat (adhisthƒÅna) of BhagavƒÅn Vispu. Therefore, it is stated in the Adi varƒÅha PurƒÅna: ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡•®‡•®‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ After conscientiously worshiping ≈öiva for thousands of life- times, a person of awakened discernment becomes a Vaisnava, when all of his sins have been dissolved. (Adi-varƒÅha Purana) 28 ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•å ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§∂‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á- ‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§â‡§™‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§∂‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§∂‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∏‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§•‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∏‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§∂‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù (‡§®‡•É‡•¶ ‡§§‡§æ‡•¶‡•´/‡•ß‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ 28 janm√§ntara-sahasre≈üu samaradhya v·πõ·π£a-dhvajam vaisnavatvam labhed dhimƒÅn sarva-pƒÅpa-ksaye sati 568 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan So there is indeed a vast difference between the devotees of Bhagavan Nrsimhadeva and those of ≈öiva. In this regard, the following statement is made in the ≈öri Nrsimha-tapani ≈öruti: One brahmacƒÅri who has undergone the sacred thread cere- mony is equal to a hundred of those who have not done so. One householder (grhastha) is equal to a hundred brahmacƒÅrƒ´s who have undergone the sacred thread ceremony. One vanaprastha is equal to a hundred householders. One sannyasi is equal to a hundred vƒÉnaprasthas. One person who chants the Rudra- mantra is equal to a hundred sannyƒÅsƒ´s. One teacher of the Atha- rv√§ngƒ´rasa branch of the Vedas is equal to a hundred chanters of the Rudra-mantra. And one teacher of the king of mantras is equal to a hundred such teachers of the AtharvƒÅngƒ´rasa Vedic branch. (Nrsimha-tapani ≈öruti, Purva 5.10)29 ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡•É‡§ó‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§™‡•ã ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•™‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•®‡•≠-‡•®‡•Æ) - ‚Äî What is referred to in this verse as mantra-r√§ja, or “the king of mantras,” is the Sri Nrsimha-mantra. If, however, one worships ≈öiva independently as Bhagavan, he cannot surmount the influ- ence of Bhrgu Muni’s curse, which is described in the Fourth Canto: 29 ‡§µ‡•à ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•à ‡•§ ‡§≠‡•É‡§ó‡•Å‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•®‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§≠‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§∑‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•®‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ [Hearing the curse that Nandi invoked upon the brƒÅhma·πáas,] Bhrgu pronounced the following insurmountable curse in retal- iation, as a form of brahminical punishment: “Those who take anupanita satam ekam ekenopanitena tat-samam. upanita-satam ekam ekena grhasthena tat-samam. grhastha-satam ekam ekena vƒÅnaprasthena tat-samam. v√§naprastha-satam ekam ekena yatina tat-samam. yatinan tu satam p≈´r·πáam ekena rudra-j√§pakena tat-samam. rudra-jƒÅpaka-satam ekam ekenatharv√§rgƒ´rasa-sikhadhyapakena tat-samam. atharv√§ngirasa-sikhadhyapaka-satam ekam ekena mantra-r√§j√§dhyƒÅpakena tat-samam. 569 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya a vow to worship ≈öiva as well as those who follow them shall become heretics and antagonistic to the principles of authentic scripture.” (SB 4.2.27-28)30 ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§∑‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡§æ‡§∑‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ- ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•™‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•©‡•ß) - In this verse, “the vow to worship ≈öiva” (bhava-vrata) refers only to those vows that are prescribed in the Vedas. Otherwise, if the vows in question were prescribed elsewhere instead, the curse to become a pƒÉ≈üandi, or “a heretic,” would be irrelevant, because the state of heresy would then be an already previously established fact [i.e., by virtue of the Vedic authority’s having been rejected from the outset]. It is therefore concluded that scriptures such as the BhƒÅgavata PurƒÅ·πáa, which stand in oppo- sition to those that promote the independent worship of ≈öiva, are authentic (sat-≈õastra). Those that propagate the indepen- dent worship of ≈öiva, such as the S≈´ta Samhita, are clearly spu- rious (asat-≈õƒÅstra). Consequently, the defect being pointed out here lies only in the worship of ≈öiva as an independent divin- ity, because in the same passage, Bhrgu himself has established Bhagavan Sri Janardana as the foundation of the Vedas: ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§É || ‡•®‡•®‡•Ø ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Indeed, this is the only eternal, auspicious path for humanity, which saintly people followed in the past and whose authority is Bhagavan Janardana. (SB 4.2.31)31 ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§¢‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‚Äú‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•® ‡•§ ‡•®‡•©) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ 30 31 tasyaivam vadata·∏• sapam ≈õrutva dvija-kulƒÅya vai bhrgu·∏• pratyasrjac chapam brahma-dandam duratyayam bhava-vrata-dhara ye ca ye ca tan samanuvratƒÅ·∏• pƒÅ·π£a·πá·∏çinas te bhavantu sac-chastra-paripanthinah esa eva hi lokƒÅnƒÅm siva·∏• panthah sanatana·∏• yam purve canusantasthur yat-prama≈Üam janardana·∏• 570 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan In this verse, the pronoun e»ôa, “this,” refers to the path pre- scribed by the Vedas. The phrase yat-pramƒÅ·πáam janardana·∏•, “whose authority is Janardana,” means, “whose root (mula) is Janardana.” Therefore, bhakti to ≈örƒ´ Visnu is firmly estab- lished in this episode [of Dak·π£a’s yaj√±a] by positive concomi- tance as well.32 This is also confirmed by statements such as the following: In this regard, luminosity (sattva), dynamism (rajas), and sta- sis (tamas) are the three universal qualitative constituents (gunas) of primordial nature (prak·πõti). Endowed with these, the one Supreme Immanent Being assumes three names - Hari [Visnu], Virinci [Brahma], and Hara [Siva], respectively - for the sustenance, creation, and dissolution of this material world. Among them, however, the ultimate benefits for human- ity ensue from Vis≈Üu alone, who is the direct embodiment of unalloyed being (visuddha-sattva). (SB 1.2.23)33 ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á ‡•©‡•ß‡•Æ‡•Ø‡•ß‡•Æ) - And in the Harivamsa, there is a statement by Siva himself: ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§†‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•©‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ O brƒÅhma·πáas, Bhagavan Hari alone is to be meditated upon constantly by you, who are firmly established in the state of perpetual being (sattva-samsthitai·∏•). You should always intone Vi≈ünu-mantras and meditate on Ke≈õava. (Harivamsa, Bhavisya-parva 89.8)34 32 The two verses quoted above (SB 4.2.27-28) established the same conclusion through negative concomitance by demonstrating the negative result (i.e., heresy) ensuing from the non-worship of Visnu (i.e., from the independent worship of Siva). Thus, the words anvayen√§pi, “by positive concomitance as well,” used here, refer to this prior application of negative concomitance. 33 sattvam rajas tama iti prak·πõter gunƒÅs tair yukta·∏• para·∏• puru≈üa eka ihasya dhatte sthity-adaye hari-virinci-hareti sanj√±ƒÅ·∏• ≈õreyamsi tatra khalu sativa-tanor nrnƒÅm syuh 34 harir eva sadƒÅ dhyeyo bhavadbhi·∏• sattva-samsthitaih vis≈Üu-mantram sada viprƒÅ·∏• pathadhvam dhyƒÅta kesavam 571Commentary I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya Here, ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´ continues to examine the topic of how an unalloyed devotee of Bhagavan Vi·π£·πáu or Krsna should regard the devas, and in particular ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva, who is preeminent among them. Previously, he made the point that devas, such as ≈öiva and Brahma, are to be honored as great Vaisnavas. As an alternative to this, he now proposes that Siva or other devas can be worshiped as the existential seats (adhisthƒÅna) wherein Bhagavan Vi·π£≈Üu appears. To illustrate this principle, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va relates the story of a Vai·π£·πáava brƒÅhma·πáa and the son of a village chief. This story is found in the 354th chapter of the third book of Visnu-dharmottara PurƒÅna. In an emergency wherein no other course of action is possible, a devo- tee of Vi·π£·πáu can worship ≈öiva as the seat of Bhagavan, inwardly reflecting that Bhagavan has manifested in that form. This was the situation faced by the brahmana named Visvaksena. The brahmana envisioned that he was worshiping Siva as Nara- simhadeva, who destroyed the tamasika demon Hiranyakasipu. ≈öiva oversees the material principle of tamas and thus attracts people under the influence of tamas. To destroy the tamas of his followers, the brahmana inwardly resolved to invoke and worship Narasimha in the cylindrical (linga) form of ≈öiva. When Visvak- sena began the worship by uttering the Narasimha-mantra, the son of the local village chief took it as an affront to ≈öiva. Being unable to tolerate this behavior, he became enraged and raised his sword to kill the brahmana. To protect His devotee, Bhagavan Narasimha at once burst forth from the Siva-linga and killed the chieftain’s son along with his associates, just as He had previously appeared from a pillar to protect the great devotee Prahlada. In doing so, He also fulfilled the wish of His devotee that the tamas of the followers of ≈öiva may be destroyed. From this, it is concluded that ≈öiva or other devas can be worshiped either as Vai·π£·πáavas or as existential seats (adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅnas) wherein Bhagavan Vis≈Üu appears. If, on the other hand, one worships Siva independently as the Supreme God, then he will turn into a heretic by the curse of the sage Bhrgu. Once, Dak·π£a, a powerful progenitor (prajapati) and 572 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan son of Brahma, organized an elaborate yaj√±a in the foothills of the Himalayas, attended by all the devas, including Brahma and ≈öiva. There was a large and eminent assembly in the sacrificial arena that included the devas, celebrated sages, and numerous scholars. When the host, Daksa, arrived, everybody stood up to honor him except for the two chief gods. Since Brahma was the father of Daksa, it was not wrong for him to remain seated. ≈öiva, however, was Daksa’s son-in-law, and hence for him not to demonstrate outward respect for his father-in-law by standing to greet him was consid- ered highly improper. To stand up out of respect for seniors in age or relation is a norm in Vedic society. Daksa became so enraged by this transgression of protocol that he launched into a public condemnation of Siva’s character. The followers of ≈öiva in turn were infuriated by Daksa’s blatant disre- spect of the great god, and they cursed him and his followers. In retaliation, Bhrgu counter-cursed the worshipers of Siva. There- fore, the moral of the story is that one should neither disrespect ≈öiva nor worship him as an independent god. Additionally, the deeper implied meaning of the story is that one should follow nei- ther the karma-marga, represented by Dak·π£a, nor that of the Saivas but should take to the Vaisnava-marga. 106.4 The Devas Can Be Worshiped As Vibhutis of K·πõ·π£·πáa ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ- ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ- ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§®‡§∞‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§®‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§® (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•≠ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•©‡•®) - If the above-stated conclusions are applicable even in the case of bhakti to ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva, then the injunction to worship even other devatƒÅs found in scriptures like the Vai·π£·πáava Agamas refers specifically to those transcendental entities who are beyond the phenomenal world (aprƒÅk·πõtƒÅnƒÅm), being servants situated 573 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya in the outer circle (bahiranga-avarana) of Bhagavan’s spiritual domain.35 Worship of other devas is seen in the case of those who are devoted to Bhagavan and are setting an ideal for people in general that leads them toward devotion. It is also seen in the case of Bhagavan’s eternal associates (pƒÅr·π£adas) who partic- ipate in His human-like lƒ´lƒÅ and thus behave in a manner that conforms to the nature of such human-like play. In either of these cases, however, it should be understood that in the yaj√±as that are performed solely for the pleasure of BhagavƒÅn, as with the Rajasuya sacrifice of King Yudhisthira, the devas are wor- shiped only as vibh≈´tis of Bhagavan, that is, as manifestations of His opulence. An example of the devas being worshiped in this manner is seen in the case of ≈örƒ´ Prahlada: ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ ‡§µ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•©‡•ß ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Thereafter, Prahlada, having worshiped Brahma, ≈öiva, the prajapatis, and the devas, who are all minute portions (kalƒÅs)36 of Bhagavan, bowed before them, touching his head to the ground. (SB 7.10.32)37 ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§µ (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ /‡•≠‡•®‡•§‡•©) - ≈öri Yudhisthira himself said: 35 The compound bahiranga-avarana, “the outer circle,” here refers to the outer circumference of the yoga-pitha, the transcendental seat of Bhagavan’s divine lilƒÅ. Some of Bhagavan’s eternal associates in the outer circle of the yoga-pitha have the same names as the devas in the material world. Thus, when the Vaisnava Agamas recommend the worship of Indra, Candra, and other divine beings, they refer to these eternal associates of Bhagavan and not to the gods in the material world bearing the same names. For more information on this topic, refer to Anuccheda 285 in this same volume. 36 In Sri Jiva GosvƒÅmi’s commentary on Srimad Bhagavata (1.3.27), he glosses the word kalƒÅ, “a minute portion,” as vibhuti, or “a manifestation of lesser power‚Äù (vibhutayah, alpa-sakte·∏• prakƒÅ≈õatv√§t). Here as well, the word kalƒÅ·∏•, used in reference to the devas, clearly specifies them as vibh≈´tis. "” tatah sampujya sirasa vavande parame·π£thinam bhavam prajapatin devan prahlado bhagavat-kalah 574 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•Ä‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø ‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•ã ‡•• ‡•®‡•©‡•® ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ O Govinda, by the performance of this Rajasuya, the chief of all sacrifices, I will worship Your purifying” vibh≈´tis, or partial manifestations. O Lord, kindly bring this sacrifice to fruition for us. (SB 10.72.3)39 ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ In this manner, ≈öri Yudhisthira expressed his intent to worship the devas as Bhagavan’s vibhutis, or partial manifestations. ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ - In the KƒÅrtika-mƒÅhƒÅtmya section of the Padma Purana, BhagavƒÅn ≈öri Krsna informed ≈örƒ´mati SatyabhƒÅmƒÅ: 38 ‡§∏‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∂‡•à‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§∂‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§π ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§™‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡•• ‡•®‡•©‡•© ‡•• ‡§è‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§π‡§Ç ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ß‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤ ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É || ‡•®‡•©‡•™ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Just as rain water reaches the ocean [via the rivers], so too the worshipers of the Sun, ≈öiva, Ga·πáe≈õa, Vis≈Üu, and ≈öakti attain Me alone here in this world. Just as one man named Devadatta is referred to by different appellations, such as son, brother, and father, likewise I, K·πõ·π£·πáa, am indeed one, but I manifest in a five- fold manner according to My different acts and names. (Padma PurƒÅ·πáa, Uttara-khanda 88.43-44)40 In his Vaisnava-to≈üani commentary on this verse, Sri Sanatana GosvƒÅmi interprets the adjective pƒÅvani·∏•, “purifying,” qualifying the vibhutis (i.e., the devas), as meaning that through their worship, “they wipe away the defects in the form of the obstacles to bhakti to You [Govinda],” tvad-bhakti-vighnƒÅdi-dosa nirasanƒ±·∏•. ≈örƒ´ Vi≈õvanatha Cakravarti interprets the same word as meaning that “the devas purify others by virtue of having seen You, meaning that by the vision of You [in the yajna sphere], they too become instruments for others to attain the state of accomplishment,” tvƒÅm aloky√§tmana·∏• pƒÅvayantir iti tvad-dar≈õanayƒÅ tƒÅ api k·πõtƒÅrthi kartum iti bhavah. 39 kratu-r√§jena govinda rajasuyena pƒÅvani·∏• yak·π£ye vibhutir bhavatas tat sampadaya na·∏• prabho 40 saura≈õ ca saivƒÅ gƒÅnesƒÅ vai·π£·πáavƒÅ·∏• ≈õakti-pujaka·∏•‚Üí‚Üí 575 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§ö- In reality, however, the Vai·π£·πáavas alone are preeminent among all these various types of worshipers. This is expressed in a dia- logue between Brahma and Narada in the Skanda PurƒÅna. Else- where in the same Purana, in the section known as the Prahlada- samhitƒÉ, we find the following statement in the context of observing the all-night vigil (j√§gara·πáa) on EkƒÅda≈õƒ´: ‡§® ‡§∏‡•å‡§∞‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•à‡§µ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§® ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§É ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•©‡•´ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Neither a worshiper of the Sun, nor of ≈öiva, nor of Brahma, nor of Sakti, nor a devotee of any other devatƒÉ can compare to a devotee of Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa. (Skanda PurƒÅ·πáa)“1 ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§∏‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§® ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§≠- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ- ‡§®‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ - The attainment of Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa by the worshipers of the Sun or of other devas [referred to above in PP 6.88.43-44] is not exclu- sively [or independently] due to the worship of those various deities. Rather, such attainment is by virtue of pure devotion (≈õuddha-bhakti), which comes into being when the worship of these devas is undertaken solely for the pleasure of Bhagavan. Alternatively, the attainment of Bhagavan may come about due to the influence of dying in a holy place related to ≈örƒ´ Vi·π£≈Üu. An illustration of this is seen in the Padma Purana in the fol- lowing statement of Bhagavan ≈öri Krsna, which He made while narrating the story of Devasarma and Candra≈õarma, who were worshipers of the Sun: mƒÅm eva pr√§pnuvantiha varsapa·∏• sagaram yatha eko ham pa√±cadhƒÅ jƒÅta·∏• krƒ´·∏çayƒÅ n√§mabhi·∏• kila deva-datto yatha kascit putrƒÅdi-jana-namabhi·∏• 41 na sauro na ca saivo vƒÉ na brahmo na ca sƒÅktikah na canya-devata-bhakto bhaved bhagavatopamah 576 106 Respect All, but Worship Only BhagavƒÅn ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§£ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•å ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•å ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§™‡§ó‡•à‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•©‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤ ‡•• ‡•®‡•©‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ By the influence of that holy place (tat-k·π£etra) and also by virtue of their embodying the principles of dharma, these two men, who were devoted to Me, were led to My abode, Vaikuntha, by My associates. I was indeed perfectly satis- fied with them because of their worship of the Sun, which they carried out throughout their lives. ( Padma PurƒÅna, Uttara-khanda 88.41-42)42 ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä ‡•§ ‡§§‡•å ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ The compound tat-k·π£etra, “that holy place,” refers to MƒÅyƒÅpurƒ´ [present day Haridwar]. It is well known from the Padma PurƒÅna that these two were born as SatrƒÅjita and Akr≈´ra dur- ing the avataric descent of Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa. Accordingly, Pundarika’s** attainment of Bhagavan Vi·π£·πáu through service to his parents should be understood in the same manner. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Ø‡•§‡•®‡•©-‡•®‡•´ ) - The attainment of Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa by independent worship of the devas is emphatically denied in the GitƒÅ: 42 43 ‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡•å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç || ‡•®‡•©‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§ö ‡•§ tat-k·π£etrasya prabhavena dharma-silataya puna·∏• vaikuntha-bhavanam nitau mat-parau mat-samipa-gai·∏• yƒÅvaj-jivan tu yat tƒÅbhyƒÅm s≈´rya-pujadikarn krtam tenaha·πÅ karma·πáƒÅ tƒÅbhyam suprƒ´to hy abhavam kila It is not clear where this story is described or which Pundarika in particular is being referred to here by Sri Jiva. In Chapter 224 of the Anu≈õƒÅsana-parva of Mahabharata, there is a story of a brahmana named Pundarika, who attained NƒÅrƒÅyana by worshiping Him in accordance with the instructions of the sage Narada. This is perhaps the example that Sri Jƒ´va had in mind. 577 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•®‡•©‡•Ø ‡•• ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Ñ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•™‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ O son of Kunti, even those devotees of other devas who worship them, being endowed with faith, actually worship Me alone, although in an improper manner. Indeed, I alone am the one for whom all yaj√±as are intended and the one who bestows their results. But they do not know Me in truth, and thus they fall down. The worshipers of the devas go to the devas, the wor- shipers of the departed ancestors go to their ancestors, the wor- shipers of the spirit entities go to the abode of the spirits, while My worshipers attain even to Me. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.23-25)44 ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Thus, worshiping the devas as “belonging or related to Bhagavan” (tadiyatvena)” may also prove beneficial at times. Commentary The other devas can also be worshiped as Vaisnavas. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va refers to the worship of the associates of Krsna or Vis≈Üu found in the Vaisnava Agama literature, such as the Gautamiya-tantra and Haya- sƒ´r·π£a Pa√±carƒÅtra. These books provide a description of the yoga- pitha in which Radha and K·πõ·π£·πáa, or Lak·π£mi-NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, are sitting on a throne or under a tree surrounded by their eternal associates 44 ye’py anya-devata-bhakta yajante ≈õraddhayanvit√§h te’pi mam eva kaunteya yajanty avidhi-p≈´rvakam aham hi sarva-yaj√±ƒÅnƒÅ·πÅ bhokta ca prabhur eva ca na tu mƒÅm abhijƒÅnanti tattvenƒÅtas cyavanti te yanti deva-vrata devan pit·πõn yanti pitr-vrata·∏• bhutani yanti bh≈´tejya yanti mad-yajino’pi mƒÅm 45 The word tadiya, lit., “His,” here signifies that the devas “belong to” or are “inseparably related to” Bhagavan. So far, Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´ has demonstrated that the devas may be worshiped either as devotees of Bhagavan, as existential seats of His manifestation (adhisthƒÅnas), or as His vibhutis. The word tadiya applies to all three of these possibilities, because all three exist in the state of “belongingness” to Him. So, if at all the devas are to be worshiped, they should be regarded as “His” (tadiyatvena), in any of these three ways. 578 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan (parikaras). In this context, one also finds an injunction to worship Bhagavan’s associates. Sometimes these associates include tran- scendental (aprƒÅk·πõta) devas, such as Ga·πáe≈õa. It is to be understood that the devas mentioned in these descriptions are not the same as the phenomenal (prƒÅk·πõta) devas of this world. They are pure devo- tees and eternal associates of Bhagavan in His spiritual abode. The worship of these devas, which is called avara·πáa-pujƒÅ, is to take place before one worships Bhagavan. In var·πáƒÅ≈õrama-dharma, performing yaj√±as is ordained. This includes offering oblations to the devas, such as Indra and Can- dra. While offering oblations to them, a Vaisnava should inwardly regard them as K·πõ·π£·πáa’s vibh≈´tis and not as independent gods. Although a Vai·π£·πáava has no need to adhere to the principles of var·πáƒÅ≈õrama-dharma, he may do so within the cultural context of such a society simply to set an example for others. Otherwise, people in general may be prone to abandon their conventional dharma, citing the examples of those devotees. Alternatively, they may criticize the devotees for neglecting their dharmic duties and thus harbor an offensive attitude in regard to them. Devotees con- duct themselves in such a manner that they do not impel ordinary people to commit offenses. For this reason, even a great devo- tee like King Yudhisthira performed the Rajasuya yaj√±a and thus worshiped the devas as vibhutis of Krsna. He worshiped them exclu- sively for the satisfaction of Krsna and not for the sake of the devas themselves. An objection may be raised in this regard. It is observed that some people have attained Vaikuntha by worshiping a deva, as learned from the story of Devasarma and Candra≈õarmƒÅ (Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda, chapter 88). Deva≈õarma was a learned brƒÅhma·πáa and had a very beautiful daughter, named Gu≈Üavati. He married his daughter to one of his students, named Candra≈õarmƒÅ. Since he had no son of his own, he treated Candra≈õarma like a son. They were both great worshipers of the Sun god. Throughout their entire lives they worshiped the Sun with great devotion. One day, they went to the forest near the Himalayas to collect some 579 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya kusa grass and wood for worship. There they encountered a ter- rifying raksasa (man-eater), and being unable to run away, they were killed by him. After death, however, they ascended at once to Vaikuntha. How was it possible that by worshiping the Sun god they were able to reach the abode of Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa? ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ replies that they worshiped the Sun god solely for the satisfaction of Sri Krsna. This is understood from Krsna’s own words, cited in the anuccheda (PP 6.88.42). If they had wor- shiped the Sun god independently, they would have gone to the sun planet instead, in accordance with K·πõ·π£·πáa’s declaration: The worshipers of the devas go to the devas, the worshipers of the departed ancestors go to their ancestors, the worshipers of the spirit entities go to the spirits, while My worshipers attain even to Me. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.25)46 Thus, the conclusion is that the independent worship of the devas is forbidden. 106.5 The Devas Should Never Be Disrespected ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§É ‚Äú ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§π‡§ø‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•© ‡•§ ‡•®‡•¨) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ But to disrespect the devas is a transgression of propriety (dosa), just as it would be wrong to disparage other scriptures, as affirmed in this verse: “One should have faith in scriptures that disclose Bhagavan and should not deride other scriptures” (SB 11.3.26).47 ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á- That one should not disrespect the devas is stated in the Padma PurƒÅ·πáa: 46 yanti deva-vrata devan pit·πõn yanti pit·πõ-vrata·∏• bh≈´tƒÅni yanti bh≈´tejya yanti mad-yajino’pi mam 47 ≈õraddham bhagavate sastre’nindƒÅm anyatra cƒÉpi hi 580 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§® ‡•• ‡•®‡•™‡•ß ‡•§‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ 48 Only Bhagavan Hari, the Supreme Isvara even of the Isvaras** of all the devas, is to be reverenced always. The other devas, headed by Brahma and Rudra, should never be disrespected. (Padma PurƒÅna) 49 ‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á‡§ö- The Gautamiya Tantra also says: ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡•®‡•™‡•® ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ If one worships ≈örƒ´ Gopala [K·πõ·π£·πáa] but disparages other deva- tƒÅs, not only is there no question of his attaining transcendental dharma but even the positive effects of his previous pious acts are annulled. ( Gautamiya Tantra 33.84 ) 50 ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ " ‡§π‡§Ø‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§•‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§π‡•á‡§≤‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•¨‡•§‡•Æ‡•§‡•ß‡•≠) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§ó‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ Therefore, in the incantation for the “≈örƒ´ NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa Armor,” atonement is accounted for in the event of such a transgression (ƒÅgah, ie, dosa ) : ‚Äú May BhagavƒÅn Haya≈õƒ´rsa protect me from treading the path of offending the devas” (SB 6.8.17 ) .51 ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§É - ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ã ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Å‡§°‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏ ‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ 48 Here, sarva-deve≈õvara, “the isvaras of all the devas, ‚Äù refers to Brahma and Siva, who are supreme among the devas. Bhagavan Hari is the Isvara even of them. Hence, He is referred to as sarva-devesvaresvara·∏•, “the Isvara of the isvaras of all the devas.” 49 harir eva sadƒÅradhya·∏• sarva-devesvaresvarah 50 51 itare brahma-rudradyƒÅ nƒÅvaj√±eyƒÅ·∏• kadacana gopalam pujayed yas tu nindayed anya-devatƒÅm astu tavat paro dharmah purva-dharmo’pi nasyati hayasir·π£ƒÅ mƒÅm pathi deva-helanat 581I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya [Regarding the topic of how the devas are ideally to be regarded,] the following history is cited in the Visnu-dharma PurƒÅ·πáa: “Once upon a time, ≈örƒ´ Ambarƒ´·π£a underwent penances for many days in worship of Bhagavan. When his worship was concluded, Bhagavan Himself, taking the form of Indra, mounted His car- rier, Garuda, who had assumed the form of Indra’s carrier, the elephant AirƒÅvata. Bhagavan approached Ambarƒ´·π£a and attempted to seduce him with a boon. Ambarƒ´≈üa, seeing the form of Indra, honored Him by bowing down but did not wish to receive any boon from Him. ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‚Äú‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É " ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§• ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§π ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ- ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ “Ambarƒ´·π£a said: ‘Only He whose form is that of my worshipful deity can be the one to grant me boons, and no one else.’ Bha- gavan in the form of Indra replied: ‘I myself will offer what- ever boon is to be given by Him.’ In spite of His insistence, how- ever, Ambari·π£a was unwilling to accept any boon from Indra. At this, Indra took up his thunderbolt and was prepared to strike Ambarƒ´·π£a, yet Ambarƒ´·π£a still would not accept a boon. Being highly pleased with Ambarƒ´·π£a, Bhagavan withdrew His Indra form, revealed His original true form, and blessed Ambarƒ´·π£a.‚Äù [Here ends the story from Visnu-dharma Purana.] ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§è‡§µ ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∂‡§æ‡§™‡§É ‚Äú‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§π ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å ‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•™‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•®‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ As far as affront to the devas is concerned, the disrespect of Siva is a particularly severe offense, as shown in the Fourth Canto in the curse uttered by Nandi≈õvara: “May those who follow this prajapati [Dak·π£a], an offender to ≈öiva, rotate here in the cycle of birth and death” (SB 4.2.24).52 ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ - ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ 52 samsaranty iha ye camum anu sarvƒÅvamƒÅninam 582 106 Respect All, but Worship Only BhagavƒÅn ‚Äú‡§π‡•á‡§≤‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•™‡•§‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•©‡•©) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡•Ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡•á‡§£ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ø‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É‡§™‡•Å- ‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ This admonition itself hardly needs mentioning, meaning that because ≈öiva is a great devotee of Bhagavan, it is self-evident that disrespecting him is an offense. This was pointed out by Svayambhuva Manu [when he instructed Dhruva to desist from killing the yak·π£as, the servants of Kubera]: “You have disrespected the god of wealth, Kubera, the brother of ≈öiva” (SB 4.11.33).53 In accordance with Syayambhuva Manu’s advice, ≈örƒ´ Dhruva at once approached Kubera, acutely aware of the latter’s friendship with ≈öiva. Aspiring for the all-encompassing humility that springs from the essential nature of bhagavad- bhakti, and being repeatedly overwhelmed with a yearning for bhakti, ≈öri Dhruva prayed for the boon of devotion to Bhagavan, even from Kubera. This is the import of this narration from the Fourth Canto. ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§ï‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á) ‚Äì Therefore, it is said in the Kurma PurƒÅ·πáa: ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•™‡•© ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ One who worships Me constantly with one-pointed devotion but disparages Mahadeva ≈öiva certainly goes to hell. (Kurma Purana)54 ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ This was evident in the life of King Citraketu. 53 helanam girisa-bhrƒÅtur dhanadasya tvaya k·πõtam 54 Manu implied that Dhruva was also implicated in an offense to Bhagavan Siva by disrespecting his brother. The reference to Kubera as Siva’s brother is to show their intimacy. yo mam samarcayen nityam ekantam bhavam asrita·∏• vinindan devam i≈õƒÅnam sa yati narakam dhruvam 583 Commentary I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya In this subsection of Anuccheda 106, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ emphasizes the point that the devas should never be disrespected. Just as it is pleasing to Bhagavan when the devas are respected as Vaisnavas, so too any disrespect shown to them is displeasing. The devas are always supported by Visnu. Whenever they are tormented by the asuras, Vi≈ü≈Üu sides with them. Whether the devas are regarded as devotees of Vis≈Üu, as parts of His body - such as demonstrated in the Universal Form described in Chapter Eleven of Bhagavad GitƒÅ - as vibh≈´tis, described in Chapter Ten, or as adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅnas, meaning the existential seats of Vis≈Üu’s manifestation, any disrespect shown to them is opposed to bhakti. For this reason, there are numerous scriptural statements prohibiting such behavior. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ also cites the incantation for the “≈örƒ´ NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa Armor, ,“55 in which is included a prayer to Bhagavan Haya≈õƒ´r·π£a appealing for protection from any potential disrespect toward the devas. This shows that such disrespect is both undesirable and dangerous. Although disrespect shown to any of the devas is an offense, an affront to ≈öiva is of the greatest severity. This is because among all the devas, ≈öiva is most dear to Visnu - vaisnavƒÅnƒÅ·πÅ yatha sambhu·∏• (SB 12.13.16). Nandi≈õvara, the chief associate and carrier of ≈öiva, has pro- nounced a curse on those who offend Siva that they may continue to rotate in the cycle of birth and death. The seriousness of an offense to Siva, who is a great devotee of Bhagavan, is understood from the story of King Dhruva. His half-brother was killed by a servant of Kubera. Enraged at this, Dhruva attacked Alaka-puri, Kubera’s capital. A fierce battle broke out between Dhruva and Kubera’s followers, and Dhruva killed many of his adversaries. Dhruva’s grandfather, Manu, then intervened and informed him that he had committed an offense to Kubera by killing his followers. 55 The Sanskrit word kavaca means “a warrior’s protective armor,” but it can also refer to a class of occult mantras or incantations that are meant to protect the utterer from danger. These are often written down and worn in an amulet for protection from an array of malefic forces. 584 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan Manu referred to Kubera as girisa-bhrƒÅtu·∏•, “Siva’s brother.” Kubera is not actually Siva’s brother but only a friend. In fact, he is only a neighbor. But by way of this allusion, Manu emphasized the gravity of Dhruva’s offense. Any insult to Kubera is an insult to ≈öiva owing to their friendship. Nobody is pleased when their friend is insulted, and certainly not a great deva such as ≈öiva. ≈öiva is a great devotee of Vi·π£·πáu, and thus to displease him would not be pleasing to Vis≈Üu, who is Dhruva’s ista-deva. Dhruva understood the sig- nificance of Manu’s words, and as such, he pleaded for Kubera’s blessings and prayed that he may be graced with devotion to Bha- gavan Hari. Dhruva recognized that if Kubera was displeased, it would become an obstacle to his bhakti. The only way to be released from an offense to a Vaisnava is by appeasing him or her. Citraketu stands as a glaring example of one who, although a perfected devotee, had to become an asura because of an offense to ≈†iva. This episode is described in the 17th chapter of the Sixth Canto. 106.6 A Devotee Should Not Disrespect Any Living Being ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•©‡•§‡•®‡•Ø‡•§‡•®‡•ß ) - To say nothing of disrespecting a great devotee such as ≈öiva, Bha- gavƒÅn ≈örƒ´ Kapiladeva has condemned even the disrespect of ordi- nary living beings. This is clearly expressed in the following statement: ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç || ‡•®‡•™‡•™ ‡•• I am ever existent as the Supreme Immanent Self in all living entities. If a mortal being disregards any one of them (tam) and hence Me (mƒÅm), yet worships My deity form, he makes a mockery of such worship. (SB 3.29.21)56 56 aham sarve·π£u bhute·π£u bhutƒÅtmƒÅvasthita·∏• sadƒÅ tam avaj√±ƒÅya mƒÅ·πÅ martya·∏• kurute’rca-vi·∏çambanam 585 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§≠‡•É‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡•§ ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ As will be elaborated further on [in SB 3.29.28-33], the word bh≈´te·π£u in the present verse refers to all grades of living entities (jƒ´vas), beginning from those bereft of life air (prana) up to those who have surrendered the self to Bhagavan. The word bh≈´tƒÅtmƒÅ means the Supreme Immanent Self ( antaryƒÅmƒ´) within all liv- ing beings. The clause tam mam avaj√±ƒÅya, “by disregarding any one of them and hence Me,” means that “by disregarding other living beings, one in fact disrespects Me, who am the Indweller within the existential seats of their own bodies (adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅnaka). Consequently, one who behaves in this manner and then wor- ships My deity form makes a mockery (vi·∏çambanam) of such worship, meaning that he exhibits only disrespect (avaj√±ƒÅm) for that deity.‚Äù ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•©‡•§‡•®‡•Ø‡•§‡•®‡•® ) - Bhagavan Kapila affirms this conclusion in the immediately succeeding verse: ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡•å‡§¢‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§ú‡•Å‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•™‡•´ ‡•• One who disregards Me, the Immanent Self (AtmƒÅ ) and Sup- reme Regulator (I≈õvara) within all living beings, and worships the deity from an attitude of ignorance, pours his oblations into ashes alone. (SB 3.29.22) 57 ‡§Æ‡•å‡§¢‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§- ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•à‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§ú‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The word maudhyat, “from an attitude of ignorance,” means from the deluded notion that the deity in question is an idol 57 yo mam sarvesu bh≈´te≈üu santam ƒÅtmƒÅnam isvaram hitv√§rcam bhajate maudhyad bhasmany eva juhoti sah 586 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan made of stone or wood. “The person who worships My deity form while holding to this deluded notion disregards Me, the Immanent Self (Paramatma ) and Supreme Regulator (Isvara), who am present within all living things, being unable to per- ceive My oneness with the deity form. Such a person offers water and other items to the deity only as a matter of social custom.‚Äù ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡•á- A reference to this type of mentality is made in the Agni Purana, regarding the lamentation of the ascetic sage [Andha Muni], whose son was [accidentally] killed by Da≈õaratha: ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§•‡§ø ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•™‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•™‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Did I ever consider the deity of Bhagavan Hari to be a stone idol? Did I ever see a devotee of Bhagavan Vi·π£·πáu on the road, his body marked with the symbols of Vi≈ü≈Üu, and fail to honor him within my mind? What calamitous deed have I committed as a result of which I am to suffer such grief for my son? (Agni Purana)58 ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á- The Padma Purana reiterates the same idea: ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•å ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•Å ‡§®‡§∞‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§•‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§Ω‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•Å‡§∑‡§π‡•á ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•à ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•™‡•Æ ‡•• Anyone who considers the deity of Vis≈Üu to be a stone idol; the guru, an ordinary human being; a Vaisnava, to belong to a par ticular caste; the water that has washed the feet of Bhagavan 58 sila-buddhi·∏• k·πõtƒÅ kim va pratimƒÅyƒÅm harer mayƒÅ kim mayƒÅ pathi drstasya visnu-bhaktasya karhicit tan-mudrankita-dehasya cetasa nadarah k·πõtah yena karma-vip√§kena putra-soko mamed·πõ≈õa·∏• 587 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya Visnu or the Vaisnavas, which purifies the sins of the age of Kali, as ordinary water; the mantra of the pure name of Bhagavan, which dispels all impurities, as ordinary words; and BhagavƒÅn Vis≈Üu, who is the Supreme Controller of all other controllers, as equal to other gods, certainly dwells in hell. (Padma PurƒÅ·πáa)59 ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡•Å‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ “‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•≠‡•§‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏- ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•™‡•≠ ) - [Returning again to the discussion of SB 3.29.22, quoted above, Jiva GosvƒÅmi continues to paraphrase Kapila’s words:] “Because such an ignorant person is unable to recognize My presence within the deity, he ends up disrespecting all living beings as well [who are also the seats of My indwelling]. Consequently, because of this defect, the worship of such a faithless person is bereft of fruit (phala-abhƒÅva), as if he were to cast his oblations into a heap of ashes. In Bhagavad GitƒÅ, Arjuna raises the following relevant question: O Krsna, what is the conviction (ni·π£·π≠hƒÅ) of those who, although endowed with faith, engage in worship while disregarding scriptural injunctions? Is it of the nature of sattva, rajas, or tamas? (Gƒ™TƒÄ 17.1)60 According to what is stated in this question, there are some who worship with a degree of faith born only from social custom. They, however, are known as kani·π£·π≠ha-bhƒÅgavatas, or “devotees of the lowest rung.” They are described by the sage Hari, one of the Nava-yogendras, in this statement: 59 arcye vi≈ünau sila-dhir guru≈üu nara-matir vaisnave j√§ti-buddhir vi·π£·πáor vƒÅ vai·π£·πáavƒÅnƒÅm kali-mala-mathane pada-tirthe mbu-buddhih suddhe tan-nƒÅmni mantre sakala-kalusa-he sabda-samanya-buddhir vi≈ü≈Üau sarve≈õvarese tad-itara-sama-dhir yasya vai nƒÅraki sah 60 ye ≈õ√§stra-vidhim uts·πõjya yajante ≈õraddhayƒÅnvita·∏• te·π£ƒÅm nisthƒÅ tu kƒÅ k·πõsna sattvam aho rajas tamah 588 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§π‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á‡§π‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•™‡•Ø ‡•• One who offers worship to Hari with faith in the deity form alone but who fails to honor Him as present in His devotees or in other living beings is recognized as a beginning devo- tee (pr√§k·πõta-bhakta, lit., “a devotee rooted in gross material vision”). (SB 11.2.47)61 ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§ï‡§•‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ù‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§æ‡§´‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç " ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•© ‡•§ ‡•®‡•Ø‡•§‡•®‡•´ ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ I The latter statement implies that although any sort of worship at all will eventually yield fruit, this will not occur immediately [as long as one disregards other beings]. It is thus affirmed that [the neophyte’s] worship does eventually bear fruit, and this is also indicated a few verses ahead by Kapiladeva: As long as one does not directly perceive Me within his heart as the Interior Regulator (I≈õvara) present within all living beings, he should worship Me in the deity form while carrying out his prescribed duties. (SB 3.29.25)62 ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•©‡•§‡•®‡•Ø‡•§‡•®‡•© ) - If such is the case for the mere lack of regard for other liv- ing beings, what then can be said of outright maliciousness? Bhagavan Kapila sums up this condition in the next verse: 61 ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø || ‡•®‡•´‡•¶ || A person who bears hostility toward Me situated in all other bodies, who perceives only duality (bhinna-darsinah), who is thus “ego-identified and proud” (maninah), and who is thereby arcayam eva haraye pujam ya·∏• ≈õraddhayehate na tad-bhakte≈üu canye·π£u sa bhakta·∏• pr√§k·πõtah smrtah 62 arcƒÅdƒÅv arcayet tavad isvaram mam sva-karma-k·πõt yavan na veda sva-hrdi sarva-bh≈´te≈üv avasthitam 589 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya bound by enmity to other beings, can never attain the state of utter mental tranquility (mana-santim). (SB 3.29.23)63 ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú- ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•å‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§® ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á- The compound bhinna-darsinah, “the perceiver of duality,” means “one who is devoid of the vision of unity that is rooted in the Immanent Self’s (antaryami’s) omnipresence.” Alterna- tively, the same compound can be read as a-bhinna-darsƒ´,64 “one who is unable to discern distinction,” in which case it would mean that such a person is incapable of perceiving that Bhaga- v√§n ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa, the son of the king of Vraja, is absolutely distinct from all other beings. On account of either of these two flawed ways of seeing, he is “ego-identified and hence proud” (mani- nah). As a further consequence, he is also bound by enmity to other beings. The exact opposite of this mentality is described in the Mahabharata: ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•ã ‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡•®‡•´‡•ß ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Bhagavan Hr·π£ikesa [Krsna] is quickly pleased with a person of pure disposition, who is never the cause of anxiety for others and who treats them in the same manner that a kindhearted father treats his child. (Mahabharata) 65 ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•©‡•§‡•®‡•Ø‡•ß‡•®‡•™ ) - Kapiladeva continues: 63 dvi·π£atah para-kaye mam manino bhinna-darsinah bh≈´te≈üu baddha-vairasya na mana·∏• santim ·πõcchati 64 The compound bhinna-darsinah can also be read as a-bhinna-darsinah, with elision of the initial vowel because of a sandhi rule. Taking this alternate reading, ≈öri Jiva interprets the compound in the sense of bhinna-a-darsinah, meaning “one who is unable to discern (a-darsinah) the absolute distinction (bhinna) between Krsna and all other living beings.” 65 piteva putram karuno nodvejayati yo janam visuddhasya hr·π£ikesas tasya turnam prasidati Verse not found in the printed edition. 590 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ò‡•á ‡•§ ‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§É || ‡•®‡•´‡•® ‡•§‡•§ O sinless one (Devahuti), I am certainly not pleased with a per- son who disrespects other living beings, even if he worships Me in the deity form by enacting elaborate rituals conducted with all manner of articles. (SB 3.29.24)66 ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß | ‡•®‡•© | ‡•©) - The word avamanina·∏•, “one who disrespects others,” means “a person who defames or criticizes others” (nindƒÅ-kartu·∏•). The word ninda, “defamation,” is equivalent to dve»ôa, “enmity or hostility.” In some instances, defamation can prove to be even more hurtful than outright hostility, as indicated in the following statement by Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa: ‡§® ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ó‡•à‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á‡§∑‡§µ‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•´‡•© ‡•• A man who is pierced by arrows that have struck his vital organs is not so deeply wounded as when stung by the deadly shaft- like words of an ill-tempered person that pierce his heart and torment him. (SB 11.23.3)67 ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§™‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ Since according to K·πõ·π£·πáa’s statement, nindƒÅ is more grievous than dvesa, the sequence of topics discussed by Bhagavan Kapila is not improper. It is with this in mind that he did not describe criticism (ninda) prior to hostility (dve·π£a).68 66 aham uccavacair dravyaih kriyayotpannayanaghe 67 68 naiva tusye’rcito’rcayam bh≈´ta-g a-grƒÅmavamaninah na tatha tapyate viddha·∏• puman banair hi marma-gaih yatha tudanti marmastha hy asatƒÅm paru·π£esavah Bhagavan Kapila spoke about dvesa, “hostility,” in SB 3.29.23 and then about avamƒÅna (i.e., ninda), “criticism,” in SB 3.29.24. According to the rules of sequential order, in a list of negative items the worst attribute should come last. Although hostility may generally be thought of as worse than criticism, here the opposite is shown to be true. Thus, there is no transgression of order in Bhagavan Kapila’s presentation of these two items. This is Jiva GosvƒÅmi’s point. 591I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑ ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•©‡•§‡•®‡•Ø‡•§‡•®‡•´) -

In this manner, we first described the deficiency of a person who, [although worshiping the deity form,] lacks faith in bhakti due to the absence of awareness (j√±ƒÅna-abhƒÅva) of the Imma nent Self’s (I≈õvara’s) presence within all beings [SB 3.29.21-22] After this, worship of the deity itself combined with the perfor mance of one’s prescribed duties was shown to engender this awareness of the Immanent Self (tat-j√±ƒÅna), which is instru mental in establishing faith in bhakti to Bhagavan [SB 3.29.25] For this reason, in the latter statement [repeated here again] Kapiladeva accepts that even such worship [which lacks the realization of I≈õvara’s presence within all living beings] is not without utility: ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•´‡•™ ‡•• As long as one does not directly perceive Me within his heart as the Interior Regulator (Isvara) present within all living beings, he should worship Me in the deity form while carrying out his prescribed duties. (SB 3.29.25)69 ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á “‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§‡•®‡•¶‡•§‡•®‡•≠) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ Kapiladeva makes the point that as long as one has not realize Him, the Interior Regulator (I≈õvara), who is present within al beings, he should worship Bhagavan’s deity form while carry ing out his prescribed duties. The prescription here to take sup port from one’s prescribed duties is given because the perso in whom faith is not yet established is ineligible for pure devi tion. This idea will be elaborated later with reference to stat ments such as the following: “A person who has developed fait 69 arcadav arcayet tavad isvaram mam sva-karma-k·πõt yavan na veda sva-h·πõdi sarva-bh≈´te≈üv avasthitam 592 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan in the narrations of My divine acts should worship Me with love” (SB 11.20.27-28).70 ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‚Äú ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•ß‡•ß | ‡•®‡•¶ | ‡•Ø) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ- ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•´‡•´ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡§Ø‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ Thus, a person in whom faith has been born out of the awareness of Bhagavan’s presence in all beings should undertake worship without any further recourse to prescribed duties. Rather, he should engage only in pure worship and other such acts directly related to Bhagavan. This is the conclusion. This will also be established later by statements such as the following: As long as detachment has not been aroused, or as long as one has not awakened faith in hearing narrations about Me, a person should continue to engage in his prescribed duties. (SB 11.20.9)” By this, however, it is to be understood that the worship of Bhagavan’s deity form is not to be given up under any circum- stances, because this is opposed to the following statement of the Hayasir·π£a Pa√±carƒÅtra: One should never abandon the worship of an installed deity and should worship the deity fittingly as long as one lives. It would be better to give up one’s life or to cut off one’s head than to forsake such worship. (Hayasir·π£a Pa√±carƒÅtra)“2 70 j√§ta-sraddho mat-kathƒÅsu… bhajeta mam prita·∏• " tavat karmƒÅ≈Üi kurvita na nirvidyeta yƒÅvatƒÅ mat-katha-≈õrava·πáƒÅdau vƒÅ ≈õraddha yavan na jayate pratisthitarcƒÉ na ty√§jy√§ yƒÅvaj-jƒ´va·πÅ samarcayet varam prƒÅ·πáa-parityaga·∏• siraso vapi kartanam 72 593 Commentary I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya After discussing three primary ways in which devotees of Bhaga- v√§n are to regard the devas (either as Vaisnavas, as adhisthƒÅnas, or as vibh≈´tis), ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi then stressed the importance of avoid- ing any disrespect to the devas, because this is a major obstacle to devotion. Among all the devas, ≈öiva is preeminent, and hence dis- respect shown to him is particularly damaging. Now, in this sub- section of Anuccheda 106, ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmi extends the discussion to include all living beings. In this regard, he cites Kapiladeva, who informs Devah≈´ti that He, Bhagavan, is present in all beings (SB 3.29.21). To disrespect any living being is also to disrespect Him. Dislike for a country amounts to dislike for its residents. The principle being examined here is that every living being is an integrated part of Paramatma’s intermediary potency (ta·π≠astha- ≈õakti) in the form of the jivas. There is an inseparable relation of oneness and difference that exists between the Energetic Source (≈õaktim√§n) and its energies (saktis). Consequently, an offense to a living being is also an offense to the source of that living being, who is the Indweller present within him. For this reason, ≈örƒ´ Caitanya Mahaprabhu advised sincere practitioners of bhakti to offer respect to all beings (mƒÅna-dena). This is a very simple but essential prin- ciple of sadhana-bhakti. Progress on the path of bhakti is impeded solely due to offenses. One of the primary reasons for committing offenses is pride, which stems from the misidentification with the body. ≈öri Kapila advises the sadhaka to carefully avoid this pitfall. ≈örƒ´ Jiva comments (on SB 3.29.21) that ParamƒÅtmƒÅ is present even in insentient beings like mountains and rivers (aprƒÅ·πáa-bh·πõt- bh≈´te·π£u). They too should be respected as existential seats of His indwelling. An ignorant devotee offers respect to the deity form of Bhagavan in the temple but disrespects other living beings. Kapila declares that such ceremonious respect or worship is only a show (vidambanam). The reason for this assessment is that the same ParamƒÅtmƒÅ who is present in the deity form is also present in all living beings. This truth, however, is not perceived by the materialistic devotee. 594 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan The behavior of such a devotee can be compared to that of an employee who respects his boss while at work but who disparages him when meeting him in the street. Obviously, the boss will feel affronted. Then, however much respect the employee had previ- ously shown in the office, it will not make an impact on his boss, who will take the disrespect more seriously than the respect. The same is true of a devotee who worships the deity in the temple but offends his fellow beings. He is unable to recognize that the same Bhagavan is present everywhere and in all things. Bhagavan does not accept the worship of such a person, because ultimately, his concept of the deity is also material. He thinks that the deity is made of stone or wood or some other product of matter. The fact is that the deity is Bhagavan Himself. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va cites various statements to show that it is a serious offense to consider the deity of Bhagavan as a mere idol made of stone or wood. He refers to the story of ≈öravana KumƒÅra. This young man was very devoted to his parents, both of whom were blind. When they expressed their desire to visit the holy places in India, ≈öravana carried them to these different places in baskets held on his shoulders. One day, he arrived in the kingdom of Ayo- dhya, which was ruled by King Dasaratha. Dasaratha had gone out hunting but had been unable to find any wild animal to kill. He con- sidered it shameful to return to his palace without having killed at least one animal. Evening was approaching and the sun was about to set. Dasaratha went to the bank of the Sarayu River, hoping that some wild animal would come there to drink water at night and he would be able to shoot it. He hid in the branches of a tree and began to wait, but no animal came. Just then, ≈öravana, who was camping nearby, came to fetch water for his parents. When he dipped his pot in the river to fill it, it made a gurgling sound. As it was already dark, Dasaratha shot an arrow toward the sound, mistaking it for the sound of an animal drinking water. The arrow pierced the heart of ≈öravana, who cried out and dropped to the ground writhing in pain. Hear- ing the human cry, Dasaratha realized his mistake. He rushed 595 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya to the spot feeling deeply aggrieved. He begged Sravana to for- give him. ≈öravana was gasping for breath, and before dying, he requested Dasaratha to take the water to his thirsty parents. When his parents received the terrible news, they broke out crying. The verses cited here were spoken by ≈öravana’s father, Andha Muni. Instead of blaming the king, Andha Muni began to reflect on his own past karma. He conjectured that in the past, he had perhaps disregarded the deity of Hari as a mere block of stone, and that as a consequence he was condemned to have to face the death of his son. The verse from Padma Purana also conveys the same idea. It states that to consider the deity of Visnu as a stone idol, the guru as an ordinary human, and so on, is to dwell in hell. The story of Andha Muni as well as the statement of Kapila imply that if one wor- ships and respects the deity of Bhagavan while at the same time dis- regarding other living beings, it is tantamount to disrespect. The worship conducted by such a person yields no spiritual benefit. Rather, it is comparable to pouring oblations into ashes. Oblations are to be poured into fire, which conducts it to the corresponding deva. But any spiritual act performed without faith bears no fruit (Gƒ™TƒÄ 17.28). If one has faith in the deity and in the process of worship but does not regard the devotees with respect, his progress will be very slow. Worship of this nature, however, is not entirely with- out value. Bhagavan Kapila recommends that such neophyte wor- shipers should continue to worship the deity while executing their prescribed duties until they can sense the presence of God in all beings. Once this occurs, they should continue the worship with- out any further obligation to perform prescribed duties. If at all they continue to execute prescribed duties at this point, it would only be to set an ideal example for others and so as to not disrupt the social norm. The above instruction, however, does not mean that after directly intuiting God’s omnipresence, one should give up the wor- ship of the deity, as some people mistakenly think. Deity worship should never be given up. Some people misunderstand Kapila’s 596 106 Respect All, but Worship Only Bhagavan words and think that deity worship is meant only for neophytes. They surmise that it is a sign of advancement to eventually abandon such worship. In reality, worship of the deity is meant to be con- tinued but from a higher, direct realization of Bhagavan’s oneness with the deity and with all living beings. 106.7 Worship Devoid of Compassion Does Not Yield Perfection ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§® ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•©‡•§‡•®‡•Ø‡•§‡•®‡•¨ ) - Worship of the deity accompanied by the execution of one’s prescribed duties does not become successful without extend- ing kindness to other living beings, as expressed by Bhagavan Kapila: ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ß‡•á ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§¨‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•´‡•¨ ‡•• To the perceiver of duality (bhinna-darsinah), who upholds a distinction between his own interiority and that of other living beings,” I, as death personified, allot overwhelming fear [in the form of cyclic existence (samsaram)]. (SB 3.29.26)74 ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§∞‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø- ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ã‡§Ω‡§π‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§¨‡§£‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ 73 ≈öridhara SvƒÅmƒ´ analyzes the compound antarodaram as follows: The word antara means “difference” (bhedam), the word ut means “even” (api), and aram means “a little” (alpam). If antarodaram is taken in this sense, the clause ya·∏• karoty antarodaram would mean, “one who upholds even the slightest distinction [between himself and other living beings].” If, however, udara is taken in its conventional application as a single word, it means “the stomach” or “the interiority” [of any particular thing]. In this interpretation, which is favored by ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmi, the clause yah karoty antarodaram means “one who upholds a distinction between his own ‘stomach’ and that of others.” 74 atmana≈õ ca parasyƒÅpi yah karoty antarodaram tasya bhinna-drso m·πõtyur vidadhe bhayam ulba·πáam 597 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya [≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va paraphrases Kapila’s statement:] “One who upholds duality (bhedam) by differentiating between his own ‘interior- ity’ or ‘stomach’ (udara) and that of others does not perceive others as essentially identical to his own self, inasmuch as they too are the existential seats of My indwelling. The sense is that even after seeing others hungry or in need, he fills only his own belly and attends only to his own needs.
