(SB 11.5.2-3) bhik≈üor dharmah samo’himsa tapa ik·π£ƒÅ vanaukasah ≈õrava·πáam kirtanam casya smaranam mahatam gate·∏• sevejyƒÅvanatir dasyam sakhyam atma-samarpanam n·πõ·πáƒÅm ayam paro dharmah sarve·π£ƒÅm samudah·πõta·∏• mukha-bƒÅhuru-padebhyah purusasyasramai·∏• saha‚Üí‚Üí 639 ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á - I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya The Mahabharata also says: ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•Æ‡•ß ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ One who does not worship the worshipful Lord of all the devas [deve≈õam, i.e., Bhagavan], who is the agent behind the evolution and dissolution [of the cosmos], and who completely protects all living beings just like a mother, should be considered as the killer of a brahmana. (Mahabharata)’ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ö (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•≠/‡•ß‡•´) - In Bhagavad Gƒ´tƒÅ also, Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa says: ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•Æ‡•® ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Those who are utterly bereft of discrimination, those who are the lowest of men, those whose intellective capacity has been stolen away by illusion (maya), and those who have embraced the secularist-materialistic nature - all such performers of unmeritorious acts do not take refuge in Me. (GITA 7.15)* ‡§Ü‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ö - In the Agni Purana and in the Visnu-dharma Purana as well it is said: 7 8 catvƒÅro jajnire var·πáƒÅ gu·πáair vipradaya·∏• prthak ya e≈üam puru≈üam sak·π£ad atma-prabhavam isvaram na bhajanty avaj√§nanti sth√§nƒÅd bhra·π£·π≠a·∏• patanty adha·∏• mƒÅtrvat parirak·π£antam srsti-samh√§ra-k√§rakam yo n√§rcayati deve≈õam tam vidyad brahma ghatakam According to sastra, killing a brahmana is one of the most heinous crimes that a person could commit. Thus, to equate the nonworship of Bhagavan with such an act shows the severity of the defect of nondevotion. na mƒÅm du≈ük·πõtino mudha·∏• prapadyante narƒÅdhamƒÅ·∏• mƒÅyayapah·πõta-j√±ƒÅnƒÅ ƒÅsuram bhƒÅvam ƒÅ≈õritƒÅ·∏• 640 111 Bhakti Is the Intrinsic Duty of Everyone ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•Æ‡•© ‡•• There are two categories of living beings in the creation ‚Äî the godly and the ungodly. Those intently engaged in bhakti to Bha- gavan Vi·π£·πáu are godly, whereas, those who do just the opposite are ungodly. (Agni Purana, Visnu-dharma Purana)” ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•≠ /‡•Ø/‡•ß‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Another example was quoted earlier [in Anuccheda 100]: In my opinion, a dog-eater who has offered his mind, speech, actions, wealth, and life to Bhagavan is superior to a brƒÅhma·πáa who, although endowed with twelve exalted qualities, is not devoted to the lotus feet of Bhagavan, whose navel is shaped like a lotus. Such a dog-eater purifies his whole family, whereas the overly proud brƒÅhma·πáa is unable to do so. (SB 7.9.10)1o ‚Äú‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ö‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ‡§≤ ‚Äù ( ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ The same idea is expressed in this verse from NƒÅrada PurƒÅ·πáa: O King, a devotee of Visnu is better than a dvija, even if he is a dog-eater, but a dvija devoid of Visnu-bhakti is worse than a dog-eater. (Narada Purana 2.10.37b-38a)” ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§°‡•á- 9 In the Garuda PurƒÅ·πáa, it is said: ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§® ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§ß‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•Æ‡•™ ‡•• dvi-vidho bh≈´ta-sargo’yam daiva asura eva ca visnu-bhakti-paro daiva asuras tad-viparyayah 10 viprad dvi-sad-guna-yutad aravinda-nƒÅbha- pƒÅdƒÅravinda-vimukhƒÅt svapacam varistham manye tad-arpita-mano-vacanehit√§rtha- prƒÅ·πáam punƒÅti sa kulam na tu bhuri-mƒÅna·∏• 11 ≈õvapaco’pi mahƒ´pƒÅla vi·π£·πáor bhakto dvijadhika·∏• visnu-bhakti-vihino yo dvijati·∏• ≈õvapacƒÅdhikah 641I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya Even if one has mastered the conclusion of all the Vedas, and even if one knows the meaning of all scriptures, if he is not devoted to the Supreme Immanent Self of all living beings (sarvesvara), he should be considered as the lowest of humankind. (Garuda Purana 1.231.17)12 ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á‡§ö- The Brhan-naradiya PurƒÅ≈Üa states: ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ó‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•Æ‡•´ ‡•• Those who do not worship Bhagavan Hari, who are antagonistic to the Vedas, and who are inimical toward the brƒÅhma·πáas and cows, are called r√§k·π£asas. (BNP 1.37.5)13 ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•©‡•® ) - Furthermore, the devas pray to Sri Bhagavan as follows: ‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•Æ‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Olotus-eyed Lord, others, who consider themselves as liberated but who are devoid of devotion to You, are of impure intelli- gence. Although they elevate themselves to an exalted status through great hardship, they fall down from that position if they disregard Your lotus feet. (SB 10.2.32)14 ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§É (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§‡•ß‡•™‡•§‡•®‡•® ) - First of all, it is stated that because they have “cast aside” (asta) all affection (bhava) for You (tvayi), meaning that because of the non-existence of bhakti for You in them, their intelligence 12 13 14 antam gato pi vedanƒÅm sarva-sastrartha-vedyapi yo na sarvesvare bhaktas tam vidyat puru·π£ƒÅdhamam hari-puja-vihƒ´nƒÅ≈õ ca veda-vidvesinas tatha dvija-go-dve≈üinas capi raksasah parikirtitƒÅ·∏• ye nye ravindƒÅk·π£a vimukta-maninas tvayy asta-bhavad avi≈°uddha-buddhaya·∏• aruhya k·πõcchre·πáa param padam tatah patanty adho’nad·πõta-yusmad-anghraya·∏• 642 111 Bhakti Is the Intrinsic Duty of Everyone is impure (avi≈õuddha-buddhayah). This is supported by Krsna’s statement in ≈örimad Bhagavata: ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡•á‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡§ø ‡•• ‡•®‡•Æ‡•≠ ‡•• Socio-religious duty (dharma) endowed with truth and compas- sion, or even knowledge (vidyƒÅ) accompanied by penance, cer- tainly does not completely purify the mind if devoid of devotion to Me. (SB 11.14.22) 15 ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø- ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§É “‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•® ‡•§‡•´ ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ß‡§É ‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ In spite of this, however, by adherence to the path of j√±ƒÅna, they consider themselves as liberated (vimukta-m√§ninah), meaning that they presume themselves to have transcended the gross and subtle bodies. So, even after elevating themselves through great hardship (krcchrena) to an exalted status (param padam ), meaning the state of living liberation (jƒ´van-mukti), they fall down from that position. The difficulty in attaining this state is confirmed in Bhagavad Gƒ´tƒÅ: The hardship of those whose minds are attached to the unman- ifest is greater, because the goal of the unmanifest is attained with difficulty by embodied beings. (Gƒ´rƒÅ 12.5) 16 ‡§ï‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É‚Äú‡§Ö‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§§” ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç- ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä- ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ When [i.e., under what circumstances] do they fall down? In anticipation of this question, [the devas respond,] ‚Äú[If] they disregard Your lotus feet‚Äù (anƒÅdrta-yusmad-anghrayah). The 15 dharma·∏• satya-dayopeto vidya va tapasƒÅnvitƒÅ mad-bhakty√§petam ƒÅtmƒÅnam na samyak prapunƒÅti hi 16 kle≈õo ‘dhikataras tesƒÅm avyaktƒÅsakta-cetasamn avyakta hi gatir du·∏•kham dehavadbhir avapyate 643 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya word yadi, “if,” though not stated in the verse, is to be adduced here to complete the sense. This disregard occurs because of the nonmanifestation of bhakti’s intrinsic power within them, and hence there is nothing to prevent them from unintentionally disrespecting You. Additionally, even though they may have burnt all their sinful reactions, their latent predispositions for enjoyment sprout up once again due to offending the supremely powerful lotus feet of Bhagavan. ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç - ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•Æ‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ- ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à ‡§® ‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•Æ‡•Ø ‡•• A statement to this effect is found in the Bhagavat-parisista cited in the VƒÅsanƒÅ-bhƒÅ·π£ya: Even jivan-muktas fall into the bondage of karma again if they become offenders to Bhagavan, who has inconceivable supreme power. (Bhagavat-parisista)1 Therefore, in the same book, it is also said: Sometimes, jƒ´van-muktas are beset with desires that pertain to conditional existence (samsara). But yogis who are exclusively devoted to Bhagavan are never implicated by the reactions of their karma. (Bhagavat-parisista)1o ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∞‡§•‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç - 17 18 jivan-muktƒÅ api punar bandhanam yanti karmabhi·∏• yady acintya-maha-saktau bhagavaty aparƒÅdhina·∏• jivan-mukta·∏• prapadyante kvacit samsara-vƒÅsanƒÅm yogino vai na lipyante karmabhir bhagavat-parƒÅ·∏• 644 111 Bhakti Is the Intrinsic Duty of Everyone In the Vis≈Üu-bhakti-candrodaya, the following verse is cited from another Purana in regard to the Rathayatra festival: ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•Ø‡•¶ ‡•• A person who out of delusion does not follow Parame≈õvara while He rides in His chariot becomes a brahma-rƒÅk·π£asa [the ghost of a brƒÅhma·πáa who led an unholy life], even if he had previously burnt all his karma in the fire of j√±ƒÅna. (Visnu-bhakti-candrodaya)19 ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•à‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•©‡•§‡•Ø‡•§‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Thus, in ≈örimad Bhagavata, Brahma also says: “We bow down to You again and again, Bhagavan, who are disregarded by those who are destined for hell and who are committed to an illogical perspective that fails to accommodate the Absolute as personal God” (SB 3.9.4).20 ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•ß‡•´ ) - Consequently, Bhagavan Krsna instructed Uddhava as follows: 19 ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ | ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ú ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•Ø‡•ß ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Therefore, O Uddhava, directly intuiting your authentic self up to the stage of immediate awareness, and being endowed with knowledge and realization, worship Me with devotion. (SB 11.19.5)21 nƒÅnuvrajati yo mohad vrajantam parame≈õvaram j√§√§n√§gni-dagdha-karm√§pi sa bhaved brahma-raksasah 20 tasmai namo bhagavate nuvidhema tubhyam 21 yo’nad·πõto naraka-bhagbhir asat-prasangai·∏• The compound asat-prasangai·∏• is glossed by Sridhara SvƒÅmƒ´ as nirisvara-kutarka-nisthaih. The above translation has been rendered accordingly. See Bhagavat Sandarbha (Anuccheda 51) for further elaboration of this verse. tasmƒÅj j√±ƒÅnena sahitam j√±ƒÅtva svƒÅtmƒÅnam uddhava j√±ƒÅna-vij√±ƒÅna-sampanno bhaja mam bhakti-bh√§vita·∏• 645 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• Thus, it is certainly concluded that bhakti to Bhagavan Hari is the perpetual and invariable duty for all people. Commentary ≈öRI JIVA GOSVƒÄMI began this book by analyzing the root cause of the living being’s entanglement in conditional existence (samsara). He concluded that it is due to the beginningless prior absence of awareness of the Absolute Reality, which also includes ignorance of the individual self’s own true nature. It naturally follows then that the solution to the problem is to become established in imme- diate awareness of the Absolute. Such direct knowing is possible only through bhakti. Therefore, bhakti is the means (abhidheya) that must be adopted by everyone to attain the supreme goal of life. To support this proposition, ≈örƒ´ Jiva Prabhu undertook an anal- ysis of the teachings of the major speakers throughout ≈örƒ´mad Bhagavata. This was completed in Anuccheda 92. After this, in the next two anucchedas, he showed that this conclusion is not just the opinion of Srimad Bhagavata alone but also of other scrip- tures. Then, from Anucchedas 95-98, he demonstrated that even when other processes, such as var·πáƒÅ≈õrama-dharma, j√±ƒÅna-yoga, and a·π£·π≠ƒÅnga-yoga are prescribed in the scriptures, their intention is to lead one to bhakti. Without bhakti, none of these paths can award their designated fruits. In Anucchedas 99-105, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va established bhakti as the abhi- dheya by negative concomitance (vyatireka), through the disregard expressed for the paths of karma, j√±ƒÅna, and yoga. Then, in Anucche- das 106-110, he again established bhakti as the abhidheya through vyatireka, by demonstrating the futility of taking shelter of any other deva. Now, in the present anuccheda, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va summarizes his conclusion with reference to both types of statements, anvaya as well as vyatireka, drawn from different scriptures. Many of these verses have already been cited earlier in this book. 646 111 Bhakti Is the Intrinsic Duty of Everyone He begins by quoting two verses from Bhagavad Gƒ´tƒÅ, wherein ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa explicitly states that a bhakti-yogi is superior to all other yogis. In the second of the two verses, the word yoginƒÅm, lit., “of all yogis,” is in the genitive case22 The immediate reading of the verse would indicate that K·πõ·π£·πáa’s intention in using the genitive case is to show that the bhaktas are the best of all those belonging to the same class of entities, namely, the yogis. The ablative case, on the other hand, is used to compare two different categories of objects or entities. ≈örƒ´ Jiva comments that in this instance the genitive case should be taken in the sense of the ablative, yogibhya·∏•, “[greater] than all yogis.” The reason for this is that in the previous verse, K·πõ·π£·πáa had used the ablative repeatedly to point out the yogis’ superiority to other kinds of spiritual practitioners. To maintain logical and syn- tactical consistency, the same case should also have been used in the second verse. Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi comments in this way so as to dis- pel the idea that a bhakti-yogi is merely another kind of yogi. In comparative constructions, the genitive case is used to specify the superlative within a given class, whereas the ablative is used to indicate categorical superiority23 Thus, by taking the word yogi- nƒÅm in the sense of yogibhyah, the bhakta is shown to belong to an altogether distinct classification, “superior to all yogis,” which nec- essarily includes all the various types of practitioners listed in the previous verse as well as those mentioned in the fourth chapter. After this, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va cites K·πõ·π£·πáa’s instruction to Uddhava and ≈örƒ´ NƒÅrada’s instruction to King Yudhisthira on var·πáƒÅ≈õrama. They out- line the respective duties (dharmas) that pertain to the different varnas and asramas. Bhakti, however, is the common duty of all human beings regardless of social classification. There are certain codes of behavior that are meant to be observed at all times (yama), and others that are to be followed occasionally (niyama). Bhakti is 22 tapasvibhyo’dhiko yogi j√±ƒÅnibhyo’pi mato’dhika·∏• karmibhyas cadhiko yogi tasmad yogi bhavarjuna yoginƒÅm api sarve·π£ƒÅm mad-gaten√§ntar-ƒÅtmanƒÅ ≈õraddh√§v√§n bhajate yo mam sa me yuktatamo matah 23 See HarinƒÅmƒÅm·πõta-vyakarana (4.140), sƒÅmƒÅnyato vise·π£asya nirddhara·πáe ≈üa≈üthi-saptamyau vi≈°esatas cet pa√±camy eva. 647 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya the regular obligatory duty for everyone and is therefore called a nitya-dharma. If one does not follow it, one becomes implicated in detrimental reactions. There is no alternative to bhakti. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va cites various statements to this effect. Even elevated j√±ƒÅnis, who have attained the state of living liber- ation (jƒ´van-mukti), can fall from their exalted status if they com- mit offenses toward Bhagavan or disregard the principles of bhakti. This is almost certainly the case for nondevotee j√±ƒÅnis, because they can commit offenses to Bhagavan or His devotees inadvertently. Being devoid of prema-bhakti, they would not be guided by bhakti’s intrinsic power. This shows that bhakti is compulsory for everyone. A doubt may be raised in this regard. Earlier, it was stated that bhakti is highly confidential (guhya). Even the twelve mahajanas, who are in full awareness of bhakti, do not reveal it to everyone. So if bhakti is established as compulsory for all, how then can it be kept confidential? The answer is that bhakti is confidential for those who do not have faith in it. For them, bhakti cannot be disclosed all at once. If faithless people are instructed about the glory of bhakti, they will only deride it and become further entangled by virtue of their offense. Their condition is comparable to a child who is so sick that he cannot even assimilate the medicine that can cure his illness. In this state, the child is given a very light diet or is fed intravenously so that he can gain some strength before being administered the medicine. The prescription of karma-yoga is for such people. Once a person has attained faith in bhakti by the grace of a devotee, he should abandon karma-yoga and take to bhakti (SB 11.20.9). 648 Anuccheda 112 Bhakti Persists Even beyond Liberation ‡•ß‡•ß‡•® ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ç‡§®‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•™ ‡•§ ‡•®‡•´) - SCRIPTURES Confirm that bhakti persists even after the heart is freed from all predispositions toward conditional action (karma ƒÅ≈õaya) through the dawning of divine love (prema ). Sri Bhagavan informs Uddhava of this as follows: ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•á‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•Ø‡•® ‡•• Just as gold, when smelted by fire, discards the dross and attains its original pure state, so too by My bhakti-yoga, the self casts aside the predispositions toward conditional action and, there- after, becomes perfectly established in divine service to Me. (SB 11.14.25 ) 1 ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡•ç‡§£‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•≠‡•§‡•®‡•ß ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä- ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• The meaning of this statement is that in the manner described, the ƒÅtmƒÅ, which here refers to the individual self ( jƒ´va), casts 1 yath√§gnina hema malam jah√§ti dhmatam punah sva·πÅ bhajate ca rupam atma ca karmanusayam vidh≈´ya mad-bhakti-yogena bhajaty atho mƒÅm In his Krama-sandarbha commentary on this verse, ≈örƒ´ Jiva glosses the verb bhajati, “he worships,” as “he attains the completion stage of divine service through the appearance of supreme love” (maha-premƒÅvirbhƒÅvƒÅt p≈´r·πáƒÅ·πÅ seva-paddhatir prƒÅpnotity arthah). 649 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya aside the predispositions toward conditional action (karma- asayam) by the dawning of divine love (prema) for Bhagavan. Thereafter, he attains his pure liberated form and identity (≈õuddha-svarupam) and renders service to Bhagavan. This is referred to in a statement of Sarvaj√±a Muni, cited by ≈öridhara Svami in his commentary on ≈örimad Bhagavata: “Even liberated beings accept a body out of their will and worship Bhagavan” (BhƒÅvƒÅrtha-dipikƒÅ 10.87.21)2 Commentary ONE of the meanings of the word yoga is “a means,” or in other words, that which is undertaken to attain some particular result. This is the implication of the word yoga in the compound karma- yoga (i.e., karma as a means either to fulfill, or to become puri- fied of, one’s material desires) and in the compound j√±ƒÅna-yoga (i.e., j√±ƒÅna as a means to attain mukti). A means generally refers to that which comes to an end when the destination is reached, like boarding a ship to cross the ocean. Once a person arrives on the other continent, the ship has no further utility for them. Accordingly, karma-yoga, j√±ƒÅna-yoga, and raja-yoga or a·π£·π≠ƒÅnga- yoga come to an end once their ultimate goal has been attained. This, however, is not the case with bhakti. Rather, bhakti is inten- sified all the more as one progresses on the path. Once a devotee has attained prema, then bhakti becomes his or her very existence. It is so enchanting that even liberated ƒÅtmƒÅrƒÅmas, who delight in the self alone, become attracted to it, as happened in the case of ≈öukadeva GosvƒÅmi and the four KumƒÅras. 650 mukta api lilaya vigraham k·πõtva bhagavantam bhajante. This parenthetical comment comes from the Puri Dasa edition. Anuccheda 113 Bhakti Is Incumbent Even upon the Devas ‡•ß‡•ß‡•© ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á- ‚Äî IN the Reva-khanda of the Skanda PurƒÅ·πáa, we find even the following type of statement: ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§§‡§¶‡•à‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ö‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ ‡•• ‡•®‡•Ø‡•© ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•Ø‡•™ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ O Kesava ! Indra, Mahe≈õvara [Siva], BrahmƒÅ, and even a dog- eater become Param-brahma at the precise moment when You become pleased with them. On the other hand, O Acyuta, BrahmƒÅ, ≈öiva, and the other gods, all become lower than a dog- eater at that very moment when You turn away from them. (Skanda PurƒÅna, RevƒÅ khanda ) 1 ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§π ‚Äú‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•å‡§ö‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•©‡•§‡•®‡•Æ‡•§‡•®‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Bhagavan Kapila also spoke in a similar vein: “≈öiva became siva, or ‘auspicious,’ by accepting upon his head the sacred water of 1 indro mahesvaro brahma param brahma tadaiva hi svapaco’pi bhavaty eva yada tu≈üto’si kesava svapacad apak·πõ·π£·π≠atvam brahme≈õƒÅnƒÅdaya·∏• surah tadaivacyuta yanty ete yadaiva tvam paranmukha·∏• 651I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya the Ganga, which is the best of rivers, because it issued forth from the water that washed the feet of Bhagavan” (SB 3.28.22)2 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ The meaning of this statement is self-evident. ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•á “‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•≠‡•§‡•®‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§∏‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡•• Thus, the fact that bhakti is the perpetual and invariable sup- reme duty for all is another reason why it has been estab- lished as the abhidheya. Later, in verses such as SB 10.87.20, bhakti alone will be demonstrated as the constitutional state (svabhƒÅva-siddha) of the living beings. Commentary ≈öRI JIVA shows from yet another perspective that bhakti is the eter- nal supreme duty for all classes of living entities. The purport of the verses from Skanda Purana is that even Brahma and Siva, who are foremost among all the devas and perfect beings, engage in bhakti. Their eminence is only because of their devotion to K·πõ·π£·πáa. So, if bhakti is incumbent even upon the greatest of the devas, it is cer- tainly to be taken up by all beings whatsoever. This is what ≈örƒ´ Jiva intends to show. The word siva means “auspicious.” ≈öiva is auspicious because he reverentially accepted on his head the Ganga River, which issued forth from the foot-wash of Vamanadeva. Prior to this event, King Bhagiratha had undertaken severe penances to bring down the Ganga from the celestial sphere to earth. Being pleased with his devotion, Ganga-devƒ´, the personified Goddess of the river, agreed to his proposal. She cautioned the king, however, that without someone to bear the tremendous force of her descent, she would pierce right through the core of the earth planet and carry on yac-chauca-ni·∏•srta-sarit-pravarodakena tirthena murdhny adhik·πõtena sivah sivo bhut 652 113 Bhakti Is Incumbent Even upon the Devas T down to the subterranean realms. Then, on Bhagiratha’s request, ≈öiva agreed to accept the Ganga on his head, knowing well that she is the sacred foot-wash of Visnu. Because bhakti is the eternal dharma for all beings, it naturally follows that bhakti is the abhidheya. To engage in the service of Bha- gavan is the jivas’ natural state, because all jivas are intrinsic parts of Bhagavan. By its constitutional or existential makeup, a part is meant to be of service to the whole, just as the cells in the body exist only for the sake of the body. They do not have any independent purpose. So too the jivas exist exclusively for the pleasure of Bhaga- van. The glory of a jƒ´va culminates in the acceptance of this natural status by engaging in bhakti. Otherwise, one is tossed about in the ocean of material existence. 653 Bhakti Established by the Hermeneutics of ≈örƒ´mad BhƒÅgavata Anucchedas 114-120 Anuccheda 114 Bhakti Established by the Sixfold Hermeneutical Criteria - Sad-linga ‡•ß‡•ß‡•™ | ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•à‡§∞‡§µ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã- ‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ “‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•ß‡•ß‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á “‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø” ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ IN THIS manner, by the auxiliary import (avantara-tƒÅtparya) of Srimad Bhagavata, bhakti alone is understood to be the abhi- dheya through the six hermeneutical criteria as well (sad-linga). By the concurrence of the BhƒÅgavata’s opening and conclud- ing statements, which is the first of these six criteria, bhakti is shown to be the abhidheya, as presently elaborated. In the open- ing verse (upakrama-padye), the following supplication is made: “Let us meditate on the Supreme Absolute Truth, from whom ensue the evolution, sustenance, and dissolution of this cosmos” (janmady asya yata·∏• … satyam param dhimahi, SB 1.1.1)? The sixfold criteria by which the import of a text can be ascertained are as follows: (1) upakrama-upasamhƒÅra, concurrence of the opening and closing statements, (2) abhyasa, repetition of the subject throughout the text, (3) ap≈´rvatƒÉ, novel disclosure pertaining to the subject under discussion, (4) phala, specification of the end to be attained, (5) arthavada, glorification of the subject, and (6) upapatti, logical confirmation. There are two primary questions to be examined here: What is meant by param satyam, or “the Supreme Absolute Truth,” and what does the process of meditation (dhimahi) on the Absolute involve? By first establishing that the Absolute Truth being referred to is Bhagavan, it naturally follows that meditation on Him is nothing other than bhakti, of which, dhyana, or‚Üí 657 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å “‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á” (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠- ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç “‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç” (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•≠ ‡•≠) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å “‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç” (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•™ ‡•§ ‡•®‡•≠) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§™‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ- ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å- ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•á (‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶‡•™) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ In this connection, it is affirmed in Gƒ™TƒÄ 12.1-5, in response to Arjuna’s opening question, that meditation (dhyana) is effected without difficulty only in regard to Sri Bhagavan and that those who meditate on Him are the most elevated in yoga. Then, by K·πõ·π£·πáa’s assertions that “There is no truth superior to Me” (mattah parataram nanyat ki√±cit, Gƒ™TƒÄ 7.7) and that “I am the support of Brahman” (brahmano hi pratisthƒÅham, Gƒ™TƒÄ 14.27), the highest conception of the Absolute, indicated by the word para [in satyam param dhimahi, SB 1.1.1], culminates in the form of Sri Bhagavan alone. Additionally, because of His omniscience and omnipotence, He alone can be the source of the evolution, sustenance, and dissolution of this cosmos. From all of this rea- soning, it is concluded that meditation on ≈öri Bhagavan alone [and therefore bhakti] is what is ordained in the opening verse. This verse [SB 1.1.1] was explained in precisely the same manner in ParamƒÅtma Sandarbha (Anuccheda 105). “‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•® ‡•ß‡•ß‡•© ‡•ß‡•ß‡•Ø) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§™- ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø “‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø” ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö “‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•ß‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ In the concluding verse (upasa·πÅhara-padye) of Srimad BhƒÅga- vata as well, the same supplication is repeated: “Let us medi- tate on the Supreme Absolute Truth (satyam param dhimahi), who in the beginning revealed this peerless lamp of knowl- edge [i.e., Srimad Bhagavata] unto Brahma” (SB 12.13.19). Hence, “meditation,” is one component. This is the analysis now being undertaken by ≈öri Jiva. kasmai yena vibhƒÅsito’yam atulo jnana-pradipa·∏•… satyam param dhimahi In Srimad Bhagavata, Twelfth Canto, chapter 13, there are four remaining verses after the one quoted here. So in Sri Jiva’s statement, the words 658 114 Bhakti Established by the Sixfold Hermeneutical Criteria - Sad-linga from this statement, it is unmistakably evident that the Sup- reme Absolute Truth (satyam param) to be meditated upon is ≈örƒ´ Bhagavan, because He is the one who spoke the BhƒÅgavata to BrahmƒÅ. The same point was made in the opening verse, “It is He only who first revealed the Veda to the first seer [Brahma] by way of the heart” (SB 1.1.1).” ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ By the second criterion for determining the import of scrip- ture, namely, repetition of the subject throughout the text (abhyasa), bhakti is established as the abhidheya. We have already cited numerous examples of how bhakti is repeated throughout Srimad Bhagavata, and many more examples have been left without mention. ‡§Ö‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§´‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•å ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§™‡§∂‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•≠‡•§‡•¨) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ By the third and fourth criteria for determining the import of scripture, namely, novel disclosures regarding the recom- mended process (ap≈´rvatƒÅ) and specification of the end state to be obtained through unfoldment of the means (phala), bhakti is shown to be the abhidheya in the samadhi of ≈örƒ´ VyƒÅsa, as expressed in the following words: “≈örƒ´ VyƒÅsa saw that the yoga of unalloyed devotion to Bhagavan, who is beyond the purview of the senses, is the direct means to extinguish the miseries of material existence … Indeed, in the very act of receptively and attentively hearing this Srimad BhƒÅgavata, bhakti [i.e., prema- bhakti] for ≈öri Krsna, the Supreme Purusa, self-manifests in a person’s heart” (SB 1.7.6-7).5 $ upasamhƒÅra-padye, “in the concluding verse,” refer to one of the concluding verses. tene brahma h·πõda ya adi-kavaye Thus, the opening and closing statements of Srimad Bhagavata concur that the Absolute Truth (satyam param) is Bhagavan and that bhakti, characterized by meditation on Him (dhyƒÅna), is the abhidheya, the prescribed means for His attainment. anarthopa≈õama·πÅ sƒÅk·π£ad bhakti-yogam adhoksaje‚Üí 659 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ By the fifth criterion for determining the import of scripture, namely, the subject glorified throughout the text (arthavƒÅda), bhakti is established as the abhidheya. As in the case of the sec- ond criterion (abhyƒÅsa), many examples of such glorification can be found here and there throughout Srimad Bhagavata. ‡§â‡§™‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö “‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•ß‡•® ‡•ß‡•©‡•≠) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ And by the sixth criterion, namely, logical reasoning (upapa- tti), bhakti is established as the abhidheya. There are many statements in which logical reasoning is employed, such as the following: The living entity’s non-recognition of its intrinsic nature (asmrti) that occurs through the influence of BhagavƒÅn’s extrin- sic potency (tan-mƒÅyayƒÅ) is rooted in the perpetual diverting of regard away from Him (isad apetasya). As a consequence of this non-recognition, the jiva’s self-concept is reversed (viparyaya), meaning that he becomes identified with the body instead. This reversal of identity in turn results in the absorption in that which is secondary (dvitƒ´yƒÅbhinive≈õa), meaning preoccupation with the body and its relations. It is from this absorption in the secondary that fear then arises. Therefore, one whose aware- ness has been awakened, regarding his spiritual preceptor as a direct embodiment of the Divine and as his dearest self, …yasyƒÅm vai ≈õr≈´yamƒÅ·πáƒÅyƒÅm k·πõ·π£·πáe parama-puru≈üe bhaktir utpadyate pumsa·∏•… In S8 1.7.6, bhakti is shown to be the abhidheya by the novel disclosure (ap≈´rvatƒÅ) that bhakti is the direct means to extinguish the miseries of material existence. Then, in SB 1.7.7, bhakti is shown to be the abhidheya by the specification of the end state (phala), i.e., prema, to be attained through unfoldment of the means. Although ≈öri Jiva quotes only the first quarter of SB 1.7.6, the words ity adi, “and so on,” are to be understood as referring to SB 1.7.7 as well, since the fruit of prema is clearly expressed therein. That the end state (phala) is explicitly stated in SB 1.7.7 (and not SB 1.7.6) is understood from the opening words of Sri Jiva’s Krama-sandarbha commentary on this verse. He begins, “Now this verse [SB 1.7.7] is spoken to make evident the goal to be attained” (atha prayojana·πÅ ca spa≈ütayitum…). 660 114 Bhakti Established by the Sixfold Hermeneutical Criteria - ≈ûad-linga turns his intentful regard in worship of Bhagavan, through the conscious medium of one-pointed devotion. (SB 11.2.37) ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‚Äú‡§á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•®‡•® ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ Here, in ≈örimad Bhagavata, by the principle of gati-sƒÅmƒÅnya as well, or “the universal concordance of all scriptures,” bhakti is established as the abhidheya. This is illustrated in statements such as the following: The realized mystic poets (kavis) have concluded that the description of the attributes of Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa, who is glorified in chosen verses, is indeed the unceasing [i.e., eternal] fruit of a human being’s austerities, study of the Vedas, sacrifice, recitation of mantras, knowledge, and charity. (SB 1.5.22)” ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§π ‚Äú‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ñ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§É " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•©‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•ß‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ The same idea is expressed in Vidura’s statement to Maitreya: “The sage K·πõ·π£·πáa Dvaipayana Vyasa, who is also your friend, transmitted the Mahabharata with the sole intent of describing the qualities of Bhagavan” (SB 3.5.12). ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§É ‡•• The meaning is self-evident. 6 7 8 bhayam dvitiyƒÅbhinive≈õatah syad isad apetasya viparyayo’sm·πõti·∏• tan-mayayƒÅto budha abhajet tam bhaktyaikayesam guru-devatƒÅtmƒÅ In this verse, the word atah, “therefore,” [in tan-mayaya-ata·∏•] introduces the conclusion that is to be drawn from the logical sequence of thought presented in the first half of the verse. Hence, in this verse, bhakti is concluded to be the means through analytic reasoning. idam hi pumsas tapasa·∏• ≈õrutasya va svi·π£·π≠asya s≈´ktasya ca buddhi-dattayo·∏• avicyuto’rthah kavibhir nirupito yad uttamasloka-gunƒÅnuvar·πáanam munir vivak·π£ur bhagavad-gunƒÅnƒÅm sakhapi te bhƒÅratam aha k·πõ·π£·πáa·∏• 661Commentary 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ≈öRƒ™ JIVA GOSVƒÄMƒ™ takes pains to ensure that no scope is left for any trace of doubt regarding bhakti’s status as the only abhidheya, the prescribed means to attain the perfection of human life. In this anuccheda, he employs the hermeneutics of P≈´rva-mƒ´mƒÅmsƒÅ to establish this point. The methodical strategy devised by Purva-mƒ´mƒÅmsƒÅ for the interpretation of scripture submits that one can ascertain the essential subject of any Vedic text by examining six criteria, known as sad-linga: (1) upakrama-upasamhƒÅra, the opening and closing statements; (2) abhyasa, repetition of the subject; (3) ap≈´rvatƒÅ, extraordinary claims regarding the subject; (4) phala, specifica- tion of the results to be obtained; (5) arthavada, glorification of the subject; and (6) upapatti, logical reasoning to establish a con- clusion. Each of these criteria points to bhakti-yoga, the practice of devotion to God, as the intended abhidheya of Srimad Bhagavata. ≈örƒ´ Jiva illustrates each of these with citations from the text. In addition to these six criteria, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va also establishes bhakti as the abhidheya by the hermeneutical principle known as gati- sƒÅmƒÅnya, or “the universal concordance of all sastras.” Since Bhaga- vƒÅn is the source of all the Vedas, the PurƒÅ≈Üas, and the Itihasas, it is perfectly fitting that they would share a common import. This is the logical strategy known as gati-sƒÅmƒÅnya-nyƒÅya, as established in Vedanta-sutra.” The word gati here means “conception,” samanya means “common,” and nyaya means “a principle.” Hence, taken as a whole, the compound gati-samanya-nyaya refers to the principle that there is a common subject described throughout all ≈õƒÅstras. From the two verses cited in this anuccheda (SB 1.5.22 and SB 3.5.12), it is clear that the intent of all the Vedas as well as the Mahabharata is to disclose Krsna as the Supreme Absolute Truth and bhakti as the means of attainment. The fact that Krsna is the 9 ‚ö´ upakramopasa·πÅharau abhyaso’purvatƒÅ phalam 10 11 arthavadopapatti ca lingam tatparya-nirnaye See Tattva Sandarbha (Anucchedas 12-14). gati-samanyat (vs 1.1.10) 662 114 Bhakti Established by the Sixfold Hermeneutical Criteria - ≈ûad-linga ultimate object to be known is also supported by S≈´ta GosvƒÅmi’s statement, “The Vedas are exclusively intent upon Bhagavan Vasu- deva” (vasudeva-parƒÅ vedƒÅ, SB 1.2.28), and by Krsna’s own state- ment, “I alone am to be known through all the Vedas” (vedais ca sarvair aham eva vedyah, Gƒ™TƒÄ 15.15). Bhagavan in general, or ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa in particular, is known only through bhakti, bhaktyƒÅ- ham ekayƒÅ grƒÅhya·∏• (SB 11.14.21). Thus, it naturally follows that the abhidheya prescribed in all sastras must be bhakti. 663 Anuccheda 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya 115.1 The Abhidheyatva of Bhakti As a Primary Topic of ≈örƒ´mad BhƒÅgavata ‡•ß‡•ß‡•´ ‡•§ ‡§á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‚Äú‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•à‡§§‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•§‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö” ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•ß‡•¶‡•§‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§¶‡§∂‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø “‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•ß‡•ß‡•¶‡•§‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ IT IS THIS very bhakti that is referred to [as parama-dharma] in the following statement: “In this Srimad Bhagavata, the sup- reme essential duty (parama-dharma) of those who are free from envy and established in the state of authentic being is disclosed, utterly devoid of all deception” (SB 1.1.2)! Bhakti, specified as sad-dharma, or “the path of authentic religion” (in SB 2.10.4) is also included as one of the ten primary topics of ≈örimad Bhagavata, enumerated in SB 2.10.12 1 2 dharma·∏• projjhita-kaitavo tra paramo nirmatsarƒÅ·πáƒÅm satƒÅm atra sargo visargas ca sthanam posanam ≈´taya·∏• manvantaresanukatha nirodho muktir asraya·∏• In this list of ten topics from SB 2.10.1, the sixth, namely, manvantara, is concerned with sad-dharma, or “the path of authentic religion,” as illustrated three verses later in SB 2.10.4. ≈örƒ´ Jiva comments that the term sad-dharma, mentioned in the latter verse, refers to bhakti, thus establishing bhakti as one of the ten primary topics of Srimad Bhagavata. This point is elaborated further in the commentary. 664 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya Commentary UP TO THE previous anuccheda, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ established bhakti as the abhidheya by an analysis of the statements of the primary teachers throughout Srimad Bhagavata, both from the perspective of affirmation and negation. He also showed the inadequacy of devotion that is directed not to Bhagavan but to the devas instead. Bhakti was also demonstrated as the abhidheya by the lack of regard expressed for other paths. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va then established that bhakti is an eternal path. It is not given up even after attaining the per- fected state of prema. In the previous anuccheda, ≈örƒ´ Jiva analyzed the import of Srimad Bhagavata from the six hermeneutical crite- ria known as ≈üad-linga. From this perspective as well, bhakti is val- idated as the abhidheya. This is the universally concordant view of all scriptures, gati-sƒÅmƒÅnya. Now, in this anuccheda, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va shows that bhakti is the abhi- dheya implicit in the very design of Srimad BhƒÅgavata. In the begin- ning of an educational text or scripture, the author elaborates four topics, called anubandha-catu·π£·π≠aya, one of which is the abhidheya, or “the prescribed means of attaining the subject under study in the book.” According to Purva-mƒ´mƒÅmsƒÅ, there are five types of statements found in the Vedas, namely, vidhi (injunctions), ni≈üe- dha (prohibitions), mantra (hymns), n√§madheya (names of sacri- fices), and arthavada (commendatory passages). Among these five, the vidhi statements are primary, whereas the remaining four are subsidiary to and supportive of the injunctions. Any statement other than a vidhi must be applied to a vidhi. The purpose of the Vedas is to delineate dharma, which is in the form of an injunc- tion (codana-lak·π£ano’rtho dharma·∏•, Jaimini-sutra 1.1.2). Therefore, abhidheya, or “the prescribed means,” which is synonymous with dharma and vidhi, is the most important of the four topics specified in the opening portion of a book. The abhidheya is referred to in the second verse of the BhƒÅga- vata as parama-dharma, “the supreme essential duty.” This parama- dharma is nothing but bhakti, as evidenced from the discussion of verses such as this: 665 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya That alone is humanity’s supreme essential duty (para-dharma) by which causeless, unobstructed bhakti to Adhok·π£aja, ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa, can come into being, as a consequence of which the self is completely fulfilled. (SB 1.2.6)3 Apart from bhakti’s being specified as the abhidheya in the book’s introduction, it is also included in the ten primary topics of Srimad BhƒÅgavata. Sukadeva, the principal speaker of the BhƒÅga- vata, points out that the book consists of ten topics (SB 2.10.1). The sixth of these is manvantara, or “the religious path enacted by the Manus.” Of all the ten topics, this is the one that is directly con- cerned with abhidheya, or the means of attainment. To make this all the more evident, Sukadeva then defines the word manvantara as sad-dharma, “the path of authentic religion,” three verses later (SB 2.10.4). A manvantara consists of one-fourteenth part of a day of Brahma. The management of the lower realm of the universe changes in each manvantara. The purpose of this system is to prop- agate and maintain sad-dharma, which is synonymous with the term parama-dharma, or bhakti. This is summed up in the follow- ing statement: “The topic of manvantara is concerned with the path of authentic religion (sad-dharma) [or the religious path (dharma) of those established in authentic being (sat)]” (manvantarƒÅni sad-dharma, SB 2.10.4). This sad-dharma is none other than bhakti. Thus, bhakti is also established as the abhidheya by its inclusion within the ten primary topics of ≈örƒ´mad Bhagavata. This is also confirmed by S≈´ta GosvƒÅmƒ´, the speaker, while providing a summary of the complete book in the second to last chapter. Therein, he says that bhakti-yoga has been described elaborately throughout this book (SB 12.12.5). 3 sa vai pumsƒÅm paro dharmo yato bhaktir adhoksaje ahaituky apratihata yayƒÅtmƒÅ suprasƒ´dati See Anuccheda 3. 666 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya 115.2 The Abhidheyatva of Bhakti in the Catu·∏•-≈õloki ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•Ø‡•§‡•©‡•´) - Bhakti is demonstrated to be the abhidheya of Srimad Bhagavata in the book’s four seed verses (catu·∏•-sloki) as well [SB 2.9.32- 35]. [Bhakti is specifically indicated in the final verse from this group:] ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ ‡•• ‡•®‡•Ø‡•´ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ This alone [etavad eva, i.e., sadhana-bhakti], which is encoun- tered everywhere (sarvatra) and at all times (sarvadƒÅ) and which is established both through affirmation (anvaya) and negation (vyatireka), should be inquired into (jij√±ƒÅsyam) by one who is inquisitive to realize the truth of the Self [i.e., the mystery (rahasya) of prema for the Self, Bhagavan]. (SB 2.9.35)* ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§¶‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•á (‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡•¶ ‡•Ø‡•¨) ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ- ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ö “‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡•§ Prior to and by way of introduction to these four seed verses, Bhagavan declared that He would expound only four topics - transcendental knowledge of the Absolute (j√±ƒÅna); immediate realization of the same Truth (vij√±ƒÅna); the confidential mys- tery [of prema for the Absolute as Bhagavan] (rahasya); and its intrinsic part [in the form of sadhana-bhakti] (tad-anga) [SB 2.9.30]. Of these four topics, the first three were described respectively in the first three verses of the catu·∏•-sloki, as explained in Bhagavat Sandarbha (Anuccheda 96). In this con- text, the word rahasya, “the confidential mystery,” refers to prema-bhakti, or devotion in the perfectional stage of divine etavad eva jij√±ƒÅsyam tattva-jij√±ƒÅsunƒÅtmana·∏• anvaya-vyatirekƒÅbhyam yat syat sarvatra sarvadƒÅ 667 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya love, while tad-anga, “the intrinsic part of that mystery,” refers to sadhana-bhakti, or devotion in the stage of practice. ≈örƒ´- dhara SvƒÅmi also confirms the same in his commentary: “The word rahasyam means ‘bhakti,’ and tad-anga means ‘sadhana,’ or devotion in the stage of practice.” ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß | ‡•ß‡•™ | ‡•© ) - ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∏‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§É ‡•• ‡•®‡•Ø‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§ö ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ Thus, according to the order of the topics discussed in the catu·∏•- ≈õloki, and according to Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa’s statement cited hereafter, it is specifically sadhana-bhakti that is elaborated in the fourth seed verse quoted above [SB 2.9.35]: In due course of time, this speech of Mine, known as the Veda, remained undisclosed during the period of dissolution. In it, the dharma that is entailed is constituted of the very essence of My Being (mad-atmaka·∏•). It was spoken by Me once again to Brahma at the beginning of a new evolutionary cycle. (SB 11.14.3) ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø- ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§ø- ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡•á- ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ? ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§£ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ß‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ We are examining this verse [SB 2.9.35] again here in order to expand on the explanation [given previously in Bhagavat

The footnote to SB 11.14.3 in Anuccheda 76 may be referred to here for an explanation of the words mad-atmakah dharmah. As in SB 2.9.35, also spoken by Krsna, this expression is another veiled reference to bhakti, being the functional essence (atmakah) of Bhagavan’s intrinsic potency (svarupa-sakti), predominated by hladini. ‚ö´ kalena na·π£·π≠ƒÅ pralaye vaniyam veda-sanjnitƒÅ mayadau brahmane prokta dharmo yasyam mad-atmaka·∏• 668 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya Sandarbha, Anuccheda 96]? The word atmana·∏•, “of the Self,” means, “of Me, Bhagavan.” The compound tattva-jij√±ƒÅsunƒÅ, ‚Äúby one who is inquisitive to realize the truth of the Self,” means, “by one who aspires to experience directly the mystery of divine love” [for Bhagavan]. The phrase etavad eva jij√±ƒÅsyam, “this alone should be inquired into,” means that this topic alone is worthy of being learned from an authentic spiritual preceptor (≈örƒ´ Guru). And what is that? The one [method, i.e., s√§dhana- bhakti], which is encountered (syat, i.e., upapadyate) [every- where (sarvatra) and always (sarvada)] and which is estab- lished both “by affirmation” (anvayena), meaning “by direct injunction” (vidhi-mukhena), and “by negation” (vyatireke·πáa), meaning “by prohibition.” 7 8 In Bhagavat Sandarbha, in the beginning of Anuccheda 96, Jiva GosvƒÅmi states that the two words rahasya and tad-anga will be explained later on (agre vyanjayi·π£yate), meaning here in Bhakti Sandarbha. His statement in this regard is as follows: “This confidential mystery (rahasya) is unalloyed devotion in unconditional love (prema-bhakti), as will be elaborated later on. [Krsna continues:] ‘Moreover, embrace also its intrinsic part (tad-anga).’ This [i.e., j√±ƒÅna alone], however, will not quickly disclose immediate realization (vij√±ƒÅna) and the mystery of divine love (rahasya) if obstructed by offenses (aparadha). Therefore, you should also embrace [the intrinsic part of the mystery], which supports the unfolding of that knowledge. This is the sense. This intrinsic part is in the form of sadhana-bhakti, characterized by devotional acts such as hearing and so on. This topic will be elaborated later on” (tac ca [rahasyam] prema-bhakti-rupam ity agre vyanjayisyate. tatha tad-argam ca grhana. tac ca sati tv aparƒÅdhƒÅkhya-vighne na jhatiti vij√±ƒÅna-rahasye prakat·π≠ayet. tasmat tasya j√±ƒÅnasya sahayam ca g·πõhanety arthah. tac ca ≈õravanadi-bhakti-rupam ity agre vyanjayisyate). In Jiva GosvƒÅmi’s statement here, the words sarvatra sarvadƒÉ, “everywhere and at all times,” have been omitted. However, in a nearly identical gloss on the second line of SB 2.9.35 given in Bhagavat Sandarbha (Anuccheda 96), he includes the words sada sarvatra, “always and everywhere,” as part of his elucidation. Borrowing from this statement, we have included these words in the above explanation to complete the sense of the second line of the verse. 669 Commentary I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya After pointing out that bhakti is specified as the abhidheya in the second of the BhƒÅgavata’s opening verses as well as in the ten pri- mary topics discussed in the text, ≈öri Jiva GosvƒÅmi now refers to the BhƒÅgavata’s four seed verses. These verses are the basis of the entire ≈örƒ´mad Bhagavata. The book as a whole is an elaboration of the core ideas contained in these four verses. The first three verses were explained in Bhagavat Sandarbha (Anuccheda 96). Now, in this anuccheda of Bhakti Sandarbha, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va analyzes the last of the four seed verses. These verses were spoken by ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa to Brahma. In one of the two lead-in verses to the catu·∏•-sloki, Krsna informs Brahma that He will speak to him of four items, namely, j√±ƒÅna, vij√±ƒÅna, rahasya, and its anga. These then are the subjects of the four verses of the catu·∏•-sloki, specified as follows: Receive this most confidential knowledge regarding Me (j√±ƒÅna), which includes its immediate realization (vij√±ƒÅna), along with its mystery (rahasya), and the intrinsic part of that mystery (tad-anga), as enunciated by Me. (SB 2.9.30)9 The word j√±ƒÅna is understood here to mean transcendental knowledge pertaining to Bhagavan, or in other words, knowledge of Bhagavan that is disclosed through and as revealed speech. The word vij√±ƒÅna signifies a deeper direct form of cognition of Bhaga- van through immediate intuition. The word rahasya, “the mystery,” implies that even in the immediate intuition of Bhagavan, there is something even more confidential that yet remains concealed. This refers to the state of divine love (prema), which is awareness laden with transcendental affect. The whole point of immediate realiza- tion culminates in the state of prema. Finally, the compound tad- anga, “the intrinsic part of that,” or in other words, “the intrinsic part of the mystery of prema,” refers to sadhana-bhakti, the means by which the rahasya of prema is self-disclosed to the practitioner. 9 jnanam parama-guhyam me yad vij√±ƒÅna-samanvitam sa-rahasyam tad-angam ca grhana gaditam maya 670 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya The fourth item above (tad-anga, i.e., sadhana-bhakti) is spoken of in the fourth verse of the catuh-sloki (SB 2.9.35), which is the subject of discussion throughout the remainder of this anuccheda. ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa declares that this alone (etavad eva) is to be studied or inquired into (jij√±ƒÅsyam). From this statement, it is clearly evident that bhakti is established as the abhidheya in the catuh-sloki. K·πõ·π£·πáa reconfirms the same conclusion in SB 11.14.3, stating that the Vedas are concerned only with that dharma which is constituted of the very essence of His Being (mad-atmaka-dharma), which is bhakti alone. In the fourth seed verse, Krsna indicates bhakti’s universal- ity as the means by saying that it is encountered everywhere and at all times (sarvatra sarvadƒÅ syƒÅt), and that it is established in ≈õƒÅstra both by affirmation and negation (anvaya-vyatirekabhyam). In the ongoing discussion, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va will elaborate on the significance of these words. 115.3 Bhakti Established by Affirmation and Negation ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ " ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•≠‡•§‡•≠‡•§‡•´‡•´) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ In this connection, bhakti is established as the abhidheya by affirmation (anvaya), as in the following statements: Unalloyed devotion (ekƒÅnta-bhakti) to Bhagavan Govinda by which the direct vision of Him is immediately self-disclosed in everything - this alone has been recognized as the ultimate good for human beings in this world. (SB 7.7.55)10 ‚Äú‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Ø‡•§‡•©‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ 10 et√§v√§n eva loke’smin pursa·∏• svartha·∏• parah sm·πõtah ekanta-bhaktir govinde yat sarvatra tad-ik·π£a·πáam There are in fact three verses in the BhƒÅgavata that begin with this same first line, all with roughly the same import, i.e., direct instructions to engage in bhakti. The other instances are SB 3.25.44 and SB 6.3.22, discussed earlier in Anucchedas 47 and 92, respectively. Note the use of the words et√§v√§n eva, “this alone,” which are also found in the catu·∏•-sloki verse under discussion. 671I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya Also in the GitƒÅ: ‚ÄúFix your mind on Me, become My devotee, worship Me, and bow down to Me‚Äù (GITƒÄ 9.34 and 18.65). " ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•®-‡•© ) - Bhakti is also established as the abhidheya through negation (vyatireka), as in the following statements: ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§π ‡•§ ‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç ‡•• ‡•®‡•Ø‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§Ø ‡§è‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§É ‡•§‡•§ ‡•®‡•Ø‡•Æ ‡•§‡•§ From the mouth, arms, thighs, and feet of the Puru≈üa appeared the four respective vocational classifications (varnas) along with the four stages of life (asramas). The varnas were distinc- tively divided into vipra, ksatriya, vaisya, and sudra accord- ing to the corresponding gunas that determine their natures. Among human beings belonging to these divisions, those who [naively] neglect to worship the Puru≈üa, who is directly the primordial ground of being of all individual beings (atma- prabhavam) and the Supreme Immanent Regulator of all being (I≈õvara), or who show Him contempt, are deprived of their status and fall into degradation. (SB 11.5.2 - 3 ) 12 ‚Äú‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§æ‡§É‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•≠ ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•´ ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç ‡§ú‡§®‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∞‡§∏‡•à‡§ï‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç ‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§≤‡§≠‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡•• ‡•®‡•Ø‡•Ø ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§ö ‡•§ Also in the GitƒÅ: 11 Those who are utterly bereft of discrimination, those who are the lowest of men, those whose wisdom has been carried man-manƒÅ bhava mad-bhakto mad-yaji mam namaskuru 12 mukha-bahurupƒÅdebhyah purusasyƒÅ≈õramaih saha catvƒÅro jajnire varna gunair vipradayah prthak ya e·π£ƒÅm puru·π£a·πÅ sƒÅk·π£ad atma-prabhavam isvaram na bhajanty avajananti sthƒÅnƒÅd bhra·π£·π≠a·∏• patanty adhah 672 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya away by maya, and those who have embraced the secularist- all such performers of unmeritorious materialistic nature ‚Äï acts do not take refuge in Me. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 7.15)13 And in the Padma PurƒÅna: On earth, as long as a person does not partake of the ambrosial elixir of the narrations of Visnu-bhakti, which is the sin- gular essence of all aesthetic relish, he is subjected to hun- dreds of attacks of pain in the form of birth, death, and old age proceeding from innumerable bodies. (Padma PurƒÅ·πáa, PƒÅtƒÅla-khanda 85.33)14 Commentary Here, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi continues to analyze the fourth seed verse of the catuh-sloki, which is concerned with sadhana-bhakti as the abhi- dheya, or the means of attaining the mystery of prema. In K·πõ·π£·πáa’s statement, that which is to be inquired into (i.e., the abhidheya) is said to be established in scripture both by affirmation (anvaya) and by negation (vyatireka). In this subsection of Anuccheda 115, ≈örƒ´ Jiva first cites two verses as examples of bhakti being established through affirmation. In the first of these (SB 7.7.55), ekanta-bhakti, or “unalloyed devotion,” is directly stated to be the sole means to the ultimate good and that by which the immediate vision of Bha- gavan is disclosed. In the second verse (Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.34 and 18.65), K·πõ·π£·πáa gives an unequivocal instruction to engage in bhakti. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va then cites three verses establishing bhakti as the abhi- dheya through negation. All three of these verses show the defect of the non-performance of bhakti. It is to be noted that in SB 11.5.3, cited above, sage Camasa informs King Nimi that neglecting to wor- ship Isvara is itself contemptuous and the cause of one’s degrada- tion. K·πõ·π£·πáa refers to all such people as dusk·πõtina, or “performers 13 14 na mƒÅm dusk·πõtino mudhah prapadyante narƒÅdhamah mayayapah·πõta-j√±ana asuram bhavam ƒÅ≈õritƒÅ·∏• yƒÅvaj-jano bhajati na bhuvi vis≈Üu-bhakti-vartta-sudha-rasam ase·π£a-rasaika-s√§ram tƒÅvaj-jarƒÅ-mara·πáa-janma-satƒÅbhighƒÅta-du·∏•khƒÅni tƒÅni labhate bahu-deha-jƒÅni 673 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya of unmeritorious acts” (Gƒ™TƒÄ 7.15). This means that if one neglects to worship Bhagavan, he is engaged in unmeritorious deeds, even if his actions are otherwise accepted as virtuous by society in general. Prahlada has also declared that nondevotees are devoid of illustri- ous or divine qualities (SB 5.18.12). Their so-called admirable qual- ities are congenial only in a relative sense. When viewed from the perspective of life’s ultimate purpose, they are not meritorious at all. In the next subsection, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va will elaborate on the meaning of bhakti’s being encountered “everywhere” (sarvatra). 115.4 Bhakti Is Encountered Everywhere ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ? ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§´‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ Where is bhakti encountered (upapadyate)? “Everywhere” (sarvatra) - in all (1) scriptures (sastra), (2) performers or agents of action (karty), (3) places (desa), (4) senses (karana), (5) objects (dravya), (6) actions (kriya), (7) prescribed duties (kƒÅrya), and (8) results (phala). [We will now examine examples of each of these in sequence.] (‡•ß) ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á - (1) Bhakti is established as the abhidheya in all scriptures (sarva- ≈õƒÅstra), as stated in the Skanda Purana in a dialogue between Brahma and Narada: ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ò‡•ã‡§∞‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•á ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•©‡•¶‡•¶ ‡•• The worship of Bhagavan Vasudeva has been declared by the proponents of various scriptures as the means of deliverance in this terrifying material world, which is beset with birth and death. (Skanda PurƒÅ·πáa)15 15 samsƒÉre’smin mahƒÅghore janma-m·πõtyu-samƒÅkule p√ºjanam vasudevasya tarakam vadibhih sm·πõtam 674 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‚Äú‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ” ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•©‡•™ ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ In the same regard, bhakti is established as the abhidheya in all scriptures by positive concomitance (anvaya), as in the following statement: After thrice studying and deliberating upon the entire corpus of the Vedas, the venerable Brahma, who was of one-pointed intel- lectual resolve, ascertained through his faculty of discernment that by which love for the Self [≈öri Hari] is evoked. (SB 2.2.34)16 ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§ö- A similar statement is found in the Skanda and Padma PurƒÅ≈Üas: ‡§Ü‡§≤‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§É ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡•• ‡•©‡•¶‡•Ø ‡•• By churning all the scriptures and deliberating on them again and again, this alone is rightly concluded - that Bha- gavan NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa is to be meditated upon constantly. (Skanda PurƒÅ≈Üa 4.25.35, Linga Purana 2.7.11)17 ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§°‡•á ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ Bhakti is established by negative concomitance (vyatireka), as in this statement from the Garuda PurƒÅ·πáa: Even if one has studied all the Vedas and knows the meaning of all scriptures, if he is not devoted to the Isvara of all beings, he should be known as the lowest of humankind. (Garuda PurƒÅ≈Üa 1.231.17)18 16 bhagavan brahma k√§rtsnyena trir anviksya mani·π£ayƒÅ tad-adhyavasyat ku·π≠astho ratir ƒÅtman yato bhavet See Anuccheda 29. 17 alodya sarva-sastrƒÅ·πái vicƒÅrya ca punah punah 18 idam eva suni≈üpannam dhyeyo nƒÅrƒÅya·πáa·∏• sadƒÅ This verse could not be traced in the Padma Purana, but it is found in the Linga Purana. antam gato’pi ved√§nƒÅm sarva-sastrartha-vedyapi yo na sarvesvare bhaktas tam vidyat purusadhamam 675 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya From these statements, it is to be understood that bhakti has been established everywhere. This will also be shown at the end [of this anuccheda]. (‡•®) ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•≠‡•§‡•™‡•¨ ) - ( 2 ) Bhakti is encountered, or is possible, in all performers (sarva-karty) [implying that all living beings are eligible to participate in bhakti]. This is shown in Srimad Bhagavata: ‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•à ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•Ç‡§£‡§∂‡§¨‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á || ‡•©‡•¶‡•® ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Those who have been instructed in the moral integrity (sila) of those who are exclusively intent upon Bhagavan, the performer of extraordinary deeds, can certainly understand and cross over Bhagavan’s deluding potency, even if they are women, sudras, hunas, sabaras, sinful beings, or even lower species, such as animals and birds. So, what can be said of those who have received the Vedic knowledge and fixed it in their hearts? (SB 2.7.46 ) 19 ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§°‡•á‡§ö- A similar statement is found in the Garuda PurƒÅna as well: ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ü‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§π‡§∞‡•å ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•©‡•¶‡•© ‡•• The worms, birds, and animals whose minds are fixed on Bhaga- van Hari certainly attain a higher destination, so what can be said of human beings who are situated in knowledge? (Garuda PurƒÅna, ƒÅcƒÅra khanda 230.30 ) 20 ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§ø‡§£‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø- ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ- ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ 19 te vai vidanty atitaranti ca deva-mƒÅyƒÅm stri-sudra-huna-sabarƒÅ api pƒÅpa-jƒ´vƒÅh yady adbhuta-krama-parƒÅyana-sila-siksƒÅs tiryag-janƒÅ api kim u ≈õruta-dhƒÅranƒÅ ye 20 kita-paksi mrgƒÅnƒÅm ca harau sannyasta-cetasƒÅm ≈´rddhvƒÅm eva gatim manye kim punar-j√±ƒÅninƒÅ·πÅ n·πõ·πáƒÅm 676 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya In this respect, bhakti is observed (a) in people of virtuous con- duct and those of ill conduct, (b) in the learned and those bereft of learning, (c) in those who are freed from attachment and those who are still attached, (d) in those seeking liberation and those already liberated, (e) in those whose bhakti is not yet per- fected and those in whom it is perfected, (f) in those who have attained the liberated status of being associates of Bhagavan (prƒÅpta-bhagavat-pƒÅr·π£adas), and those who are eternally liber- ated associates (nitya-pƒÅr≈üadas). Because bhakti is seen to be universally present in all these different types of performers, “its being present everywhere” (sƒÅrvatrikatƒÅ), or in other words, “its accessibility to all” is thereby established. ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ (‡§ï) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Ø‡•§‡•©‡•¶ ) - (a) Bhakti is encountered both in people of virtuous conduct and in those of ill conduct, as expressed in the GitƒÅ: ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§É || ‡•©‡•¶‡•™ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ If even a person who is exceedingly ill-behaved worships Me with exclusive devotion, he should be regarded as indeed virtuous, because he is rightly resolved. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.30)21 ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•á‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ The word api, “even,” implies that since even a person of ill conduct is to be regarded as virtuous if engaged in exclu- sive devotion, then what can be said of a person of righteous conduct? (‡§ñ) ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö “‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§• ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡•à ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß | ‡•ß‡•ß | ‡•©‡•©) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ (b) Bhakti is encountered both in the learned and in those bereft of learning, as expressed in the following verse: 21 api cet sudurƒÉcƒÉro bhajate mam ananya-bhƒÅk sƒÅdhur eva sa mantavya·∏• samyag vyavasito hi sah 677 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya Whether aware or unaware of the extent of My being, who I am in reality, and of what nature I am constituted, those who wor- ship Me with exclusive devotion I consider to be the best of all devotees. (SB 11.11.33)22 ‚Äú‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É‚Äù (‡§®‡§æ‡•¶ ‡§™‡•Å‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•¶‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ The same idea is affirmed in the Brhan-naradiya PurƒÅ·πáa: Bhagavan Hari takes away sins even if remembered by those of impure awareness, [just as] fire certainly burns even if touched unintentionally. (BNP 1.11.100)23 (‡§ó) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§ø‡§£‡§ø ‡§ö ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§‡•ß‡•™‡•§‡•ß‡•Æ) - (c) Bhakti is encountered both in those who are freed from attachment and by those who are still attached, as indicated in this verse: ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡§≤‡•ç‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•©‡•¶‡•´ ‡•• Although still attracted to the sense objects, a devotee of Mine who has not yet attained mastery over the senses is gener- ally not overwhelmed by them because of bhakti’s inherently powerful capability. (SB 11.14.18)24 ‡§Ö‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•á‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ The word api, “although” [in the phrase “although still attracted”], implies that one who is not so attracted is certainly not overwhelmed. This is the sense. (‡§ò) ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‚Äú‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ò‡•ã‡§∞‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•ç” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•®‡•¨) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ jn√§tv√§jn√§tv√§tha ye vai mam yavan yas casmi yad·πõ≈õa·∏• bhajanty ananya-bhavena te me bhaktatamƒÅ matƒÅ·∏• “harir harati pƒÉp√¢ni du≈üta-cittair api smrtah anicchayapi samsprsto dahaty eva hi pavaka·∏• *^ badhyamano pi mad-bhakto visayair ajitendriyah prayah pragalbhaya bhakty√§ visayair nabhibhuyate 678 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya (d) Bhakti is encountered in those seeking liberation and in those who are already liberated. Instances of these two are shown respectively in the following two verses: As such, those who aspire for liberation (mumuksus), while alto- gether free from enmity [toward other gods], worship only the beatific expansions of Bhagavan NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, avoiding frightful forms and the custodians of worldly beings. (SB 1.2.26)25 ‚Äú‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§Ø‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•≠‡•§‡•ß‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ And: The sages, though liberated from the knot of egoic identity, and though delighting in the Self alone, engage in causeless devotion to ≈öri Krsna, the majestic player (Urukrama), for ≈örƒ´ Hari is intrinsically endowed with such captivating qualities. (SB 1.7.10)26 (‡§ô) ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§ö (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•¨‡•§‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•´) - (e) Bhakti is encountered in those whose bhakti is not yet per- fected and those in whom it is perfected.
