Instances of these two are shown respectively in the following two verses: ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ò‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡•Ä‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É || ‡•©‡•¶‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ And some, who are exclusively intent upon Vasudeva, destroy all their sins in their entirety through unalloyed devotion, just as the sun dissipates the morning fog. (SB 6.1.15)27 ‚Äú‡§® ‡§ö‡§≤‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•® ‡•§ ‡•´‡•©) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ And: 25 26 mumuksavo ghora-rupan hitva bh≈´ta-patin atha nƒÅrƒÅya·πáa-kalƒÅ·∏• santa bhajanti hy anasuyava·∏• ƒÅtmƒÅrƒÅmƒÅ≈õ ca munayo nirgrantha apy urukrame kurvanty ahaitukim bhaktim ittham-bh≈´ta-guno harih 27 kecit kevalaya bhakty√§ v√§sudeva-parƒÅya·πáƒÅ·∏• agham dhunvanti k√§rtsnyena nihƒÅram iva bhaskara·∏• 679 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya He is the foremost Vai·π£·πáava whose unabated remembrance never strays even for half a moment - not even for the sake of the opulence of the three worlds-from the lotus feet of Bhaga- van, which are sought even by the gods for whom Ajita is their very Self. (SB 11.2.53)28 (‡§ö) ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•Ø‡•§‡•™‡•§‡•¨‡•≠ ) - (f) Bhakti is encountered in those who have attained the liber- ated status of being associates of Bhagavan (prapta-bhagavat- pƒÅr·π£adas), as expressed in the following verse: ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§®‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•©‡•¶‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Those devotees of Mine who have attained to the state of com- pletion (purna) through divine service (seva) do not desire even the four types of liberation - such as eternal residence in My abode (s√§lokya) - which ensue of their own accord by service to Me. How then could they covet any other boon that is subject to the ravages of time? (SB 9.4.67)29 ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶ ‡§ö ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•©‡•§‡•ß‡•´‡•§‡•®‡•® ) - Bhakti is also encountered in Bhagavan’s eternally liberated associates (nitya-pƒÅr·π£adas), as confirmed in Brahma’s statement to the devas: ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡§ü‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§∏‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É ‡•• ‡•©‡•¶‡•Æ ‡•• O devas, when ≈öri Devi [i.e., Lak·π£mi] accompanied by her maid- servants, worships her beloved Lord with tulasi leaves in her pleasure garden, then seeing her face, with exquisite nose and gorgeous curls of hair, reflected in the crystal clear ambrosial water of her pond, whose banks are made of coral, she considers 28 tri-bhuvana-vibhava-hetave’py akuntha-smrtir ajit√§tma suradibhir vim·πõgyat na calati bhagavat-padaravindal lava-nimi≈üƒÅrddham api sa vai·π£navƒÅgrya·∏• mat-sevaya pratitam te salokyƒÅdi-catu≈ütayam 29 necchanti sevayƒÅ p≈´r·πáƒÅ·∏• kuto’nyat kala-viplutam 680 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya herself greatly fortunate, thinking, “this face has been kissed by Bhagavan.” (SB 3.15.22)30 (‡•©) ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ (3) It is well known from scriptures such as Srimad Bhagavata that the worship of Sri Bhagavan is performed by various devo- tees in all divisions of the Earth (var·π£as), all planets (bhuvanas), all universes (brahmƒÅ·πá·∏ças), and even beyond them. Therefore, this should be understood as an illustration of how bhakti is encountered in all places (sarva-desa). (‡•™) ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ- (4) Bhakti is encountered in the instrumentality of all the senses (sarva-karana), as indicated in this statement: ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡§Ω‡§µ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•á ‡•• ‡•©‡•¶‡•Ø ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ By joyfully serving Bhagavan Hari with objects conceived within the mind, some devotees directly attained Him, who is beyond speech and mind.31 31 ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•á ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ö‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ By such statements, it is evidenced that bhakti is enacted even through the mind and speech, not to mention through the external senses. This is a well-known fact. (‡•´) ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡•Æ‡•ß‡•§‡•™ ) - 30 31 vƒÅpƒ´·π£u vidruma-ta·π≠ƒÅsv amalƒÅm·πõtƒÅpsu presyƒÅnvita nija-vane tulasibhir isam abhyarcati svalakam unnasam ik≈üya vaktram ucchesita·πÅ bhagavatety amatanga yac-chri·∏• manasenopacarena paricarya harim mudƒÅ pare van manasagamyam tam sƒÅk·π£ƒÅt pratipedire This verse is quoted in Bhakti-rasƒÅm·πõta-sindhu (1.2.182), where it is credited to “another Purana” (pur√§n√§ntare). 681I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya (5) Bhakti is encountered in relation to all objects (sarva- dravya): ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§π‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É || ‡•©‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ If one offers Me with devotion a leaf, a flower, fruit, or water, I partake of that offering presented with love by a person whose consciousness is fixed on Me. (SB 10.81.4) 32 (‡•¨) ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•ß‡•® ) - (6) Bhakti is encountered in all actions (sarva-kriyƒÅ), as shown in the following statements: ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§π‡§ø ‡•• ‡•©‡•ß‡•ß ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Whether heard about, repeated to others, meditated upon, honored, or simply approved of, this religion of devotion (sad- dharma, i.e., bhƒÅgavata-dharma) certainly purifies at once even those who are inimical to the devas and the world. (SB 11.2.12)33 ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Ø‡•§‡•®‡•ß- And: 32 ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç ‡§ú‡•Å‡§π‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø ‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ï‡•å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•©‡•ß‡•® ‡•• Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sac- rifice, whatever you donate in charity, and whatever austerity you perform, O son of Kunti, do that as an offering unto Me. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.27)34 patram puspam phalam toyam yo me bhakty√§ prayacchati tad aham bhakty upah·πõtam a≈õnami prayatƒÅtmanah 33 ≈õruto’nupathito dhyata ad·πõto vanumodita·∏• sadya·∏• punƒÅti sad-dharmo deva-visva-druho’pi hi 34 yat karo≈üi yad a≈õnƒÅsi yaj juhosi dadasi yat yat tapasyasi kaunteya tat kuru≈üva mad-arpanam 682 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ In this manner, even in the category of a mere semblance of bhakti (bhaktyƒÅbhƒÅsa) and even in the matter of offenses that nonetheless involve a semblance of bhakti, we find examples such as that of Ajamila and the mouse, respectively.35 (‡•≠) ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ (‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ) - (7) Bhakti is encountered in all types of prescribed duties (sarva- kƒÅrya), as stated in the Skanda PurƒÅ·πáa: ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§§‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•©‡•ß‡•© ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ I offer obeisance to Bhagavan Acyuta, by whose remembrance or by uttering whose name, all imperfections in the perfor- mance of penance, sacrifice, and rituals are immediately rectified. (Skanda PurƒÅna)36 (‡•Æ) ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§´‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§ß‡•Ä‡§É” ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®|‡•©|‡•ß‡•¶ ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ (8) Bhakti is encountered in regard to the attainment of all varieties of results (sarva-phala), as expressed in the following verse: 35 The example of Ajamila shows that even by the routine act of calling his son, named NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, Ajamila received the benefit of chanting the name of Bhagavan NƒÅrƒÅyana. This is an instance of bhakty√§bhasa, which will be discussed in greater detail in Anuccheda 172. Similarly, there was a mouse that lived in a temple of Bhagavan. This mouse used to steal ghee wicks offered to the deity, which was a type of offense. One day, the ghee wick, which was still burning, got stuck in its teeth. Due to the pain, the mouse started jumping up and down and finally died. His jumping up and down with the burning ghee wick was taken as a semblance of bhakti in the form of an arati ceremony, and thus in the next life, he was born as a queen who was fond of offering ghee lamps to the deity. She became liberated in that life. This topic will be discussed in Anuccheda 153. yasya sm·πõtya ca namoktyƒÅ tapo-yaj√±a-kriyƒÅdi·π£u 36 ny≈´na·πÅ samp≈´r·πáatƒÅm yati sadyo vande tam acyutam 683 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya A person of evolved discernment, whether desireless, full of desire, or seeking liberation, should worship the Supreme Puru≈üa with resolute bhakti-yoga. (SB 2.3.10)37 ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‚Äú‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ö‡§®‡•á‡§® ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•™ ‡•§ ‡•©‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ- ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ Additionally [apart from the eight criteria just discussed], bhakti’s universality (sƒÅrvatrikatƒÅ) is indicated in statements such as the following: Just as by pouring water on the root of a tree, its trunk, branches, and twigs become nourished, and just as by supplying food to the vital life current (prƒÅna), the senses gain strength, so too by worshiping Bhagavan Acyuta [Krsna], the worship of all entities is effected. (SB 4.31.14)38 By this principle as well, bhakti’s universality (sƒÅrvatrikatƒÅ) is established, because by rendering service to BhagavƒÅn Hari the worship of all entities and even of all other devas is automatically accomplished. ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á - This is also affirmed in a conversation between ≈örƒ´ BrahmƒÅ and Narada in the Skanda Purana: ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•á ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É || ‡•©‡•ß‡•™ || When Bhagavan Vis≈Üu, the Supreme Deva of all the devas, who wields a conch, a disc, and a club, is worshiped, then all other devas are worshiped, because Bhagavan Hari is present within everything. (Skanda Purana)“9 37 akƒÅma·∏• sarva-kƒÅmo vƒÅ mok·π£a-kama udara-dhƒ´·∏• 38 tivrena bhakti-yogena yajeta purusam param yatha taror mula-nisecanena trpyanti tat-skandha-bhujopa≈õƒÅkhƒÅ·∏• prƒÅ·πáopahƒÅrƒÅc ca yathendriyƒÅnƒÅ·πÅ tathaiva sarvarhanam acyutejyƒÅ 39 arcite deva-deve≈õe sankha-cakra-gadadhare arcitƒÅ·∏• sarva-devƒÅ·∏• syur yata·∏• sarva-gato hari·∏• The verse is not found in the printed edition. 684 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya Commentary In this subsection of Anuccheda 115, ≈öri Jiva GosvƒÅmi continues to analyze the fourth seed verse of the catu·∏•-sloki (SB 2.9.35). In reply to the question, “where is bhakti encountered?” the verse answers, “everywhere” (sarvatra). Taking this in a very literal sense, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va then elaborates eight categories in which bhakti’s pervasiveness is evidenced, providing examples for each. He states that bhakti is encountered in all (1) scriptures (sastra), (2) performers or agents of action (karty), (3) places (desa), (4) senses (karana), (5) objects (dravya), (6) actions (kriya), (7) prescribed duties (kƒÅrya), and (8) results (phala). Additionally, ≈öri Jiva shows that by perform- ing bhakti to Bhagavan, the worship of all the devas and of all living beings is automatically effected. From this analysis, bhakti’s status as the abhidheya of Srimad BhƒÅgavata is emphatically established. 115.5 Bhakti Is Encountered in All the Grammatical Cases ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä- ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§Ø‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï- ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ Bhakti is thus encountered even in all the grammatical cases, since it is evidenced in the PurƒÅ≈Üas that the person who per- forms bhakti, the cow or other items that are offered to Bhaga- v√§n, the instrument by means of which bhakti is performed, the one to whom a gift is presented for the satisfaction of ≈öri Bhaga- vƒÉn, the cow and other entities from whom milk and other items are taken to be offered to Bhagavan, and the place or the fam- ily in which someone performs devotion, all attain fulfillment thereby. In this manner, the “all-pervasiveness” (sƒÅrvatrikatƒÅ) of bhakti is established. 685 Commentary I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya 40 Bhakti’s all-pervasiveness is also verified by the fact that it can be applied to all the karakas, or grammatical cases. In this regard, Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi points out that in the Puranas we find statements about bhakti regarding the subject, direct object, agent, indirect object, source, and location of the action, all of which are perfected (k·πõtƒÅrtha) because of contact with bhakti. The word k·πõtƒÅrtha, “per- fected or fulfilled,” is applied to each of these in the examples given. The statements found in the Puranas proceed along the following general lines:

  1. Yo bhaktim karoti, “One who performs bhakti [is fulfilled].” Here, the pronoun yah, “one who,” is in the nominative case, being the subject of the sentence.
  2. Yad gavadikam bhagavate diyate, “The cow or other items that are offered to Bhagavan [attain perfection].” The word gavƒÅdikam, “the cow or other items,” although the subject of this passive voice sentence, retains the sense of the accusative in Sanskrit, because it refers to the object given.
  3. Yena dvara-bh≈´tena bhakti·∏• kriyate, “The instrument by means of which bhakti is performed [is perfected].” The phrase yena dvara-bh≈´tena, “the instrument by means of which,” is in the instrumental case, showing agency.
  4. Yasmai ≈õri bhagavat-pri·πáanartham diyate, “The one to whom a gift is presented for the satisfaction of ≈örƒ´ Bhagavan [attains perfection].” The pronoun yasmai, “the one to whom,” is in the dative case, being the indirect object of the verb.
  5. Yasmad gavƒÅdikƒÅt paya adikam adaya bhagavate nivedyate, “The cow and other entities from whom milk and other items are taken to be offered to Bhagavan [are fulfilled].” The words yasmƒÅd gavƒÅdikat, “the cow and other entities from whom,” are in the ablative case, showing the source of the milk and other items. 40 The six karakas of Sanskrit correspond to the following cases in English: the nominative (the subject of the action), accusative (the direct object), instrumental (the agent or instrument by means of which the action is performed), dative (the indirect object), ablative (the source or origin from which the action proceeds), and locative (the place or location of the action). 686 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya
  6. And yasmin de≈õadau kule va ka≈õcid bhaktim anutisthati, “The place or the family in which someone performs devotion [is perfected].” The phrase yasmin desadau kule va, “the place or the family in which,” is in the locative case, because it shows the location of the action. 115.6 Bhakti Is Encountered at All Times ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π - ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Next, we will examine bhakti’s omnitemporality (sadƒÅtana- tvam), commenting on the word sarvadƒÅ, ‚Äúat all times” [from the fourth seed verse of the catuh-sloki (SB 2.9.35)]. ( ‡•ß ) ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‚Äú‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∏‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§§‡§æ” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß | ‡•ß‡•™ | ‡•© ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ (1) Bhakti was in existence from the very beginning of the evolutionary cycle, as stated in the following verse: In due course of time, this speech of Mine, known as the Veda, remained undisclosed during the period of dissolution. In it, the dharma that is entailed is constituted of the very essence of My Being (mad-atmakah). It was spoken by Me once again to Brahma at the beginning of a new evolutionary cycle. (SB 11.14.3)*1 ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡•§ There are innumerable statements verifying bhakti’s contin- ued existence during the ongoing period in the midst of an evolutionary cycle. (‡•®) ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‚Äú‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ï ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∞‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï ‡§â ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡•á‡§∞‡§§‡•á‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•©‡•§‡•≠‡•§‡•©‡•≠) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡•á ‡•§ 41 kalena nasta pralaye vaniyam veda-sa√±jnitƒÅ mayadau brahmane prokta dharmo yasyam mad-atmaka·∏• 687 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ( 2 ) Bhakti exists even during the four different categories of dis- solution, as implied by Vidura’s question: “When Bhagavan lies down during the period of dissolution, who worships Him and who follows Him into repose?” (SB 3.7.37).42 (‡•©) ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á‡§∑‡•Å (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•©‡•§‡•´‡•® ) - ( 3 ) Bhakti exists in all the yugas: ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§ñ‡•à‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡•å ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•©‡•ß‡•´ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ What is attained in Satyayuga by meditation on Bhagavan Vis≈Üu, in Tretayuga by worshiping Bhagavan through sacri- fice, and in Dvaparayuga by worship of the deity, is attained in Kaliyuga merely by singing the praises of Bhagavan Hari. (SB 12.3.52 ) 43 ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ? - What more needs to be said? ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•©‡•ß‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•á ‡•§ When a moment or even an instant is passed without aware- ness of Vasudeva, that is a loss, that is a tragic mistake, that is delusion, and that is a great confusion. (Visnu Pur√§na ) * (‡•™) ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‚Äì (‡§ï) ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç ( ‡§ñ ) ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å (‡§ó) ‡§Ø‡•å‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å (‡§ò) ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å (‡§ô) ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§Ω‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å (‡§ö) ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å (‡§õ) ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø - 42 tatremam ka upasiran ka u svid anuserate 43 k·πõte yad dhyƒÅyato vis≈Üum tretayam yajato makhai·∏• dvapare paricaryƒÅyƒÅ·πÅ kalau tad dhari-kirtanƒÅt “4 s√• hanis tan mahac-chidram sa moha·∏• sa ca vibhramah yan-muhurtar ksanam vapi vasudevo na cintyate This verse is not found in the extant editions of Visnu PurƒÅna. 688 15 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡•å ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É || ‡•©‡•ß‡•≠ || ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ (4) Bhakti is also seen to exist in all stages of life (sarva-avasthƒÅ): It is well known that even in the womb bhakti was evidenced in ≈örƒ´ Prahlada, who was induced to hear about Bhagavan by ≈örƒ´ NƒÅrada. Bhakti was present in Dhruva and others in childhood, in Ambarƒ´≈üa and others during youth, in Dh·πõtarastra and others in old age, in Ajamila and others at the time of death, in Citra- ketu and others in the afterlife on attaining heaven, and in yet others even after entering hell. Bhakti’s existence even in hell is verified in the following verse from the Nrsimha PurƒÅ≈Üa: In accordance with the manner in which the residents of hell chanted the name of Bhagavan Hari, they attained correspond- ing positions in the divine abode, taking support from their devotion to ≈öri Hari. (Nrsimha PurƒÅ·πáa)45 ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡§æ ‚Äú‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•Ø‡•§‡•™‡•§‡•¨‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Therefore, the sage Durv√§s√§ said: “[What indeed is impossi- ble for You, Bhagavan], by the chanting of whose name even a resident of hell may be liberated?” (SB 9.4.62).46 ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•ß) - And [the fact that bhakti is seen to be present at all times, mean- ing both in the stages of sadhana and s√§dhya] is also confirmed in the following verse: 45 46 yatha yatha harer n√§ma kirtayanti sma nƒÅrakƒÅ·∏• tatha tatha harau bhaktim udvahanto divam yayu·∏• mucyeta yan-namny udite nƒÅrako’pi 689 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§è‡§§‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡•É‡§™ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•©‡•ß‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡•§ O King, for those seeking fulfillment of material desires [iccha- tƒÅm, i.e., kƒÅminƒÅm], for those who are indifferent to worldly existence [nirvidyamƒÅnƒÅnƒÅm, i.e., mumuk·π£≈´≈ÜƒÅm] and seeking the state of utter fearlessness [akuto-bhayam, i.e., mok·π£am iccha- tam],” and for those already established in immediate realiza- tion of the Truth [yoginƒÅm, i.e., j√±ƒÅninƒÅm], this constant chant- ing of the holy name of Bhagavan Hari has been ascertained [both as the means of attainment (sadhana), in the case of the first two, and as the end to be attained (sƒÅdhya), in the case of the last]. (SB 2.1.11)48 Commentary After providing examples to illustrate sadhana-bhakti’s omnipres- ence (sƒÅrvatrikatva), lit., “its being present everywhere” (sarvatra), ≈örƒ´ Jiva next demonstrates bhakti’s omnitemporality (sadƒÅtana- tvam), or “its being present at all times” (sarvadƒÅ). In this regard, he shows bhakti’s existence in the three primary categories of uni- versal time, namely, (1) at the very beginning of creation, (2) in the midst of the dissolution, and (3) throughout the period of sustenance, which is divided into four yugas. He then adds a fourth category, which relates to the phases of individual time. In this respect, he shows that bhakti is found to exist in all the var- ious stages of life (sarva-avastha), beginning from the prenatal or embryonic period and extending throughout childhood, youth, old age, death, and the afterlife, including both the ascension to heaven and even existence in hell. 47 ≈örƒ´ Viraraghava 48 etan nirvidyamƒÅnƒÅnƒÅm icchatƒÅm akuto-bhayam yoginƒÅm nrpa nirnitam harer n√§m√§nukirtanam Unless otherwise indicated, all bracketed inserts in this verse are according to the commentary of Sridhara Svami. 690 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya It is striking to learn that even people in hell performed bhakti and were liberated. This story is recounted in the seventh and eighth chapters of Nrsimha Purana. The sage Bhrgu had a son named Mrkandu, who had a son called M√§rkandeya. At his birth, an astrologer predicted that M√§rkandeya would die at the age of twelve. His parents were aggrieved to hear of this. The boy grew up and became vastly learned at a young age, but his parents remained sorrowful, remembering the astrologer’s prediction. One day, M√§rkandeya asked them the reason for their gloom. His mother then informed him of the prediction. The boy assured her, saying, “Do not worry, Mother, I will resort to penance and conquer over death.” Saying this, he left for the forest. Arriving there, M√§rkandeya met his grandfather Bhrgu in the assembly of sages. After exchanging greetings, Bhrgu asked him why he had come to the forest at such a tender age. The boy told him the reason. Bhrgu instructed the boy to take shelter of Krsna and chant the twelve-syllable mantra. MƒÅrka·πá·∏çeya learned how to meditate from his grandfather and then began to engage in severe penance. His mind was fully absorbed in thoughts of K·πõ·π£·πáa. When the time for his death arrived, the servants of Yamaraja appeared before M√§rkandeya. When they tried to approach him, they were struck by the clubs of Vis≈Üu’s servants. Then Death him- self came, but he too was driven away by the servants of Vi·π£·πáu. In this manner, M√§rkandeya conquered over death. The Yamad≈´tas then approached their master, YamarƒÅja, and related the whole incident. They questioned him about the identity of Vi≈ünu’s servants and the reason why they had come to protect M√§rkandeya. YamarƒÅja instructed them about Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa and ordered them never to approach a Vaisnava. He added that they were fortunate that the Vi·π£·πáud≈´tas had spared their lives. YamarƒÅja was then suddenly filled with compassion for the resi- dents of hell. He asked them why they did not take shelter of Krsna and recite His names, for K·πõ·π£·πáa promised to deliver anyone who did so, even from hell. Krsna’s statement in this regard is as follows: 6911 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya I uplift even from hell, anyone who remembers Me constantly, call- ing out, “K·πõ·π£·πáa! K·πõ·π£·πáa! K·πõ·π£·πáa!” Such a person breaks free like a lotus emerging from the water. I deliver anyone who declares, “O Lotus-eyed one! O Lord of the devas, O Narasimha! Trivikrama! I have taken shelter of You.” I rescue from all miseries anyone who approaches Me in full submission, saying, “I have surrendered to You, O Lord of Lords, Janardana!” (Nrsimha Purana 8.27-29)49 On hearing these instructions, the residents of hell began call- ing out the names of Krsna and Narasimha and were immediately liberated. It is thus shown that bhakti is possible even in hell. The statement from the Visnu Purana sums up the importance of not allowing a moment to pass in forgetfulness of Vasudeva. In concluding the discussion of the fourth category related to time, namely, how bhakti is present in all possible phases of individ- ual life (sarva-avastha), ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va cites SB 2.1.11. According to ≈örƒ´- dhara SvƒÅmi’s commentary on this verse, Sukadeva’s statement shows that bhakti exists both in the stage of sadhana and in that of sadhya. For those desiring material fruits or liberation, bhakti is ascertained as the means, whereas for those who have attained perfection in realization, bhakti is recognized as the end result. 115.7 Bhakti Established through Negative Concomitance ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á- ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§µ‡§£‡•à‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡•• ‡•©‡•ß‡•Ø ‡•• 49 he k·πõ·π£·πáa k·πõ·π£·πáa k·πõ·π£·πáeti yo mam smarati nitya≈õa·∏• jalam bhittv√§ yathƒÅ padma·πÅ narakad uddharamy aham pun·∏çarƒ´kƒÅk·π£a deve≈õa narasimha trivikrama tvƒÅm aha·πÅ ≈õara·πáam prapta iti yas tam samuddhare tvƒÅm prapanno’smi saranam devadeva janardana iti yah saranam praptas tam klesad uddharamy aham 692 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•á ‡•• ‡•©‡•®‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø ‡•§ Now, by negative concomitance ( vyatireka), a few other exam- ples will be shown that confirm bhakti’s existence everywhere and at all times. The following statement is found both in the B·πõhan-naradiya Purana and the Padma Purana: For those who are devoid of bhakti to Bhagavan Vis≈Üu, what is the use of studying the Vedas or any other scriptures, of under- taking a pilgrimage to the holy places, of observing penances, or of performing sacrifices? Furthermore, for one who is endowed with bhakti to Bhagavan Janardana, what is the point of study- ing many scriptures, of observing penances, of performing sac- rifices, or even of conducting thousands of Vajapeya sacrifices? (Brhan-nƒÅradiya PurƒÅna, Padma PurƒÅna) 50 ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•™‡•§‡•ß‡•≠, ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•´‡•§‡•ß‡•Ø‡•§‡•®‡•™, ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶‡•´‡•Ø/‡•™‡•ß ) - [The following statements are from Srimad BhƒÅgavata:] ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∏‡•á ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•©‡•®‡•ß ‡•• ‡§® ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ‡§™‡§ó‡§æ ‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ‡•ã ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§µ‡•à ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•©‡•®‡•® ‡•• ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö ‡§Ü‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ü‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∂‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§è‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡§π‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§¢‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•©‡•®‡•© ‡•• Those who are devoted to penance [the j√±ƒÅnis], those who are charitable [karmis in general], those who are of great repute [karmis of unique distinction who execute elaborate sacrifices, such as the a≈õvamedha], those who practice mindfulness [the 50 kim vedai·∏• kim u sastrair va kim va tirtha-nisevanai·∏• vis≈Üu-bhakti-vihinƒÅnam kim tapobhih kim adhvaraih kim tasya bahubhi·∏• sastrai·∏• kim tapobhi·∏• kim adhvarai·∏• v√§japeya-sahasrair va bhaktir yasya janardane Neither of these verses could be found in the extant editions of these two scriptures. 693 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya yogis], those who are adept in the science of mantras [i.e., in the Agama scriptures], and those who perform virtuous works [i.e., those who adhere to a strict moral code], all obtain no bene- fit if they do not offer their actions to Bhagavan. I offer repeated obeisances to Him, whose fame is most auspicious. (SB 2.4.17) 51 Be it the abode even of Brahma, the chief of the gods, that place is certainly not fit to be dwelt in where the ambrosial rivers of Bhagavan’s narrations do not flow, where there are no saintly devotees of Bhagavan taking shelter of such topics, and where there are no grand festivals performed in worship of the Lord of Sacrifice. (SB 5.19.24)52 And: Bowing down in reverence and touching ≈öri Krsna’s feet with the tip of his crown, Indra had formerly petitioned Bhagavan Acyuta to accomplish his objectives. But once his purpose had been fulfilled, he- although of great eminence (mahan)- fought with Him. Alas! Even the gods succumb to ignorance. Shame on their opulence! (SB 10.59.41)53 “‡§∏‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•©‡•§‡•®‡•Ø‡•§‡•ß‡•© ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§® ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡§™‡•ã ‡§®‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ” ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•≠/‡•≠/‡•´‡•® ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ “‡§®‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß| ‡•´ | ‡•ß‡•® ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ ‚Äú‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡§£‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•©‡•§‡•ß‡•´‡•§‡•™‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ And: Even if granted by Me, [My] people (janah) do not accept mukti in the form of residence on the same planet as Me (salokya), enjoyment of similar opulence (s√§rsti), proximity to Me (sami- pya), endowment with a form identical to Mine (sar≈´pya), or 51 tapasvino dƒÅna-para yasasvino manasvino mantra-vidah sumangalƒÅ·∏• 53 k≈üemam na vindanti vina yad-arpanam tasmai subhadra-≈õravase namo namah The bracketed inserts are according to the gloss of Sri Vi≈õvanatha Cakravarti. na yatra vaikuntha-katha-sudhƒÅpaga na sadhavo bhƒÅgavatƒÅs tad-ƒÅ≈õrayƒÅ·∏• na yatra yaj√±esa-makha mahotsavah suresa-loko’pi na vai sa sevyatƒÅm yayƒÅca anamya kirita-kotibhi·∏• padau sp·πõ≈õann acyutam artha-sadhanam siddhartha etena vigrhyate mahan aho surƒÅnƒÅ·πÅ ca tamo dhig adhyatƒÅm 694 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya oneness with Me (aikatvam), if such liberated states preclude the possibility of service to Me. (SB 3.29.13)54 And: Bhagavan Hari is pleased only by untainted devotion and not by charity, penance, worship, purity, or vows. Without devotion, everything else is merely a show. (SB 7.7.52)55 And: Even naiskarmya-j√±ƒÅna, or “the awareness that pertains to the very nature of Brahman,” which frees one from all taints (nira- njanam), is inadequately illuminating if devoid of devotional affect (bhava) for Bhagavan Acyuta [Sri Krsna]. What then can be said of motivated action [kamya-karma], which is always inauspicious, or even of unmotivated action (akƒÅra·πáam), when not offered to Bhagavan? (SB 1.5.12, SB 12.12.52)56 And: O Dear One, Your glories are themselves a sacred place of pil- grimage (tirtha) and hence worthy of recitation. Those who have taken shelter of Your lotus feet, who are skillful in narrat- ing Your stories, and who are conversant with the aesthetic rap- ture (rasa) implicit in such topics, do not regard even ultimate liberation as Your mercy, to say nothing of other boons, which are susceptible to fear at the merest knitting of Your eyebrows. (SB 3.15.48)57 54 s√§lokya-sƒÅr·π£·π≠i-samipya-sar≈´pyaikatvam apy uta 55 56 diyamana·πÅ na grhnanti vina mat-sevanam janƒÅ·∏• na danam na tapo nejya na saucam na vratƒÅni ca priyate’malaya bhakty√§ harir anyad vidambanam naiskarmyam apy acyuta-bhava-varjitam na ≈õobhate j√±ƒÅnam ala·πÅ nira√±janam kuta·∏• puna·∏• sasvad abhadram isvare na carpitam karma yad apy akƒÅra·πáam 57 natyantikam viganayanty api te prasƒÅdam kim v anyad arpita-bhayam bhruva unnayais te ye’nga tvad-anghri-sarana bhavata·∏• kathayƒÅ·∏• kirtanya-tirtha-yasasa·∏• kusala rasa-j√±ƒÅ·∏• 695 Commentary 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya After demonstrating how bhakti has been established as the abhi- dheya for all circumstances of place and time with regard to Srimad BhƒÅgavata (2.9.35), ≈öri Jiva now confirms the same from the logic of negative concomitance (vyatireka). In this regard, the verses that he cites point out that even studying scriptures, undertaking vari- eties of auspicious or prescribed actions, being promoted to heav- enly abodes, such as that of BrahmƒÅ, or even attaining any of the five types of liberation, are all without value if the performer is devoid of bhakti. The imperativeness of bhakti is thus established through the logic of negation. In the next subsection, ≈örƒ´ Jiva will cite a number of references in which bhakti is established as essential both “everywhere” and “at all times.” 115.8 Bhakti Established for All Places and Times ‡§Ö‡§• ‚Äú‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§™‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‚Äú‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•©‡•¨) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ Now, with reference to the phrase, ‚Äúwhich is encountered every- where (sarvatra) and at all times (sarvadƒÅ)” [from SB 2.9.35], we present examples in which bhakti is established simultaneously both for all places and all times: Therefore, O King, Bhagavan Hari is to be heard about, glorified, and remembered always and everywhere by all human beings with the totality of their being. (SB 2.2.36)58 ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ (‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ) - 58 tasmƒÅt sarvƒÅtmanƒÅ rƒÅjan hari·∏• sarvatra sarvadƒÅ ≈õrotavya·∏• kirtitavyas ca smartavyo bhagavan n·πõ·πáƒÅm 696 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya In the next verse from the Padma Purana, we find an example of bhakti being recommended for all times both by affirmation and by negation: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§É || ‡•©‡•®‡•™ ‡•• One should remember Bhagavan Vis≈Üu always and never forget Him even for a moment. All the injunctions and prohibitions of scripture are servants of these two principles alone. (Padma PurƒÅ·πáa, Uttara-khanda 71.100)59 ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‚Äú‡§® ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§É " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•©‡•©) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•á (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•©‡•¨) - Now, taking the second line of SB 2.9.35 in its entirety (anvaya- vyatirekƒÅbhyƒÅ·πÅ yat syat sarvatra sarvada), we can show how bhakti has been established for all circumstances of time and place, both by affirmation and by negation. This is evidenced in a group of verses beginning from SB 2.2.33 and concluding with SB 2.2.36. The opening statement is as follows: For human beings entangled in this world of repeated birth and death, there is no other path more auspicious than that by which (yatah) bhakti-yoga for Bhagavan Vasudeva can come into being. (SB 2.2.33)60 The concluding statement from this group is as follows: 59 ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•©‡•®‡•´ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Therefore, O King, Bhagavan Hari is to be heard about, glorified, and remembered always and everywhere by all human beings with the totality of their being. (SB 2.2.36)61 smartavya·∏• satatam vi≈ünur vismartavyo na jƒÅtucit sarve vidhi-ni·π£edhah syur etayor eva kinkarƒÅ·∏• 60 na hy ato’nyah sivah pantha visata·∏• sams·πõtƒÅv iha vasudeve bhagavati bhakti-yogo yato bhavet 61 tasmat sarvƒÅtmanƒÅ rƒÅjan hari·∏• sarvatra sarvadƒÅ ≈õrotavyah kirtitavya≈õ ca smartavyo bhagavan n·πõ·πáƒÅm 697 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§®‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ " ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•É‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•≠‡•§‡•®‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ In this verse, the word n·πõ·πáam, literally, “for all men,” means, “for all living beings” (jƒ´vƒÅnƒÅm). The word ny has been inter- preted in the same manner [by ≈öridhara SvƒÅmi] in SB 10.87.20, in reference to the clause iti nr-gatim vivicya kavaya·∏•, “The realized mystic poets, having thus ascertained the existential nature of the living beings (nr-gatim, i.e., jƒ´va-tattvam)…’ Commentary “62 In SB 2.2.33 from the group of verses referred to by ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´ (SB 2.2.33-36), the word bhakti-yoga is directly mentioned. In this verse, ≈örƒ´ ≈öukadeva positively affirms bhakti as the most auspi- cious path (anvaya) and also disaffirms the relevance of other paths (vyatireka). Although the words sarvatra and sarvada are not men- tioned in this verse, they are found in the final verse from this group. Thus, by the grammatical rule known as mand≈´ka-pluti- nyaya, these two words can be conjoined to the first verse, because the subject of the two intervening verses is also bhakti. From this analysis, it is abundantly clear that the BhƒÅgavata’s purpose, or in other words, its abhidheya, is to engage everyone in bhakti. 63 In this manner, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va has shown that the words sarvatra and sarvadƒÅ in SB 2.9.35, whether taken individually or together, by affirmation as well as by negation, have their import in bhakti alone. It may be noted that there is no direct mention of bhakti in SB 2.9.35. The verse simply states that one who is inquisitive to realize the truth of the Self should inquire into that alone (etavad eva) which is applicable everywhere and at all times, both through the logic *2 ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi’s gloss is as follows: nr-gatim nur jivasya gatim tattvam, “In the compound nr-gatim, the word ny means of the living beings’ (jivasya) and the word gatim means ’existential nature’ (tattvam).” 63 Manduka-pluti literally means “the jump of a frog.” The sense is that just as a frog moves by leaping over an intervening space, so too a word or words from a preceding verse or sutra can be correlated to a following verse by omitting one or more verses in the middle. This principle is often used in the interpretation of Panini’s sutras. 698 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya of affirmation and negation. Jiva GosvƒÅmi has taken it axiomati- cally that this can refer only to bhakti. He has also quoted many scriptural statements throughout this anuccheda to demonstrate that bhakti alone is possible in all times and circumstances. To fur- ther strengthen his conclusion, he will now show that this cannot refer to anything else. 115.9 Bhakti Alone Is without Cessation ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø - ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‚Äú‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ” ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø ‡•§ ‚Äú‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É ‚Äù ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‚Äú‡§∏‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø ‡•§ ‚Äú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç” ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ One more point is to be noted here. The path of karma-yoga reaches its conclusion either on accepting the renounced order (sannyasa) or on obtaining a body suitable for enjoyment (bhoga- ≈õarƒ´ra); yoga ends after attaining yogic perfection (siddhi); sankhya ends with the immediate realization of the self (atma- j√±ƒÅna); and j√±ƒÅna ends at the point of liberation (mok·π£a). Each of these paths has its respective capacity to bring forth these corresponding results. Consequently, in regard to karma-yoga and the other paths of such nature, the transience (vyabhicƒÅritƒÅ) of the associated practices laid down by scripture is understood to be the case. In contrast, however, bhakti to Bhagavan Hari has been estab- lished by its preeminence of being prescribed for all times and in all places, both by affirmation and negation, and for this rea- son it is appropriate to refer to it as a limb (anga) of the mystery (rahasya) [of divine love]. As a mystery or secret is confidential, so the intrinsic part of that secret is also confidential. There- fore, sadhana-bhakti has been spoken of in a concealed manner 699 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya in this verse [SB 2.9.35], covering its true identity in the garb of knowledge (j√±ƒÅna-r≈´pa). ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§™‡•á‡§£‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•®/‡•≠/‡•´‡•®)- Accordingly, ≈örƒ´ Brahma, while instructing ≈öri Narada in brief on the principles of the BhƒÅgavata, made him resolve to propagate the latter precisely in this manner, as stated: ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡•å ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø || ‡•©‡•®‡•¨ ‡•• Elucidate this [≈örimad Bhagavata], resolving thus, that by the manner [of your exposition], bhakti to BhagavƒÅn Hari, the Immanent Self of all beings and the ultimate refuge of everything, will come about for all humanity. (SB 2.7.52)64 ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø || ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• In the clause yatha bhaktir bhavisyati, “in such a manner that bhakti will come about,” the verb bhavisyati means “will cer- tainly come about” (avasyam bhavet). The words iti sankalpya, “resolving thus,” mean, “assenting as a manner of principle (niyamena angik·πõtya) [to teach] in this way (imam prakƒÅram).‚Äù [This may be summed up as follows: “You should elucidate this ≈örimad BhƒÅgavata, assenting as a manner of principle to teach in such a way that humanity will certainly develop bhakti for Bhagavan Hari.”] Commentary To further emphasize the point that bhakti alone is the eternal abhi- dheya, ≈öri Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´ remarks that all other paths - be it karma- yoga, j√±ƒÅna-yoga, or a·π£·π≠anga-yoga- come to an end after deliver- ing their respective fruits. Bhakti, however, continues beyond the 64 yatha harau bhagavati n·πõ·πáƒÅm bhaktir bhavisyati sarvƒÅtmany akhil√§dh√§ra iti sankalpya varnaya 700 115 The Essential Primacy of Bhakti As the Abhidheya attainment of perfection. Moreover, the other paths are not acces- sible to all human beings. They each have specific requirements of eligibility that restrict their application. Such, however, is not the case with bhakti, which is universally available. In conclusion, all other paths have clearly defined limits, but bhakti is eternal. Once begun, it never comes to an end. Although bhakti is not explicitly mentioned in SB 2.9.35, the words sarvatra and sarvadƒÉ cannot be meaningfully applied to any other path. Consequently, by the process of elimination, or in other words, by the principle of the remainder (p√§rise·π£ya-nyƒÅya), it is to be understood that the verse is recommending bhakti alone. A doubt may be raised in this regard: If bhakti is the abhidheya, why is it not explicitly mentioned in SB 2.9.35? In reply, ≈örƒ´ Jiva explains that bhakti has not been so mentioned because it is the means to attain prema, which has been described as a confiden- tial mystery (rahasya). Prema is the most highly precious item of all that is obtainable, and just as people keep their valuables hid- den, so too prema is carefully concealed so that it may not be dis- respected. When something of great value is made cheaply avail- able, people tend to become indifferent toward it. Sadhana-bhakti is referred to in SB 2.9.30 as a limb (anga) of the mystery of prema. The limb or intrinsic part of a great mystery is itself equally mys- terious. Bhakti and prema are the same by constitutional nature, the only difference being that prema is love of God in its fully mani- fest state, while sadhana-bhakti, the means to attain prema, is its incomplete disclosure to the conditioned being who aspires for it. Just as the four seed verses that Brahma heard from Bhagavan were about bhakti, so too the instructions that Brahma imparted to his son Narada on the BhƒÅgavata were also concerned with bhakti. Consequently, he made it clear (in SB 2.7.52) that Narada should elu- cidate the BhƒÅgavata in such a manner so as to disclose bhakti and not j√±ƒÅna or karma. This also validates the fact that the import of SB 2.9.35 is in bhakti, because Brahma passed on to his own son what he received directly from Bhagavan. 701I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya Next, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va refers to Narada’s instruction to Vyasa to expound bhakti, as a result of which the Bhagavata Purana was manifested by him. 702 Anuccheda 116 The BhƒÅgavata Was Manifested to Facilitate Bhakti - I ‡•ß‡•ß‡•¨ ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•ß‡•©) ‚Äì ≈öRƒ™ NƒÄRADA in turn instructed Vyasa in precisely the same man- ner with the intent that he should bring forth this MahƒÅpurƒÅ·πáa, Srimad Bhagavata: ‡§Ö‡§•‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ò‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§â‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•©‡•®‡•≠ ‡•• Therefore, O greatly fortunate Vyasa, since you are of infallible vision, pure in glory, established in truth, and of firm vows, you should continuously recollect- through transcognitive aware- ness (samadhi) - the divine acts of Bhagavan, who performs extraordinary feats, doing so for the liberation of all living beings from material bondage. (SB 1.5.13)1 ‡§Ö‡§•‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É " ‡§®‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß | ‡•´ | ‡•ß‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ The word atha·∏•, “therefore,” is used in the sense of ata·∏•, “for the reason just stated,” because this statement is semantically linked to what was just said in the immediately preceding verse, as follows: 1 atho maha-bhƒÅga bhavan amogha-drk suci-≈õrava·∏• satya-rato dh·πõta-vrata·∏• urukramasy√§khila-bandha-muktaye samadhin√§nusmara tad-vicestitam 703 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya Even nai≈ükarmya-j√±ƒÅna, or “the awareness that pertains to the very nature of Brahman,” which frees one from all taints (nira- njanam), is inadequately illuminating if devoid of devotional affect (bhava) for Bhagavan Acyuta [Sri Krsna]. What then can be said of motivated action [kamya-karma], which is always inauspicious, or even of unmotivated action (akƒÅra·πáam), when not offered to Bhagavan? (SB 1.5.12)2 ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•à‡§µ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• In SB 1.5.13, the words, “you should continuously recollect the divine acts of Bhagavan” (vice·π£·π≠itam anusmara) imply uninterrupted devotion (akhanda-bhakti). Commentary IN THE Conclusion to the previous anuccheda, ≈örƒ´la Jiva GosvƒÅmi cited Brahma’s instruction to his son Narada to elucidate the BhƒÅga- vata in such a manner that bhakti may be attained in this world by suffering humanity. NƒÅrada transmitted that same instruction here to his student VyƒÅsa. In India, traditionally knowledge was transferred from teacher to student. The student was meant to approach the teacher with humility and respect. With this foundation, he would study under the teacher while rendering favorable service to him or her. Out of affection and compassion, the teacher would then reveal the secrets to such a sincere student, as pointed out by Saunaka: All of that [which is realized by Vyasa and other sages] is known to you in truth by their grace, O gentle one [Suta], because the spir- itual preceptors reveal even the most confidential secrets to their affectionate student. (SB 1.1.8)3 nai≈ükarmyam apy acyuta-bhƒÅva-varjitam na ≈õobhate j√±ƒÅnam alam niranjanam kuta·∏• punah sasvad abhadram isvare na carpitam karma yad apy akƒÅra·πáam vettha tvam saumya tat sarvam tattvatas tad anugrahat br√ºyu·∏• snigdhasya sisyasya guravo guhyam apy uta 704 116 The Bhagavata Was Manifested to Facilitate Bhakti - I This manner of imparting knowledge from teacher to student is known as sampradaya, or “sacred tradition.” Bhagavan transmitted the four seed verses of Srimad Bhagavata to Brahma, BrahmƒÅ taught them to NƒÅrada, who in turn instructed Vyasa. In SB 1.5.13, the indeclinable atha·∏•, “for the reason just stated,” shows the causal connection to the immediately preceding verse (SB 1.5.12), wherein the futility of the paths of both karma and j√±ƒÅna was impressed on Vyasa. The conclusion to be drawn from this rea- soning is that Vyasa should meditate upon and then describe the lƒ´lƒÅs of Bhagavan in the form of Srimad Bhagavata, so that humanity may be liberated through bhakti. 705 Anuccheda 117 The BhƒÅgavata Was Manifested to Facilitate Bhakti ‚Äî II 1 ‡•ß‡•ß‡•≠ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ö (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß/‡•´/‡•™‡•¶ ) - NƒÄRADA also made this statement at the conclusion of his instructions to VyƒÅsa: ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∂‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡•• ‡•©‡•®‡•Æ ‡•• O Vyasa, you too, whose knowledge of the Vedas is without limit, should describe the glory of the omnipotent, omnipresent Lord (Vibhu), by which the quest for enlightenment of those who are wise finally reaches its end. They [the wise] do not recog- nize any other means of extinguishing the torment of those who are repeatedly oppressed by the miseries of material existence. (SB 1.5.40)1 ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç || ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• The word vidƒÅm means, “of those endowed with wisdom” (vidu≈üƒÉm). tvam apy adabhra-sruta vi≈õrutam vibho·∏• samapyate yena vidam bubhutsitam prakhyƒÅhi duhkhair muhur ardit√§tmanƒÅm sanklesa-nirvƒÅnam usanti nanyatha 706 117 The Bhagavata Was Manifested to Facilitate Bhakti - II Commentary NARADA, the teacher of Vyasa, instructed him to describe only the divine acts of Bhagavan, because this alone can bring an end to the inquiry of those who are wise and extinguish the miseries of people in general. NƒÅrada did not make the same claim about any other path. As a consequence of Narada’s instructions, Vyasa manifested the Srimad Bhagavata. 707 Anuccheda 118 Bhakti Disclosed As the Means in Vyasa’s SamƒÅdhi ‡•ß‡•ß‡•Æ ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•á ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•Å- ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•á ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç “‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§ø‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•≠‡•§‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ " ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§É " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•Ø ‡•§ ‡•©‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç “‡§≠‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•ß‡•Ø ‡•ß‡•™‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‚Äú‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•Ø‡•§‡•™‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ≈öRI VYASA as well, in the preparatory stage before disseminat- ing this great PurƒÅ·πáa, realized in the state of transcognitive awareness (samadhi) that only bhakti can grant the ultimate good. This was shown in the first [Tattva] Sandarbha while analyzing the section of verses beginning with SB 1.7.4 (bhakti- yogena manasi). The same verdict was approved by ≈örƒ´ Bhagavan Himself in response to the question, “What is gain (lƒÅbha)?‚Äù (SB 11.19.30). To this, Krsna replied: “Devotion to Me is the greatest gain” (SB 11.19.40)! ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• The meaning is self-evident. Commentary BEFORE Vyasa composed Srimad Bhagavata, he sat in devotional samadhi and was granted a direct vision of Bhagavan along with 1 labho mad-bhaktir uttamah 708 118 Bhakti Disclosed As the Means in Vyasa’s Samadhi His potencies. He also saw Maya and the deluding influence she exerted on the jivas. In this state of transcognitive awareness, bhakti alone was disclosed to Vyasa as the only solution to the suffering of the jƒ´vas. It was on this basis that Vyasa then com- posed Srimad Bhagavata. This topic has been discussed in Tattva Sandarbha (Anucchedas 30-49). In the Eleventh Canto, chapter 19, Uddhava poses various ques- tions to K·πõ·π£·πáa. One of them was, “What is considered as gain?” In response, K·πõ·π£·πáa said that the greatest gain is bhakti. 709 Anuccheda 119 Vyasa Deliberates on the Cause of His Dissatisfaction ‡•ß‡•ß‡•Ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß | ‡•™ | ‡•©‡•ß) - ≈öRI VYASA, therefore, deliberated within himself as follows: ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•©‡•®‡•Ø ‡•• Is this because I have insufficiently described the dharmas that are dear to the most highly elevated devotees - those pertain- ing directly to Bhagavan - since only these dharmas are loved by Bhagavan Acyuta [≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa]? (SB 1.4.31)1 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡•• The meaning of this statement is clear. Commentary VYASA divided the single Veda into four so that its import could be easily understood and applied. He then wrote eighteen PurƒÅ≈Üas as a supplement to the Vedas to enable people to easily grasp their essential message. He wrote Vedanta-sutra to synthesize the mean- ing of the Upanisads as a whole. He also wrote the epic, MahƒÅbhƒÅ- rata, for those who were ineligible to study the Vedas. Even after 1kim vƒÅ bhƒÅgavata dharma na praye·πáa nir≈´pitƒÅ·∏• priyƒÅ·∏• paramahamsƒÅnƒÅm ta eva hy acyuta-priya·∏• 710 119 Vyasa Deliberates on the Cause of His Dissatisfaction accomplishing all this work for the benefit of humanity, he was still not satisfied, feeling that something was amiss. It was in this mood that he deliberated on the cause of his unhappiness, as described in the present verse. He intuited that it was because he had not explic- itly established bhakti, which alone is dear to Bhagavan. The singu- lar importance of bhakti was buried under a multitude of instruc- tions regarding rituals and routine religious duties. Vyasa’s doubt was later confirmed by his teacher, Narada, in the verses discussed above in Anucchedas 116 and 117. 711Anuccheda 120 Bhagavan’s Supremacy Is Due to Imparting Bhakti ‡•ß‡•®‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‚Äú‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§π ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•¨ ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•¨ ‡•§ ‡•™‡•¶ ) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ALTHOUGH BHAGAVAN is the instructor of all, His supreme emi- nence (parama-utkarsa) is spoken of only by dint of His impart- ing instructions on bhakti. Citraketu expressed this to Bhaga- van Sri Sankar·π£ana: “O Invincible Lord [Ajita], You became established in supreme eminence [jitam, i.e., paramotkar·π£e·πáa sthitam]’ when You spoke this irreproachable bhƒÅgavata-dha- rma” (SB 6.16.40)2 ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• In this verse, the past participle jitam, “eminence was attained,” is to be understood as connected to the instrumental case pro- noun bhavatƒÉ, “by You” [which becomes the subject in the pas- sive voice, i.e., “You became established in eminence”]. The pro- noun bhavan, “You,” [which is omitted in the verse,] should be adduced as the subject of the verb “spoke‚Äù (ƒÅha). 1 2 This is ≈örƒ´dhara Svami’s gloss, which employs the same compound “parama-utkarsa” as used by ≈öri Jiva to point out that Bhagavan’s supreme eminence is due to His imparting instructions on bhakti. jitam ajita tada bhavata yadaha bhƒÅgavatam dharmam anavadyam 712 120 Bhagavan’s Supremacy Is Due to Imparting Bhakti Commentary THERE are two schools of Srimad Bhagavata. One, originating from Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa Himself, descends in a line of succes- sion through Brahma, Narada, Vyasa, and Sukadeva. The other descends from Bhagavan Sankar·π£a·πáa to the KumƒÅras and on to King Prthu and others. Citraketu is a devotee of Sankar·π£a·πáa, and it is to Him that he addresses the present verse, thus making ref- erence to the second of these two schools. He says that Bhagavan’s supreme eminence (parama-utkarsa) is that He has conquered (jita) the hearts of His unconditional devotees by propagating bhakti.

In his commentary on SB 6.16.40, ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmƒ´ interprets the word jitam, lit., “conquered or victorious,” in two different ways one exceptional and one common? First, by extension of mean- ing, he takes it in the sense of “established in supreme eminence” (paramotkar·π£e≈Üa sthitam), on account of having spoken bhƒÅgavata- dharma. This accords with Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi’s opening statement to this anuccheda. Then, taking jitam in its common sense, he connects it with the second line of the verse, which illuminates the meaning of Bhagavan’s being victorious. He is victorious because of having conquered His unconditional devotees, such as Sanat KumƒÅra and other sages (ni≈üki√±cana·∏• sanat kumƒÅrƒÅdaya·∏• munaya·∏• jitam). ≈örƒ´ Jiva’s specific use of the compound parama-utkarsa in his opening statement is a clear reference to Sridhara Svami’s exceptional gloss on the word jitam in SB 6.16.40. 3 The past participle jitam is formed by applying the suffix kta on the root ‚àöji. The root v‚àöji has two primary meanings - to be victorious and to excel. 713 2 The Essential Nature of Bhakti Anucchedas 121-164 Purifying Power of Bhakti Anucchedas 121-132 Bhakti Is Nirguna Anucchedas 133-138 Bhakti Is Bhagavan’s Svarupa-sakti Anucchedas 139-147 The Power of a Single Act of Bhakti Anucchedas 148-164 Purifying Power of Bhakti Anucchedas 121-132 Anuccheda 121 Bhakti Bestows Auspiciousness and Dispels Obstacles ‡•ß‡•®‡•ß | ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§â‡§™‡§¶‡§ø- ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ IN THIS manner, bhakti alone has been established as the abhi- dheya. In this regard, we find many instructions in scripture to perform bhƒÅgavata-dharma [i.e., bhakti] mixed with karma or other processes. It is to be understood, however, that these instructions are offered for the benefit of practitioners who are devoted to those particular paths, so that they may be made suc- cessful by way of contact with bhakti. Additionally, they are pro- vided so that some of them, who by acquiring a taste for bhakti, may be impelled to take up the path of pure bhakti alone. ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ- ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ Although we have already discussed the glories of bhakti, we will now explain the nature of bhakti in a systematic way just to emphasize that bhakti alone has been established as the abhidheya in all scriptures. ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ- ‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‚Äú‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•¨‡•§‡•©‡•§‡•®‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ " 719 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®|‡•©|‡•ß‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å “‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•ß‡•ß‡•ß‡•Ø) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§ö ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§- ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ For all people and especially for the devotees, there is nothing other than bhakti that is imperative to be done. With this inten- tion, it was already demonstrated that bhakti is the supreme dharma and that it fulfills all aspirations. The first of these two points is shown in the following verse: In this world, this alone is asserted to be the supreme essential duty (para-dharma) of humanity, namely, to engage in bhakti- yoga to Bhagavan by uttering His names and other such direct acts of devotion. (SB 6.3.22)1 And the fact that bhakti fulfills all aspirations is shown in the next two verses: A person of evolved discernment, whether desireless, full of desire, or seeking liberation, should worship the Supreme Puru≈üa with resolute bhakti-yoga. (SB 2.3.10)2 And: For humanity, the worship of Bhagavan ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa’s feet is the root cause of the attainment of heaven and liberation, of the pro- curement of the wealth of this world or that of the subterranean realm, and of all perfections as well. (SB 10.81.19)3 et√§v√§n eva loke’smin pumsam dharmah parah smrtah bhakti-yogo bhagavati tan-nama-graha·πáƒÅdibhi·∏• akƒÅma·∏• sarva-kƒÅmo vƒÅ mok·π£a-kama udara-dhih tivrena bhakti-yogena yajeta puru≈üam param svargƒÅpavargayo·∏• pumsƒÅm rasayam bhuvi sampadƒÅm sarvƒÅsƒÅm api siddhƒ´nƒÅm m≈´la·πÅ tac-cara·πáarcanam ≈örƒ´ Jiva cites only the words sarvasam api siddhƒ´nƒÅm from the verse. There is some ambiguity regarding which verse he is referring to, since the same words also appear in SB 11.15.35. For easy reference, we provide the translation of the latter verse here as well: “I [Sri Krsna] am the instrumental cause [hetu·∏•, i.e., kƒÅra·πáam], the guardian [pati·∏•, i.e., palayita], and the originating ground [prabhuh, i.e., upapadanam] of all perfections, of the systems of yoga, s√§rkhya, and dharma, and of the exponents of the Vedas” (sarvƒÅsƒÅm api siddhƒ´nƒÅm hetu·∏• patir aham prabhu·∏•, aham yogasya sarikhyasya dharmasya brahma-vƒÅdinƒÅm). The bracketed inserts are from Sridhara Svami’s gloss. 720 121 Bhakti Bestows Auspiciousness and Dispels Obstacles ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∏‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á- In the Skanda Purana also, in a dialogue between Sanat KumƒÅra and Markandeya, it is said: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§§‡§™‡•ã‡§π‡•ã‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•©‡•©‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•©‡•©‡•ß ‡•• Worship of Vi·π£·πáu is a dharma distinct from all other duties of humankind. By the worship of Vis≈Üu, one receives millions of times over whatever results are attained by performing all man- ner of sacrifices, austerities, oblations, and by bathing in all the holy places. Therefore, with all diligence one should worship Bhagavan NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa in this world. (Skanda Purana)* ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á ‡§ö- And in the same PurƒÅ·πáa, in a dialogue between Brahma and Narada: ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•©‡•©‡•® ‡•• Even if one performs 100,000 horse sacrifices, he cannot achieve the same result as obtained by My devotees. (Skanda PurƒÅ≈Üa) ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§ò‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‚Äú‡§∏‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ö‡•Ä‡§®‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§≠‡§Ø‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•¨‡•§‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•≠) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ Bhakti also destroys inauspiciousness (asubha), as shown in this statement: 4 visi≈ü·π≠a·∏• sarva-dharmƒÅnƒÅ·πÅ dharmo vi·π£·πáv arcanam n·πõ·πáƒÅm sarva-yajna-tapo-homa-tirtha-snanais ca yat phalam tat-phalam koti-gunitam visnum sampujya capnuyat tasmat sarva-prayatnena nƒÅrƒÅya·πáam iharcayet asvamedha-sahasranam sahasram yah karoti vai na tat phalam avapnoti mad-bhaktair yad avapyate 721I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya In this world, this path [of bhakti] is certainly most appropri- ate, because it is the source of all auspiciousness and altogether free of fear [from impediments of any kind]. Those who tread this path are of ideal character (susilah), established in virtue (sadhava·∏•), and exclusively devoted to Bhagavan NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa. (SB 6.1.17)6 ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ö - " ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó ‡§á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡•§ ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmƒ´ also comments: “Therefore, [because those who tread this path are of ideal character (susƒ´lƒÅ·∏•) and established in virtue (sƒÅdhava·∏•)], in bhakti there is no fear that one will be left without assistance, as on the path of j√±ƒÅna. Furthermore, in bhakti there is no fear from those who are envious of other’s achievements, as on the path of karma.” ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç- Similarly, Bhagavan made this statement in the DvarakƒÅ- mƒÅhƒÅtmya of the Skanda Purana: ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç || ‡•©‡•©‡•© ‡•• For human beings engaged in My devotion, there is no inauspi- ciousness in this world or the next. The bhakti of such devo- tees carries millions of their ancestors and descendants to Vaikuntha. (Skanda Purana)” ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á ‡§ö- And the Visnu PurƒÅ≈Üa also says: 7 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Æ‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•©‡•©‡•™ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ sadhricino hy ayam loke panthah k·π£emo’kuto-bhaya·∏• susila·∏• sadhavo yatra nƒÅrƒÅya·πáa-parƒÅya·πáƒÅ·∏• mad-bhaktim vahatam pumsam iha loke pare’pi vƒÅ nƒÅsubham vidyate loke kula-kotim nayed divam 722 121 Bhakti Bestows Auspiciousness and Dispels Obstacles I take shelter of Bhagavan Hari, the unborn and eternal Puru»ôa. Simply by remembering Him, one becomes the recipient of all good fortune. (VP 5.17.17) ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•©‡•©) - Bhakti removes all obstacles, as Brahma and the devas said to ≈örƒ´ Bhagavan: ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§® ‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶ ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï‡§™‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•ã ‡•• ‡•©‡•®‡•´ ‡•• On the other hand, O Madhava [husband of Laksmi], Your devo- tees, who are bound to You by affection, never fall away from the path of auspiciousness. Protected on all sides by You, O Lord, they proceed fearlessly, placing their feet on the heads of the superintendents [i.e., the devas] of all obstacles. (SB 10.2.33) ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç “‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•©‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∂ ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É - ‡§§‡§•‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ- ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡§ú‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∂‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ In the verse that precedes this one (SB 10.2.32), it was said that even those who are liberated fall down from the path of tran- scendence by disregarding Bhagavan. Here, in SB 10.2.33, it is stated that this is not the case for devotees. The j√±ƒÅnis fall down even from the supreme state [of living liberation (jƒ´van-mukti)], which they had previously attained, yet Bhagavan’s devotees do not fall from the path in this manner, even from the stage of practice (sadhana-avastha). What then can be said of those who have already attained Bhagavan? Although ≈öri V·πõtra, Gajendra, and Bharata fell down from their auspicious births, it is seen that their residual predispositions (v√§sanƒÅs) for bhakti were carried over into their next births in lower species. 8 9 sm·πõte sakala-kalya·πáa-bhajanam yatra jƒÅyate puru≈üam tam ajam nityam vrajami saranam harim tatha na te madhava tavaka·∏• kvacid bhrasyanti m√§rgat tvayi baddha-sauh·πõda·∏• tvayabhigupta vicaranti nirbhaya vinayakƒÅnƒ´kapa-murdhasu prabho 10 See Anuccheda 111. 723 ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö- I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§É || ‡•©‡•®‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡•§ But in the case of liberated j√±ƒÅnƒ´s who disrespect Bhagavan, their sublatent desires for worldly enjoyment are again revived, as stated in the VasanƒÅ bhƒÅsya: Even liberated individuals fall prey to worldly desires once again, if they become offenders to Bhagavan, who has inconceivable supreme power. ( VƒÅsanƒÅ bhƒÅsya) m ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‚Äú‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶‡•§‡•® ‡•§ ‡•©‡•® ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø- ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•à‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§® ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§∂‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•Å‡§≠‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Æ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•å‡§π‡§¶- ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç " ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•™‡•§‡•ß‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡•§ An alternative meaning to the principal verse of this anuccheda [SB 10.2.32] is as follows: As undeniable as it is that those who are indifferent to You fall down, as stated in the verse previ- ous to this one, it is equally indisputable that Your devotees do not fall down. The sense is that there is equality in the certi- tude of falling down and not falling down in respect to these two types of practitioners. The devotees do not fall because they are bound to You by affection ( tvayi baddha-sauhrdƒÅh). The word sauhrdam, “affection,” should here be understood to mean faith (≈õraddhƒÅ), because the word mƒÅrgƒÅt, ‚Äú from the path,‚Äù clearly indicates that they are still aspiring practitioners (sƒÅdhakas).
