(SB 6.2.49) satƒÅm prasangan mama virya-samvido bhavanti h·πõt-karna-rasayana·∏• kathƒÅ·∏• taj-josan√°d ƒÅ≈õv apavarga-vartmani sraddha ratir bhaktir anukramisyati mriyamano harer nama grnan putropacƒÉritam ajamilo’py agad dhama kim uta ≈õraddhaya g·πõ·πáan 1007 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø- ‡§∂‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ This ≈õraddha is a limb (anga) only of the assured ascertainment (avadhƒÅrana) of the subject propounded in scripture (i.e., the abhidheya), because ≈õraddha means to have trust (vi≈õvƒÅsa) in the import of scripture. Therefore, it is not counted as a limb (arga) of the actual practice of bhakti. ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§´‡§≤‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ- ‡§£‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ? ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á " ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•á‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§æ‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡•§ Furthermore, bhakti does not depend upon any ordinance of scripture for it to produce its effects, for like fire’s power to burn, the acts of bhakti, such as hearing and singing about Bha- gavan, have the potency to bring forth effects inherent in their very nature (svarupa). How then can bhakti be dependent on ≈õraddha? Thus, it is sometimes seen that even foolish beings attain success in bhakti without ≈õraddha, as was stated above, “If Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa’s name is chanted even once, whether with faith or carelessly (helayƒÅ vƒÅ), it delivers a human being.” ‡§π‡•á‡§≤‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§® ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§≤‡§µ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§£‡•á ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§µ‡§π‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡•§ Although “carelessness” (helƒÅ) is in the form of an offense, if it is expressed unintentionally, it does not obstruct bhakti, because there is no ill-heartedness (dauratmya) involved. This point has been discussed already [in Anuccheda 159]. But in the case of those who are proud of their petty knowledge (j√±ƒÅna-lava- durvidagdha), [carelessness] does obstruct bhakti, because it is impelled by the opposite of this attitude [meaning that it is expressed intentionally out of ill-heartedness]. An example of this is seen in the case of King Ve≈Üa, who uttered Bhagavan’s name with malicious intent. Sometimes, the natural power of 1008 172 The Criterion of Eligibility for Ananya-bhakti an object becomes curtailed, just as the burning power of fire is hampered in the case of wet wood. ‚Äú‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•®‡•≠ ‡•§‡•ß‡•≠) ‚Äú‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•á‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ In the following statement, the words ≈õraddha and bhakti’ simply imply reverence (adara): Even water offered to Me with reverence (≈õraddha) by a devo- tee (bhakta) is dear to Me. However, even an extraordinary gift offered to Me by a nondevotee does not give Me satisfaction. (SB 11.27.17B-18A) 8 ‡§∏ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§£‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§´‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§®- ‡§™‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§® ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞- ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§‡•®‡•¶‡•§‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‚Äú‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•®‡•¶/‡•®‡•≠) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ This reverence dispels the offensive attitude of disrespect (anƒÅdara) that impedes the unfolding of the exceptional fruit of giving satisfaction to Bhagavan. Therefore, ≈õraddha is not a limb (anga) of bhakti but an attribute ( vi≈õesana) of a person eligible to perform ananyƒÅ-bhakti, just as wealth, physical abil- ity, and knowledge are attributes of a person qualified to per- form karma and not parts of the practice of karma. Thus, in the two verses under discussion [sB 11.20.8, cited in the begin- ning of Anuccheda 171, and sB 11.20.27, quoted at the beginning of this anuccheda], the compound j√§ta-≈õraddha (“the person in whom faith has been born’) is used as a qualifier (vi≈õesana) of the person eligible to perform bhakti. ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§® ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡•á ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ- ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‚Äú‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß | ‡•®‡•¶ | ‡•©‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ 8 The word bhakti is not actually present in this verse, but it is implied by the word bhakta, i.e., “the one endowed with bhakti, or reverence.” ≈õraddhayopah·πõtam prestham bhaktena mama vary api bh≈´ry apy abhaktopah·πõtam na me to·π£aya kalpate 1009I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya In this statement [SB 11.20.28], the pronoun tata·∏•, “from that,” means “beginning from the point of ≈õraddha” [one should wor- ship Bhagavan], and the fifth case [i.e., the ablative case] has been used to convey this meaning in place of the gerund form (lyap), which has been dropped? This indicates that bhakti is without any specified end, and thus it is sometimes taken up even by those who have attained to the status of an atmarama, or “one who delights in the self alone.” By this unlimited character- istic of bhakti, the complete sovereignty (samrajya) of bhakti has been implied. Later in the same chapter of Srimad BhƒÅgavata, ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa says: Indeed, My exclusive devotees, who are endowed with wisdom (dhirƒÅ·∏•) and established in authentic being (sadhava·∏•), do not covet anything at all, not even ultimate liberation from rebirth, even if awarded by Me. (SB 11.20.34)10 ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ By thus disclosing the complete sovereignty (sƒÅmr√§jya) of bhakti, the fact that karma and j√±ƒÅna cannot be successful without bhakti is also made evident. Commentary IN THE previous anuccheda, ≈örƒ´ Jiva cited two verses spoken by ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa (SB 11.20.7-8) that specify the criteria of eligibility for the three types of yoga. In the second of these two verses, K·πõ·π£·πáa mentions three qualifications that are relevant to the path of bhakti: 9 The pronoun tatah is in the ablative or fifth case, which has been used in place of the second case after dropping the gerund (lyap) “beginning from” (arabhya). Thus, instead of saying tƒÅm (≈õraddham) arabhya, “beginning from the point of this ≈õraddha,” Krsna simply says tata·∏•, “from this point forward.” The meaning is the same in both cases, since “arabhya” and “sraddha” are implied by the word tatah. For details of such usage, see HarinƒÅmƒÅm·πõta-vyakarana (4.122). This rule is commonly referred to as lyap-lope pa√±cami. 10 na ki√±cit sadhavo dhira bhakta hy ekantino mama vƒÅ√±chanty api mayƒÅ dattam kaivalyam apunar-bhavam 1010 172 The Criterion of Eligibility for Ananya-bhakti
  11. ≈öraddha, or implicit faith in bhakti as the preeminent path. 2. N√§ti-nirvinna, or not being excessively indifferent to sense objects.
  12. N√§ti-sakta, or not being overly attached to sense objects. ≈öri Jiva’s intent is to show that out of these three, the real crite- rion of eligibility for bhakti is ≈õraddha alone. The other two qualities are merely concomitant effects of the beginning stage of ≈õraddha. To make this clear, he begins this anuccheda by citing two other verses spoken by K·πõ·π£·πáa from His teachings to Uddhava (SB 11.20.27- 28). These two verses are an elaboration on SB 11.20.8, cited in the previous anuccheda, in which the eligibility for bhakti is described. The three characteristics mentioned in SB 11.20.8 are reiterated in SB 11.20.27. In the latter verse, the eligible devotee is directly stated to be one in whom ≈õraddha is born (j√§ta-≈õraddha) in regard to hearing the narrations (katha) of Bhagavan. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va first clar- ifies that when it is said that a person acquires faith in kathƒÅ, it indicates in a broader sense that the person acquires faith in other forms of devotion also. The words nirvinna·∏• sarva-karmasu mean that the faithful devotee has given up all hope of obtaining ben- efit from works, and the words parityage’py anisvara·∏• mean that he is yet unable to completely abandon material enjoyment. These statements correspond to the definitions given in the earlier verse (SB 11.20.8). This is the state of a beginner on the path of bhakti. Krsna recommends that even such a person, who is yet unable to give up material enjoyment, should take directly to bhakti. It is not that he or she needs to practice some other process first to become eligible for bhakti. Such is not the case, however, with the path of j√±ƒÅna. To be eligible for j√±ƒÅna, one must first be fully renounced. According to Sadananda Yogindra, the eligibility for j√±ƒÅna-mƒÅrga is as follows: The eligible candidate, however, is one who has at once under- stood the import of all the Vedas by having studied the Vedas and VedƒÅngas according to the prescribed method. His heart is com- pletely pure, because either in this birth or another, after having already desisted from both fruitive and prohibited actions, he 1011 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya has become free from all impurities through execution of regular duties (nitya-karma), incidental duties (naimittika-karma), expi- atory duties (praya≈õcitta), and meditation (upƒÅsanƒÅ). Being thus endowed with the four wealths of practice (sadhana-catustaya- sampatti), he becomes a pramƒÅtƒÅ, or “one qualified to apprehend valid knowledge” [pramƒÅ-j√±ƒÅna-kartƒÅ]. (Vedanta-sƒÅra 1.6)11 The four wealths referred to above are those of discrimination between matter and spirit (viveka), dispassion toward all sense pleasure (vairagya), the six endowments (sat-sampatti - mental equilibrium, sense control, detachment, tolerance, fixity of mind, and faith), and a strong will to liberation (mumuksutƒÅ). In contrast to this rigid set of prerequisites, the eligibility for bhakti is simply ≈õraddha. K·πõ·π£·πáa stresses, however, that the begin- ning devotee must remain aware that sense pleasures culminate in suffering. Therefore, if some pleasure comes about as a result of past meritorious karma, the devotee should not become overly enchanted by it. If he does so, he will only create further samska- ras for enjoyment and will never be able to extricate himself. But if he partakes of the experience while remaining internally detached, he will not sow the seed for further entanglement. Krsna here is offering very practical advice for the neophyte bhakta. Often an aspiring devotee will react to sense pleasures that come of their own accord with an attitude of hatred or disgust, not knowing that these negative emotions are as binding as the feeling of attraction. Hatred, or repulsion (dvesa), is also an attachment, but in the negative sense. Krsna advises the neophyte to remain natural and neutral but aware of the reality. In these verses, K·πõ·π£·πáa also implies that bhakti is potent in and of itself, and thus it is supremely independent. It does not depend on j√±ƒÅna or vairagya. Thus, out of the three characteristics mentioned 11 adhikari tu vidhivad-adhita-veda-ved√§ngatvenƒÅpƒÅtato’dhigatƒÅkhila-vedartho’smin janmani janm√§ntare vƒÅ kƒÅmya-ni·π£iddha-varjana-puras-saram nitya-naimittika-praya≈õcittopƒÅsanƒÅnu·π£·π≠hƒÅnena nirgata-nikhila-kalma·π£atayƒÅ nitanta-nirmala-svanta·∏• sadhana-catustaya-sampanna·∏• pramƒÅtƒÅ. 1012 172 The Criterion of Eligibility for Ananya-bhakti in SB 11.20.8 and again in SB 11.20.27, only ≈õraddha is the actual quali- fication required for bhakti. Detachment from works is a direct con- sequence of ≈õraddha. Everything a devotee does is undertaken on the basis of sraddha. Thus, ≈õraddha itself in regard to bhakti implies a disinterest in karma. Accordingly, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ writes that the condition of being detached (nirvinna) is only a reconfirmation of what was said about ≈õraddha. It is not expressing some new characteristic of a bhakta. The conclusion therefore is that ≈õraddha alone is the real crite- rion of eligibility for bhakti. Of course, faith is needed to under- take any path, or for that matter, any action at all, but other paths require some other qualifications in addition to ≈õraddha, such as freedom from desire or a suitable birth in the var·πáƒÅ≈õrama sys- tem. In bhakti, nothing other than ≈õraddha is required. All other qualities manifest by the grace of bhakti. This was discussed earlier. What is the meaning of ≈õraddha? It signifies a firm belief in the import of scripture. The dawning of faith in hearing the narrations of Bhagavan and other practices of devotion means a firm convic tion that this alone is the supreme good. For this reason, the devo- tee becomes apprehensive when participating in actions that are fruitive in nature. Without faith, one cannot be exclusively devoted to the path of bhakti. Bhakti is potent in and of itself, and so it does not depend on anything else to deliver its result. Additionally, it does not depend on the Vedic injunctions, as is the case for the acts of karma-yoga. It is analogous to fire, which burns anyone who touches it regard- less of whether the person is acquainted with its burning power or not. The power of fire to burn is inherent in its constitution and not dependent on anything external, such as a Vedic injunction. Bhakti is analogous in nature. In this regard, we hear various stories about even foolish beings, who had no ≈õraddha in bhakti, such as Ajamila or the mouse who used to steal ghee wicks, but who obtained the benefit of bhakti even without ≈õraddha. In contrast, however, karma-yoga does not have the inherent power to deliver its intended fruit. In the case of the Vedic rituals that form part of the path of karma-yoga, it is the 1013 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya power present in the Vedic injunctions themselves in the form of the orders of Bhagavan that is invested into the Vedic actions. Oth- erwise, they are not different from laukika, or “worldly,” actions. So, since bhakti is independently powerful, why is ≈õraddha nec- essary at all? ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va answers this question in two ways. First, although bhakti’s power is inherent, it will not manifest in a person who is crooked at heart and thus offensive in nature. In this respect, bhakti’s power is comparable to fire’s inherent burning capacity, which is obstructed in the case of wet wood. If the fuel is wet, or in other words, unsuitable for use, only smoke will be produced but no fire or light. Consequently, the devotee who is obstructed by an offense needs to practice bhakti regularly to purify his heart, just as one has to dry wet wood before being able to set it aflame. But if one is faithless, he will not have the impetus to practice bhakti to become free of offensiveness and crookedness of heart. Secondly, even if such a person does practice, he will not be exclusive to the path of bhakti. For these reasons, ≈õraddha is the necessary criterion of eligibility for ananya-bhakti. The above analysis leads us to the conclusion that ≈õraddha is not a direct limb (anga) of bhakti itself. Otherwise, people would not be able to execute bhakti prior to the appearance of ≈õraddha, but such is not the case. Moreover, if ≈õraddha were a limb of bhakti, then ≈õraddha alone would yield perfection, without the necessity to engage in any other act of devotion. This, however, is not sup- ported by any scriptural statement. Therefore, ≈õraddha is under- stood to be only an attribute (vise·π£ana) of the eligible practitioner, and it is ≈õraddha that impels one to take to bhakti in an exclusive manner. A further doubt is raised in this regard. If ≈õraddha is not a limb of bhakti, then why is it that in SB 11.27.17 it is mentioned as being instrumental to bhakti in the compound ≈õraddhayopah·πõtam, “offered with faith?” ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va explains that the word ≈õraddhaya here only means “with respect” (adara). Therefore, ≈õraddha is only an attribute of a bhakta, and this is precisely how K·πõ·π£·πáa has used the word in the compound j√§ta-≈õraddha, lit., “the person in whom faith is born” (SB 11.20.8 and 11.20.27). 1014 172 The Criterion of Eligibility for Ananya-bhakti ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va makes one more pertinent comment on SB 11.20.28 in regard to the independent nature of bhakti. He explains that the word tata·∏•, “from that,” means “beginning from the point of ≈õraddha.” This signifies that the formal practice of bhakti begins on the appearance of ≈õraddha, even in a person who is still attached to sense pleasure. Additionally, the phrase “from that point forward,” is an open-ended statement, indicating that bhakti is without any specified end. This means that bhakti continues even beyond liber- ation, and thus it is sometimes taken up even by those who have attained to the completion stage of an ƒÅtmƒÅrƒÅma, or “one who delights in the self alone.” All other paths have a limited range of jurisdiction. Karma ends upon the awakening of detachment, and j√±ƒÅna ends at liberation. But bhakti continues even beyond liber- ation. This is further evidence that bhakti is not dependent upon these other processes. 172.2 How Beginning Bhajana Should Be Conducted ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø - ‡§∏ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ- ‡§≤‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•É‡§¢‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ [≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmi continues the discussion of SB 11.20.28, cited at the beginning of this anuccheda.] In this way, after stating that ≈õraddha alone is the criterion of eligibility for executing ananya- bhakti, Krsna instructs in what manner worship, or bhajana, should be conducted. The word ≈õraddhƒÅlu, “being established in faith,” means “being endowed with trust” (vi≈õvƒÅsavƒÅn) [in the words of scripture]. The word prita, lit., “being loving,” means “being attached to the taste (ruci)12 [for bhakti] that has come 12 The word ruci is used here in a general sense to mean a simple “liking” or “predilection.” It does not refer to ruci in the technical sense as the fifth stage of development of bhakti, as given in Rupa GosvƒÅmi’s famous progression (BRS 1.4.15-16). This is evident from the fact that the practitioner being described is one who is unable to give up sense enjoyment, whereas ruci in the technical ‚Üí‚Üí 1015 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya about.” The compound drdha-niscaya, “being firmly resolved,” means “being without deviation in one’s efforts to enact the practices of devotion.” ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ú‡•Å‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•á ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É - ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ- ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§ï‡§•‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ- ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ Because the person being described is unable to give up sense pleasures immediately, he partakes of them (ju·π£amƒÅ·πáa) while also condemning them (garhayan). The reason for this condem- nation is that such pleasures will end in misery (du·∏•khodarkƒÅn), meaning that later on they will result in lamentation and other forms of distress. The sense pleasures referred to in this verse are those that are not sinful, because scriptures never ordain sinful acts. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§- ‡§™‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§™‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§É ‡•• ‡•™‡•Æ‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ Rather, sinful enjoyment is forbidden even prior to the stage in which one simply offers one’s karma to Bhagavan, as indicated in the Visnu PurƒÅ·πáa: O King, Bhagavan Kesava is pleased with a person whose mind is not set on others’ wives, others’ wealth, and violence to others. (VP 3.8.14)13 ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø " ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•¶ ‡•§‡•ß‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§®‡§ø- ‡§∑‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ Furthermore, in the context of discussing niskƒÅma-karma as well, ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa has forbidden sinful acts in the words “if he 13 sense refers to a practitioner who has transcended the stage of anarthas. para-patni-para-dravya-para-hims√§su yo matim na karoti puman bhupa to≈üyate tena kesavah 1016 172 The Criterion of Eligibility for Ananya-bhakti does not perform other [i.e., forbidden (ni≈üiddha)]1 acts” (yady anyan na samƒÅcaret), from the following verse, which is to be discussed further ahead [in Anuccheda 174]: O Uddhava, if a person who is fixed in his prescribed duties, who does not desire the fruits of action, and who worships [Me] through sacramental actions (yaj√±as), refrains from forbidden acts, he will not go either to heaven or to hell. (SB 11.20.10)15 ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡•§ By ordaining the relinquishment of karma, it naturally follows that one is meant to give up sinful karma as well. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á- ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•ã ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•™‡•Æ‡•≠ || ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ In the Visnu-dharma, it is stated that Vaisnavas are also forbidden to engage in sinful acts: A person who transgresses the prescribed behavior established by Bhagavan can never be called a devotee of Vis≈Üu, because Bhagavan Hari is worshiped by saintly conduct. (Visnu-dharma PurƒÅ·πáa) 16 ‚Äú‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§™‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•™‡•§‡•®‡•ß‡•§‡•©‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç- 15 ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§®‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•• ‡•™‡•Æ‡•Æ ‡•• 14 This is ≈örƒ´dhara Svami’s gloss on the word anyat. sva-dharma-stho yajan yaj√±air anƒÅsih-kama uddhava na yƒÅti svarga-narakau yady anyan na samacaret maryƒÅdƒÅm ca k·πõtƒÅm tena yo bhinatti sa mƒÅnava·∏• na vis≈Üu-bhakto vij√±eya·∏• sadhu-dharmarcano harih 16 1017 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡•§ We may also consider the following statement of P·πõthu MahƒÅrƒÅja: The taste to serve the lotus feet of Bhagavan, which increases day-by-day and is of the nature of unalloyed being (sati),” imme- diately cleanses the mind’s impurities accumulated over unlim- ited births of those who are afflicted by worldly existence, just as the river GangƒÅ, which originated from the toe of Bhagavan [also washes away sinful desire]. (SB 4.21.31)18 The word sadya·∏•, “immediately,” in the clause “immediately cleanses” (sadya·∏• k·π£inoti), indicates that the cleansing of the mind’s impurities takes place from the very moment that the taste (ruci) for service comes into being. That Vaisnavas do not engage in sin is also understood from the following principle stated in the Visnu-dharma: O lord of men! When a person no longer desires to engage in sin- ful acts and longs only for virtue, it is understood that Bhagavan Hari is situated in his heart. (Visnu-dharma)19 ‚Äú‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç ‡§ö‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§•‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•™‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø- ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§•‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ “‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§≠‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¨‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡•§ We may also consider this verse from Srimad Bhagavata: “7 ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi glosses the word sati (qualifying abhiruci) as s√§ttviki, “of the nature of authentic being,” and ≈örƒ´ Vi≈õvanatha Cakravarti glosses the same word as suddha-sattva-svarupa nityety arthah, “of the nature of unalloyed being and, hence, eternal.” The word sat refers to “being” or “existence,” in general. It also signifies that which is true and not false (asat). Thus, the expression “of the nature of authentic being” refers to a manner of being or existing that is rooted in the authentic self, or in specific contexts, being that is of the essence of Suddha-sattva. Additionally, ≈örƒ´dhara Svami glosses the word tapasvinam as samsara-taptƒÅnƒÅm, “of those who are afflicted by worldly existence.” yat-pada-sevabhirucis tapasvinƒÅm ase·π£a-janmopacitam malam dhiyah sadyah k·π£inoty anvaham edhati sati yatha padangustha-vini·∏•s·πõtƒÅ sarit yada necchati pƒÉp√¢ni yadƒÅ punyƒÅni v√¢√±chati 18 19 j√±eyas tada manusyendra h·πõdi tasya hari·∏• sthitah 1018 172 The Criterion of Eligibility for Ananya-bhakti If a forbidden act should somehow occur in the case of a beloved devotee, who is engaged in the worship of the soles of Bhaga- van’s feet and who has forsaken all other affections, the Sup- reme Immanent Self, Hari, being situated within his heart, cleans it away in totality. (SB 11.5.42)20 In this verse, the word katha√±cit, “somehow,” indicates that involvement in forbidden acts runs contrary to the nature of those who have attained bhakti. Furthermore, according to the NƒÅmƒÅparƒÅdha-bhanjana-stotra from the Padma PurƒÅ≈Üa, to commit sins on the strength of Hari-bhakti is an offense: “For one who intentionally commits sins on the strength of the holy name, the means of his purification through rules simply does not exist” (Padma PurƒÅ·πáa, Brahma-khanda 25.16).21 ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Ø‡•§‡•©‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§™‡§∞ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø- ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§∞‡§É " ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Ø‡•§‡•©‡•ß ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ó‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• A related point that should be clarified is from this verse of Bhagavad GitƒÅ: “If even a person who is exceedingly ill-behaved worships Me with exclusive devotion, he should be regarded as indeed virtuous, because he is rightly resolved” (Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.30) .22 The intention here is to point out the defect of disrespecting a person who is firmly resolved to worship Bhagavan, irrespec- tive of his character, and not to give license for sinful behavior. This is clear from the verse that follows, in which it is said: “Such a person quickly becomes righteous” (Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.31).23 Here, it is the auspiciousness of having his sinfulness removed that is being pointed out. 20 21 22 22 23 sva-pada-mulam bhajatah priyasya tyaktanya-bhavasya hari·∏• paresa·∏• vikarma yac cotpatitam katha√±cid dhunoti sarvam hrdi sannivista·∏• namno balad yasya hi papa-buddhir na vidyate tasya yamair hi suddhi·∏• api cet sudurƒÉcƒÉro bhajate mam ananya-bhƒÅk sadhur eva sa mantavya·∏• samyag vyavasito hi sah k·π£ipram bhavati dharmƒÅtmƒÅ 1019Commentary 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya In SB 11.20.28, Krsna specifies three attributes of a practitioner, namely, (1) being established in faith (≈õraddhƒÅlu), (2) being engladdened (prita), or in other words, attached to the taste for bhakti (jƒÅtƒÅyƒÅm rucav asakta·∏•), and (3) being firmly resolved (drdha-niscaya). Among these three, faith is the basic quality. The other two ensue from firm faith. One naturally relishes doing what one believes in, and one is thus determined about it. The mind wavers when one lacks faith. Even with faith, if one has deeply embedded samskaras of past sense pleasure, the mind may be led astray by them. The senses are exceedingly powerful and can lead astray the mind even of a person of knowledge (balavan indriya-grƒÅmo vidvƒÅmsam api kar·π£ati, SB 9.19.17). ≈örƒ´ Jiva stipulates, however, that even such a devotee will not engage in forbidden pleasure. Why is that? Because he has ≈õraddha, signifying firm belief in the words of scripture. Any engagement in forbidden pleasure runs contrary to his faith. Faith is what inspires one to act. A person does not act in opposition to his faith, espe- cially if the activity is sinful and anti-social. Therefore, it is imper- ative to study sastra. Faith in sastra will protect one from sinful pleasures. This also implies that a practitioner of ananya-bhakti is naturally moral. This is the meaning of Prahlada’s statement that all virtuous qualities become manifest in an aki√±cana-bhakta (SB 5.18.12).24 A doubt may be raised in this regard. In Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.30, K·πõ·π£·πáa says that a person who is exclusively engaged in bhakti but who is exceedingly ill-behaved should nonetheless be considered as vir- tuous. Does this not imply that some devotees do engage in sinful acts? ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ replies that this verse is spoken in praise of bhakti and is not meant to be taken as a license to engage in sinful acts. This is why the words “even if” (api cet) have been used in the verse. They signify that normally it is not possible for a devotee to engage in any sinful act. But if it so happens, even then he will 24 yasy√§sti bhaktir bhagavaty akincana sarvair gunais tatra samasate surah harav abhaktasya kuto mahad-gunƒÅ manorathenƒÅsati dhavato bahih 1020 172 The Criterion of Eligibility for Ananya-bhakti become rectified very quickly by the power of bhakti. He will not continue to engage in sinful acts. Thus, the verse was spoken just to give an indication of the power of bhakti. To correctly ascertain the meaning of a statement, two things, besides the literal meaning of the words, are critically important. The first is the context, and the second is the speaker’s intent. State- ments are not made out of context, and a discerning speaker does not employ meaningless or incoherent words. In Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.30, K·πõ·π£·πáa is speaking only about the power of bhakti and not offering a license to engage in immoral acts. Since He declares elsewhere that He avatarically descends to establish dharma, it would contravene His own intention to support immorality on the authority of this verse. Moreover, this verse is about a person who has ≈õraddha in bhakti but whose ≈õraddha is not based on sastra. A devotee with ≈õastriya- ≈õraddha will never engage in any forbidden act, because that would go against the ≈õraddha that is his very existence, for as Krsna says, “A person is whatever his ≈õraddha is” (yo yac-chraddha·∏• sa eva sa·∏•, Gƒ™TƒÄ 17.3). 1021 Anuccheda 173 A Devotee Should Give Up Karma 173.1 Eligibility to Abandon Karma ‡•ß‡•≠‡•© ‡•§ ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•à‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á- ‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß/‡•®‡•¶‡•ß‡•Ø) – AT THIS POINT, a doubt may be raised that in the verses cited so far from the Eleventh Canto of Srimad Bhagavata [11.20.6- 8, cited in Anucchedas 170 and 171], Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa has spo- ken of karma, j√±ƒÅna, and bhakti as independent paths (kevala). But aside from the practices that are specific to these respective paths, there are daily and occasional duties, known as nitya and naimittika-karma, that are obligatory for all. So, if this is the case, how can pure j√±ƒÅna and bhakti be performed when they have to be combined with karma? Anticipating this doubt, Bha- gavan spoke the following verse to refute the idea that j√±ƒÅna and bhakti are still under the jurisdiction of karma: 1 ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç ‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•™‡•Æ‡•Ø ‡•• One should engage in works only until one has developed detachment from sense pleasure, or until one has awakened faith in hearing narrations about Me. (SB 11.20.9)1 tavat karmani kurvita na nirvidyeta yƒÅvatƒÅ mat-katha-≈õrava·πáadau vƒÅ ≈õraddha yavan na jayate 1022 173 A Devotee Should Give Up Karma ‚Äú‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•à‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø " ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ö ‡•§ ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi comments: “The word karmƒÅni, ‘works,’ refers to the daily and occasional obligatory duties (nitya and naimittika-karma).” ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ - ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§â‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§É ‡•§‡•§ ‡•™‡•Ø‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ Therefore, the defect mentioned in the following verse does not apply to one in whom either detachment or ≈õraddha has been born: ≈öruti and Smrti are My orders. One who transgresses them disobeys Me and is averse to Me. Even if such a person is My devotee, he cannot be considered a Vaisnava.2 The reason why the defect mentioned here is inapplicable to one in whom detachment or ≈õraddha has been born is because Bhagavan Himself has ordered the abandonment of nitya and naimittika-karma at that point. Rather, if one were to continue to engage in nitya and naimittika-karma even after the awak- ening of either detachment or ≈õraddha, that itself would be a transgression of Bhagavan’s order [as given in SB 11.20.9]. ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß | ‡•ß‡•ß | ‡•©‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç- “‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø” ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The same point is confirmed in the following verse along with SvƒÅmƒ´pƒÅda’s commentary: 2 ≈õruti-smrti mamaiv√§jne yas te ullanghya varttate √§jn√§cchedi mama dvesi mad-bhakto’pi na vaisnavah 1023 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya In like manner, he is the best of those established in authentic being (sattama·∏•) who worships Me, having abandoned all of his prescribed duties, even though they have been ordained by Me, and in spite of knowing the virtues [of performing them] and the defects [of neglecting them]. (SB 11.11.32)3 ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi comments: “Because of firmness in bhakti, such a person becomes qualified for the path of niv·πõtti, or ‘detachment,’ and thus relinquishes his prescribed duties.” ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§® ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß | ‡•´ |‡•™‡•ß ) - The devotee’s eligibility for the path of niv·πõtti is described by sage ≈örƒ´ Karabhajana: ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•Ñ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•É‡§£‡•Ä ‡§ö ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•™‡•Ø‡•ß ‡•• O King, one who abandons all obligations and wholeheart- edly resorts to the refuge of Bhagavan Mukunda, who alone is worthy of shelter, is no longer a servant of or a debtor to the devas, the sages, the living beings in general, family members, humankind, or the forefathers. (SB 11.5.41)* ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ø- ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ From this statement, it is clear that a person who has taken full shelter of Bhagavan is no longer a servant of all those mentioned in the verse but only a servant of Bhagavan. Con- sequently, he is no longer eligible for the practice of karma. The word kartam, “obligations,” means “that which is ordinarily to be done” (krtyam). [The devotee abandons all such conven- tional obligations.] This word can also mean “distinction” or “difference” (bhedam), in which case it indicates that a devotee

aj√±ƒÅyaivam gunan dosan mayadi·π£·π≠an api svak√§n dharman santyajya yah sarvan mam bhajet sa ca sattama·∏• devar·π£i-bh≈´tƒÅpta-nrnƒÅm pitnƒÅm na kinkaro nayam rni ca rƒÅjan sarvƒÅtmana ya·∏• saranam saranyam gato mukundam parihrtya kartam 1024 173 A Devotee Should Give Up Karma abandons the mentality of considering the devas or other living beings as worshipable independent of Bhagavan. ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§°‡•á- This mentality and its rejection by a devotee are referred to in Garuda PurƒÅna: ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•™‡•Ø‡•® ‡•• ‚ÄúThis is a deva, this is a sage, this is BrahmƒÅ, and this is Brhas- pati, all of whom are meant to be worshiped by me.” This notion persists as long as one does not take to the worship of Bhagavan Hari. (Garuda Purana ) s ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ Additionally, if the devotee engages in a forbidden act, there is no need to perform a separate ritual act (karma) as a form of atonement, because one who is surrendered to Bhagavan is not inclined to perform forbidden acts in the first place. ‡§ï‡§•‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß/‡•´/‡•™‡•®) - ‚Äî If, however, one should somehow engage in a forbidden act, even then atonement is automatically accomplished merely as a con- comitant effect of remembering Bhagavan. This point was made by the sage KarabhƒÅjana in the immediately following verse: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ú‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç ‡§ö‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§•‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡•• ‡•™‡•Ø‡•© ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ 5 ayam devo munir vandya esa brahma b·πõhaspatih ity akhyƒÅ jƒÅyate tavad yavan n√§rcayate harim 1025 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya If a forbidden act should somehow occur in the case of a beloved devotee, who is engaged in the worship of the soles of Bhaga- vƒÅn’s feet and who has forsaken all other affections, the Sup- reme Immanent Self, Hari, being situated within his heart, cleans it away in totality. (SB 11.5.42)6 1 ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø- ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ- ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§¶‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ- ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The compound tyaktanya-bhƒÅvasya, “of one who has forsaken all other affections,” should be understood to mean “of one by whom affection (bhava), or in other words, devotion (bhakti) for other gods as if for Bhagavan, has been given up.” Here [in SB 11.5.41], since the intent is to specify it as the cause of aban- doning the path of works (karma), taking shelter (sara·πáƒÅpatti) is identical in meaning to faith (≈õraddha) [as used in SB 11.20.9, cited in the beginning of this anuccheda]. This is also appropri- ate, because faith means firm conviction (vi≈õvƒÅsa) in the import of scripture, and scripture affirms that there is fear for those who have not taken refuge and fearlessness for those who have. Therefore, taking refuge in Bhagavan (≈õara·πáƒÅpatti) is itself the symptom (lingam) that faith has arisen in a person. ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ö‡§®‡•á‡§® " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•™ ‡•§ ‡•©‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•å‡§®‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡•§ Additionally, there is no need to worship the devas separately even for the sake of appeasing them, because such worship is stated to be redundant in verses such as the following: 6 Just as by pouring water on the root of a tree, its trunk, branches, and twigs become nourished, and just as by supplying food to the vital life current (prƒÅna), the senses gain strength, ‚ö´ sva-pada-mulam bhajatah priyasya tyaktanya-bhavasya hari·∏• paresa·∏• vikarma yac cotpatitam katha√±cid dhunoti sarvam hrdi sannivista·∏• 1026 173 A Devotee Should Give Up Karma so too by worshiping Bhagavan Acyuta [K·πõ·π£·πáa], the worship of all entities is effected. (SB 4.31.14)” ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ò‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á " ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ω‡§• ‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•ß‡•≠) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡•§ 12 After a person gives up karma, then even if in the course of undertaking bhakti he becomes hindered due to obstacles, it is still improper for him to lament over the abandonment of karma, as stated by ≈örƒ´ NƒÅrada: Has inauspiciousness (abhadram) ever befallen a person, what- ever his circumstances might be (yatra kva vƒÅ), who, having abandoned his prescribed duty (sva-dharma), takes to the sacred service (bhajana) of the lotus feet of Bhagavan Hari, even if he falls away from such bhajana while still in an immature condition? On the other hand, what value (artha) is gained through adherence to prescribed duty by those who fail to worship Bhagavan? (SB 1.5.17)8 ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ö (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•Æ | ‡•¨‡•¨ ) - In the Gita also, it is said: ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§É ‡•• ‡•™‡•Ø‡•™ ‡•§‡•§ Abandoning completely all [attachment to] conventional duties, seek refuge in Me alone. I will free you from all sins; do not grieve. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 18.66)” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø “‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•™‡•ß ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ 7 B yatha taror mula-nisecanena typyanti tat-skandha-bhujopa≈õƒÅkha·∏• pranopah√¢r√¢c ca yathendriyanam tathaiva sarvarhanam acutejy√§ tyaktv√§ sva-dharmam caranambujam harer bhajann apakva’tha patet tato yadi yatra kva vabhadram abhud amu≈üya kim ko vartha apto bhajatƒÅm sva-dharmatah " sarva-dharman parityajya mam ekam ≈°aranam vraja aham tvƒÅm sarva-papebhyo mok·π£ayisyƒÅmi ma sucah 1027 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya This verse and the verse cited previously (SB 11.5.41) about taking refuge of Bhagavan after abandoning all obligations [parih·πõtya kartam] are seen to have the same meaning. Therefore, in the very beginning of bhakti, karma should be given up by its consti- tutional nature (svarupata eva). This indeed is the significance of the prefix pari in the word pari-tyajya, “completely forsake.” ‚Äú‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•Æ ‡•§ ‡•¨‡•´) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø- ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡•á‡§∂ ‡•§ In the GitƒÉ verse [prior to the one just cited], Bhagavan has given instructions specifically on exclusive devotion (ananya-bhakti): Fix your mind on Me, become My devotee, worship Me, and bow down to Me. By so doing, you will come to Me. I promise this to you truthfully, because you are dear to Me. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 18.65) 10 ‡§ó‡•å‡§§‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á‡§ö- In the Gautamiya Tantra as well [the abandonment of all ritual actions other than exclusive devotion is ordained]: ‡§® ‡§ú‡§™‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§‡•§ ‡•™‡•Ø‡•´ ‡•§‡•§ For those who continuously meditate only on the lotus feet of Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa, there is no need of uttering mantras, wor- ship, other forms of meditation, or Vedic rituals. (Gautamiya Tantra 33.57)” ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø (‡§µ‡§ø‡•¶ ‡§™‡•Å‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•ß‡•© ‡•§ ‡•Ø-‡•ß‡•¶ ) - The same point is made in the Visnu Purana in ParƒÅ≈õara’s statement about King Bharata: 10 11 man-mana bhava mad-bhakto mad-yƒÅjƒ´ mƒÅm namaskuru mƒÅm evaisyasi satyam te pratijane priyo’si me na japo narcanam naiva dhyanam napi vidhikrama·∏• kevalam satatam k·πõ·π£·πáa-cara·πáƒÅmbhoja-bhƒÅvinƒÅm 1028 173 A Devotee Should Give Up Karma ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§ ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã ‡§π‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•™‡•Ø‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§Æ‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡•• ‡•™‡•Ø‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ O Maitreya, the king only chanted the names, “Yaj√±e≈õa, Acyuta, Govinda, Madhava, Ananta, Kesava, Krsna, Visnu, and Hrsƒ´ke≈õa.‚Äù Even in his dreams, he did not utter anything else. (vP 2.13.9- 10)12 ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä- ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§•‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ó‡§§‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø- ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ In this regard, the king’s doing so was due to the fact that he had no occasion whatsoever even to utter any other words. Conse- quently, it is accepted that he completely forsook all other acts of speech. Here it is understood that even if the king became involved in any action at all, he did so exclusively while chanting Bhagavan’s names, because he perceived Bhagavan’s presence everywhere. From this, it is evident that he accepted only pure bhakti. ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‚Äì This is also discussed in the Padma Purana: ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡§ú‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•™‡•Ø‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The destination that is easily attained by those who have for- saken all duties (dharma) and chant only the name of Bhagavan Visnu cannot be attained even by all those who religiously carry out their prescribed duties. (Padma Purana) 13 ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ 12 13 yaj√±e≈õƒÅcyuta govinda madhavananta kesava k·πõ·π£·πáa vi≈üno hr≈üike≈ùety aha r√§j√§ sa kevalam nanyaj jagƒÅda maitreya ki√±cit svapnantare·π£v api sarva-dharmojjhit√§ vi≈ünor nama-m√§traika jalpakƒÅ·∏• sukhena yam gatim yanti na tam sarve pi dharmik√§h 1029I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya In this manner, even according to the opinion of other sastras, it is concluded that a person who is endowed with faith is eligible to perform ananya-bhakti and is no longer eligible for karma. Commentary ≈öRI JIVA GOSVƒÄMI flourished in an era when var·πõ·πáƒÅ≈õrama-dharma was still prevalent. Those who were born and educated in this system firmly believed in it and could not imagine abandoning it. Those who were not part of this system were called veda-bƒÅhya, “people outside the jurisdiction of the prescribed duties in the Vedas.” Those who were born within varnasrama but who did not follow it were called dvija-bandhus. A true follower of var·πáƒÅ≈õrama would have no social dealing with these two classes of people, lest he fall from his dharma. There are instances in Indian history of individuals who had dealings with veda-bƒÅhyas and then had to undergo atonement and purificatory rites before being accepted back into the system. Many people voluntarily gave up their lives, because they felt they had been polluted by coming into contact with a veda-bahya. If a Hindu king was defeated by a Muslim king, the former’s queen and her maidservants would rather burn themselves alive than be touched by a veda-bahya. It is for people of this mindset that ≈örƒ´ Jiva raises a doubt at the beginning of this anuccheda. The doubt is as follows: In the var·πáƒÅ≈õrama system, everyone has to execute duties that are of two types - regular (nitya) and incidental (naimittika). No one is exempt from them. Such being the case, how is it possible to execute exclusive devotion (ananya- bhakti), as prescribed by Krsna in the previous anuccheda? Krsna Himself provides the answer to this question. He says that karma has jurisdiction only up to the point that a person has either developed detachment from it or has acquired ≈õraddha in bhakti. Consequently, there are two types of Vedic injunctions: one is to engage in karma according to one’s varna and asrama, and the 1030 173 A Devotee Should Give Up Karma other is to desist from karma when one has developed either vairƒÅ- gya or ≈õraddha in bhakti. The first is a general instruction, because it is applicable to common people. The second is an exceptional instruction. When both of these injunctions are seen to be applicable, meaning that when a person is both born and educated in varna- ≈õrama and has developed either vairagya or ≈õraddha, then the sec- ond injunction will override the first. This is determined by the Mƒ´mƒÅmsƒÅ principle, “In a conflict between general and special rules, the former is overridden by the latter, as in the case of a stan- dard form ritual (prak·πõti), [which is overridden by a specialized or altered form ritual (vik·πõti)].” Therefore, one who has attained ≈õraddha is relieved of his eligibility for karma, both nitya and naimi- ttika. In fact, it would be a defect on the part of such a person to continue to engage in karma at that point, because he would then be in violation of Krsna’s injunction given in SB 11.20.9.15

A further doubt may be raised. Every human being is born with five types of debts to the devas, the rsis, the forefathers, living beings in general, and to all humanity! One must either fulfill these responsibilities or incur sin. This obligatory duty is a nitya- karma, called the fivefold sacrifice (pa√±ca-yaj√±a). So, if one engaged in bhakti fails to attend to these debts in the prescribed manner, will he not incur sin? This question is answered by sage Karabhajana, who says that a person who has taken shelter of Bhagavan is not indebted to any- one. This is comparable to a person who is working directly for the emperor, in which case he is not obliged to the local governor. The devas, the sages, the forefathers, and all other living beings are 14 15 paurvaparye purva-daurbalyam prak·πõtivat Mimamsa-s≈´tra 6.5.54 tƒÅvat karmƒÅ≈Üi kurvita na nirvidyeta yƒÅvatƒÅ mat-katha-≈õravanadau va ≈õraddha yavan na jƒÅyate 16 In SƒÉ 11.5.41, cited in this arruccheda, six classes of entities are mentioned. In the pa√±ca-yaj√±a, however, both family members (aptah) and humankind (n·πõ·πáƒÅm), mentioned as two separate categories in SB 11.5.41, are included under the single heading of manusya-yaj√±a, which is one of the five pa√±ca-yaj√±as. Thus, there is no discrepancy between the two listings. 1031 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya not independent of Bhagavan and are sustained by Him. If water is poured on the root of a tree, then all of its branches, leaves, fruits, and flowers are automatically nourished. It was said earlier that by performing bhakti, everyone is satisfied. An additional question may be raised as an extension of the above principle. It is understood that a devotee is relieved of nitya and naimittika-karma. But what about the atonement rituals and penances, known as praya≈õcitta-karma, which are prescribed in the event of sin? In case a devotee engages in a forbidden act, know- ingly or unknowingly, he must atone for it, as prescribed in the Sm·πõti-≈õƒÅstra. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ replies, first of all, that a devotee does not engage in sinful actions. This was said before. The reason for this is that it goes against his ≈õraddha. But if he somehow commits a forbidden act, he does not have to atone for it in the manner pre- scribed according to the dictates of Hindu law, i.e., the Sm·πõti-sastra. Remembering Bhagavan is itself the recommended atonement for him. He has taken shelter of Bhagavan and thus chosen Bhagavan as his protector. Consequently, the conclusion is that a devotee is completely free from any type of duty prescribed in the Vedas related to social position. Karma-yoga and bhakti-yoga are two dif- ferent paths. A person on the path of ananya-bhakti-yoga does not participate in karma-yoga. This is the very meaning of ≈õraddha in bhakti. He takes shelter of bhakti only and not of karma or j√±ƒÅna. Thus, ≈õraddha is naturally symptomized by surrender to Bhagavan. If one doubts that a person who has ≈õraddha may not be surren- dered, then ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmi argues that such is not the case. In SB 11.5.41, quoted above, sara·πáƒÅpatti, or “surrender to Bhagavan,” is described as the cause of eligibility for giving up karma, which is also true of ≈õraddha, as expressed in SB 11.20.9. In this sense, the meaning of surrender and faith is the same, because both are the basis for giving up karma. This is also appropriate for the following reason. ≈öraddha means faith in the import of scripture, and sastra 17 devar»ôi-bh≈´tƒÅpta-nnam pit·πõ·πáam na kinkaro nayam ni ca r√§jan sarvƒÅtmana ya·∏• ≈õaranam saranyam gato mukundam parih·πõtya kartam 1032 173 A Devotee Should Give Up Karma informs us that one who does not surrender to Bhagavan is fear- ful, whereas, one who surrenders to Bhagavan is fearless. There- fore, taking shelter of Bhagavan is the symptom that ≈õraddha has manifested in a person. 173.2 Symptoms of Faith in Bhakti ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ? ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§æ- ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•à‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∂‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§ø “‡§Ü‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§É” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å- ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Ø‡•§‡•®‡•®) - We must, however, discuss how one can know whether or not ≈õraddha truly exists within an individual. Earlier sara·πáƒÅpatti, or “taking refuge in Bhagavan,” was specified as the precur- sory symptom [linga] of ≈õraddha’s existence; and the charac- teristics of this taking refuge, which will be described later [in Anuccheda 236], include the resolve to act favorably (ƒÅnuku- lyasya sankalpah) and other attributes. In addition [to these primary attributes], even the absence of the feeling of being destitute (k√§rpanya)’s in the matter of ordinary worldly deal- ings is to be understood as a symptom of faith. Indeed, the statements of sƒÉstra inspire this type of faith in Bhagavan, as does the following statement of the Gita: 18 ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•™‡•Ø‡•Ø ‡•§‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ It is to be noted here that the word karpanya in ≈örƒ´ Jiva’s statement does not refer to the karpanya (i.e., “humility”) mentioned as one of the six symptoms of surrender in the famous verse from the Vaisnava Tantra on saranagati, discussed later in Anuccheda 236. Here, karpanya refers to the sense of feeling oneself to be destitute in the matter of worldly dealings. A devotee is devoid of this attitude because of his conviction that Krsna will provide his necessities and preserve what he has, as He Himself avows in the Gita verse (9.22) cited in support of this statement. Consequently, the absence of the feeling of destitution (karpanya-abhava) is an additional symptom of the existence of faith, apart from the six primary characteristics described later. 1033 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya Those people who are exclusively devoted to Me and who wor- ship Me, being constantly absorbed in meditation on Me - for them, who are thus ever united with Me, I bear the responsi- bility to provide their necessities and preserve what they have. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.22)19 ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§π‡§ø- ‡§ï‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ï‡§•‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ- ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ( ‡§¨‡•É‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á) - Furthermore, when a person endowed with faith hears from scripture about the nature of objects, existents, qualities, and actions related to Bhagavan, even in terms of their power to influence worldly and practical phenomena, he has no doubt about the truth of such matters. Therefore, he will never abstain from them due to seeing them as ordinary material objects and perceiving some particular fault in them. Objects related to Bha- gavƒÅn truly possess such powers. An indication of this is given in the Brhan-naradiya PurƒÅ·πáa: ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∂‡§Æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡•ã‡§™‡§∂‡§Æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§¶‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•´‡•¶‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ The auspicious water that has washed the feet of Bhagavan Hari, wards off accidental death, destroys all disease, and removes all miseries. (BNP 1.37.16) 20 ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø- ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ Some people, in spite of having faith in the power of objects related to Bhagavan, obscure their power, surmising that their effects are not manifesting at present due to their own offenses. 19 ananya≈õ cintayanto mam ye jana·∏• paryupasate te·π£am nityabhiyukt√§n√§·πÅ yoga-k·π£emam vahamy aham 20 akala-m·πõtyu-samanam sarva-vyƒÅdhi-vinƒÅ≈°anam sarva-du·∏•khopa-samanam hari-padodakam subham 1034 173 A Devotee Should Give Up Karma ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å " ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§É " ( ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§°‡•á) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ- ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ On the other hand, we find statements such as this one from the Garuda PurƒÅna: ‚ÄúOne who remembers the lotus-eyed Bhaga- vƒÅn is clean, both within and without” (Garuda PurƒÅna, Preta- khanda 47.52 ) 21 Some people, in spite of having faith in such statements, still continue to bathe just to honor the tradition of ethical conduct established by personalities like ≈örƒ´ Vyasa and Narada. Oth- erwise, transgression of such conduct would itself become an offense. These sages have established such norms to prevent people from behaving in an avaricious manner. ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•å ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡•ã‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø- ‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø- ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§£‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•à‡§µ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ Moreover, having attained faith, whether still in the practice stage or in the stage of perfection, they constantly endeavor to follow the conduct of great saints, like a person who is eager to master the art of gold production [through the alchemical trans- mutation of base metals]. Perfection (siddhi) here is understood to be in the form of the direct self-disclosure (sphurana) of Bha- gavƒÅn ≈örƒ´ Hari [in one’s heart], which destroys defects, such as ulterior desire (kama), from the heart and transports one to the supreme limit of transcendental bliss. ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§ö ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ In that state of constant engagement in the means (sadhana) to bring about one’s intended goal, there is absolutely no trace of conduct that is plagued with impurities, such as duplicity and 21 ya·∏• smaret pundarikak·π£a·πÅ sa bahyabhyantarah suci·∏• 1035 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya desire for honor. It is thus all the more self-evident that there is no scope for consciously committing offenses, such as disre- specting great devotees, because such offenses are diametrically opposed to the revelation of Bhagavan in the heart. ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ- ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ Therefore, it should be understood that King Citraketu’s offense toward ≈öri Mahadeva [≈öiva] was due to not recognizing him as a great devotee, because ≈öiva’s intrinsic nature was concealed by his own independent and contradictory behavior. ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•à‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç “‡§ú‡•Å‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß | ‡•®‡•¶ | ‡•®‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‚Äú‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß | ‡•ß‡•™ |‡•ß‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§ö ‡•§ On the other hand, a devotee, in spite of having faith in bhakti, may remain habituated to involvement in sense pleasure due to the influence of the matured effects of his past karma (prƒÅra- bdha). If such is the case, then even at the time of contacting sense objects, the devotee understands them to be an obstacle to devotion, and thus bhakti in the form of humility surges up. This was expressed earlier in this statement: “While still partaking in those pleasures, he should condemn them, knowing that they will end in misery” (SB 11.20.28).22 A similar condition is described in this verse: “Although still attracted to the sense objects, a devotee of Mine who has not yet attained mastery over the senses is generally not overwhelmed by them because of bhakti’s inherently powerful capability” (SB 11.14.18).23 ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Ø ‡•§ ‡•©‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ 22 23 ju·π£amƒÅna≈õ ca tan k√§m√§n du·∏•khodarkƒÅm≈õ ca garhayan badhyamano’pi mad-bhakto visayair ajitendriya·∏• prayah pragalbhaya bhaktyƒÅ vi·π£ayair nƒÅbhibh≈´yate 1036 173 A Devotee Should Give Up Karma ‡§ñ‡§≤‡•Å ‚Äú‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•≠‡•§‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™- ‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ In regard to the following verse, [however, a distinction is to be made]: If even a person who is exceedingly ill-behaved worships Me with exclusive devotion, he should be regarded as indeed virtuous, because he is rightly resolved. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.30)24 In this statement, the ≈õraddha that is indicated by the compound ananya-bhƒÅk, “exclusive devotion,” is one that has been acquired merely through social acculturation (loka-paramparƒÅ) and not through ascertainment of the import of scripture. This type of conventional faith is referred to in verses such as the following: O Krsna, what is the conviction (nistha) of those who, although endowed with faith, nonetheless worship with disregard for the scriptural injunctions? Is it of the nature of sattva, rajas, or tamas? (Gƒ™TƒÄ 17.1)25 ‡•§ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ “‡§™‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§™‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‚Äù (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§™‡•Å- ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•á) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§£‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç “‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‚Äù (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡•§ When, however, one develops sastriya-≈õraddha, or “faith rooted in the import of scripture,” there is no scope for the ill-behavior referred to in Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.30, because it is opposed to the principles of scripture that give satisfaction to Bhagavan Vis≈Üu, such as stated in the verse cited earlier from the Visnu Purana: O King, Bhagavan Kesava is pleased with a person whose mind is not set on others’ wives, others’ wealth, and violence to others. (VP 3.8.14)26 24 api cet sudurƒÉcaro bhajate mam ananya-bhƒÅk 25 26 sƒÅdhur eva sa mantavya·∏• samyag vyavasito hi sah ye sastra-vidhim uts·πõjya yajante ≈õraddhayƒÅnvitƒÅ·∏• te·π£am ni·π£·π≠hƒÅ tu kƒÅ k·πõ·π£·πáa sattvam aho rajas tama·∏• para-patni-para-dravya-para-himsasu yo matim na karoti puman bhupa to·π£yate tena kesavah 1037 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya It also runs contrary to the essential “devoteeness” (bhaktatva) of a devotee of Bhagavan Vi·π£·πáu, as stated in the Vi·π£·πáu-dharma PurƒÅ·πáa: A person who transgresses the prescribed behavior established by Bhagavan can never be called a devotee of Vis≈Üu, because Bhagavan Hari is worshiped by saintly conduct. (Vi≈ünu-dharma PurƒÅ·πáa)27 ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•à‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ú- ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ “‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ” (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Ø‡•§‡•ß‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É “‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡•§ In addition, this ill-behavior is not based on faith in the glory of bhakti to Bhagavan. This is clear from the verse in question (Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.30), because the word api, “even,” used to qualify the word sudurƒÅcƒÅra·∏•, “an exceedingly ill-behaved person,” empha- sizes that such behavior is to be abandoned. Furthermore, in the succeeding verse, “He quickly becomes righteous and attains eternal peace” (Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.31),28 it is indicated that this ill-behavior will subsequently be given up. And finally, [the person endowed with ≈õastriya-≈õraddha desists from such behavior,]2” because it is an offense to the holy name, as stated in the following verse: “For one who intentionally commits sins on the strength of the holy name, the means of his purification through rules simply does not exist” (Padma Purana, Brahma-khanda 25.16).30 ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§® ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ- ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ 27 maryƒÅdƒÅ·πÅ ca k·πõtƒÅm tena yo bhinatti sa mƒÅnava·∏• 28 29 na vis≈Üu-bhakto vij√±eya·∏• sadhu-dharm√§rcano harih k·π£ipram bhavati dharmatma sasvac-chantim nigacchati In Sri Jiva’s Sanskrit passage, which begins with the principal clause, sastriya-≈õraddhƒÅyƒÅn tu jƒÅtƒÅyƒÅ·πÅ sudur√¢caratvayogah syat, he gives six reasons why the person endowed with sastriya-sraddha desists from the ill-behavior mentioned in Gƒ™TA 9.30. The last of these is mentioned here. Since in the original construction, this entire passage including the quoted verses forms a single sentence, we have repeated here the translation of the principal clause, to which each of the six reasons is syntactically connected. 30 n√§mno balad yasya hi papa-buddhir na vidyate tasya yamair hi suddhih 1038 173 A Devotee Should Give Up Karma Therefore, the conventional ≈õraddha referred to in Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.30 should not be included as an attribute of the person eligible to perform bhakti that is rooted in scripture, but rather as simple glorification of bhakti [inasmuch as it shows that even the least worthy of individuals becomes exalted by virtue of contact with bhakti]. ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ “‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø " (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ß‡•≠‡•§‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Bhakti executed even with such conventional ≈õraddha is instru- mental in purifying the heart, which is not the case with the worship of other gods. That this is not observed in other forms of worship is indicated in the GitƒÉ verse referred to above: “What is the conviction (ni·π£·π≠ha) of those who, although endowed with faith, nonetheless worship with disregard for the scriptural injunctions?” (Gƒ™TƒÄ 17.1).31 31 ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡•à‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á- In contrast, the completion stage of this ≈õraddha is described in the Brahma-vaivarta PurƒÅ·πáa: ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§π ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ || ‡•´‡•¶‡•ß ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø | O King, at first one investigates whether scriptural statements [regarding the power of bhakti] are true or false. At the com- pletion stage of this investigation, one thoroughly abandons the idea of their being untrue. At this point, one’s ≈õraddha becomes perfect, and being then complete, it yields the supreme fruit. (Brahma-vaivarta PurƒÅ·πáa)12 32 ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‚Äú‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß |‡•®‡•¶‡•ß‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø “‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§µ‡§æ” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß/‡•®‡•¶‡•ß‡•Ø) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ 31 ye ≈õ√§stra-vidhim uts·πõjya yajante ≈õraddhayƒÅnvita·∏• te·π£ƒÅm nisthƒÅ tu kƒÅ krsna sattvam aho rajas tama·∏• 32 kim satyam an·πõtam ceha vicara·∏• sampravartate vicare’pi k·πõte rajann asatya parivarjanam siddham bhavati purna syat tada ≈õraddha mahƒÅphala 10391 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya When the ≈õraddha characterized above has manifested, as under- stood by the appearance of its symptoms, only then are the instructions in the following verses ordained for a person: However, for a person who, by great fortune, has acquired faith in hearing My narrations and other similar devotional acts, and who is neither completely indifferent to sense objects nor overly attached to them, bhakti-yoga bestows perfection. (SB 11.20.8)33 And: One should continue to engage in prescribed karma only as long as one has not developed detachment from sense pleasure or as long as one has not awakened faith in hearing narrations about Me.
