(SB 11.20.9) 34 ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•á (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•©‡•§‡•®‡•¨ ) - Therefore, the instructions of Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa and ≈örƒ´ NƒÅrada given below are intended respectively for the person ineligible to give up karma and for the person eligible to do so. Bhaga- van Kr·π£·πáa’s instruction is for those who are ineligible to give up karma: ‡§® ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ú‡•ã‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§®‡•ç ‡•• ‡•´‡•¶‡•® ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ A wise person should not unsettle the minds of the unaware who are attached to action (karma). Rather, being situated in evenness of mind, he should engage them in action, while meticulously carrying out all manner of action. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 3.26)35 yad·πõcchaya mat-kathadau j√§ta-≈õraddhas tu ya·∏• pum√§n na nirvinno natisakto bhakti-yogo’sya siddhi-da·∏• See Anuccheda 171. 34 tavat karmƒÅni kurvita na nirvidyeta yƒÅvatƒÅ mat-katha-≈õrava·πáadau va ≈õraddha yƒÅvan na jƒÅyate See the first subsection of this anuccheda (173.1). 35 na buddhi-bhedam janayed aj√±ƒÅnƒÅm karma-sanginƒÅm jo≈üayet sarva-karmani vidvan yukta·∏• samƒÅcaran 1040 ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß/‡•´/‡•ß‡•´- 173 A Devotee Should Give Up Karma NƒÅrada’s instruction [which appears to contradict the above directive], is meant for those who are eligible to give up karma: ‡§ú‡•Å‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§á‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•¶‡•© ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ It was a great impropriety on your part to prescribe repre- hensible actions in the name of religion for people who are already naturally predisposed to such actions. On the strength of your instructions, the common person, having determined this alone as primary dharma, will not heed any prohibition of such motivated actions. (SB 1.5.15) 36 ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•¨ |‡•Ø|‡•´‡•¶ ) - Similarly, the words of Bhagavan Ajita are intended for persons eligible to give up karma: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§£‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•¶‡•™ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ One who is personally acquainted with the supreme good does not instruct an inexperienced person to engage in karma, just as an expert physician does not prescribe unwholesome food for a sick patient, even if he requests it. (SB 6.9.50 ) 37 ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•à‡§µ ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•à‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§® ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç “‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ- ‡§£‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• In ananya-bhakti, faith is the only cause for eligibility, and since it is not possible for a person ignorant of ≈õ√§stra to have acquired this faith, the instruction to give up karma is not intended for 36 jugupsitam dharma-k·πõte’nusasata·∏• svabh√§va-raktasya mah√§n vyatikrama·∏• yad-vakyato dharma ititarah sthito na manyate tasya nivƒÅra·πáam janah 37 svayam ni·∏•≈õreyasam vidvan na vakty aj√±ƒÅya karma hi na rati rogino’pathyam va√±chato’pi bhisaktamah 1041 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya him. [One may then question the validity of the above two instructions, which discourage participation in karma even for such a person.] In spite of this, however, it may be assumed that the individuals for whom the instruction is given [though unac- quainted with the glories of devotion], are carrying the impres- sions from some type of contact with devotion in past lives. This makes them fit to abandon the path of karma, and thus there is no fault in offering such an instruction. Otherwise, it would be a fault on the part of the preceptor to offer such instructions. To do so would constitute an offense, as stated later on, “It is an offense to instruct a person who is faithless, disinterested, or unwilling to hear.“38 Commentary In this subsection of Anuccheda 173, ≈örƒ´ Jiva makes the point that taking refuge in Bhagavan (sara·πáƒÅpatti) is the practical and unmis- takable symptom that ≈õraddha truly exists within an individual. Later [in Anuccheda 236] it will be explained that such taking refuge involves six characteristics: the resolve to accept that which is favorable to devotion, to reject whatever is unfavorable, to have faith that Bhagavan will provide protection, to accept Bhagavan as one’s maintainer, to offer oneself completely to Bhagavan, and to develop humility. If one studies sastras, such as Bhagavad Gita and Srimad BhƒÅga- vata, from a qualified devotee, then one naturally develops ≈õraddhƒÅ characterized by these six attributes. This is because one will find statements throughout the scripture wherein Bhagavan promises to protect His devotee, or one will read stories depicting such things. Therefore, hearing sastra is essential to the development of firm faith. Apart from this sixfold ≈õara·πáƒÅpatti (counted here as the first symptom), ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va discusses several other symptoms of ≈õraddha in this anuccheda. The second symptom of ≈õraddha is the absence 38 asraddadhane vimukhe’py asravati ya≈õ copade≈õa·∏• 1042 173 A Devotee Should Give Up Karma of the feeling of being destitute (karpa·πáya-abhƒÅva) in the matter of worldly or conventional dealings (vyavahƒÅra). This means that a devotee does not act in a way to incite feelings of pity in others in order to procure some material help from them. Such behav- ior is contrary to ≈õraddha. Anyone who acts in this way has no faith that Bhagavan is the Supreme Master of the cosmos and is compassionate toward His devotees. A devotee does not go to rich people and beg from them. This is an insult to Bhagavan. It is comparable to a son of a very wealthy person who goes to some small businessman and asks him for a few dollars. If the boy’s father comes to know of it, he would feel insulted. A devotee should not feel indigent in front of materialis- tic people. This is not humility but weakness of heart and the sign of a lack of ≈õraddha. One should remember Suka’s rhetorical ques- tion, “Why should the wise flatter those who are blinded by their wealth?“39 The third symptom of ≈õraddha is that one fully accepts the state- ments of sastra that describe the articles, categorical existents, qualities, and actions related to Bhagavan as nonmaterial, even though they may not appear to be so to one with mundane vision. For example, V·πõndƒÅvana is described as a spiritual place, the abode of Sri K·πõ·π£·πáa. But when one sees it, it does not seem different from any other place. A devotee, however, believes it to be transcenden- tal; he or she has no doubt in this regard. The same is true about the form of Bhagavan in the temple, the objects offered to Him, and so on. Although a devotee may not have personally experienced the power of these objects as described in the sastra, he or she has faith that they do indeed possess such power. The reason for this is ≈õraddha, which is to believe in the meaning of the words of sastra. The power of these objects may not always be manifest, because Bhagavan or bhakti choose not to reveal their power. Alterna- tively, their power may remain concealed from a particular person, because the latter’s offenses are obstructing their manifestation. 39 kasm√§d bhajanti kavayo dhana-durmadƒÅndhƒÅn SB 2.2.5 1043 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya In this context, a doubt may be raised. The Garuda PurƒÅna verse cited in this anuccheda (Preta-khanda 47.52)40 states that one who remembers the lotus-eyed K·πõ·π£·πáa becomes purified within and without. From this, one may conclude that if people have faith in this statement, there is no need for them to bathe, or that if they do bathe, they must not have faith in this statement. How to resolve this? ≈örƒ´ Jiva replies that in such instances, the example of great sages, such as Sri Narada and Vyasa, should be considered as deci- sive. Thus, one should continue to bathe in spite of having faith in the verse. To do otherwise would be a sign of disrespect to such sages. Moreover, it would set the wrong example for people in general, who may consider the devotee in question as an authority. The fourth symptom of ≈õraddha is that the devotee assiduously engages in bhakti. He or she has no interest in anything else. There is nothing that can deviate the mind of a devotee who is firmly established in ≈õraddha. This is true both for the practicing and the perfected devotee. The practicing devotee is eager to attain the per- fectional stage involving the immediate self-disclosure of Bhaga- v√§n, and the perfected devotee relishes bhakti at every step and thus cannot imagine doing anything else. The fifth symptom of ≈õraddha is that a devotee is very sincere and straightforward. Earlier (in Anuccheda 153), crookedness or hypocrisy (kautilya) was described as one of the five primary effects of offenses. In contrast, ≈õraddha results in simplicity. A devotee has no desire for name and fame. A true devotee, therefore, makes no effort to achieve these. As the saying goes, “personal honor is nothing but a sow’s feces,” pratisthƒÅ s≈´karƒ´-vi·π£·π≠hƒÅ. The sixth symptom of ≈õraddha is that a devotee carefully avoids offenses, especially criticism of or disrespect toward great devo- tees of Bhagavan. The seventh symptom is that a devotee makes no effort for sense pleasure. If, however, a devotee is presented with the opportunity for material enjoyment by virtue of past mer- itorious karma and is unable to discard it due to the force of past samskƒÅras, he or she will feel humbled and will pray for the grace of Bhagavan. Even while partaking in such experiences, a devotee ya·∏• smaret pundarƒ´kƒÅk·π£a·πÅ sa bahyabhyantara·∏• ≈õucih 40 1044 173 A Devotee Should Give Up Karma will not become absorbed in sense pleasure, because his mind is fixed in service, which is a source of superior satisfaction. After elaborating these symptoms of ≈õraddha, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va makes a clarification regarding Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.30. This verse should not be mis- interpreted as a license to engage in immoral behavior. Rather, it emphasizes the greatness of exclusive devotion to Bhagavan by describing its power to exalt even the lowest of individuals. It thus implies that this ill-behavior is to be rejected. It is also under- stood from the subsequent verse that once a devotee becomes estab- lished in virtue, such behavior will be given up. Moreover, such ill-behavior is an offense to the holy name, as stated in this verse: For one who intentionally commits sins on the strength of the holy name, the means of his purification through rules simply does not exist. (Padma Purana, Brahma-khanda 25.16)“1 In this context, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ makes a keen observation. He writes that the devotee spoken of in Gƒ™TƒÄ 9.30 as behaving in an abominable manner is not a devotee having ≈õraddha based on ≈õ√§stra. Rather, his ≈õraddha is acquired from social convention (loka- paramparƒÉ). This is the type of ≈õraddha described in Gƒ™TƒÄ 17.1-4. A devotee with faith that is rooted in scripture (sastriya-≈õraddha) will not engage in any act forbidden in sastra. This is the very mean- ing of sastriya-≈õraddha. Thus, there are two types of ≈õraddha - one that is based upon sastra and the other, on social convention. Most practitioners have some combination of the two. It is for practitioners endowed with sastriya-≈õraddha that K·πõ·π£·πáa ordains the abandonment of karma and exclusive engagement in bhakti. Therefore, the statements of sastra advising one not to dis- turb the minds of people engaged in karma, and those that recom- mend the abandonment of karma are intended for two different classes of people. The first type of instruction is for those who do not have ≈õƒÅstriya-≈õraddha in bhakti, and the second is for those who have acquired such ≈õraddha. From this analysis, it is clear that sastriya-≈õraddha cannot mani- fest in a person who is ignorant of sastra. Only those who have 41 nƒÅmno balad yasya hi papa-buddhir na vidyate tasya yamair hi suddhih 1045 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya heard the ≈õƒÉstra from a qualified teacher can have sastriya-≈õraddhƒÅ, not others. It is for those who are unaware of sastra that K·πõ·π£·πáa gives the instruction not to provoke them to give up karma (Gƒ™TƒÄ 3.26). They should first be inspired to listen to sastra. If they become inquisitive about sastra, they should be given ≈õƒÅstrƒ´ya knowledge and then advised to take to bhakti. If, however, they are unwill- ing to hear sastra, they should not be given sastric knowledge. Otherwise, it would be an offense on the part of the instructor. 1046 Anuccheda 174

Karma or Bhakti The Doorway to Either J√±ana ‡•ß‡•≠‡•™ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§π ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•ß‡•®‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•¶-‡•ß‡•ß ) - Now WE MAY return to the topic under discussion. After delin- eating the three paths of karma, j√±ƒÅna, and bhakti and the source of eligibility for each, ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa explains how even karma can become a means to turn one’s intentful regard toward Bhagavan (bhagavat-sammukhya): ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•à‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡•å ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•´‡•¶‡•´ ‡•§‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡§ò‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•• ‡•´‡•¶‡•¨ ‡•• O Uddhava, if a person who is fixed in his prescribed duties, who does not desire the fruits of action, and who worships [Me] through sacramental actions, refrains from forbidden acts, he will not go either to heaven or to hell. While remaining in this world and adhering to his prescribed duties, avoiding sin, and remaining pure, he attains either unadulterated aware- ness (vi≈°uddha-j√±ƒÅna), or by exceptional grace, devotion to Me. (SB 11.20.10-11)1 1 sva-dharma-stho yajan yaj√±air anasih·∏•-kƒÅma uddhava na yati svarga-narakau yady anyan na samacaret asmin loke vartamƒÅna·∏• sva-dharma-stho’naghah sucih j√±ƒÅnam visuddham apnoti mad-bhaktim ca yad·πõcchaya 1047 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö - " ‡§Ö‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§´‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•à‡§µ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§´‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi comments: “The compound anƒÅsƒ´·∏•-kƒÅma·∏• means ‘without desire for the fruits of action’ (aphala-kƒÅma·∏•). In the clause yady anyan na samacaret, ‘if he refrains from other acts,’ the pronoun anyat, ‘other’ refers to ‘forbidden actions’ (ni≈üidham) and ‘fruitive actions’ (kƒÅmyam). There are two paths leading to hell - one is by failing to carry out one’s prescribed duty, and the other is by performing forbidden acts. Conse- quently, because he adheres to his sva-dharma, and because he avoids forbidden acts, he does not go to hell. Additionally, because he does not desire the fruits of action, he does not go to heaven either. ‚Äú‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ò‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ä ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø- ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡•§ [So then, what does he attain? The second verse answers this question.] “The words asmin loke, ‘while remaining in this world,’ mean, ‘while residing in this very body.’ The word anagha·∏•, ‘sinless,’ means that he has forsaken forbidden actions. Consequently, he is also pure (suci·∏•), meaning that his impu- rities, such as attachment (rƒÅga) and so on, have been elimi- nated. The word yad·πõcchaya, ‘by exceptional grace,’ indicates that bhakti’s rarity exceeds even that of unqualified awareness (kevala-j√±ƒÅna).” [Here ends ≈örƒ´dhara Svami’s comment.] ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§´‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ In this verse, when it is said that a person performs his pre- scribed duties without desire for the fruit (aphala-kƒÅmatva), it means that he carries out such responsibilities only by consid- ering them as the orders of Isvara. In this circumstance, if he 2 This is the comment of Sri Vi≈õvanatha Cakravarti. 1048 174 Karma The Doorway to Either J√±ana or Bhakti obtains the association of a j√±ƒÅni, the mere execution of his pre- scribed duties itself becomes the offering to Bhagavan. If, how- ever, he obtains the association of a devotee, the same duties are performed directly for the pleasure of Bhagavan? ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•® ‡•§ ‡•© ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• Therefore, the word yad·πõcchaya, “by exceptional grace,” as explained previously [in Anuccheda 171], indicates his fortune in the form of obtaining the association and mercy of a devotee, as ≈örƒ´ Suka said: The ultimate benefit attainable for those engaged in the wor- ship of various gods lies in this alone - that in the course of such worship (iha), by the association of devotees, unswerving devotion for Bhagavan is evoked. (SB 2.3.11)* Commentary IN ANUCCHEDA 170, it was said that there are three means to the ultimate good, namely, karma, j√±ƒÅna, and bhakti. The general understanding about karma is that it leads only to heaven. K·πõ·π£·πáa, however, makes the point that karma can also be instrumental in orienting awareness toward Bhagavan, by becoming a doorway to j√±ƒÅna or bhakti. If a karma-yogi performs his duties without desiring anything and avoids all forbidden action, he will neither go to heaven nor hell. This is because he does not desire heaven, and he does not deserve hell. Thereafter, depending upon whether he obtains the association of a j√±ƒÅnƒ´ or a bhakta, he will either take to j√±ƒÅna- yoga or bhakti-yoga. According to ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi, bhakti’s rarity 3 4 Literally, “[the same duties] become of the nature of that which is directly pleasing to Bhagavan” (tat-santosamayatvam). et√§v√§n eva yajatam iha nihsreyasodayah bhagavaty acalo bhavo yad bhagavata-sangata·∏• See Anuccheda 32. 1049I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya exceeds that of j√±ƒÅna, because it ensues from exceptional grace (yad·πõcchaya), meaning only when one attains the grace of a bhakta. This implies that without any association at all - either of a j√±ƒÅnƒ´ or a bhakta - the eligible candidate would be drawn to no more than j√±ƒÅna-yoga. Accordingly, the candidate will attain either liberation or the abode of Bhagavan, following the two modes of orienting aware- ness, sammukhya. In the first case, he must perform his karma con- sidering it to be the order of Bhagavan, or he must offer the karma and its results to Bhagavan. This will instill dispassion in him and thus lead to j√±ƒÅna-yoga. In the second case, he will perform such actions exclusively for the pleasure of Bhagavan alone. Thus, in either case, the action is not given up. In other words, here too K·πõ·π£·πáa is not prescribing sannyasa in the sense of abandoning all prescribed action, as He says in the Gita: Without performing prescribed action, one cannot gain freedom from the bondage of karma (naiskarmya), and a person of impure heart cannot attain perfection merely by giving up prescribed action. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 3.4)5 One who performs the work for which he is meant without expect- ing the fruits of action is both a sannyƒÅsƒ´ and a yogi, but not the per- son who renounces the sacred fire and who merely desists from action. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 6.1) In the next anuccheda, Krsna instructs that one should act according to one’s eligibility. 5 6 na karmanƒÅm anarambhƒÅn nai·π£karmyam puruso’snute na ca sannyasanad eva siddhim samadhigacchati anasrita·∏• karma-phalam karyam karma karoti ya·∏• sa sannyasi ca yogi ca na niragnir na cƒÉkriyah 1050 Anuccheda 175 To Act According to One’s Eligibility Is a Virtue 1 ‡•ß‡•≠‡•´ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ- ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•ß‡•§‡•®) - IN THIS MANNER, the offering of prescribed action (karma- arpana), the cultivation of unqualified awareness ( kevala- j√±ƒÅna), and exclusive devotion ( kevala - bhakti) have been pre- scribed according to the difference in eligibility. Therefore, one should act specifically in accordance with one’s own eligibility, as stated by Bhagavan: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§Ω‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§≠‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§∑ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•¶‡•≠ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Adherence (ni·π£·π≠hƒÅ) to one’s own respective eligibility is extolled as a virtue, whereas the opposite [i.e., behaving contrary to one’s eligibility] is a fault. This is the definitive determination regarding these two - virtue and fault. (SB 11.21.2)1 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç || ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• The meaning of this statement is clear. sve sve dhikare ya nistha sa gunah parikirtita·∏• viparyayas tu do·π£a·∏• syad ubhayor esa niscaya·∏• 1051 Commentary I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya THERE are four types of people in the world: gross materialists (kƒÅmƒ´s), karma-yogis, j√±ƒÅna-yogis, and bhakti-yogis. The a·π£·π≠ƒÅnga- yogis, hatha-yogis, and raja-yogis are included in the category of j√±ƒÅna-yogis. Out of these four categories, the first has no place in our discussion, because those who are swayed by desire alone do not have faith in any of the three means to the ultimate good. To follow a path that accords with one’s eligibility is a virtue, whereas to follow a path for which one is ineligible is a vice. For the gross materialists, the classifications of virtue and vice have no real basis. They are thus arbitrary fabrications of the human mind that vary from one culture to another. If a person who is qualified either for the path of karma or j√±ƒÅna follows that path properly with an admixture of bhakti, it will be considered a virtue, because these paths cannot bestow their result without bhakti. But if a bhakta mixes his or her practice with karma or j√±ƒÅna, it will be considered a defect, because it shows a lack of ≈õraddha in bhakti. This is the significance of the statement, “To behave contrary to one’s eligibility is a fault.” In the next anuccheda, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi demonstrates that although the yogas of karma, j√±ƒÅna, and bhakti have been accepted as different means to turn one’s awareness toward the Absolute, in reality, bhakti-yoga is the sole means to do so in completion. 1052 Anuccheda 176 Bhakti Is the Real Means of Sammukhya ‡•ß‡•≠‡•¨ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ IN THIS respect, karma, being merely a gateway leading to the shift of intentful regard toward the Absolute (sammukhya), extends only as far as the appearance of j√±ƒÅna or bhakti, which are the factual paths of direct (sƒÅk·π£ƒÅt) sammukhya. Hence karma is naturally discarded by both j√±ƒÅna and bhakti. ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Among the two paths of s√§k·π£ƒÅt-sammukhya, or “direct turning of regard toward the Absolute,” the path that orients atten- tion toward the unqualified Absolute (nirvise»ôa-sammukhya) is known as the path of immediate awareness (j√±ƒÅna). The qualified aspect of the Absolute has two primary manifesta- tions (ƒÅvirbhƒÅvas) : BhagavƒÅn, the Supreme Transcendent Self, and ParamƒÅtmƒÅ, the Supreme Immanent Self. Therefore bhakti, which orients attention toward the qualified Absolute (savise·π£a- s√§mmukhya), has two primary divisions: that which is intent on Bhagavan and that which is intent on ParamƒÅtmƒÅ. ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ " ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Æ‡•ß‡•©) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‚Äú‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ã ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø " ( ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Æ‡•§‡•ß‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ 1053 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya These three manifestations of the Absolute [Brahman, Param- ƒÅtmƒÅ, and Bhagavan] and their corresponding forms of sammu- khya [j√±ƒÅna and the two divisions of bhakti] are mentioned in the Gƒ´tƒÅ. In the statement, “The Supreme Imperishable (paramam ak≈üaram) is Brahman‚Äù (Gƒ™TƒÄ 8.3), the word ak·π£ara, “imperishable,” refers to the aforementioned Brahman. The method of worship (upƒÅsanam), involving the cultivation of immediate awareness (j√±ƒÅnƒÅtmakam), is described a few verses later as the means of orienting attention toward Brahman (tat-sammukhyam): I shall tell you in brief about that supreme destination, which the knowers of the Vedas refer to as the Imperishable (aksara), into which the mendicants who are bereft of all desire enter and aspiring for which students adopt the vow of celibate apprenticeship. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 8.11)2 ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‚Äú‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Æ‡•§‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‚Äú ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã‡§Ω‡§π‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Æ‡•§‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ The ParamƒÅtmƒÅ feature is described in this verse: O best of embodied beings, perishable existence [i.e., the exis- tence of objects that are subject to passing away] is what is meant by phenomenality (adhibhutam), the cosmic being (purusa) [i.e., virƒÉ»õ] is known as the supreme deity of cosmic governance (adhidaivatam), and I Myself am the impeller and bestower of the results of all action in the form of the Immanent Self (adhiyaj√±a) present in this body. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 8.4)3 ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§°‡•ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Ä ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§®‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•ÆI‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§æ ‚Äú‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äù (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Æ‡•Ø) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ak·π£aram brahma paramam yad-ak·π£aram veda-vido vadanti visanti yad yatayo vita-rƒÅgƒÅ·∏• yad-icchanto brahmacaryam caranti tat te padam sangrahena pravaksye adhibh≈´tam k·π£aro bhava·∏• purusas cƒÅdhidaivatam adhiyaj√±o’ham ev√§tra dehe deha-bh·πõtƒÅm vara 1054 176 Bhakti Is the Real Means of Sammukhya After speaking of these two apparently distinct features of ParamƒÅtmƒÅ in accordance with the two fields over which they preside - the cosmos as a whole (virƒÉ»õ-rupa) and the individual body (vya≈ü»õi-rupa) - two types of bhakti are correspondingly depicted. These two types of bhakti toward ParamƒÅtmƒÅ, how- ever, are generally characterized as one. Among them, bhakti directed toward ParamƒÅtmƒÅ in the form of the virat-puru≈üa is referred to in this statement: O Arjuna, being constantly immersed in contemplation on the divine Supreme Cosmic Being (paramam puru≈üam) by absorp- tion in the practice of meditation with an unwavering mind, one attains Him alone. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 8.8)* Bhakti directed toward ParamƒÅtmƒÅ in the form of the Immanent Self (vya≈üti-purusa) is referred to in this verse: At the time of death, one who, being endowed with devotion, and having carefully fixed the vital force (prƒÅna) at the √§j√±ƒÅ- cakra through the power of yoga, meditates constantly with an undeviating mind on the Puru»ôa, who is omniscient, begin- ningless, the primordial preceptor, subtler than the atom, the universal sustainer, whose form transcends the limits of rationality, who is resplendent like the sun and beyond igno- rance - such a person attains that divine Supreme Immanent Self. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 8.9-10)5 ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•Æ‡•§‡•ß‡•™ ) - ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≤‡§≠‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•¶‡•Æ || ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ abhyasa-yoga-yuktena cetasa nanya-gaminƒÅ paramam puru≈üam divyam yati parthƒÅnucintayan S kavim purƒÅ·πáam anusƒÅsitaram anor a·πáiyamsam anusmared ya·∏• sarvasya dhƒÅtƒÅram acintya-rupam aditya-varnam tamasah parastat prayƒÅ·πáa-kƒÅle manasa’calena bhakty√§ yukto yoga balena caiva bhruvor madhye pranam ƒÅvesya samyak sa tam param puru≈üam upaiti divyam 1055 1 Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya Bhakti directed to Bhagavan, who is known as ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa and is referred to in the following verse by the pronoun mat, “Me,” is described in this manner: O Arjuna, one who constantly remembers Me from moment to moment, his mind being fixed exclusively on Me - to such a yogi, who is ever united with Me, I am easily attainable. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 8.14) ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•©‡•§‡•©‡•®‡•§‡•®‡•¨ ) - These three paths of sammukhya [j√±ƒÅna, bhakti toward Param- ƒÅtmƒÅ, and bhakti toward Bhagavan] are also spoken of by Bhagavan Kapiladeva: ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§ï ‡§à‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•´‡•¶‡•Ø ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ According to the differences in the seeing capacity (drsi)’ and the mutually distinct modes of contemplation (bhava), the One [Nondual Absolute] is self-disclosed as Parabrahman, in the form of consciousness alone (j√±ƒÅna-mƒÅtram), as ParamƒÅtmƒÅ, the Supreme Regulator (I≈õvara) and Immanent Self (Puman), or as Bhagavan. (SB 3.32.26) ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ã ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§ï ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§® ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ 6 7 8 ananya-ceta·∏• satatam yo mam smarati nitya≈õa·∏• tasyaham sulabha·∏• partha nitya-yuktasya yogina·∏• ≈örƒ´ Jiva takes the compound drsyadibhi·∏• to mean d·πõsya adibhi·∏•, “according to the differences in the seeing capacity (drsi), and so on.” ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmƒ´ takes it to mean d·πõsya adibhi·∏•, “according to the distinctions in the Reality to be seen (drsya), and so on.” ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi thus interprets the compound as a whole to mean “according to the distinctions in the Reality to be seen (drsya), the seer (drasta), and the instruments of seeing (karana).” The translation has been rendered according to Sri Jiva’s interpretation. j√§√§na-matram param brahma paramatmesvara·∏• puman drsyadibhi·∏• prthag bhƒÅvair bhagavan eka iyate 1056 176 Bhakti Is the Real Means of Sammukhya The word drsi·∏•, “the seeing capacity,” means “the modality of knowing” (j√±ƒÅna). So, according to the different (p·πõthak), i.e., “mutually distinct” (parasparam-anyƒÅd·πõ≈õa), modes of con- templation (bhƒÅva, i.e., bhƒÅvanƒÅ), and according to the cor- responding modalities of knowing (j√±ƒÅnƒÅdibhi·∏•), operative within different individuals (yesu), the One (eka eva) [Nondual Absolute], which is utterly complete in intrinsic nature and attributes, is self-disclosed (iyate) as Parabrahman, as Param- ƒÅtmƒÅ, or as Bhagavan. In this regard, the One [Nondual Abso- lute] is disclosed as Parabrahman through immediate aware- ness (j√±ƒÅna), as ParamƒÅtmƒÅ, through a qualified [i.e., limited] type of devotion (bhakti-vi≈õesa), and as Bhagavan, through complete devotion (p≈´r·πáa-bhakti). The intrinsic characteris- tic (svarupa-lak·π£a·πáa) of Parabrahman is consciousness alone (j√±ƒÅna-mƒÅtram) [i.e., consciousness without an object], that of ParamƒÅtmƒÅ is the Supreme Regulator (I≈õvara) and the Imma- nent Self (Puman), and that of Bhagavan is the Supreme Tran- scendent Self replete with all qualities to the highest degree (BhagavƒÅn). ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É - ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É " ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ | ‡•ß‡•™ |‡•¨) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ These three modes of orienting one’s regard toward the Absolute (sammukhya) have been described in the Bhagavat and Parama- tmƒÅ Sandarbhas. The sammukhya of Brahman was described in verses such as this: O Unlimited One (bhuman)! This glory (mahima) of Yours, who are devoid of qualification (aguna), can nonetheless be directly intuited as self-revealing in nature (ananya-bodhyatmatayƒÅ) and not otherwise perceivable, by those whose inner percep- tual faculty has been purified, or in other words, turned within (amal√°ntar-atmabhih). This realization is possible through immediate apperception of the inner cognizing faculty [antah- karana] as one in identity with the self (sv√§nubhavat), by way of its becoming free from transformation (avikriyƒÅt) and devoid of 1057 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya any particularized form or objectness (arupata·∏•). (SB 10.14.6) ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‚Äú‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç” ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•®‡•ß‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ The sammukhya of ParamƒÅtmƒÅ was described in verses such as this: Some practitioners meditate with fixed attention on the Puru≈üa, residing in the space of the heart of their own bodies and mea- suring the span of the thumb and forefinger. He has four arms and holds a lotus, disc, conch, and club. (SB 2.2.8)1o ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§É " ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§ø ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•≠‡•§‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö ‡•§ And the sammukhya of Bhagavan was depicted in verses such as this: In his pure heart, which was established in perfect fixity through the yoga of unalloyed devotion, Vyasa saw the Com- plete Original Person along with His extrinsic potency, mƒÅyƒÅ, which was apart from and yet supported by Him. (SB 1.7.4)11 ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ Moreover, the processes of j√±ƒÅna and the two types of bhakti are without distinction in terms of sammukhyatƒÅ, meaning that they all focus one’s intentful regard toward the Absolute and, in so doing, counteract the tendency for attention to be directed away from the Absolute. ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø " ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ | ‡•ß‡•™ |‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‚Äú‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç 9 tathƒÅpi bhuman mahimagunasya te viboddhum arhaty amalantar-atmabhi·∏• avikriyƒÅt sv√§nubhavad arupato hy ananya-bodhyatmataya na canyathƒÅ See Bhagavat Sandarbha, Anuccheda 6 for an explanation of this verse. 10 kecit sva-dehƒÅntar-h·πõdayƒÅvak√§se prade≈õa-matram purusa·πÅ vasantam catur-bhujam kanja-rathƒÅnga-sankha-gada-dharam dharanaya smaranti See Paramatma Sandarbha, Anuccheda 4. 11 bhakti-yogena manasi samyak pranihite’male apasyat puru·π£am purnam mƒÅyam ca tad-apƒÅ≈õrayam 1058 176 Bhakti Is the Real Means of Sammukhya ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•ß‡•®‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡•©‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‚Äú‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡§æ‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•¶‡•§‡•©‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§´‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ In spite of this, however, even j√±ƒÅna is rejected for the following three reasons: (1) Without bhakti, unqualified awareness (kevala-j√±ƒÅna) is pointless, as stated by Brahma: O Almighty Lord, those who discard bhakti unto You, which is the means to supreme blessedness, and strive instead to attain realization of the radically unqualified Absolute, are left in the end with nothing more than their own labor, like those engaged in threshing coarse husks devoid of grain. (SB 10.14.4)12 (2) Bhakti, on the other hand, does not depend on j√±ƒÅna, as affirmed by ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa: Therefore, for the yogi who is endowed with bhakti for Me and whose mind is fixed on Me, knowledge and renunciation are not generally conducive to the ultimate good here in this world. (SB 11.20.31) 13 (3) Furthermore, bhakti can award the results of all other paths as its concomitant effects, as stated by ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa: 12 13 Whatever may be attained by execution of prescribed duties (karma), penances, the cultivation of j√±ana, renunciation, prac- tice of yoga, offering of charity in accordance with the princi- ples of dharma, or even by any other means to the ultimate good, is easily attained by My devotee simply through engagement in bhakti-yoga unto Me. If My devotee should somehow aspire for heaven, liberation, or My abode, he can also attain these. (SB 11.20.32-33)14 Sreyah-s·πõtim bhaktim udasya te vibho klisyanti ye kevala-bodha-labdhaye te≈ü√¢m asau klesala eva sisyate nanyad yatha sthula-tus√§vaghƒÅtinƒÅm tasman mad-bhakti-yuktasya yogino vai mad-√¢tmana·∏• na j√±ƒÅnam na ca vairagyam praya·∏• ≈õreyo bhaved tha 14 yat-karmabhir yat-tapasa jnana-vairagyata≈õ ca yat yogena dana-dharmena sreyobhir itarair api sarvam mad-bhakti-yogena mad-bhakto labhate √±jasƒÅ svargƒÅpavargam mad-dhama katha√±cid yadi va√±chati 1059I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya ‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§µ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø- ‡§ï‡§∂‡§ø‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡§™‡§ø “‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•≠‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•®‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∂‡§É ‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡•Ä‡§¶‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•≠ ‡•§ ‡•® ‡•§ ‡•©‡•Ø) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•å ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æ- ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∏ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Consequently, what remains out of the processes that center one’s awareness on the Absolute is bhakti in the form of wor- ship of the qualified Absolute (savise·π£a-upƒÅsanƒÅ). Even in regard to bhakti of this classification, there are some who disregard the forms of Bhagavan Vi·π£·πáu and worship I≈õvara as ultimately formless (nirƒÅkƒÅra-i≈õvara), while others esteem the worship of I≈õvara in some other form (anyƒÅkƒÅra-i≈õvara) [such as that of the devas]. These types of worship are also rejected for the follow- ing reasons. First of all, even the great asura, Hiranyakasipu, had brahma-j√±ƒÅna, as indicated in his own words: The ƒÅtmƒÅ is eternal, imperishable, pure, all-pervading, omni- scient, and transcendental to matter. By the influence of its own deluding potency, the ƒÅtmƒÅ adopts a material body and thus accepts the gunas of primordial nature. (SB 7.2.22)15 Secondly, Hiranyakasipu’s conception of Isvara as ultimate- ly formless (nirƒÅkƒÅra-i≈õvara) is evident from the historical anecdote narrated by him, in which he said: 15 O gentle ladies, the Immutable Regulator (avyaya·∏• i≈õa·∏•)16 cre- ates, sustains, and dissolves this world by His own will. For that nitya ƒÅtmƒÅvyaya·∏• ≈õuddha·∏• sarvagah sarva-vit para·∏• dhatte’sav atmano lingam mayaya vis·πõjan gu·πáƒÅn 16 The word avyaya primarily means “free from change, mutation, modification, or decay.” According to the Hindi Sabda-sagara, avyaya also means “that which perpetually exists in the state of ‘One Taste’ [i.e., Brahman]” (sadƒÅ eka-rasa rahane-vƒÅlƒÅ). In the same lexicon, avyaya is also given as a synonym for “Parabrahman.” Since Sri Jƒ´va uses the term parabrahman in this anuccheda to refer to the unqualified Absolute, characterized as “consciousness alone” (j√±ƒÅna-mƒÅtram), it is evident that he is taking the words avyayah isah here as synonymous with nirakara-isvara, “the formless Absolute.” Additionally, in SB 10.14.6, which ≈örƒ´ Jiva cites in this anuccheda as an illustration of the 1060 176 Bhakti Is the Real Means of Sammukhya powerful Regulator (isitu·∏•), this world of mobile and stationary beings is said to be a plaything. Therefore, He is fully competent, both in the matter of sustenance and dissolution. (SB 7.2.39)17 In addition, Hiranyakasipu’s prayers to ≈örƒ´ Brahma [as the Sup- reme Controlling Entity, SB 7.3.26-34] indicate that he held to a conception of Isvara separate from Bhagavan Vi·π£·πáu (anyƒÅkƒÅra- i≈õvara). Hiranyakasipu is condemned, however, for considering Bhagavan Vi·π£·πáu as an ordinary devatƒÅ. ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§π‡§æ- ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç “‡§∏‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•© ‡•§ ‡•®‡•Ø‡•§‡•ß‡•© ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§´‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•á‡§Ø‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ Then in other places, ahangrahopƒÅsanƒÅ, or “worship of one- self as the Supreme,” is also rejected, because it is ridiculed by pure devotees like the Yadus, who derided Paundraka-Vasudeva. [Paundraka considered himself to be Bhagavan Vasudeva and advised K·πõ·π£·πáa to give up His pretense of being BhagavƒÅn.] Fur- thermore, the fruit of ahangrahopƒÅsanƒÅ, which is liberation, is described as fit to be rejected in verses such as this: Even if granted by Me, [My] people (janƒÅ·∏•) do not accept mukti in the form of residence on the same planet as Me (s√§lokya), enjoyment of similar opulence (s√§r»ôti), proximity to Me (sƒÅmi- pya), endowment with a form identical to Mine (sar≈´pya), or oneness with Me (aikatvam), if such liberated states preclude the possibility of service to Me. (SB 3.29.13)18 ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ " ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡•ã ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø” ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ sammukhya of Brahman, we find the word avikriyat, which is identical in meaning to the word avyaya. Sridhara Svami glosses the word avikriyat as vi≈°e·π£ƒÅkƒÅras tad-rahitat, “devoid of any particular form.” From this perspective as well, the word avyaya here can be understood to refer to the formless Absolute. 17 yad·πõechaye≈õa·∏• srjatidam avyayo ya eva rak·π£aty avalumpate ca yah tasyabalah kri·∏çanam ahur isitus caracaram nigraha-sangrahe prabhu·∏• 18 s√§lokya-s√•rsti-sƒÅmƒ´pya-s√§r√ºpyaikatvam apy uta diyamƒÅnam na grhnanti vina mat-sevanam jan√§h 1061 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya A similar sentiment is expressed by the great devotee ≈örƒ´ Hanuman: “Which fool would desire the post of mastership after attaining the state of being a servant?“19 ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡§ø ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß/‡•®‡•¶‡•ß‡•©‡•™ ) - With all this in mind, Bhagavan singles out niski√±cana-bhakti alone as being the topmost path by glorifying such selfless devotees: ‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•à‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•´‡•ß‡•¶ || Indeed, My exclusive devotees, who are endowed with wisdom (dhirah) and established in authentic being (sadhava·∏•), do not covet anything at all, not even ultimate liberation from rebirth, even if awarded by Me. (SB 11.20.34)20 ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö - ‚Äú‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡•à‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡•§ ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi comments: “The word dhirah means, ’endowed with wisdom’ (dhimanta·∏•). This is because they are ’exclusively devoted to Me’ (mamaikantina·∏•), meaning that they have love (priti-yuktƒÅ·∏•) for Me alone (mayy eva). Therefore, since they do not accept liberation even if awarded by Me, it goes without saying that they do not covet it. The compound apunar-bhavam, ’liberation from rebirth,’ means ‘absolute oneness with Brah- man’ (atyantikam kaivalyam).” [Here ends ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi’s comment.] ‡§à‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§°‡•á- The supreme glory of exclusive devotees such as this is described in the Garuda PurƒÅ·πáa: 19 ko mudho dasatƒÉm pr√§pya prabhavam padam icchati Padyavali 110 20 na ki√±cit sadhavo dhira bhakta hy ekƒÅntino mama vƒÅ√±chanty api maya dattam kaivalyam apunar-bhavam 1062 176 Bhakti Is the Real Means of Sammukhya ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ó‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•´‡•ß‡•® ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ A brahmana who performs a particular type of sacrifice known as satra-yaga is superior to thousands of other brahmanas. One who knows the conclusion of all the Vedas is superior to thou- sands of such performers of the satra-yaga. A devotee of Bha- gavƒÅn Vi·π£·πáu is better than millions of those who know the con- clusion of all the Vedas, and an exclusive devotee is superior to thousands of Vaisnavas. (Garuda Purana)21 Commentary IN SB 11.20.6 (cited in Anuccheda 170), ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa said that He prop- agated the three paths of karma, j√±ƒÅna, and bhakti with the intent of bestowing the highest good (≈õreyas) upon humanity. In reality, the highest good is to turn one’s intentful regard toward the Abso- lute Reality (para-tattva-sammukhya), because the root cause of a living being’s suffering is the beginningless absence of awareness of that Reality. This was stated in the very beginning of Sri Jiva’s exposition on the abhidheya, or the means of ultimate attainment (Anuccheda 1). Among these three paths, karma is only an indirect means. If executed without any material motive, it will lead one to j√±ƒÅna or bhakti. In this respect, it is comparable to a car that one uses to go to the airport. The utility of the car comes to an end once one reaches the airport. Thus, truly speaking, there are only two means of para-tattva-sammukhya. The one nondual tattva is self-disclosed in three features - as Brahman, ParamƒÅtmƒÅ, and Bhagavan. J√±ana is the means of brahma-sammukhya, j√±ƒÅnam tad brahma-dar≈õanam (SB 3.32.31). The 21 brƒÅhma·πáƒÅnƒÅm sahasrebhya·∏• satra-yƒÅji visi≈üyate satra-yaji-sahasrebhya·∏• sarva-vedanta-p√§raga·∏• sarva-vedanta-vit-kotyƒÅm visnu-bhakto visisyate vai·π£·πáavƒÅnƒÅ·πÅ sahasrebhya ekanty eko visisyate 1063 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya other two manifestations of the tattva can be realized by bhakti. The specific manner in which the tattva is self-disclosed is in accor- dance with the conviction of a particular practitioner. This is the import of Kapila’s statement cited in this anuccheda (SB 3.32.26). Although the tattva is one, It manifests according to the distinct mode of contemplation (bhava, i.e., bhavana) of the sadhaka. Those who adopt the path of j√±ƒÅna and who thus hold to the conviction that the tattva is devoid of all qualification, realize It as Brahman. The yogis, who meditate on the Immanent Self within the core of their hearts and consider Him to be the supreme tattva, realize It as ParamƒÅtmƒÅ. Those, however, who regard the tattva as the Com- plete Person, self-endowed with unlimited potency, and who wor- ship Him with bhakti, realize It as Bhagavan. This subject has been discussed in Bhagavat Sandarbha and Paramatma Sandarbha. ≈örƒ´ Jiva cites Gƒ™TƒÄ 8.3 as a reference to Brahman and verse 8.11 as the means of Its realization. He cites Gƒ™TƒÄ 8.4 as a reference to ParamƒÅtmƒÅ in two distinct yet related features. In this verse, the word puru≈üa refers to the virat-puru≈üa, or the cosmic form of ParamƒÅtmƒÅ in the shape of the universe. This virat-puru≈üa is known as adhidaivatam, or the support and presiding deity of the devas. This refers to the ParamƒÅtmƒÅ feature that is immanent within the cosmos as a whole. In the same verse, K·πõ·π£·πáa then states that within the body, He Himself is the adhiyaj√±a, or “the inner impeller and object of all action.” This refers to the ParamƒÅtmƒÅ feature that is immanent within the individual bodies of the living beings (vya≈üti-purusa). The means to realize these two features of ParamƒÅtmƒÅ are then given in Gƒ™TƒÄ 8.8 and Gƒ™TƒÄ 8.9-10, respectively. The third aspect of the tattva is Bhagavan, who is referred to as ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa in Gƒ™TƒÄ 8.14. The means of realizing Him is also described in the same verse. After first acknowledging these three types of sammukhya (j√±ƒÅna, bhakti toward ParamƒÅtmƒÅ, and bhakti toward Bhagavan), ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmi argues that in fact the real sammukhya occurs only by way of bhakti. It has been said repeatedly that without bhakti, j√±ƒÅna cannot bring forth its intended fruit. Therefore, even the sammukhya of j√±ƒÅna is made possible only by the grace of bhakti. 1064 176 Bhakti Is the Real Means of Sammukhya Bhakti, however, is not at all dependent upon j√±ƒÅna for anything. Such being the case, even j√±ƒÅna, like karma, is not a true or inde- pendent means of sammukhya. Thus, only bhakti remains as the genuine and complete form of sammukhya. ≈örƒ´ Jiva explains that within bhakti in the broadest sense as savise·π£a-sammukhya, there are different types of sammukhya. He divides them into two primary groups - those who are intent upon Visnu or Krsna as Bhagavan, and those who are intent upon some entity other than Vi·π£·πáu as Bhagavan. In the second category, there are three further divisions, namely, considering Bhagavan as form- less, considering oneself as Bhagavan, and considering some other deva as Bhagavan. Among these three, the first type considers Bhagavan as qualified with potency but formless (sagu·πáa-nirƒÅkƒÅra). Thus, their object of worship is not the same as Brahman, which is unqualified and formless (nirguna-nirƒÅkƒÅra). The third type consid- ers devas such as Ga·πáe≈õa as Bhagavan. These three types of bhaktas are found mostly in the western part of India. Worshipers of the second category do not meet the true crite- ria of bhakti, because their bhakti is not intended for Bhagavan as He is in His own intrinsic being. In Bhagavat Sandarbha as well as in K·πõ·π£·πáa Sandarbha, Bhagavan’s true identity was established as Vi≈ü≈Üu, and Svayam Bhagavan’s identity, as Krsna. From this under- standing, worship of any other entity cannot be accepted as true bhakti. ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va gives the example of Hiranyakasipu, who considered himself to be a staunch enemy of Visnu. He also engaged in a form of bhakti intended for the Supreme Controller, with the idea that He is formless or has a form other than that of Visnu. By such devotion, he did not bring about tattva-sammukhya. Rather, he tortured his own son Prahlada, who was a genuine devotee of Bhagavan. More- over, he considered Vis≈Üu to be but one of the devas. For all these reasons, such bhakti is not accepted as the abhidheya. The practice of considering oneself as Bhagavan, known as ahangrahopƒÅsanƒÅ, is condemned, because it is based on a gross misconception about the nature of the living being. No individual being can be Bhagavan. It is akin to the idea of aham brahmasmi 1065 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya of the j√±ƒÅna-marga. This goes against the fundamental principle of bhakti, in which a loving relationship permanently exists between the bhakta and Bhagavan. Therefore, pure devotees mock such worship and even consider it offensive. The conclusion then is that only exclusive devotion, ananya-bhakti, is the abhidheya. In the next anuccheda, the two divisions of ananyƒÅ-bhakti, namely, the one based on scriptural injunctions and the other based upon natural liking, are described. 1066 Bhakti Born of Natural Attraction Is the Abhidheya Anucchedas 177-178 Anuccheda 177 Bhakti Born of Natural Attraction Transcends Virtue and Vice ‡•ß‡•≠‡•≠ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ß‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑ ‡§è‡§µ ‡•§ BECAUSE this bhakti surpasses all other types of bliss (ananda), it is the embodiment of supreme bliss (paramƒÅnanda). There- fore, to engage in bhakti out of natural attraction (svabhƒÅvata eva) is a virtue (guna). Although bhakti is truly of the nature of supreme bliss, some practitioners are unable to experience its sweetness due to their own defects. Such persons may engage in devotion only by weighing the consequences of merit and demerit (guna dosa ) based solely on the injunctions and prohi- bitions of scripture (vidhi- nisedha). To do so, however, is consid- ered a defect (dosa) in contrast to engagement in devotion out of natural attraction. ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á ‚Äú‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§æ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•ß‡•Ø ‡•§ ‡•©‡•¨) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç " ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•Ø‡•§‡•™‡•´) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‚Äú‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç‡§≠‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•§‡•™‡•´) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ- ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ß‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡•å ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•ß‡•®‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•©‡•¨) - As ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa said in the previous chapter of Srimad BhƒÅga- vata, ‚ÄúSama, or ‚Äòunwavering mental tranquility,’ is fixity of the 1069I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya intellect on Me” (SB 11.19.36)! In this and the subsequent state- ments, the ordained engagement in direct bhakti is a virtue (guna), whereas neglecting to do so is a defect (dosa). Krsna con- cludes His discussion on virtues and defects with the following statement: O Uddhava, these questions of yours have all been suitably answered. What need is there for further elaboration? The definitive characteristic of virtue and defect may be summed up as follows: to distinguish virtues and faults (guna-dosa) is itself a defect (dosa), whereas to be free from the perception of both is real virtue (guna). (SB 11.19.45)2 In accordance with this teaching, those who have tasted the sweetness (madhurya) of devotion are free from the virtues and defects (guna-dosa) associated with the injunctions and prohibi- tions of scripture (vidhi-ni·π£edha). These devotees are described by Bhagavan K·πõ·π£·πáa as follows: ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡•á‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç || ‡•´‡•ß‡•© || Those who are established in authentic being (sƒÅdh≈´nƒÅm), who are thus equally disposed to all phenomenal uprisings (sama-cittƒÅnƒÅm), who have attained the transcendence [I≈õvara] beyond the scope of intellection (buddhe·∏• param upeyu·π£ƒÅm), and 1 samo man-nisthata buddheh Œ£ In SB 11.19.28-32, Uddhava asks Krsna a series of questions, including, “What is sama?” In particular, in the last three of these verses (SB 11.19.30-32), the things he inquires about would typically be regarded either as virtues (guna) or their opposite, i.e., defects (dosa), although he doesn’t explicitly use these terms. Krsna answers these questions in order in SB 11.19.33-45. It is only in the final verse in this series that He uses the terms guna and dosa, referring everything just said back to this twofold classification. According to this understanding, sama, which K·πõ·π£·πáa equates with bhakti (i.e., “fixity of the intellect on Him”), is understood as a virtue, whereas its opposite is a defect. This is the point being made here. Bhakti is also directly mentioned in this list in SB 11.19.40. eta uddhava te prasna·∏• sarve s√§dhu nirupitƒÅ·∏• kim var·πáitena bahuna lak·π£a·πáam guna-dosayoh guna-dosa-drsir doso gunas tubhaya-varjitah 1070 177 Bhakti Born of Natural Attraction Transcends Virtue and Vice who are exclusively devoted to Me, have no attributes (gunas) arising out of virtue and vice (guna-dosa). (SB 11.20.36)3 ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö - " ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä- ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi comments: “In this verse, the word gu·πáa·∏•, ‘attributes,’ refers to the piety and sin (punya-papa) that arise from virtue and vice (guna-dosa), or in other words, from [obeying] the prescriptions and [ignoring] the prohibitions of scripture.” Commentary JIVA GOSVƒÄMI has been gradually building his argument to illus- trate the splendor of bhakti. It is as though bhakti were a glitter- ing diamond that was covered with mud, sullied, and unpolished, amidst a pile of other stones that seem more colorful and attrac- tive. He has cleared away the dirt, and now he begins polishing the diamond. In this anuccheda, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va makes the point that bhakti is the most natural engagement for us to participate in. Why is that? Because we are all looking for peace and happiness unmixed with any suf- fering. This is our most basic and primary desire. In this matter, we are all equal, and we can drop all our differences. In other respects, our differences are apparent, and we find ourselves in competi- tion for the objects of our desire. By its very nature, bhakti is bliss and awareness. It bestows a quality of bliss that has no compari- son to any experience of happiness that we have ever had. There- fore, engaging in bhakti is the most natural thing for a living being. There is no injunction required for it. When a person is dying from starvation, he does not need to be given an order to eat. He will do so willingly and happily with great enthusiasm and feel great bliss. In fact, if someone were to 3 na mayy ekanta-bhaktƒÅnƒÅm guna-dosodbhavƒÅ gunah sƒÅdh≈´nƒÅm sama-cittƒÅnƒÅm buddhe·∏• param upeyu·π£ƒÅm 1071 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya try to stop him, he would even resort to fighting to get at the food. If such is the case with mere bodily or physical nourishment, then why doesn’t everyone take to bhakti, which is nourishment for the heart, mind, and soul? Why does sastra need to enjoin it? We are all suffering in different ways; everyone is starving for want of peace and happiness. We should naturally become absorbed in bhakti, the very nature of which is peace and supreme bliss, as Krsna informs Uddhava, “Mental peace (sama) is fixity of the intellect on Me” (SB 11.19.36). If the mind is absorbed in Krsna, it cannot be disturbed, because it is not available for disturbance. It is natural for the mind to become absorbed in K·πõ·π£·πáa, because the mind is attracted to beauty and pleasure. K·πõ·π£·πáa is beauty and bliss personified. Therefore, peace and happiness are concomitant effects of bhakti. In spite of bhakti’s being of such nature, however, people still do not take to it for the simple reason that they are in a diseased condition. If a person is sick with jaundice or a high fever, then he or she feels no appetite, even though the body is in need of nour- ishment. In the same manner, people are not attracted to bhakti because of the ignorance that bewilders their intelligence and the offenses that make them immune to the experience of bhakti’s bliss- ful nature. To address this condition, sastra mercifully ordains the practice of bhakti, just as a qualified physician instructs a sick patient to adopt a wholesome diet. This bhakti, however, which is taken up on the basis of scrip- tural injunctions, is known as vaidhi-bhakti. Such formal devo- tion is not undertaken with the same enthusiasm and absorption as when bhakti is performed out of natural attraction, known as rƒÅgƒÅnuga-bhakti. A sick person, who eats only on the doctor’s order, will not eat with the same gusto and absorption as a healthy person who is genuinely hungry. On this basis, Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi boldly asserts that in comparison to bhakti impelled by natural attraction, engage- ment in devotion merely on the basis of ≈õ√§strika injunctions is a defect (dosa). To speak of vaidhi-bhakti as defective here means that such practice is comparatively weaker and not that it is otherwise devoid of inherent value. 1072 177 Bhakti Born of Natural Attraction Transcends Virtue and Vice One may question how Krsna’s statement, “Sama, or ‘unwaver- ing mental tranquility,’ is fixity of the intellect on Me” (SB 11.19.36), brings bhakti under the purview of the scriptural injunctions and prohibitions, and as a consequence, of virtue and vice? The answer is that scriptural injunctions are concerned with engaging people in pious acts, which result in peace and happiness, and with pre- venting their involvement in immoral acts, which result in distur- bance and suffering. Since peace of mind (sama) is defined as fix- ity of the intellect on Krsna, it naturally follows that one should engage in bhakti and that this is a virtue. Action contrary to this is prohibited, it being a vice. Although there is no direct injunction in K·πõ·π£·πáa’s statement, it is implied. This is called a siddhopade≈õa. If a reliable and authoritative person informs you that there is a treasure hidden in your back- yard, there is no need to lay down an injunction for you to go and unearth it. Implicit within the declaration itself is the imperative to do so. The divisions of virtue and vice in regard to bhakti, however, are different from those that apply in the field of karma. Devo- tees are beyond the purview of virtue and vice as defined on the path of karma, which are based respectively on the injunctions and prohibitions given in sastra. This is because devotees do not have attributes arising from material nature, constituted of sattva, rajas, and tamas. Their qualities manifest from bhakti and are beyond the gunas of nature, even though they may appear material. 1073 Anuccheda 178 Only Aki√±canƒÅ Bhakti Is the Abhidheya 1 ‡•ß‡•≠‡•Æ | ‡§á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§§ ‡§â‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‚Äú‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§É " (‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡•¶ ‡§â‡•¶ ‡•¨ ‡•§ ‡•Ø) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡•§ ONLY that bhakti which is known as aki√±cana, or “unconditional devotion,” is by its constitutional nature appropriate for the liv- ing beings (jivas). This is due to the fact that bhakti is the natural refuge and support (asraya) of all living beings. This is indicated in the ≈öruti: “He is the original Cause and the Overlord of the presiding deities of the senses” (SU 6.9). ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡•§ Although the living beings are integrated parts (amsas) of Bha- gavan, they remain under His shelter, because their “partness” (angatva) [meaning, “the existential condition of their being conscious parts of the Whole”] is admitted as existing external sa kƒÅra·πáam kara·πáƒÅdhipadhipah Here, the implication is that since Bhagavan is the original Cause and Overlord, it is only by the infusion of a portion of His intrinsic potency (svarupa-sakti) that the presiding deities of the senses are enabled to execute their overseership office, which then facilitates the ordinary sense-functioning of all living beings. Hence, bhakti, which is the condensed essence of the svarupa-sakti, indirectly supports even the ordinary sense-functioning, and indeed the life, of all living beings. This clearly signifies that the jivas’ essential make-up is such that it is naturally supported by svarupa-sakti in the form of bhakti. On this basis, bhakti is understood as that which the jivas are meant to be involved in, by their very own essential nature. To do otherwise would be to violate their essential nature. 1074 178 Only Aki√±cana Bhakti Is the Abhidheya to Him, just as particles of sunlight exist outside the orb of the sun. ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‚Äî Therefore, in the explanation of pranava, the sacred syllable Om, found in the Uttarakhanda of the Padma PurƒÅna, [ we find a statement regarding the existential status of the living beings]: ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•´‡•ß‡•™ ‡•§‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•ß‡•´ ‡•§‡•§ Pranava consists of the three syllables A, U, and M. Beyond this, it is said to be the embodiment of the three Vedas [Sama, Rg, and Yajur] and the seat of Brahman. The syllable A represents Visnu, u represents the Goddess ≈öri [Lak·π£mi], and –º represents the twenty-fifth element, which is the servant of these two. (Padma PurƒÅna, Uttarakhanda 226. 22-23 ) 2 ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ö “‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§∑‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•å ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§®‡§É” ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ This description ends with these words: ‚ÄúThe jiva, who is referred to by the syllable M, is the irreducible remainder (sesa) [i.e., the integrated part] of Bhagavan and is conscious” (Padma PurƒÅna, Uttarakhanda 226.28) 3 ‡§§‡§•‡§æ Further, it is said in the Padma Purana: ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§â‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡•• ‡•´‡•ß‡•¨ ‡•• a-kara≈õ cƒÅpy u-kara≈õ ca ma-kƒÅra≈õ ca tatah param veda-trayƒÅtmakam proktari pranavar brahmanah padam a-kƒÅrenocyate visnuh srir u-kƒÅrena cocyate ma-karas tu tayor dasa·∏• pa√±ca-vim≈õa·∏• prakirtita·∏• bhagavac-chesa-r≈´po’sau ma-karakhyah sacetanah 1075 I Bhakti Is the Complete Abhidheya Some say that the syllable u represents ascertainment (avadha- rana), and ≈örƒ´, being intrinsically connected with Vis≈Üu, is also represented by the syllable A. She is ever united with Bhagavan Vis≈Üu, just as the sun’s effulgence is ever connected to the sun. (Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda 227.36b-39a)* ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§µ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á- Therefore, for ≈örƒ´ Vaisnavas, pranava is the only mahƒÅvƒÅkya, or “quintessential utterance of the Vedas.” Similarly, while eluci- dating the meaning of the eighteen-syllable mantra, it is stated: 4 ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç | ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡•§‡•§ ‡•´‡•ß‡•≠ ‡•§‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•´‡•ß‡•Æ ‡•§‡•§ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ú‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É || ‡•´‡•ß‡•Ø ‡•• “In all circumstances of time and place, I enact all manner of servanthood for the pleasure of ≈örƒ´ Vi·π£·πáu, the husband of God- dess KamalƒÅ [Laksmi].’ May this state of primary servitorship become my very nature.” Knowing this conclusion as the mean- ing of the mantra, one should repeat it in a complete manner. This world comprised of mobile and stationary beings exists as a servant of BhagavƒÅn. ≈örƒ´ NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa is the Lord (SvƒÅmƒ´), the Master (Prabhu), and Supreme Regulator (Isvara) of the cosmos. avadhƒÅra·πáa-vacyeva u-kara·∏• kai≈õcid isyate ≈õris ca tat-paksa-patitv√§d a-karenaiva cocyate bhaskarasya prabha yad-vat tasya nityƒÅnapƒÅyinƒ´ In this alternative explanation of pranava, the syllable a represents the One Absolute Reality consisting of Visnu as the potent source (saktiman) and Sri as His inseparable potency (sakti). In this case, the syllable u represents the ascertainment (avadharana) of Vi·π£·πáu and ≈örƒ´ as the One Complete Reality, and the syllable M (as in the previous explanation) represents the jiva, who is the servant of these two. 5 ≈õrƒ´mate vi≈ünave tasmai dasyam sarvam karomy aham desa-kalady avasthƒÅsu sarvƒÅsu kamala-pate·∏• iti svarupa-samsiddham mukhyam dasyam avƒÅpnuyƒÅt evam viditv√§ mantr√§rtham tad-v·πõttim samyag acaret 1076 178 Only Akincana Bhakti Is the Abhidheya ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶‡•§‡•Æ‡•≠/‡•®‡•¶ ) - The ≈örutis conveyed the same idea in Srimad Bhagavata: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§§‡§µ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∂‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•É‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§™‡§®‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§≠‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É || ‡•´‡•®‡•¶ ‡•• The Vedas say that the puru≈üa, or the “conscious living being,” dwelling in these fortresses of the bodies generated by You (sva- k·πõta-pure≈üu), yet [in reality] devoid of all external and internal coverings, is manifested as an integrated part of You (amsa- k·πõtam), the repository of unlimited potencies. Having thus ascertained the existential nature of the living being, the wise on earth, who are firmly established in faith, worship Your feet, which are the object of all acts enjoined by the Vedas and which bring about the cessation of material existence (abhavam)? (SB 10.87.20)8 ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§µ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§µ‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ In the compound sva-k·πõta-pure≈üu, “in the fortresses (pure»ôu) generated by Thine own Self (sva),” the pronoun sva means “by You” [Bhagavan], and the word pure»ôu means “in the bodies (dehe·π£u).” They [the Vedas] say that the conscious living being (puru≈üa), or the person dwelling in these bodies, is manifested (k·πõtam), meaning that it is eternally existent (nitya-siddham), as an integrated part of You alone (tavaivƒÅm≈õa-r≈´pena), brought dasa-bh≈´tam idam tasya jagat sthavara-jangamam sriman nƒÅrƒÅya·πáa·∏• svƒÅmƒ´ jagatƒÅm prabhur isvara·∏• ‚ö´ ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi glosses the compound sva-krta-pure≈üu as sva-karmoparjite·π£u puresu dehesu, “in the fortresses of the bodies formed out of their own karma.” This translation is according to Sridhara Svami’s gloss on the word abhavam, i.e., bhava-nivartakam.
