In addition, brahma-j√±ƒÅna necessarily contradicts the nature of pure devotion, whose characteristics are mentioned in statements such as this: 6 Sanatana GosvƒÅmi and Visvanatha Cakravarti 7 Sridhara SvƒÅmi B kurari vilapasi tva·πÅ vita-nidrƒÅ na se·π£e svapiti jagati rƒÅtryƒÅm ƒ´≈°varo gupta-bodhah vayam iva sakhi kaccid gadha-nirviddha-ceta nalina-nayana-hasodara-lilek≈üitena 1165 II How Aki√±cana-bhakti Is Attained Causeless and unobstructed devotion to the Supreme Person is stated to be the definition of pure bhakti, which is beyond the influence of the material gunas. (SB 3.29.12)9 ‡§® ‡§ö ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•´‡•´) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ó‡§§- ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ö‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• Finally, it is to be understood that this verse [SB 11.2.45] cannot refer to the immediate intuition of the formless aspect of the Absolute (nirƒÅkƒÅra-isvara-j√±ƒÅna), because such j√±ƒÅna is opposed to the highest stage of development of a mahƒÅ-bhƒÅgavata, who is defined in the concluding verse of the same chapter: One whose heart Bhagavan Hari Himself - who destroys all sins even if addressed unintentionally - is unable to abandon, because His lotus feet are bound by the rope of love, is pro- claimed as the topmost of all devotees (bhƒÅgavata-pradhƒÅna). (SB 11.2.55)10 Commentary IN THE PREVIOUS ANUCCHEDA, King Nimi requested sage Havi to describe the characteristics of a devotee. It is only by observing a person’s thoughts, speech, and actions that we can estimate his level of advancement. All these are impelled by a person’s state of consciousness. In other words, consciousness is not directly visible but can be deduced only from a person’s psychological, verbal, and physical symptoms. In response to the king’s question, sage Havi first gives the def- inition of the topmost devotee, or uttama-bhƒÅgavata. He begins by describing the state of mind of such a highly realized devotee. There is popular adage in Sanskrit, ƒÅtmavan manyate jagat, “every- one perceives the world according to his or her own consciousness.” 9 lak·π£a·πáam bhakti-yogasya nirgunasya hy udah·πõtam ahaituky avyavahita ya bhakti·∏• purusottame 10 visrjati hrdayam na yasya saksad dharir ava≈õabhihito’py aghaugha-nƒÅ≈õa·∏• pranaya-rasanaya dh·πõtƒÅnghri-padmah sa bhavati bhagavata-pradhana ukta·∏• 1166 188 The Characteristics of an Uttama-bhagavata This is true both for materialists as well as spiritualists. Every- one perceives the world at hand differently, because everyone is endowed with a different consciousness and different samskƒÅras. Just as a person wearing tinted glasses sees all objects as corre- spondingly colored, so too everyone perceives objects and actions through the filter of their own mental projections.

There are two basic bhƒÅvas, or states of consciousness that which is rooted in the fulfillment of egoic desire (kama-bhava), and that which is rooted in divine love (prema-bhava). In the first, a person is bodily-centered, and his or her objective is to satisfy the material mind and senses. In the second, the person is God- centered, with the intent being to render pleasing service to Bha- gavƒÅn. In between these two are the j√±ƒÅna-m√§rgis, or the radical nondualists, who are neither egoically-centered nor God-centered, because they consider the world, the individual self, and God to be imaginary. Since they deny the real existence of all these, they are “no-centered.” The compound word bhagavad-bhƒÅvam in SB 11.2.45 can be inter- preted in various ways. In the first meaning, the word bhƒÅva is taken in the sense of avirbhƒÅva, or “manifestation.” The sense would then be that the uttama-bhagavata directly perceives the spe- cific manifestation of Bhagavan that he cherishes in his own heart (atmanah). In the highest fervor of love, the devotee sees nothing other than this form all around him. This implies that when a devo- tee is overwhelmed with intense love for Bhagavan and exhibits the madness described a few verses earlier in SB 11.2.41, he does not even perceive other forms. Rather, everywhere he looks, he directly sees the manifestation of his beloved Bhagavan and hence bows to everything. This is one type of vision. The second meaning is that the uttama-bhƒÅgavata perceives the presence of his beloved Bhagavan in all beings. When a devotee’s love for Bhagavan becomes somewhat calm, he sees other forms, yet within them he sees the manifestation of his beloved Bhagavan. This is the second type of vision. What the Vrajadevis perceive in the creepers and trees is their own beloved K·πõ·π£·πáa. In this context, the word bhƒÅva means “presence or existence.” This leads to the 1167 II How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained meaning that the devotee perceives the presence of Bhagavan in all living beings. Prahlada is another example of an uttama-bhƒÅgavata in whom this type of vision was primary. When his father asked him, “Where is your God?” Prahlada replied that He is everywhere. Out of anger and to refute Prahlada, his father asked, “Is He also in this pillar?” Prahlada replied in the affirmative, because he was directly seeing Narasimha. When his father then smashed the pillar, Narasimha emerged, becoming visible to all. The third meaning is that the uttama-bhƒÅgavata sees that every living being has taken shelter of Bhagavan. In this sense, nobody is viewed as a nondevotee. An extension of this idea is that the devotee sees everybody and everything as accommodated within Bhagavan, just as Yasoda saw the whole universe within Krsna’s mouth. The fourth meaning is that the uttama-bhƒÅgavata sees the spe- cific mood of love that he feels for Bhagavan in all beings. Here the word bhƒÅva means “love.” This is how the Vrajadevis felt upon see- ing the waves in the Yamuna River, as though the river itself were embracing K·πõ·π£·πáa with her wave-like arms. From this analysis, it is understood that the uttama-bhƒÅgavata does not see Bhagavan everywhere at each and every moment. He may once in a while be graced with such a vision, while at other times he may simply long to see Bhagavan. If this were not so, it would become impossible for him to function in the world. ≈örƒ´ Vi≈õvanatha Cakravarti comments (on SB 11.2.45) that if we do not accept this, then the definition given here would not apply to great bhƒÅgavatas, such as Narada, Vyasa, and ≈öuka. It is observed, however, that these great bhƒÅgavatas were able to function in society. This means that the love of such great devotees undergoes surges. Sometimes their feelings of love are very intense, and at other times they are moderate. In accordance with the level of intensity, their vision also changes. If a mahƒÅ-bhƒÅgavata like NƒÅrada were to perceive everyone as having the same bhƒÅva that he feels for Bhagavan, he would not be able to instruct anyone in 1168 188 The Characteristics of an Uttama-bhƒÅgavata bhakti, because he would not feel the need for it. But we do learn from scripture that Narada offers instruction to many people, such as Dhruva, Prahlada’s mother, King Yudhisthira, and so on. Regard- less of whether or not Bhagavan’s form is directly self-disclosed, the uttama-bhƒÅgavata perceives His presence in everything. This is the import of Havi’s statement. 1169Anuccheda 189 The Characteristics of a Madhyama-bhƒÅgavata ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•Ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•™‡•¨ ) - Now the intermediate devotee (madhyama-bhƒÅgavata) is defined specifically in terms of the characteristics of his psychological disposition (mƒÅnasa-linga): ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡•ã‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•™‡•™ ‡•• One who has love for Isvara, friendship toward His authen- tically sheltered devotees, compassion for the unaware, and indifference toward the inimical, is an intermediate devotee. (SB 11.2.46 ) 1 ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‚Äú‡§∂‡•ã‡§ö‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏ ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•≠‡•§‡•Ø‡•§‡•™‡•©) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ In this verse, the statement that the intermediate devotee has love (prema) for Parame≈õvara means that he is endowed with bhakti for Him. The compound tad-adhinesu, lit., ‚Äú those who are subordinate to, or authentically sheltered in, Him [Bhaga- vƒÅn],‚Äù refers to His devotees (bhaktesu). The intermediate devo- tee feels friendship (maitri ) or amity ( bandhu-bhƒÅva) toward them. The word bƒÅli≈õesu, lit., ‚Äú the childish,‚Äù refers to those who 1 isvare tad-adhinesu balisesu dvi·π£atsu ca prema-maitri-krpopeksa yah karoti sa madhyama·∏• 1170 189 The Characteristics of a Madhyama-bhƒÅgavata are unaware of bhakti to Bhagavan and who are thus indiffer- ent to Him (udƒÉsine≈üu). The intermediate devotee feels compas- sion (k·πõpƒÅ) for them, as expressed by Sri Prahlada: “I grieve for the bewildered living beings whose regard is turned away from the immortal nectar of Your valiant narrations and who bear the burden of worldly life for the sake of the illusory pleasure derived from sense objects” (SB 7.9.43).? I ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§â‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•á ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§≠‡•á‡§®‡•å‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∂‡§ø‡§™‡•å ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§≠‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ In SB 11.2.46, the statement that the intermediate devotee feels indifference (upek·π£ƒÅ) toward those who bear animosity toward him (atmano dvi·π£atsu) means that he remains aloof from them (udƒÅsinya), because his mind is unperturbed by their animosity (dve≈üa). The intermediate devotee may genuinely feel a degree of compassion even for them, if their animosity is simply due to foolishness (bali≈õatvena), just as ≈örƒ´ Prahlada did toward Hiranyakasipu. If, however, their animosity [dvesa] is directed toward Bhagavan or His devotees, the intermediate devotee, though feeling pained at heart, remains unconsumed by such feelings. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡•ç‡§£‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ Toward the unaware (balise·π£u), the intermediate devotee expe- riences an arousal (sphurana) of compassion, and toward the inimical (dvi≈üatsu), he feels only indifference - unlike the superlative devotee, who feels a self-disclosure (sphurana) of prema for Bhagavan in regard to all living beings. This is what distinguishes the former as an intermediate devotee. 2 ≈õoce tato vimukha-cetasa indriyƒÅrtha-maya-sukhƒÅya bharam udvahato vimu·∏çhƒÅn 1171 II How Aki√±cana-bhakti Is Attained ‡§Ö‡§•‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§ß‡•Ä‡§®‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã- ‡§Æ‡•ás‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•™ | ‡•®‡•™|‡•´‡•≠ ) - ‚Äî Assuredly, even for a superlative devotee, the bliss of the self- disclosure of prema for Bhagavan (tat-sphura·πáƒÅnanda) arises in particular by seeing devotees who are truly sheltered in Bha- gav√§n (tad-adhine·π£u). Therefore, it cannot be denied that his sense of friendship (maitri) will be greater with them, but the certainty of his immediate experience of love (bhava) for Bha- gavan in regard to all living beings, remains an established fact. Even in the most highly evolved among superlative devotees, it is evidenced that the sense of friendship [maitri] is greater with respect to truly sheltered devotees [tad-adhinesu], as expressed by ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva: ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡§É || ‡•´‡•™‡•´ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Even a moment’s association with a devotee wholly attuned to Bhagavan cannot be compared with heaven or liberation, to say nothing of the petty blessings of mortal beings. (SB 4.24.57)3 ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§• ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§• ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ” ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•™ ‡•§ ‡•®‡•™ ‡•§ ‡•©‡•¶) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ Also from the song of Rudra: Therefore, great devotees (bhƒÅgavatas) like you are just as dear to me as Bhagavan Himself. And for the devotees as well, there is never anyone dearer than me. (SB 4.24.30)” 3 k·π£a·πáƒÅrdhenapi tulaye na svargam napunar-bhavam bhagavat-sangi-sangasya martyƒÅnƒÅm kim utƒÅsi·π£a·∏• *atha bhƒÅgavata yuyam priya·∏• stha bhagavan yathƒÅ na mad-bhƒÅgavatanam ca preyan anyo’sti karhicit 1172 189 The Characteristics of a Madhyama-bhagavata ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•≠‡•ß‡•ß‡•ß- The same idea is expressed by Suta: ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§ú‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É || ‡•´‡•™‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡•§ His consciousness captivated by the qualities of Sri Hari, the greatly honorable Sri Suka, the son of Badarayana [Vyasa] and ever-beloved of the devotees of Vis≈Üu, underwent the study of this great narrative. (sB1.7.11 ) * ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§®‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶‡•§‡•ß‡•§‡•©‡•´) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ It may be noted that devotees of the stature of Sri Suka may even express contempt (dvesa) for the enemies of BhagavƒÅn, such as when Suka addressed Kamsa as “the disgrace of the Bhoja dynasty” (SB 10.1.35). [This is due to the intensity of the superlative devotee’s love for Bhagavan.] ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ- ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§É ‡•§ For the intermediate devotees, however, the pervading sense of non-immersion (an-abhinivesa) in such feelings is particularly evident. [It is for this reason that the intermediate devotee is said to be simply indifferent toward the inimical.] On the other hand, the distinguishing characteristic of the superlative devo- tees is that even when they are immersed in contemptuous feel- ings toward Bhagavan’s adversaries, the immediate vision (pari- sphurti) of their beloved Bhagavan, whom they perceive as the subduer of such enemies, remains altogether unobstructed. ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É “‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§É‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•™ ‡•§ ‡•© ‡•§ ‡•®‡•©) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ 5 harer gunƒÅksipta-matir bhagavƒÅn badarƒÅyanih adhyagan mahad akhyanam nityam vi≈ünu-jana-priyah 1173 II How Aki√±cana-bhakti Is Attained It is with this vision alone that devotees even of the stature of ≈örƒ´ Uddhava offered obeisance to Duryodhana and other adver- saries of Bhagavan. The vision that inspires such behavior is summed up in the words of ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva: The state of unalloyed being (visuddha-sattva) is called vasudeva, because the Supreme Self is revealed therein as He is, without any covering. In this state of unalloyed being, Bhagavan Vasu- deva is meditated on by me through the medium of internal awareness, since He is beyond the range of sense perception. (SB 4.3.23) [Consequently, when superlative devotees such as Uddhava offer obeisance to the enemies of Bhagavan, they do so not to the body nor to the person who identifies with the body, but to Bhagavan self-disclosed within the heart of all beings.] ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‚Äú‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç” ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¨‡•Æ‡•ß‡•ß‡•≠) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Accordingly, in the narration of the abduction of Lak·π£ma·πáƒÅ, it is said: 6 7 8 Uddhava duly saluted Dh·πõtarastra, Bhisma, Dro·πáa, Bahlika, and Duryodhana and informed them of Balarama’s arrival. (SB 10.68.17)8 According to Sanskrit grammar, the word vasudeva is formed from the word vasudeva by the addition of a taddhita suffix, which strengthens the initial vowel of the original word. In this case, the word thus derived, denotes that which makes its appearance from the state or condition signified by the original word. Because Bhagavan Vasudeva manifests only in the heart saturated with the quality of unalloyed being, known as visuddha-sattva, that state is known as vasudeva, or “the ground of appearance of Bhagavan Vasudeva.” sattvam visuddham vasudeva-sabditam yad iyate tatra pumƒÅn apav·πõta·∏• sattve ca tasmin bhagavan vasudevo hy adhok·π£ajo me manasƒÉ vidhiyate so’bhivandyambika-putram bhismam dronam ca bahlikam duryodhanam ca vidhi-vad r√§mam ƒÅgatam abravit 1174 189 The Characteristics of a Madhyama-bhƒÅgavata ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§û‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§™‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ú‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø- ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Alternatively, because of the self-disclosure (parisph≈´rti) of the superlative devotee’s own feeling of love (bhava) for BhagavƒÅn in regard to all living beings in general, the same love is felt by them to be self-disclosed even in the adversaries of ≈örƒ´ Bhagavan or His devotees. This explanation is not improper, because the superlative devotees are like particles of pollen affixed to Bhaga- van’s lotus feet, for which they are prepared to offer their lives in sacrifice millions of times. On this account, they feel unset- tled by witnessing the ill behavior of those who are inimical to Bhagavan. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á - ‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã ‡§à‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§®‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ- ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§ï‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§ø‡§§- ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§æ- ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¢ ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Under the influence of their own feelings of love (bhƒÅva), the superlative devotees think as follows: “The Supreme Personal Transcendent (≈örƒ´ Purusottama) is the storehouse of all bliss and the object of unconditional supreme love. He is adorned with the jewel-like quality of delighting the whole world, and the immortal nectar of His deeds culminates in the ultimate good of all. Such being the case, how could there be even a sin- gle conscious being who would not feel love for Bhagavan or His devotees? Such a thing would indeed be a wonder! It is consequently altogether beyond our comprehension that there could be any cause for animosity toward Bhagavan or His devo- tees. Therefore, all living beings, both noble and wicked, from Brahma, the highest living entity, down to the most insignifi- cant of stationary beings, are indeed deeply moved by affection for Bhagavan.” 1175 II How Aki√±cana-bhakti Is Attained ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•á‡§® (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•ß‡•® ‡•§ ‡•ß-‡•® ) - This sentiment was expressed by ≈örƒ´ ≈öuka: ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§π ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡§É || ‡•´‡•™‡•≠ || ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡•Å ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§®‡•Å ‡§® ‡§≠‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•à‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•™‡•Æ || ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ O best of the Kurus [Parik·π£it], being intensely eager to worship ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa, Narada stayed continuously in DvƒÅrƒÅka, which was protected by the arms of Govinda. O King, what outright mortal being, if endowed with senses, would not worship the lotus feet of Bhagavan Mukunda, which are the object of worship even for the best of the immortals (such as Rudra and so on]?” (SB 11.2.1- 2)10 Commentary AFTER defining the psychological characteristics of the superla- tive devotee (uttama-bhƒÅgavata), sage Havi now describes those pertaining to the intermediate devotee (madhyama-bhƒÅgavata). Due to his intensity of love, the uttama-bhƒÅgavata directly intu- its the presence of his worshipable Bhagavan everywhere and in all beings. Thus, his unmediated vision transcends the routine perception of others’ ordinary conditioned way of being. On this account, his behavior toward others is entirely non-discriminatory. Yet, although he is equally disposed to all, his sense of friendship (maitri) is greater in regard to authentically sheltered devotees, because the bliss of the self-disclosure of love is spontaneously awakened in him simply by seeing such devotees. In contrast, 9 Sri Vi≈õvanatha Cakravarti 10 govinda-bhuja-guptayam dv√§ravatyam kurudvaha av√§tsin nƒÅrado bhik·π£·πáam k·πõ·π£·πáopƒÅsana-lalasah ko nu rajann indriyavan mukunda-cara·πáƒÅmbujam na bhajet sarvato-m·πõtyur upƒÅsyam amarottamaih 1176 189 The Characteristics of a Madhyama-bhƒÅgavata the madhyama-bhƒÅgavata is able to distinguish between a devo- tee, someone who is ignorant but simple-hearted, and an envious person. Thus, he deals with each of them accordingly. ≈öri Jiva writes that a madhyama-bhƒÅgavata does not feel per- turbed at heart when someone treats him with animosity. Rather, he remains indifferent to such a person. Additionally, if the per- son’s inimical behavior is only due to ignorance of devotion, then the intermediate devotee even feels compassion for him. There is no point in getting angry at such a person, who behaves inim- ically toward the devotee only under the influence of ignorance. That the inimical behave in such manner can hardly be otherwise, since even a person of knowledge (j√±ƒÅnavƒÅn api) is said to follow his or her priorly acquired nature (Gƒ™TƒÄ 3.33). There is no gain in becoming disturbed by their behavior. Prahlada is a perfect example of this ideal. His own father tried to kill him, but Prahlada remained calm and ventured to instruct him in the matter of bhakti. He even prayed to Bhagavan Narasimha for his well-being. If, however, a person directs his animosity toward Bhagavan or His devotees, then an intermediate devotee, though feeling perturbed at heart, does not become overwhelmed by such feelings. Ordinarily, when a person’s mind is disturbed, he becomes absorbed in thoughts of the person who precipitated the disturbance. This gives rise to a feeling of aversion toward that per- son, which impels the mind to become completely preoccupied in thoughts of him. Sri Narada says that this type of inimical absorp- tion of mind is even more pronounced than that of a vaidhi devotee’s formal intentness on Bhagavan (SB 7.1.26). A superlative devotee is so immersed in his feeling of love for Bhagavan that he is unable to fathom how anyone could harbor animosity toward the devotees or Bhagavan, who is the abode of all wonderful divine qualities and the repository of unconditional love for all beings. It is in this mood that ≈örƒ´ Sukadeva raises the rhetorical question in SB 11.2.2, cited at the end of this anuccheda. Here, it should be clarified that although the uttama-bhƒÅgavata is able to directly perceive Bhagavan in everyone, this does not mean that he can never perceive the ordinary states of awareness 1177 II How Aki√±cana-bhakti Is Attained of other beings. It is evidenced that great devotees such as NƒÅrada do discriminate between a devotee, an ignorant person, and an envious one. Thus, the basic difference between the uttama and the madhyama-bhakta is that the uttama has the ability to perceive Bhagavan or his own mood of devotion in everyone, even though this vision may not arise in him all the time, whereas a madhyama- bhakta does not have this ability. Consequently, in terms of their external behavior, an uttama and a madhyama-bhakta may conduct themselves in a similar manner. As such, it is not always easy to distinguish between them. 1178 Anuccheda 190 The Characteristics of a Neophyte Devotee ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•¶ | ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•™‡•≠ ) - Now sage Havi defines the neophyte devotee (kani≈ü·π≠ha) in terms of his physical traits (kƒÅyika-linga) - which take the form of the outward behavior he exhibits in the matter of bhagavat- dharma - and to a partial extent, in terms of his psychological disposition (mƒÅnasa-linga): ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§π‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡•á‡§π‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•™‡•Ø ‡•§‡•§ One who offers worship to Hari with faith in the deity form alone but who fails to honor Him as present in His devotees or in other living beings is recognized as a pr√§k·πõta-bhakta, or a devotee whose nature [prak·πõti] is in the very beginning stage of formation. (SB 11.2.47)1 ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§® ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø- ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß- ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§® ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‚Äú‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡§™‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§≠‡•å‡§Æ ‡§á‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡•á ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç ‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§∑‡•Å” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•™ ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•©) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ This verse states that the neophyte devotee worships BhagavƒÅn only in the form of the deity. He does not perceive Bhagavan’s 1 arcayam eva haraye p√ºjƒÅm ya·∏• ≈õraddhayehate na tad-bhakte≈üu canyesu sa bhaktah prak·πõtah smrtah 1179II How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained presence in His devotees and, consequently, certainly not in oth- ers either. This is because, within his being, there is an absence of the appearance of love for Bhagavan, an absence of awareness of the glory of true devotees, and an absence of the appearance of a devotee’s fundamental quality, which is the attitude of rev- erence for all living beings. Such a person is a prƒÅk·πõta-bhakta, “a devotee whose nature (prak·πõti) is in the very beginning stage of formation (prarambha),” meaning that his cultivation of bhakti has just recently begun. Additionally, his ≈õraddha, or faith, is not the outcome of assimilating the import of scripture. This attitude is characterized in the following statement: One whose self-concept (atma-buddhih) is rooted in this corpse- like body, which is constituted of the three elements, mucus, bile, and air; whose sense of relation (sva-dhih) is in his wife, children, and other kin; whose concept of divinity (ijya-dhih) is in earthen images; and whose notion of the sacred (tirtha- buddhi·∏•) is in the water of a river; but who never cherishes the sense of self, of relation, of divinity, and of the sacred, in regard to those who have realized the Absolute, is indeed an ass among cows. (SB 10.84.13)2 These attitudes are due to ignorance of the scriptural conclusions. ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•à‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• Consequently, the faith of the neophyte arises only out of social conventions (loka-paramparƒÅ), as described earlier. Thus, a spiritual practitioner (sadhaka) in whom divine love (prema) has not yet manifested but who is endowed with faith rooted in scriptural knowledge is to be understood as the primary standard of a neophyte devotee (kanistha). 2 yasyatma-buddhi·∏• kunape tri-dhatuke sva-dhi·∏• kalatradisu bhauma ijya-dhih yat-tirtha-buddhi·∏• salile na karhicij janesv abhij√±esu sa eva go-kharah 1180 190 The Characteristics of a Neophyte Devotee Commentary EARLIER it was said that ≈õraddha is the primary prerequisite for bhakti. This ≈õraddha can arise either from the customs and beliefs of one’s own cultural environment (laukika-≈õraddha) or from a sys- tematic study of sastra (sastriya-≈õraddha). In India, it is generally seen that in every area or village, some particular deity is wor- shiped. The people who are native to a given place naturally tend to be devoted to the deity present there, since they observe the deity’s worship being conducted by their seniors from their very child- hood. They also participate in local festivals related to that deity. All this creates firmly reinforced impressions (samskaras) in their minds, and when they grow up, they also continue the tradition of worshiping that deity. Over time, this tradition becomes an established social conven- tion (loka-parampara). If a community member does not conform to the local convention, he feels divorced from his community. This naturally creates a problem in his social life. It is thus seen that in different parts of India, people predominantly worship either Krsna, RƒÅma, Ganesa, ≈öiva, KƒÅlƒ´, or numerous other deities in accordance with whichever deity’s worship is popular in their area. These worshipers have almost no knowledge of sastra. They simply follow what others before them have done. The same of course applies to the practitioners of other reli- gions, such as Christianity, Judaism, Islam, Sikhism, and so on. When religious practice is rooted in conventional faith alone (laukika-≈õraddha), it has no basis in knowledge of either scrip- ture or theology. As a result, it tends to be weak and prone to counter-arguments and the loss of faith. The second type of ≈õraddha (sastriya-≈õraddha) is that which ensues from hearing and studying sastra under the guidance of a qualified devotee. This is the ≈õraddha that forms the basis of the three types of eligible bhaktas defined in Bhakti-rasƒÅm·πõta-sindhu (1.2.17-19) Such bhaktas are very rare. 3 tatra uttamah -> 1181 11 How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained At present, a third category of ≈õraddha has become prevalent, namely, the faith that ensues from religious proselytization. Prac- titioners who acquire such faith take to the path of bhakti (or any other religion) due to the influence of indoctrination. It is gener- ally the case that such practitioners have not studied the sastra in an authentic manner, but they are not completely ignorant of it like the first group. Most bhaktas at present belong to the first and third groups. ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmi comments that the primary standard of a neophyte is one whose ≈õraddha is based upon sastra. He is described in Bhakti- rasƒÅm·πõta-sindhu (1.2.19) as follows: “One whose [≈õastriya-] ≈õraddhƒÅ is weak (komala) is determined to be a neophyte (kanistha).” In commenting on the latter verse, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va writes that the neo- phyte is not particularly skilled in arguing on the basis of sastra, and thus it is possible for an opponent to refute him by presenting arguments contrary to bhakti. This, however, does not mean that the neophyte will give up the path, because he is endowed nonethe- less with the beginning stage of authentic faith. He may feel dis- turbed for some time by the opponent’s counter-arguments, but he will fix his mind once again on bhakti. The type of neophyte described by Havi is of a lower or even more basic category. His faith extends only to Bhagavan’s presence in the deity but not to that of His presence in other living beings, including the devotees. This is due to the fact that his vision has not been informed and transformed through a systematic study of ≈õƒÅstra. The neophyte defined in the above cited verse from Bhakti- rasƒÅm·πõta-sindhu is superior to the neophyte defined in the princi- pal verse of this anuccheda. The former has respect for devotees and will also be predisposed to feel Bhagavan’s presence in other beings, even though the immediate experience of such is lacking sastre yuktau ca nipunah sarvatha drdha-niscayah praudha-≈õraddho’dhikari ya·∏• sa bhaktƒÅv uttamo mata·∏• tatra madhyama·∏• ya·∏• sastrƒÅdi·π£v anipuna·∏• ≈õraddhavan sa tu madhyamah tatra kanisthah - yo bhavet komala-≈õraddha·∏• sa kanistho nigadyate 1182 190 The Characteristics of a Neophyte Devotee in him. He will strive to adhere to sastra, although he may not always be successful in this attempt. In comparison, a madhyama- bhakta has a deeper level of respect for devotees, because he is well acquainted with the glory of Bhagavan, bhakti, and the bhakta. He also knows that disrespecting devotees is displeasing to Bhagavan. For these reasons, he establishes friendship (maitri) with them. In the principal verse of this anuccheda (SB 11.2.47), the neo- phyte devotee is defined both in terms of his physical and psycho- logical characteristics. The neophyte’s worship of the deity is a physical characteristic, and the ≈õraddha that impels such worship is a psychological trait. 1183 Symptoms of the Superlative Devotee Anucchedas 191-198 Anuccheda 191 How the Uttama-bhƒÅgavata Engages with the World ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•ß | ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ ‚Äì ‚Äú‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•à‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‘‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø " ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ | [AFTER THE LAST THREE verses (SB 11.2.45-47) defining the superlative, intermediate, and neophyte devotees, respectively, Havi speaks eight more verses elaborating on the characteristics of the superlative devotee.] ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmƒ´ introduces the first of these: “Because the superlative devotee is so highly honorable, the sage Havi describes him once again in eight verses, beginning with this verse (SB 11.2.48).” 1 ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•™‡•Æ ) - The verse is given as follows: ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§® ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø ‡§® ‡§π‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•´‡•¶ ‡•• He who directly perceives this world as a manifestation of Bha- gavan Vis≈Üu’s extrinsic potency (mƒÅyƒÅ), and who, although engaging with sense objects through the medium of the senses, neither delights in them nor is repulsed by them, is indeed an uttama-bhƒÅgavata, or a superlative devotee. (SB 11.2.48)1 grhitv√§pindriyair arthan yo na dve≈üti na hrsyati vi·π£·πáor mƒÅyƒÅm idam pasyan sa vai bhagavatottama·∏• 1187 II How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§® ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ß‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï- ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• As described earlier, the consciousness of the superlative devo- tee is so immersed in Bhagavan that he does not appropri- ate the objects of the senses even though engaging with them through the medium of the senses. The word api, “even though,” qualifying the verb g·πõhƒ´tvƒÅ, “he accepts,” has been used in this verse just to emphasize this point. The demonstrative pronoun idam, “this,” refers to “this visible world” (vi≈õvam). Because the superlative devotee directly perceives the world to be but a display of Bhagavan’s extrinsic potency, he regards it as fit to be given up (heyam). This definition, like the previ- ous one, employs a combination of physical and psychological characteristics. Commentary SAGE HAVI again describes the character of an uttama-bhƒÅgavata in greater detail. The reason for this is that bhakti ensues from the association and grace of a devotee. The more evolved the devotee, the more potent is his association. Therefore, if we are to partake of the association of a devotee, we are advised as far as possible to seek out an uttama-bhƒÅgavata. For this to be feasible, it is essen- tial to be well-informed of such a devotee’s character and conduct. Devotees, including those of the superlative category, do not fit a stereotypical image. They encompass a great deal of variety. It is thus important to be acquainted with their distinctions so that we do not misunderstand them. Toward this end, Havi speaks eight verses to make evident the uttama-bhƒÅgavata’s characteristics. In this verse, Havi points out that although the uttama-bhƒÅga- vata makes use of sense objects, he is not overpowered by them. This is because he is internally absorbed in contemplation of his beloved Bhagavan. This is the sense of the indeclinable api, “even though,” delimiting the manner of his accepting the sense objects. 1188 191 How the Uttama-bhƒÅgavata Engages with the World Thus, externally the uttama-bhagavata may behave like anyone else, but internally he is categorically distinct, being completely unattached. Bhakti naturally gives rise to vairagya toward every- thing else. This verse thus provides a combination of the uttama- bhƒÅgavata’s physical and mental characteristics. The manner of his acceptance of the sense objects is a physical trait, whereas his inner disposition of not being overpowered by them and his imme- diate perception of the world as a display of Bhagavan’s extrinsic potency are psychological attributes. 1189Anuccheda 192 The Uttama-bhƒÅgavata Is Unperturbed by Worldly Existence ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•® ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§π ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•™‡•Ø) - HEREAFTER, from the next verse (SB 11.2.49) up to the concluding verse of this section [SB 11.2.55], ≈öri Havi describes the uttama- bhƒÅgavata exclusively in terms of his psychological disposition: ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§Ø‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§É || ‡•´‡•´‡•ß ‡•• One who, by virtue of constant remembrance of Bhagavan Hari, is never bewildered by the fundamental attributes of mate- rial existence - including the physical body’s origination and demise, the senses’ fatigue, the vital body’s hunger and thirst, the mind’s fear, and the intellect’s desire - is a superlative devotee (bhƒÅgavata-pradhƒÅna). (SB 11.2.49)1 ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞- ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡•§ One who, by virtue of constant remembrance of Bhagavan Hari, is not bewildered by the fundamental attributes of material exis- tence, such as the physical body’s origination and demise, is a topmost devotee (bhƒÅgavata-pradhƒÅna). L dehendriya-prƒÅna-mano-dhiyam yo janmapyaya-ksud-bhaya-tarsa-k·πõcchrai·∏• samsara-dharmair avimuhyamƒÅna·∏• smrtya harer bhƒÅgavata-pradhƒÅna·∏• The translation has been rendered according to the commentary of ≈öridhara SvƒÅmi. 1190 192 The Uttama-bhƒÅgavata Is Unperturbed by Worldly Existence ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å (‡§ó‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡•≠‡•§‡•®‡•Æ ) - A similar statement is made in the Gƒ´ta: ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ó‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§¢‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•´‡•® ‡•• Those virtuous human beings whose misdeeds have come to an end, being freed from the delusion of duality, worship Me with firm resolve. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 7.28)2 Commentary INDIAN PHILOSOPHY admits three types of misery: (1) that which ensues from one’s own body and mind, adhyatmika, (2) from other living beings, adhibhautika, and (3) from nature, adhidaivika. Ulti- mately all three types of misery are experienced as mental suf- fering. The mind is so-designed that at any one particular micro- moment, it can be fixed only on one object. So if the mind is con- tinuously absorbed in contemplation of Bhagavan, it cannot expe- rience anything else. A devotee established in this state remains unperturbed by the ordinary course of involvement with worldly existence. It was said in the very beginning of this book that the root cause of the jiva’s suffering is the nonremembrance (asmrti) of Bhagavan (SB 11.2.37). An uttama-bhƒÅgavata is fully absorbed in thoughts of Bhagavan and is thus free from the influence of mƒÅyƒÅ. This verse is the first of seven that describe the uttama-bhƒÅgavata exclusively in terms of his psychological disposition. 2 yesam tv anta-gatam papam janƒÅnƒÅm punya-karma·πáƒÅm te dvandva-moha-nirmuktƒÅ bhajante mam drdha-vrata·∏• 1191 Anuccheda 193 The Uttama-bhƒÅgavata Is Free of All Material Desires 1 ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•© | ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß | ‡•®|‡•´‡•¶ ) - ≈öRI HAVI continues to describe the uttama-bhƒÅgavata in the next verse: ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•´‡•© ‡•• One in whose mind expectation, striving, and the seeds of desire never arise and whose one and only refuge is Bhagavan Vasudeva is indeed an uttama-bhƒÅgavata. (SB 11.2.50)1 ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•à‡§ï‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• In this verse, the word bijƒÅnƒÅm, “seeds,” refers to the subcon- scious predispositions toward desire (vƒÅsanƒÅs), and the com- pound vasudeva-eka-nilayah means, “one whose sole refuge (ƒÅ≈õraya) is Bhagavan Vasudeva.” Commentary DIVINE LOVE of God (prema) cannot manifest in the heart of a per- son who harbors worldly desires. In the above verse, the word na kama karma-bijanam yasya cetasi sambhava·∏• vasudevaika-nilayah sa vai bhagavatottama·∏• 1192 193 The Uttama-bhƒÅgavata Is Free of All Material Desires kƒÅma, “expectation,” means “worldly desire,” karma, “striving,” means “action undertaken to fulfill such desire,” and bƒ´jƒÅni, “seeds,” signifies “the subconscious predispositions that give rise to desire” (vƒÅsanƒÅs). An uttama-bhƒÅgavata is free from all of these. The seeds of desire (bƒ´jƒÅni, or in other words, vƒÅsanƒÅs) are the root cause of all desire, and they are grounded in anadi-avidya, or beginningless ignorance of Bhagavan. One of the six primary characteristics of bhakti is that it uproots all suffering (kle≈õa), which is a product of avidyƒÅ (BRS 1.1.17). Because the uttama-bhƒÅgavata is thus cleansed even of the seeds of desire, he is also called nirdh≈´ta-ka·π£ƒÅya, as discussed earlier in Anuccheda 187. 1193 Anuccheda 194 The Uttama-bhƒÅgavata Is Devoid of Material Ego ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•™ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•® ‡•§‡•´‡•ß ) -

≈öRI HAVI continues to describe the uttama-bhƒÅgavata in the next verse: ‡§® ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡§µ‡•à ‡§∏ ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•´‡•™ ‡•• One whose sense of identity (aham-bhƒÅva) is never invested in the body on the basis of birth (janma), deeds (karma), vocation (varna), stage of life (asrama), or caste (jƒÅti), is certainly dear to Bhagavan Hari. (SB 11.2.51)1 ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§§‡§™‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§≤‡•ã‡§Æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ The word janma means “birth in a noble family” (sat-kula), and karma refers to virtuous deeds, such as undergoing penance (tapa). The word jƒÅti refers to the congenial sub- and mixed castes (anulomajƒÅ), such as the mixed brƒÅhma·πáa-k·π£atriya caste (murdhƒÅbhi·π£ikta)? 1 2 na yasya janma-karmabhyam na varnasrama-jƒÅtibhi·∏• sajjate sminn aham-bhavo dehe vai sa hareh priyah Anuloma is a term used in the Smrti texts to describe mixed castes wherein the father is of a higher caste than the mother. According to Manu-smrti 10.5, the word jƒÅti refers to the anuloma, or “congenial,” castes. The word murdhabhi·π£ikta (as well as the term brahma-k·π£atra) refers to an anuloma mixed caste wherein 1194 194 The Uttama-bhagavata Is Devoid of Material Ego ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§Ω‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•ã ‡§® ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡•å‡§™‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§è‡§µ ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ || One whose sense of identity (aham-bhƒÅva) is never invested in the body on the basis of these various factors, but [whose authentic “I-consciousness” (aham-bhava)] is related to the body only inasmuch as it is an instrument for serving Bhaga- v√§n, is dear to Bhagavan Hari. This is the sense. In accordance with the definitions given in the previous verses, the statement here that such a devotee is dear to Bhagavan Hari means that he is an uttama-bhƒÅgavata, because this is the topic of this sec- tion. He is dear to Bhagavan Hari specifically because of his actually having the essential nature of a superlative devotee (i.e., his bhƒÅgavatatva), on which basis alone he is designated as a bhƒÅgavata. Commentary BECAUSE the uttama-bhƒÅgavata is wholly absorbed in Bhagavan, and because his authentic sense of identity (aham-bhava) is as a ser- vant of Bhagavan, he is unidentified with the body on the basis of birth, education, or social status. He regards the body only as an instrument for the service of Bhagavan. Identification with the body occurs in the absence of aware- ness of Bhagavan. The uttama-bhagavata, however, is continuously absorbed in remembrance of Bhagavan, as mentioned two verses earlier in SB 11.2.49. On this account, he is not influenced by Bha- gavƒÅn’s mƒÅyƒÅ. Moreover, since he constantly remembers Bhaga- vƒÅn, who is supreme above all, there is no possibility of his feeling proud of anything. But the uttama-bhƒÅgavata’s absence of pride in the father is a brahmana and the mother, a ksatriya. According to Manu-smrti, people of this caste are to be treated as equal to brahmanas. Parasurama is a classical example of a person from the murdhabhi·π£ikta mixed caste. For more on this topic, see Yajnavalkya-sm·πõti 1.91, etc. In a different context, the word murdhabhi≈üikta is used to refer to a king who has been consecrated on the throne. Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´ takes the first meaning as applicable here. 1195 II How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained regard to nobility of birth, erudition, and so on does not mean that he is unaware of his own qualifications in these various regards. He simply remains unidentified with them. Neophyte devotees, on the other hand, may be considerably proud of taking birth in a pure family or a famous lineage. They often brag about such things. It is due to pride rooted in bodily iden- tification that neophytes do not respect other devotees, as pointed out earlier by Havi. What this means is that they may even make a show of respect externally, but within, they feel only the inflation of their own ego. Offering respect in the true sense means to feel oneself as lower than the person to whom respect is offered. 1196 Anuccheda 195 The Uttama-bhƒÅgavata Is Established in the Vision of Nonduality ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•´ | ‡§§‡§•‡§æ (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•´‡•® ) - ≈öRI HAVI continues to describe the uttama-bhƒÅgavata in the next verse: ‡§® ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•´‡•´ ‡•• One who makes no distinction between his possessions and those of others, between his own body (atmani)1 and that of others, and who is thus benevolently disposed toward all living beings and established in unwavering peace (santa),” is indeed an uttama-bhƒÅgavata. (SB 11.2.52)3 1 ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ- ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§® ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§É ‡•• The word vitte≈üu, “possessions,” refers to all objects that are generally a source of attachment. In regard to such objects, ≈örƒ´ Vi≈õvanatha Cakravarti glosses the word atmani as sva-sarire, “one’s own body.” 2 In Ganga SahƒÅya’s Anvitartha-prak√§sikƒÅ, the word santa is glossed as rƒÅgƒÅdi-rahita, “free from all attachment and so on.” ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi gives the exact same gloss on the word santa in SB 1.8.27. It is on the basis of the freedom from all attachment that the state of mental tranquility becomes unwavering. na yasya sva·∏• para iti vittesv atmani va bhidƒÅ sarva-bh≈´ta-suhrc chanta·∏• sa vai bhagavatottamah 1197 II How Aki√±cana-bhakti Is Attained the uttama-bhƒÅgavata makes no distinction that “this belongs to me” and “that belongs to another.” In regard to the body (ƒÅtmani), he makes no distinction that “this is mine” and “that is someone else’s.” As in the case of possessions, the nondistinc- tion pertaining to the body means that it is only the attitude of personal bias that is denied and not the tangible distinction that exists between individual bodies. ‡§§‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ó‡•Ä‡§∞‡§•‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á- The same idea is expressed in the Skanda Purana in a conversation between M√§rkandeya and Bhagiratha: ‡§™‡§∞‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡•• O best of kings, those human beings who consider the sufferings of others to be their own and who are resolutely intent upon bhagavad-dharma, are uttama Vai·π£·πáavas. (Skanda PurƒÅ·πáa)* Commentary AN UTTAMA-BHAGAVATA feels the presence of Bhagavan in all living beings and objects. He also directly perceives everything as belonging to Bhagavan. We are given bodies and possessions temporarily, but ultimately Bhagavan is the real owner. As a con- sequence of this understanding, an uttama-bhƒÅgavata remains unbiased. He is devoid of the separatist mentality, prthag-bhƒÅva (mentioned by Kapila in SB 3.29.8-10, Anucchedas 231-233). There is a story about the non-biased nature of the great devo- tee Prahlada. Virocana, the son of Prahlada, was friendly with Sud- hanvƒÅ, the son of sage Angiras. It so happened that Virocana and SudhanvƒÅ fell in love with the same woman. Accordingly, a con- tention arose between these two as to who was superior. They 4 para-du·∏•khenatma-du·∏•kham manyante ye n·πõpottama bhagavad-dharma-niratas te nara vais·πáavottamƒÅ·∏• This verse is cited only in a single manuscript of Bhakti Sandarbha. 1198 195 The Uttama-bhƒÅgavata Is Established in the Vision of Nonduality staked their lives on the issue. Then, both of them approached Prahlada together and requested him to give a decision as to which one of them was greater and thus more qualified to marry the girl. Thinking that Prahlada might favor his own son, who was very dear to him, SudhanvƒÅ said to Prahlada, “Sir, you should be truth- ful and impartial. If you offer a biased decision, your head will be cut into one hundred pieces by the thunderbolt of Indra.” Prahlada knew that if he decided in favor of his son, the latter would forfeit his life, and so he told Virocana, “Listen my son, SudhanvƒÅ is supe- rior to you. His father, Angiras is greater than me, and his mother is greater than your mother. So, as per your wager, you owe your life to SudhanvƒÅ.” Hearing Prahlada’s unbiased decision, SudhanvƒÅ spared Virocana’s life. The uttama-bhƒÅgavata’s vision of equality or nondistinction, however, does not mean that he considers everything as one in an absolutistic sense, as is the case with the j√±ƒÅnƒ´s. Since the j√±ƒÅnis deny the ontological reality of everything other than Brahman, the question of differentiation cannot even arise for them. The uttama- bhƒÅgavata, however, recognizes everything as the sakti of Brahman or Bhagavan. Thus all living entities and objects are perceived as being without distinction as seats of Bhagavan’s abidance. Yet this does not negate the tangible distinction that is directly perceiv- able between individual objects and living beings. This is integral nonduality. 1199Anuccheda 196 The Uttama-bhƒÅgavata’s Unflinching Remembrance of Bhagavan 1 ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•¨ ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§‡•® ‡•§‡•´‡•© ) - ≈öRI HAVI continues to describe the uttama-bhƒÅgavata in the next verse: ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡§µ‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§ö‡§≤‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•´‡•¨ ‡•• He is the foremost Vai·π£·πáava whose unabated remembrance never strays even for half a moment - not even for the sake of the opulence of the three worlds - from the lotus feet of Bhaga- v√§n, which are sought even by the gods for whom Ajita is their very Self. (SB 11.2.53)1 ‡§Ö‡§ö‡§≤‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‚Äì ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É - ‡§Ö‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•• The reason why the devotee’s remembrance never strays even for half a moment from Bhagavan’s lotus feet is that he is not allured even by the prospect of gaining sovereignty over the three worlds. The reason in this regard is that Bhagavan’s lotus feet are sought after, yet rarely attained, even by the gods headed by BrahmƒÅ, for whom Ajita, meaning Bhagavan Hari, is their very Self (ƒÅtmƒÅ). tri-bhuvana-vibhava-hetave’py akuntha-smrtir ajit√§tma-sur√§dibhir vim·πõgyat na calati bhagavat-padaravindal lava-nimisƒÅrdham api sa vai·π£·πáavƒÅgrya·∏• 1200 196 The Uttama-bhƒÅgavata’s Unflinching Remembrance of Bhagavan Commentary AN UTTAMA-BHƒÄGAVATA does not consider anything within the three worlds to be of greater value than Bhagavan’s lotus feet, and hence he never forgets Bhagavan. He will not trade even half a moment’s remembrance of Bhagavan for the opulence of the three worlds. Therefore, bhakti is said to be apratihatƒÉ, or “uninterrupted” (SB 1.2.6). There is nothing that can allure an uttama-bhƒÅgavata away from Bhagavan. Hiranyakasipu was the greatest demon in the history of this universe. In comparison to him, his five-year-old son Prahlada was exceedingly tender and vulnerable. Hiranyakasipu tried his best to wean his son away from remembering Bhagavan, but although he tortured Prahlada in numerous diabolical ways, he was not success- ful. There is a similar story about Haridasa Thakura, a Muslim by birth. He was tortured by the local Muslim king for abandoning his religion, yet he would not give up chanting the name of K·πõ·π£·πáa. 1201 Anuccheda 197 The Uttama-bhƒÅgavata Is beyond Worldly Desire ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•≠ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö‡§≤‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ- ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•å ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•´‡•™ ) - ‚Äî ADDITIONALLY, if a devotee is excessively tormented by worldly desires, his remembrance of Bhagavan may be deviated by the pursuit of sense objects. But in the case of the uttama- bhƒÅgavata, this is not possible, because he is permanently estab- lished in the bliss of service to Bhagavan. This is [poetically] indicated in the next verse by sage Havi: ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§ ‡§â‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•á ‡•§ ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§á‡§µ‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§É ‡•• ‡•´‡•´‡•≠ ‡•• Just as the heat of the sun is dissipated upon the moonrise, the fever (tƒÅpa·∏•) of worldly desire can never reappear in the heart of a devotee for whom this fever has been dissipated by the cool luster emanating from the gem-like nails of the toes of Bhagavan’s splendorous feet. (SB 11.2.54)1 ‡§â‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•å ‡§ö ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ö ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§É || 1 Bhagavan’s feet are referred to by the adjective uru-vikrama, which means that they are extraordinarily powerful. The word bhagavata uru-vikram√§nghri-sakha-nakha-mani-candrikaya nirasta-tape h·πõdi katham upasidatƒÅm puna·∏• sa prabhavati candra ivodite’rka-tapah 1202 197 The Uttama-bhƒÅgavata Is beyond Worldly Desire ≈õƒÅkhƒÅ, lit., “branches,” refers to the toes of His feet. The word candrikƒÅ, “moon rays,” means “the cool luster (dipti) that dissi- pates the devotee’s fever (tapah).” The word tapa·∏• means “the burning heat or affliction (santapa) of worldly desire and so on (kƒÅmƒÅdi).” Commentary SINCE the luster emanating from the nails of the toes of Bhaga- van’s feet is sufficient to drive away all desire from the devotee’s heart, how powerful and splendorous must His feet be? This is the significance of the adjective uru-vikrama used for Bhagavan’s feet. ≈öridhara SvƒÅmi draws out the significance of the simile in his commentary. He says that Bhagavan’s two feet are full of splendor, but of them, just consider the toes, and of the toes, just consider the nails, which are like gems. Furthermore, just consider the cool luster emanating from those gems. It is by that luster alone that the fever of worldly desire in a devotee’s heart is dissipated. In the previous verse, it was said that the uttama-bhƒÅgavata’s remembrance is never deviated from the feet of Bhagavan even for half a moment. The mind is generally very flickering, but not that of the uttama-bhagavata. The previous verse described the steady nature of the uttama-bhagavata’s mind. In the present verse, it is said that his mind is not disturbed by sense objects. Even if the mind is very steady, it may still become influenced by sense objects. This is being denied in this verse in the case of the uttama- bhƒÅgavata. The sun’s rays, which are scorching and difficult to toler- ate, are compared to worldly suffering. In contrast, the moon rays are cooling and soothing to the body and mind. A person finds relief in the cooling rays of the moon after a hot sunny day. 1203 Anuccheda 198 Gradations of Uttama-bhƒÅgavatas 198.1 The Uttama-bhƒÅgavata Binds BhagavƒÅn through Love ‡•ß‡•Ø‡•Æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•´‡•´ ) - ≈öRI HAVI Concludes his description of the uttama-bhƒÅgavata in the following verse: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ò‡•å‡§ò‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§É ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§® ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É || ‡•´‡•´‡•Æ ‡•§‡•§ One whose heart Bhagavan Hari Himself - who destroys all sins even if addressed unintentionally - is unable to abandon, because His lotus feet are bound by the rope of love, is pro- claimed as the topmost of all devotees (bhƒÅgavata-pradhƒÅna). (SB 11.2.55 ) 1 ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ö - ‚Äú‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π ‘‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡§ø’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∂‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ò‡•å‡§ò‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡§ø ? ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§® ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡•§ ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi comments: “Sage Havi speaks this verse in order to convey the essence of all the characteristics of an uttama- bhƒÅgavata mentioned previously by him. The uttama-bhƒÅgavata 1 visrjati h·πõdayam na yasya s√§k·π£ad dharir ava≈õabhihito’py aghaugha-nƒÅ≈õa·∏• pranaya-rasanaya dh·πõtƒÅnghri-padma·∏• sa bhavati bhagavata-pradhana ukta·∏• 1204 198 Gradations of Uttama-bhagavatas is he whose heart Bhagavan Hari Himself can never abandon. [And what is the power of this Bhagavan, who is powerless to abandon the devotee’s heart?] He is the one who destroys all sins even if addressed unintentionally or under duress (avasa). Why is He powerless to abandon the uttama-bhƒÅgavata’s heart? Because His lotus feet are tied to the devotee’s heart with the rope of love. Such a person is proclaimed as the topmost of all devotees (bhƒÅgavata-pradhƒÅna).” ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•á ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§É - ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡•§ [The word sƒÅk·π£ƒÅt, “directly,” or, “in person,” is used in the verse in regard to Bhagavan Hari, indicating that He Him- self is self-disclosed in the uttama-bhƒÅgavata’s heart.] In this regard, the word sƒÅk·π£ƒÅt is indicative of the cause (hetu) as to the impossibility of worldly desire (kƒÅma) arising in the uttama- bhƒÅgavata’s heart, because the immediate self-disclosure of Bha- gavƒÅn (sƒÅk·π£ƒÅtkƒÅra) is possible only after all material desires are uprooted. ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‚Äú‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø " ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡•á- ‡§∂‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§ß‡•å‡§ò‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§É ‚Äù ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö ‚Äú‡§è‡§§‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø- ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•®‡•§‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ Furthermore, the verse states that Bhagavan Hari destroys all sins even if addressed unintentionally. The uttama-bhƒÅgavata, however, whose love is such that it can bind Bhagavan to his heart, certainly continuously sings the names of Bhagavan Hari with deep absorption. It is thus all the more self-evident that the destruction of sins occurs in his case. This is what is being said. [That the uttama-bhƒÅgavata constantly chants the names of Bhagavan Hari] is implied in verses such as this: O King, for those seeking fulfillment of material desires [iccha- tƒÅm, i.e., kƒÅminam], for those who are indifferent to worldly existence [nirvidyamƒÅnƒÅnƒÅm, i.e., mumuk·π£≈´≈ÜƒÅm] and seeking 1205 II How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained the state of utter fearlessness [akuto-bhayam, i.e., mok≈üam iccha- tƒÅm], and for those already established in immediate realiza- tion of the Truth [yoginƒÅm, i.e., j√±ƒÅninƒÅm], this constant chant- ing of the holy name of Bhagavan Hari has been ascertained [both as the means of attainment (sadhana), in the case of the first two, and as the end to be attained (sƒÅdhya), in the case of the last]. (SB 2.1.11)3 ‡§§‡§§ ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ò‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‚Äú‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§§‡•á” (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•®‡•§‡•™‡•™) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ It is therefore implied from both points of view, [i.e., from the perspective that Bhagavan is immediately self-disclosed in the uttama-bhƒÅgavata’s heart, and from the perspective that the uttama-bhƒÅgavata constantly chants Bhagavan’s name], that the subconscious impressions of sins (agha-sa·πÅskƒÅra) cannot possibly remain in the uttama-bhƒÅgavata’s heart. By thus alluding to the characteristics of a devotee’s speech in this verse, the answer to King Nimi’s original question, “What is the nature of a devotee’s speech?” [SB 11.2.44] is also provided [cf. Anuccheda 187]. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‚Äú‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•ß‡•® ‡•§‡•™‡•Æ) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ- ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤- ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡•§ In this section of eight verses, beginning from SB 11.2.48, char- acterizing the uttama-bhƒÅgavata, the definitions may be taken either collectively [as constituting one continuous definition] or separately. In the case of an uttama-bhƒÅgavata who has brought Bhagavan under his control [as indicated in the con- cluding verse], the definitions are taken collectively, because all other symptoms are implicit within this one characteris- tic. Sometimes, however, an uttama-bhƒÅgavata exhibits only ‚ö´ ≈örƒ´ VirarƒÅghava 2 etan nirvidyamƒÅnƒÅnƒÅm icchatƒÅm akuto-bhayam yoginƒÅm n·πõpa nirnƒ´tam harer nƒÅmƒÅnukirtanam Unless otherwise indicated, all bracketed inserts in this verse are according to the commentary of ≈örƒ´dhara Svami. 1206 198 Gradations of Uttama-bhagavatas two or three of the symptoms mentioned. In such cases, the corresponding definitions apply separately. ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡•à‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡§§‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡•à‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‚Äú‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å‚Äù (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•® ‡•§ ‡•™‡•´) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•Å ‚Äú ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§§‡§ø‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£- ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡•§ In the case where all the verses are taken together as part of one definition, each of the eight verses serve to define the mahƒÅ- bhƒÅgavata who is first described in sB11.2.45 as one who per- ceives Bhagavan in all beings and all beings in Bhagavan. The essence of all these definitions, however, is stated in the last verse, namely that the uttama-bhƒÅgavata binds Bhagavan in his heart with the rope of love, because this quality forms the under- lying basis (hetu) of all other characteristics mentioned in the preceding verses. ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø “‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø- ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ An example of how this is so can be seen from the quality of remembrance (smrti), which is referred to in SB 11.2.49. In that verse, the uttama-bhagavata’s constant remembrance of Bhaga- vƒÅn is said to be the cause of his not becoming bewildered by the fundamental attributes of material existence. Yet the explana- tion for this state of uninterrupted remembrance is disclosed in the final statement. ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ï‡•ç ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ó‡•ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•á ‡•§ So although the definition of an uttama-bhƒÅgavata was expressed in just one verse, it should be understood that the other verses were spoken just to clarify the attributes of such a devotee. Consequently, the repetition of the words “such a person is an uttama-bhƒÅgavata,” found in each verse, is also appropriate. ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§® ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§™‡§¶‡§¨‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£- ‡§¨‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ 1207 II How Aki√±cana-bhakti Is Attained In considering the alternative case, where each of the verses are viewed as distinct definitions, the uttama-bhƒÅgavata’s stated characteristics are not always seen to be directly related to Bha- gavan. Wherever this occurs [specifically, in SB 11.2.51-52], the relation to Bhagavan is to be understood either from the word bhƒÅgavata, appearing in the verse itself, or from the context. ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ Again, where the verses are regarded as separate definitions, the word smrti, “remembrance,” mentioned either in a pre- ceding or a following verse, is to be connected to each of the other verses [since this is the fundamental attribute of an uttama-bhƒÅgavata]. ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ- ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ” ‡§á‡§§‡§ø “‡§® ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‚Äú‡§® ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‚Äú‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•à‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ “‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ 4 Viewing the verses as distinct definitions, there is a gradation among the uttama-bhƒÅgavatas referred to by these definitions. The order of increasing superiority is as follows:* One who worships Bhagavan Hari with implicit faith that He is present in the deity form, but whose awareness of His presence in devotees or in other living beings is yet unde- veloped, is a prƒÅk·πõta-uttama-bhƒÅgavata, meaning an uttama- bhƒÅgavata in the very beginning stage of development. This definition [SB 11.2.47] represents the lowest stage of evolution of the uttama-bhƒÅgavata. Previously, the three verses SB 11.2.45-47 were given as definitions of the uttama (superlative), madhyama (intermediate), and kanistha or prakrta (neophyte) devotees, respectively. The eight verses following these were then understood as elaborations on the uttama-bhagavata, defined in SB 11.2.45. Now, all eleven verses are re-considered as constituting distinct definitions of various grades of superlative devotees. In this case, the words madhyama and pr√§k·πõta, mentioned in SB 11.2.46 and 47, respectively, are understood to refer to intermediate and beginning stages of uttama-bhagavatas. 1208 198 Gradations of Uttama-bhagavatas Superior to this is the uttama-bhƒÅgavata who has given up all identification with the body based on birth, deeds, and so on [SB 11.2.51]. Superior to this is the uttama-bhƒÅgavata who makes no distinction between himself and others [SB 11.2.52]. Superior to this is the uttama-bhƒÅgavata who directly perceives the world as a manifestation of Bhagavan Vis≈Üu’s extrinsic potency, and who engages with sense objects without attach- ment or aversion [SB 11.2.48]. And superior to the latter is the uttama-bhƒÅgavata who is never bewildered by the fundamental attributes of material existence due to constant remembrance of Bhagavan Hari [SB 11.2.49]. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡•ã ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á- ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ In the uttama-bhƒÅgavata of this last category, the subconscious impressions (samsk√§ras) of desire are still present, but he is not bewildered by them. This definition refers to an uttama- bhƒÅgavata whose material desires are dormant [specified in Anuccheda 187 as murcchita-ka·π£ƒÅya] and in whom the first sprout of divine love (premankura) has newly appeared. ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‚Äú‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äú‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡§µ‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø " ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ The description of an uttama-bhƒÅgavata whose remembrance never strays from the lotus feet of Bhagavan even for half a moment - not even for the sake of the opulence of the three worlds [SB 11.2.53] - provides the explanation for his internal state depicted in SB 11.2.50, in which he is said to be free from all expectation, striving, and the seeds of desire due to having taken exclusive shelter of Bhagavan Vasudeva. ‡§á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø- ‡§§‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ The naisthiki-bhakti, or “resolute devotion,” depicted in this statement [SB 11.2.53] is known as dhyana, or “one-pointedness 1209II How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained of mental attention on the object of meditation,” and more specifically as dhruvƒÅnusm·πõti, or “uninterrupted remembrance like a continuous flow of nectar.” At this stage, the sprout of divine love (premankura) has also appeared in the uttama- bhƒÅgavata in an unconcealed manner, otherwise such contin- uous remembrance of Bhagavan would not be possible.
