P·πõthu thus establishes his conclusion on the basis of the Vedas (≈õruti-pramƒÅ·πáa), log- ical argument (yukti-pramƒÅ≈Üa), and the direct experience of realized souls (vidvad-anubhava-pramƒÅna). ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø ‚Äì ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ω‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡•§ In the last line of this series of verses [SB 4.21.30], P·πõthu spec- ifies Gadabh·πõt [as the bestower of the results of all action, i.e., Parame≈õvara]. The word varga refers to the threefold objec- tives (tri-varga) of religion (dharma), prosperity (artha), and the actualization of desire (kƒÅma). The word svarga, “heaven,” refers to the result obtained through dharma, and apavarga means “liberation” (mok·π£a). So, P·πõthu specifies Gadabh·πõt as the uniform cause (ekatmya hetuna) in the matter of the ful- fillment of all these pursuits. Here, the word ekatmya, lit., “of one (eka) unchanging Self (ƒÅtmƒÅ),” signifies that Bhagavan’s causality in this regard is in terms of His being immanently present within all beings (sarv√§ntar-gatena) in a singular form (eka-r≈´pyena). Furthermore, He is distinguished as “the pri- mary cause” (praye·πáa hetunƒÅ), [indicating that of the various causal factors involved in the fulfillment of tri-varga, svarga, and apavarga, He is the principal cause]. 9 In the translation, this line is given earlier to show its syntactical connection to the word gadabh·πõtƒÅ. 1288 ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á- 204 ≈öraddha As Occasioned by Sravana and Manana This is affirmed in Skanda PurƒÅ·πáa: ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•à‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§É || ‡•¨‡•ß‡•´ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•• He who binds the living beings with the fetters of material exis- tence, and He who releases them from those same fetters - He, the bestower of ultimate liberation, is none other than the Sup- reme Absolute (Parabrahman), the eternal Bhagavan Vis≈Üu. (Skanda PurƒÅ·πáa)10 Commentary Continuing with his description of the path of deliberation (vicƒÅra- pradhana-marga), Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmi shows how appropriate reflection (manana) on ≈õƒÉstra results in ≈õraddha in the existence of Bhagavan. The example he gives is that of King Prthu. In the group of verses cited by ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va (SB 4.21.27-30), Prthu concludes on the basis of ≈õƒÅstra (≈õruti-pramƒÅ≈Üa), logic (yukti-pramƒÅna), and the direct expe- rience of realized souls (vidvad-anubhava-pramƒÅna), that there is a Supreme Regulator (Parame≈õvara), who bestows the fruits of all action. Prthu’s main rationale is based on an analysis of the fruits of karma. It is evidenced that although two persons undertake the same action, they obtain different results, or one of them may fail completely. Sometimes, even the same person obtains different results when performing the exact same action on different occa- sions. Even if all the parameters involved in the action remain con- stant, the result may still be seen to be different. This indicates that there is some other causal factor besides our personal endeavor that determines the outcome. In this regard, Krsna instructs 10 bandhako bhava-pasena bhava-pƒÅ≈õƒÅc ca mocaka·∏• kaivalyadah param brahma visnur eva sanƒÅtana·∏• 128911 How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained Arjuna: “Your eligibility pertains exclusively to the performance of action but never to the fruits thereof” (GITA 2.47).” The idea that there is a supreme entity - namely, Bhagavan - under whose control the cosmos functions is also the direct expe- rience of great personalities, such as Manu. This conclusion is also supported by sastra, such as Vedanta-s≈´tra (3.2.38), which states that the fruits of action are awarded by Bhagavan. ≈örƒ´ Jiva next makes reference to the Antaryami-≈õruti, which is a famous chapter in the B·πõhad-aranyaka Upanisad, to show that even the devas who preside over the elements are not independent in bestowing the fruits of action. In response to UddƒÅlaka’s request for him to describe the Internal Regulator (antaryƒÅmƒ´), YƒÅj√±avalkya begins with the following statement: He who is present within the earth element, who pervades the earth from within, whom the earth does not know, whose body is the earth, and who regulates the earth from within - He is your Immortal Self, the Inner Regulator. (BAU 3.7.3)12 Beginning from this verse, Yajnavalkya proceeds in like man- ner to describe how God dwells in all the elements and their pre- siding deities as the Inner Regulator of all of them. The Brahma- sutras codify these conclusions in the Abhimany-adhikarana, or the section entitled “The Superintending Deities” (vs 2.1.5). The Antaryamy-adhikarana, or the section entitled “The Internal Regulator,” is also relevant in this regard (vs 1.2.18-20). After the practitioner has attained ≈õraddha in the existence of Bhagavan, he or she then develops faith in the path of worship that pertains to Him (tad-bhajana-marga). This will be described in the following anuccheda. “This means that a person has the choice to perform or neglect his or her duty, 12 but there is no such choice in regard to the results of one’s actions. yah prthivyam tisthan prthivyam antaro yam prthivi na veda yasya prthivi sariram ya·∏• prthivim antaro yamayaty e≈üa ta ƒÅtmƒÅntaryamy am·πõta·∏• 1290 Anuccheda 205 Faith in Bhajana Occasioned by Deliberation ‡•®‡•¶‡•´ | ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§≠‡§ú‡§® ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•™‡•§‡•®‡•ß‡•§‡•©‡•ß-‡•©‡•®) -

NEXT, faith in bhajana [which accompanies faith in Bhaga- van as a consequence of reflection (manana) on the path of deliberation] is described by King P·πõthu: ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§™‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•¨‡•ß‡•¨ ‡•• ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Æ‡§≤‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•• ‡•¨‡•ß‡•≠ || The taste to serve the lotus feet of Bhagavan, which increases day-by-day and is of the nature of authentic being (sati), imme- diately cleanses the mind’s impurities accumulated over unlim- ited births of those who are afflicted by worldly existence, just as the river Ganga, which originated from the toe of Bhagavan, [also washes away sinful desire]. A person whose mind has been thoroughly cleansed of all impu- rities, who has become empowered with the immediate realiza- tion of a particular manifestation of Bhagavan as a consequence of his detachment, and who has made his abode at the soles of 1 Sridhara SvƒÅmi glosses the word sati (qualifying abhiruci) as sattviki, “of the nature of authentic being,” and Sri Vi≈õvanatha Cakravarti glosses the same word as suddha-sattva-svarupa nityety arthah, “of the nature of unalloyed being and, hence, eternal.” Additionally, Sridhara Svami glosses the word tapasvinam as samsara-taptanam, “of those who are afflicted by worldly existence.” 1291 II How Aki√±cana-bhakti Is Attained Bhagavan’s feet, is never again subjected to the cycle of birth and death, which carries with it all miseries. (SB 4.21.31-32)2 I ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡•à‡§∑ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§π - ‡§Ø‡§•‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç || ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§∏‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• The word tapasvinƒÅm, “of the distressed,” means “of those who are afflicted by worldly existence” (samsara-taptƒÅnƒÅm). The first of these two verses demonstrates by way of an example the glory of mere contact with Bhagavan’s feet. In the second verse, the word asanga, “detachment,” means nonattachment (anƒÅsa- kti) to anything that is not connected to Bhagavan. By such detachment, a particular immediate realization (vij√±ƒÅna-vi≈°e·π£a) ensues, which here refers to the direct vision (sƒÅk·π£ƒÅtkƒÅra) of one particular manifestation of Bhagavan out of His innumerable forms. This direct vision alone then becomes the power (virya) of the person who has taken shelter of the soles of Bhagavan’s feet. Commentary BY HEARING the glories of Bhagavan, such as described by Prthu to his subjects, one develops the ≈õraddha to serve Him. The word tapasvi in SB 4.21.31 generally means “an ascetic.” ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va, however, interprets it in an uncommon manner as “those who are afflicted by worldly existence” (samsara-taptƒÅnƒÅm). This is justified, because the word tapa, “material misery,” and the word tapasvƒ´ share a common root. Moreover, materialistic people as well as ascetics both undergo suffering. Tapasvis of the first category suffer by the force of karma, whereas those of the second category choose 2 yat-pada-sevabhirucis tapasvinam ase·π£a-janmopacitam malam dhiya·∏• sadya·∏• k·π£inoty anvaham edhati sati yatha padangustha-vini·∏•s·πõtƒÅ sarit vinirdhutƒÉse≈üa-mano-mala·∏• puman asanga-vij√±ƒÅna-vise·π£a-viryavan yad-anghri-m√ºle k·πõta-ketanah punar na sams·πõtim klesa-vahƒÅm prapadyate 1292 205 Faith in Bhajana Occasioned by Deliberation to undergo voluntary suffering for religious purposes. If material- istic people are able to accept their suffering as an austerity, they can also obtain the same benefit as the tapasvis do by undertaking austerities. The example of how a person is purified by bathing in the Ganga River is given to show the supremacy of Bhagavan by way of the a fortiori principle. If the water of the Ganga has such purifying power merely because it contacted the feet of Bhagavan, then how much greater must be the purifying power of Bhagavan Himself? Through hearing and contemplating statements such as these, one develops ≈õraddha in bhajana. This ultimately leads to the direct vision of Bhagavan. 1293 ≈öravana, ≈öik·π£ƒÅ, and Mantra-gurus Anucchedas 206-213 Anuccheda 206 The ≈öravana-guru and Sik·π£ƒÅ-guru Are Generally the Same Person ‡•®‡•¶‡•¨ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§π (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•©‡•§‡•®‡•®) - THE ≈õrava·πáa-guru and the bhajana-≈°ik·π£ƒÅ-guru are generally the same person, as sage Prabuddha indicated to King Nimi: ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ã ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•¨‡•ß‡•Æ || In his presence [i.e., the ≈õravana-guru described in the previous verse], the aspirant who regards his guru as his very self and worshipful object, should learn, by way of unpretentious con- tinuous service, the dharma that pertains directly to Bhagavan, by which [dharma] ≈örƒ´ Hari, the Supreme Immanent Self, who awards even His own Self [to His devotees], becomes pleased. (SB 11.3.22)2 " ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ " ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•© ‡•§ ‡•®‡•ß) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•å ‡•§ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§§‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ 2 As seen below, this is ≈öri Jiva GosvƒÅmis gloss on the pronoun tatra, lit., “in that matter,” referring to the guru described in the immediately preceding verse (tasmad gurum prapadyeta), cited in Anuccheda 202.4. ≈öri ViraraghavacƒÅrya and other commentators gloss the same word as guru-sannidhau, “in the presence of such a guru.” tatra bhagavatan dharman sik≈üed gurv-atma-daivata·∏• amƒÅyayanuv·πõtty√§ yais tusyed atmatma-do hari·∏• 1297 II How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained The pronoun tatra refers to the ≈õravana-guru, who was described in the preceding verse, “tasmad gurum prapadyeta” (SB 11.3.21). The compound gurv-atma-daivata·∏• refers to the aspirant, who is of such disposition (tatha-bh≈´tah) that he regards his guru alone as his very self (ƒÅtmƒÅ), meaning “his veritable life” (jivanam), and as his worshipful object (daivata), meaning “his worship- ful deity” (nija-i≈ü»õa-daivata). Such an aspirant should learn (sikset) by way of unpretentious (amƒÅyaya) continuous service (anuv·πõtty√§). Here, the word amƒÅyaya means “unduplicitous” (nirdambhaya), and the word anuv·πõtty√§ means “by following him obediently” (tad-anugatya). ‡§Ø‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã- ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• The pronoun yai·∏•, “by which,” means “by which dharma” (dharmai·∏•) [≈örƒ´ Hari becomes pleased]. The word ƒÅtmƒÅ, ‚ÄúSelf,‚Äù means “ParamƒÅtmƒÅ, the Supreme Immanent Self.” [The word atma-da·∏•] means “He who awards even His own Self to His devo- tees, such as ≈örƒ´ Bali and others.” As mentioned previously, one can have numerous such sik·π£ƒÅ-gurus. Commentary THE ≈öRAVANA-GURU is the teacher from whom one learns the ≈õ√§stra, and the bhajana-siksa-guru is the one who teaches practi- cal aspects of sadhana-bhakti. Usually these two will be the same, because the teacher from whom one begins to study will naturally become one’s guide for spiritual practice. It is preferable that they be the same person, otherwise there can be confusion in the mind of the student. If the student hears different opinions from two different teach- ers, he or she will be in difficulty, because the words of one of them will have to be disregarded, which could lead to an offense. If both these gurus belong to the same spiritual tradition, then there may not be any difference in their teachings, otherwise there is bound 1298 206 The ≈öravana-guru and Sik·π£ƒÅ-guru Are Generally the Same Person to be some disparity. One sometimes hears of Vaisnavas in V·πõnda- vana who held respect for seniors or gurus on both sides of a contro- versy and who hid themselves so that they would not have to take sides, fearing that to do so would offend one of them. The guru-disciple relationship is one of the most important and unique aspects of Indian society. Indeed, this one sacred bond is what makes Indian society distinct in the whole world. Although at present there is little or no training in this honored tradition, it still runs very deep in the Indian psyche, as if it is in their genes. Its importance can be understood only by experiencing it. For the modern mind, it appears as if the disciple sacrifices his independence to become a slave of the guru. The modern mind can- not understand that the only way transcendental knowledge can be transmitted is from the heart of the guru into that of the dis- ciple. It is not simply a matter of attending a lecture in a class- room where a teacher speaks and then goes away. The disciple and teacher remain bound to each other. When the relation is pure, then the teaching is transmitted even without words. It is as if their hearts become linked up, and the knowledge is transferred through this bond. Indian history is filled with stories of this pristine relation, from the age of the Upanisads through to modern times. In this regard, Svetasvatara Upanisad makes the following assertion: The imports of the teachings described in this Upanisad are revealed only to that elevated soul in whom transcendental devo- tion for Bhagavan is present and who feels the same quality of devotion for his guru as felt for Bhagavan. (SU 6.23)3 The verse cited in this anuccheda (SB 11.3.22) is spoken by sage Prabuddha. It contains the most important instruction for a sincere disciple. In the immediately preceding verse, cited in Anuccheda 202.4, Prabuddha specified the essential characteris- tics of a qualified guru. In this verse, he elaborates those of the sincere disciple. 3 yasya deve para bhaktir yatha deve tatha gurau tasyaite kathita hy arthah prakasante mahƒÅtmanah 1299II How Aki√±cana-bhakti Is Attained The first criterion mentioned is that the student should study bhƒÅgavata-dharma, or bhakti, from the guru. Bhakti is not some- thing to be understood by reading books or articles on the inter- net. One must study it from an authentic guru. This is an injunc- tion, as indicated by use of the optative form of the verb, tatra sik≈üet, “the aspirant must learn in the presence of his guru.” There is no alternative course of action. The second criterion is that this study must be undertaken by way of rendering continuous service to the guru (anuv·πõtty√§). Moreover, this service must be done without any duplicity or pretension (amƒÅyaya). In this regard, K·πõ·π£·πáa makes the following statement: I, the Immanent Self of all beings, am not as pleased with daily sac- rifice, study of the Vedas, austerities, or renunciation, as I am by service to the guru. (SB 10.80.34)* In support of the same conclusion, Narada instructed Yudhi- sthira that one can attain perfection simply by service to a qualified guru (SB 7.15.25). On the other hand, if one disrespects the guru, he cannot achieve anything spiritually (SB 7.15.26). The guru is the key, the doorway to the spiritual world, as well as the companion in the spiritual world. For these reasons, one must treat the guru with respect and love. The compound gurv-atma-daivatah is very important. This is a reference to the aspirant, mentioned in the previous verse, who is profoundly inquisitive about the ultimate good (jij√±ƒÅsu·∏• ≈õreya uttamam). The compound signifies that the genuine aspirant is one who regards his guru as his very self (ƒÅtmƒÅ) and worshipful object (devatƒÅ). A nearly identical expression was employed in the very first anuccheda of this book, namely, guru-devatƒÅtmƒÅ (SB 11.2.37). 4 The word ƒÅtmƒÅ is used here in the sense of the object of pure, unconditional love. One should love the guru as one would love God, or K·πõ·π£·πáa. Just as nothing can remain hidden from one’s own ƒÅtmƒÅ, so too the same dynamic applies in regard to one’s guru. This gives rise to a deep sense of unity. There should be a oneness of

  • n√§ham ijy√§-praj√§tibhyam tapasopasamena ca tu≈üyeyam sarva-bh≈´tƒÅtmƒÅ guru-su≈õru·π£aya yathƒÅ 1300 206 The ≈öravana-guru and Siksa-guru Are Generally the Same Person heart between the guru and the disciple. The disciple needs to attune his or her heart with the heart of the guru, as stated in ·πög Veda: “May your intention be one and the same, your hearts united, your minds of one accord, so that intimate companionship may be yours” (RV 10.191.4)5 This is the significance of the word ƒÅtmƒÅ. It also means that one should be like an open book in front of the guru. The second word is daivatam, meaning that the guru is to be regarded in the same spirit as one’s worshipful deity. If one feels only love without a sense of reverence, then one may not take instructions from the guru. One may become too familiar with him. For this reason, the sage says daivatam - one must honor the guru in the same manner as one’s worshipable deity. One should never think of the guru as an ordinary human being, guru≈üu nara- mati·∏•. In other words, the disciple has to have both moods with the guru, ai≈õvarya and madhurya, reverence and intimacy. When one serves the guru in this way, K·πõ·π£·πáa is pleased. Krsna is referred to here as atma-da·∏•, “He who gives Himself to His devotees.” When K·πõ·π£·πáa was pleased with Bali’s surrender, He gave Himself to Bali and became his doorkeeper. This signifies that when the guru is pleased, K·πõ·π£·πáa is also pleased. 5 samƒÅni va ak≈´ti·∏• samana h·πõdayƒÅni va·∏• samƒÅnam astu vo mano yatha vah susahƒÅsati 6 Padyavali 114 1301 Anuccheda 207 The Dik·π£ƒÅ-guru Is Only One ‡•®‡•¶‡•≠ ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï ‡§è‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß ‡•§ ‡•© ‡•§ ‡•™‡•Æ) - ONE can have only one mantra-guru, as indicated by sage Avirhotra: 1 ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π ‡§Ü‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É || ‡•¨‡•ß‡•Ø ‡•§‡•§ One who has received grace (anugraha)’ from an ƒÅcƒÅrya and who has been instructed by him in the prescribed method of worship according to the Agamas, should worship the Supreme Puru≈üa [Bhagavan] in the form that is according to his longing. (SB 11.3.48)2 ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡•Å‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡•• ‡•¨‡•®‡•¶ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡•à‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ In his Bala-prabodhini commentary on this verse, ≈örƒ´ Giridhara glosses the word anugraha as “the prior investiture with the sacred thread (upanayana), mantra initiation, and so on. " Additionally, Sridhara Svamƒ´ glosses the compound sandar·π£itƒÅgama·∏• as “one who has been instructed by that ƒÅcƒÅrya in the prescribed method of worship according to the Agamas” (tenƒÅcƒÅryena sandarsita ƒÅgamo’rcana-prakƒÅro yasya sah). labdhvƒÅnugraha ƒÅcƒÅryat tena sandarsitƒÅgama·∏• maha-purusam abhyarcen murtyabhimatayƒÅtmana·∏• 1302 207 The Diksa-guru Is Only One In this verse, the word anugraha means “grace in the form of mantra initiation” (mantra-dik·π£ƒÅ-rupa·∏•). The Agama refers to the scripture that describes the mantra and the method of wor- ship according to that mantra. The use of the singular here [ƒÅcƒÅryat, “from that one ƒÅcƒÅrya”] implies that there can be only one mantra-guru. This is supported by the fact that it is forbidden to abandon one’s mantra-guru, as stated in Brahma-vaivarta PurƒÅ·πáa: One who has abandoned his guru has already rejected Bhagavan Hari. His intelligence is polluted, and he has acted duplicitously. (Brahma-vaivarta PurƒÅ·πáa)3 ‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ If simply because of being dissatisfied with one’s guru, one accepts another guru, then by virtue of accepting more than one guru, one’s previous guru is necessarily rejected. ‡§è‡§§‡§ö‡•ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§™‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç - The same point [that ordinarily one should not abandon one’s mantra-guru] is re-emphasized by the exception to the general rule provided in the Narada Pa√±carƒÅtra: ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§É || ‡•¨‡•®‡•ß ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• One goes to hell by receiving a mantra from a guru who is not a Vai·π£·πáava. Such a person should again accept a mantra from a Vaisnava guru, in conformity with the prescribed principles. (Narada PancarƒÅtra)* 3 bodhah kalusitas tena dauratmyam prakatik·πõtam 4 gurur yena parityaktas tena tyakta·∏• pura harih avai·π£·πáavopadistena mantrena nirayam vrajet puna≈õ ca vidhina samyag grahayed vai·π£·πáavad guroh 1303 II How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained Commentary ≈öRƒ™ JIVA GOSVƒÄMƒ™ has mentioned three types of gurus, viz., ≈õrava·πáa-guru, sik·π£ƒÅ-guru, and mantra-guru. The ≈õravana-guru is he from whom one studies sastra. At present, he is popularly called the sik≈üƒÉ-guru. According to ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va, the sik·π£ƒÅ-guru is the one from whom one learns the method of performing bhajana. Bhajana here means uttering of mantras, kirtana, and other related acts of devo- tion. Deity worship is also an important part of bhakti. But to be eligible for worship, one must first receive the mantra of the deity from a genuine guru. Therefore, under normal circumstances the mantra-guru naturally also becomes one’s sik·π£ƒÅ-guru. The mantra-guru is nowadays commonly called the dƒ´k·π£ƒÅ-guru. As a general rule, the ≈õravana-guru, sik·π£ƒÅ-guru, and mantra-guru are one and the same person. Very rarely are they different. It is also highly practical and advisable that all three functions are car- ried out by the same person. Otherwise, there can be confusion and conflict in the mind of the student, which can lead to offenses. The mantra-guru cannot be more than one, because one is ini- tiated only in a particular mantra. A practitioner can study from different gurus and also learn bhajana from various masters, but he cannot be initiated into mantra from two or more gurus. If he does so, it is understood that he has already rejected the previous mantra-guru as well as the mantra given by him. Therefore, there can only be one mantra-guru. Sastra informs us that there is no difference between the mantra, the guru, and Bhagavan Conse- quently, rejecting the guru also means rejecting Bhagavan. By the same logic, obtaining a guru means to attain Bhagavan. There are, however, some exceptional cases in which one is per- mitted to give up one’s guru. If one has taken dƒ´k·π£ƒÅ in a mantra other than a Vai·π£·πáava mantra, then one should abandon such a guru and mantra and accept a Vaisnava guru. There is no alternative in this regard. ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmƒ´ refers to such a predicament as the cause yo mantra·∏• sa guruh s√§k·π£ad yo guru·∏• sa hari·∏• svayam gurur yasya bhavet tustas tasya tusto harih svayam Attributed to Vamana-kalpa in Hari-bhakti-vilƒÅsa (4.351, see Anuccheda 237). 1304 207 The Dik·π£a-guru Is Only One of dissatisfaction in the student. Only under such circumstances is a student permitted to give up his mantra-guru. Indeed, according to Narada PancarƒÅtra, once a student becomes aware of this princi- ple, he must give up the non-Vaisnava guru. This also implies that a Vaisnava guru never gives a non-Vaisnava mantra. The worship recommended is according to the Agama. The word agama here means the Tantra scriptures, as is evident from the preceding verse, “One should worship Bhagavan Kesava [K·πõ·π£·πáa] by means of the Vedic rites along with the Tantrika rites” (SB 11.3.47) K·πõ·π£·πáa also recommends that in the present age, wor- ship is to be done both by Vedic mantras and Tantrika mantras: “[The practice of devotion includes] taking dƒ´k·π£ƒÅ in Vedic and Tan- trika mantras and observing vratas related to Me [such as EkƒÅdasƒ´]” (SB 11.11.37)? Generally speaking, in the Vaisnava School, Tantra is called Pa√±carƒÅtra, Pa√±carƒÅtrƒÅgama, or just ƒÄgama, as in the prin- cipal verse of this anuccheda. In contrast, the Vedas are called Nigama, as in SB 1.1.3 (nigama-kalpa-taroh). 6 7 vidhinopacared devam tantraktena ca kesavam vaidiki tantriki dƒ´ksa madiya-vrata-dhƒÅranam 1305 Anuccheda 208 Knowledge of Scriptural Truth Is Received Only from the ≈örava·πáa-guru ‡•®‡•¶‡•Æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£‡•à‡§µ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•¶‡•§‡•ß‡•®) - AMONG them [the ≈õravana-guru, sik·π£ƒÅ-guru, and mantra-guru], it is specifically by contact with the ≈õravana-guru that the immediate intuition of scriptural truths can manifest, and not otherwise, as stated by ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa: ‡§Ü‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§µ‡§π‡§É || ‡•¨‡•®‡•® ‡•• The ƒÅcƒÅrya is the lower piece of wood used for kindling a fire (adya-arani); the disciple is the upper piece of wood (uttara- arani); instruction is the middle piece of wood used as a churn- ing rod (tat-sandhanam);’ and knowledge is their union, which confers delight. (SB 11.10.12)2 ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ß‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•å ‡§≠‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡•§ 1 ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmƒ´, Visvanatha Cakravarti, and all other commentators have glossed the compound tat-sandhanam, lit., “their point of contact,” as tayor madhyamam manthana-kastham, “the churning rod placed between these two.” ƒÅcƒÅryo’ranir adyah syad antevasy uttararani·∏• tat-sandhanam pravacanam vidya sandhi·∏• sukhƒÅvaha·∏• 1306 208 Knowledge of Scriptural Truth Is Received Only from the ≈öravana-guru The word adya·∏•, lit., “the first,” means the lower piece of wood used for kindling a fire (adhara·∏• aranih). The compound tat- sandhanam, lit., “their contact point,” means “the churning rod placed between these two” (tayor madhyamam manthana- k√§·π£·π≠ham). The word pravacanam, “spoken discourse,” means “oral instruction” (upade≈õa). The word vidya, “knowledge,” refers to the knowledge disclosed in scripture, which is man- ifested out of the union of these three, just as fire is generated by the contact of the lower, upper, and middle pieces of wood. ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‚Äú‡§Ü‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç” ( ‡§§‡•à‡•¶‡•ß‡•§‡•©‡•ß‡•©) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ A similar statement is found in the ≈öruti: Now with regard to knowledge: The acarya is the prior form, the disciple, the posterior; knowledge, their junction; and instruction, the medium. (TU 1.3.3)3 ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ “‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§∏ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‚Äù (‡§Æ‡•Å‡•¶‡•ß‡•ß‡•®‡•§‡•ß‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‚Äú‡§Ü‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶” ( ‡§õ‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•¨ ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•™ ‡•§ ‡•®) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ Therefore, the ≈öruti makes the following statements [regarding the necessity of receiving knowledge from a guru]: To obtain immediate realization of the Supreme Reality, one should certainly approach a guru. (MUU 1.2.12)* One who has accepted an ƒÅcƒÅrya becomes acquainted with the Absolute. (CHU 6.14.2)5 3

athadhi-vidyam acaryah purva-rupam antev√¢sy uttara-rupam vidya sandhi·∏• pravacanam sandhanam iti adhi-vidyam ‚ö´ tad-vij√±ƒÅnƒÅrtham sa gurum evabhigacchet 5 ƒÅcƒÅryavan puruso veda 1307 II How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained " ‡§®‡•à‡§∑‡§æ ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡•á‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§† ‚Äù ( ‡§ï‡§†‡•¶‡•ß‡•§‡•® ‡•§ ‡•Ø) ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó- ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• And: O dearest one, this wisdom pertaining to the Absolute cannot be obtained by logic. Only when knowledge is received from a guru does it lead to the true understanding. (Katha Upanisad 1.2.9) Commentary IN FORMER TIMES, the fire required to perform yaj√±a was produced by churning wood of the sami tree. This wood was called arani. To start the fire, friction was created between a lower piece of wood, an upper piece, and a churning rod in the center. Since at the time in question, match boxes were not available, there was no other way of producing fire. In the same manner, there is no other way of obtaining knowledge except by approaching a guru. In this analogy, the guru is compared to the base piece of wood, the student, to the top piece of wood, and the instruction received from the teacher, to the churning rod, since it churns the mind of the student. The knowledge generated in the student from this union is compared to fire. Just as fire was used to perform yaj√±a, so too the knowledge received from an authentic guru leads one to the ultimate goal. One may object that knowledge can be obtained by one’s own initiative simply by reading books. These days, most books are available in print form or on the internet. There are also audio and video lectures available. The guru was formerly needed when these were nonexistent. So, just as match boxes or lighters are now the convenient way to ignite a fire, making the need to churn wood obsolete, so too there is no longer any need to seek knowledge from a guru. So why take the trouble to do so? 6 In response to this doubt, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va cites the principal verse of this anuccheda to affirm the absolute necessity for taking a guru. The naisƒÅ tarkena matir √§paneya prokt√§nyenaiva suj√±ƒÅnƒÅya prestha 1308 208 Knowledge of Scriptural Truth Is Received Only from the Sravana-guru practice of churning wood to generate a fire was not just because match boxes or lighters did not exist in the past, but because it was an essential part of the injunction to execute the yaj√±a. A yaj√±a has to be performed in the precise manner prescribed to attain the desired result. If any detail is altered, then it will not yield the desired result. In Mahabharata (Vana-parva, chapter 135), there is a story to illustrate the necessity of learning from a guru. There was a brƒÅhma·πáa boy named Yavakrƒ´ta, who refused to attend the traditional school, called a gurukula, where students go to live with a guru. When he grew up, he realized that he could not function as a brahmana without an education. On this basis, he decided that he must somehow obtain knowledge. But at this point, he did not want to go to a teacher, because he would feel somewhat ashamed to be with much younger students. He heard that it was possible to obtain anything by observing penances. So he went deep into the forest and engaged in severe penances in the hope of acquiring knowledge. Many years passed, but there was still no result. One day, Yavakrƒ´ta went to the nearby river to take a dip, and there he saw an old man sitting and pouring sand from the bank into the river with his hands. Yavakrƒ´ta became curious to know what the old man was trying to achieve. He approached him and asked him why he was pouring sand into the river. The old man replied in all seriousness, “I need to cross the river. I do not know how to swim, and there are no boats available, so I have decided to build a bridge across it.” When the young brahmana heard this, he could not control his laughter. The old man asked him, “What is so funny? Do you think there is an easier way to cross the river?” Yavakrƒ´ta replied, “I am laughing at your ignorance. You cannot build a bridge by pouring sand into the water. Any fool knows this much.” At this, the old man retorted, “If you think you can obtain knowledge without approaching a guru, then I can also build a bridge in this way. I will do it by my own effort.” The brƒÅhma·πáa was shocked to hear this. Then the old man revealed his identity as Indra, who had appeared there out of compassion for the brahmana. 1309II How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained Indra then asked him to find a qualified guru and study the Vedas from him. 1310 Anuccheda 209 The Bhajana-≈õik·π£ƒÅ-guru Is Also Necessary ‡•®‡•¶‡•Ø | ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§É (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡•§ ‡•Æ‡•≠ ‡•§ ‡•©‡•©) - THE SIK·π¢A-GURU is also necessary, as stated by the personified ≈örutis: ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§π‡•É‡§∑‡•Ä‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§Ø ‡§á‡§π ‡§Ø‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§≤‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§¶‡§É ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§®‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú ‡§á‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡•å ‡•• ‡•¨‡•®‡•© ‡•• O Unborn Absolute [Bhagavan]! Those who neglect the shelter of the feet of a guru and who endeavor to subdue the exceedingly volatile stallion of the mind, which cannot be controlled even by those who have conquered their senses and vital breath, are troubled by the very methods they adopt and beset with hun- dreds of tribulations in the midst of material existence. They are like merchants lost at sea without a captain [for their ship]. (SB 10.87.33)1 ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§≤‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§¶‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§® ‡§è‡§µ ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§®‡§∂‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§á‡§π ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ vijita-hrsika-vƒÅyubhir adƒÅnta-manas turagam ya iha yatanti yantum atilolam upaya-khida·∏• vyasana-≈õatƒÅnvitƒÅ·∏• samavahƒÅya guros cara·πáa·πÅ vanija ivƒÅja santy ak·πõta-karna-dharƒÅ jaladhau 1311 II How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained Those who neglect the feet of a guru (ye guros caranam sama- vahƒÅya) and who endeavor to subdue the exceedingly volatile (atilolam) and uncontrollable (adantam) stallion of the mind (manas-turagam), meaning to turn the mind’s root attention toward Bhagavan (bhagavad-unmukhi-kartum), by way of hav- ing conquered their senses and vital breath (vijitair indriyai·∏• prƒÅ·πáai≈õ ca k·πõtvƒÅ), are tormented by the very methods they adopt (te upaya-khidah). They thus meet with hundreds of tribulations (vyasana-≈õatƒÅnvitƒÅ·∏•) and as a result, certainly remain here (iha) in the midst of material existence (sa·πÅsƒÅra). ‡§π‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ú ! ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ú‡§≤‡§ß‡•å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ O Unborn Absolute (aja)! Such people are compared to mer- chants who are lost at sea (jaladhau) without having accepted a navigator (ak·πõta-karna-dhara). ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•å ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡•§ The import is that when one becomes established in knowledge pertaining to the path of devotion to Bhagavan by means of engagement in the worship (bhajana) of Bhagavan as instructed by one’s guru, then by the mercy of the guru, one is no longer overwhelmed by tribulations (vyasana), and the mind very quickly becomes unwaveringly still. ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡•à‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•á- ‚Äî Therefore, it is said in the Brahma-vaivarta PurƒÅ·πáa: ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•à‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•à‡§∞‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•à‡§É || ‡•¨‡•®‡•™ ‡•• By the remembrance of Bhagavan that ensues from devotion to one’s guru, one attains Bhagavan, who is served by the wise. But those who are filled with a sense of their own superiority cannot 1312 209 The Bhajana-sik·π£ƒÅ-guru Is Also Necessary attain Bhagavan, even if He were present before them. (Brahma- vaivarta PurƒÅna)2 ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö (‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡•¶‡•¨‡•§‡•®‡•©) - The ≈öruti also says: ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•å ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡•• ‡•¨‡•®‡•´ ‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Ø‡§É ‡•• The imports of the teachings described in this Upanisad are revealed only to that elevated soul in whom transcendental devotion for Bhagavan is present and who feels the same quality of devotion for his guru as felt for Bhagavan. (su 6.23)3 Commentary AS MENTIONED EARLIER, the sik·π£ƒÅ-guru is the teacher who instructs the bhakti-yoga practitioner in the essential details of the devo- tional praxis (bhajana). Although bhakti is a simple and natural process, one must learn how to enact it according to the method laid down in sacred tradition. There are always two ways of doing a thing, properly and improperly. This leads to two dif- ferent results intended and unintended. If we hope to attain the intended result, then it behooves us to act properly, and this means that we need to learn from a genuine guru. ‚Äî Even common day-to-day acts must be learnt from others, whether by direct instruction or by observation. This principle is all the more applicable in the case of Bhagavan, who is altogether beyond the range of our perception. How then can we hope to know Him by our own initiative? Moreover, the mind is exceedingly turbulent, as expressed by Arjuna: $ guru-bhakty√§ sa milati smaranƒÅt sevyate budhai·∏• milito’pi na labhyate jivair ahamikaparai·∏• yasya deve para bhaktir yatha deve tatha gurau tasyaite kathita hy arthah prakasante mahƒÅtmana·∏• 1313 II How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained O K·πõ·π£·πáa, because the mind is naturally unsteady, turbulent, vehe- ment, and obstinate, I consider it exceedingly difficult to control, just like the wind. (Gƒ™TƒÄ 6.34)* It is not possible to control the mind without proper guidance. Even the simple practice of uttering mantras (japa) requires guid- ance. Otherwise people go on chanting for decades without much progress. A patient needs to be given the appropriate medicine and the correct procedure of how to take it, at the right time and in the correct proportion. So it is commonly said that even those who are themselves doctors cannot be their own physician. In this regard, there is a well-known quote attributed to Abra- ham Lincoln (but from older sources): “The man who represents himself has a fool for a client and an ass for an attorney.” Sim- ilarly, one cannot be one’s own guru. Spiritual truth is beyond sense perception and intellectual striving, therefore it requires expert guidance. Millions of people take to spiritual life in one form or another, but the success rate of those who actually attain the intended goal is very low. The primary reason for this is the lack of proper guidance. Here, an objection may be raised. In apparent opposition to what is said above, ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa makes the following statement: “The ƒÅtmƒÅ alone is the guru of the individual self, particularly in the case of a human being” (atmano gurur atmaiva purusasya visesata·∏•, SB 11.7.20). So what is the need for an external guru? In reply, it must be pointed out that the meaning of any state- ment must be understood in context. If this statement were taken to mean that there is no need for an external guru, then all the statements cited in this and the previous anucchedas that ordain the necessity for a guru would be contradicted. The word “guru” in this citation does not carry the same connotation as in the present topic under discussion. The sense of the statement is that if one is dis- cerning, one can learn detachment from one’s own life experiences and environment. From this, it may be concluded that material ^ ca√±calam hi mana·∏• krsna pramathi balavad drdham tasyaham nigraham manye vayor iva sudu≈ükaram 1314 209 The Bhajana-sik·π£ƒÅ-guru Is Also Necessary life does not lead to ultimate happiness and that one should thus approach a spiritual teacher. K·πõ·π£·πáa’s statement thus signifies that the ƒÅtmƒÅ, meaning the faculty of discernment, can be the guide to lead a person to spiritual practice. In this spirit, ≈örƒ´ Jƒ´va GosvƒÅmƒ´ comments that when K·πõ·π£·πáa says that the ƒÅtmƒÅ is the guru of the individual self, it means that the ƒÅtmƒÅ is the impeller, prompting a human being to seek out and follow a guru (atmano gurur iti gurvanus√§rane pravarttaka ity artha·∏•). This statement is made by K·πõ·π£·πáa to stress the importance of applying one’s own faculty of discernment. Krsna then offers the example of an avadh≈´ta, who had 24 gurus. These gurus were not human gurus but birds, animals, and even material objects, from whom the avadhuta learned different things by attentive observa- tion. This avadhuta was none other than Dattatreya, an avatara of Vis≈Üu. This entire narration is submitted to instill detachment and not to obviate the need for a guru. If the word guru in SB 11.7.20 is not understood in this sense, then K·πõ·π£·πáa’s instructions to accept a guru in other verses (such as SB 11.10.5, 11.12.24, and 11.20.17) would all be rendered futile. 1315 Anuccheda 210 The Mantra-guru Is Also Compulsory ‡•®‡•ß‡•¶ | ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ- ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§π (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶‡•´/‡•´/‡•ß‡•Æ) - SINCE the ≈õravana- and sik·π£ƒÅ-gurus are both necessary, the mantra-guru is therefore unquestionably so. One should accept the shelter of an authentic teacher in the matter of the real- ization of spiritual truth (the paramarthika-guru), even if it means giving up a teacher who guides one in the course of ordi- nary affairs (the vyavahƒÅrika-guru). With this intention, ≈örƒ´ Rsabhadeva said: ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡•ã ‡§® ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§® ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡•Ä ‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•à‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§® ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ö‡§Ø‡•á‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•¨‡•®‡•¨ ‡•• One who cannot deliver a person for whom repeated death is preordained should not become a guru, a relative, a father, a mother, a deva, or a husband. (SB 5.5.18)1 ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ In this verse, the compound samupeta-m·πõtyum, “the person for whom death is preordained,” means “the person (tam) for whom the state of repeated birth and death (m·πõtyu, i.e., sa·πÅsƒÅra) is priorly attained (samupeta, i.e., samprƒÅpta).’ 1 " gurur na sa syƒÅt sva-jano na sa syat pita na sa syƒÅj janani na sƒÉ syƒÅt daivam na tat syan na pati≈õ ca sa syan na mocayed yah samupeta-m·πõtyum 1316 210 The Mantra-guru Is Also Compulsory ‡§Ö‡§§ ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‚Äú‡§ú‡•Å‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É‚Äù ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•§‡•´‡•§‡•ß‡•´) ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ Therefore, ≈öri Narada said: It was a great impropriety on your part to prescribe repre- hensible actions in the name of religion for people who are already naturally predisposed to such actions. On the strength of your instructions, the common person, having determined this alone as primary dharma, will not heed any prohibition of such motivated actions. (SB 1.5.15)2 ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ö‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ã‡§∑‡§≠‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• Therefore, one should treat the above-mentioned individuals as teachers, relatives, and so on only for as long as one has not obtained the shelter of the feet of a guru who can deliver one from the world of death. This is the sense. Commentary THE MANTRA-GURU is compulsory on the path of bhakti. In fact, bhakti only truly begins after one has accepted mantra-dƒ´k·π£ƒÅ. In enumerating the limbs of bhakti, ≈örƒ´ R≈´pa GosvƒÅmi counts the acceptance of a guru as the very foundation of the entire practice. He writes as follows: 2 One should take shelter of a genuine guru, accept formal initiation (dik·π£ƒÅ) from him in the K·πõ·π£·πáa-mantra, and take instructions from him [regarding bhƒÅgavata-dharma] One should render service to him with reverence and follow the path of conduct established by saintly devotees. (BRS 1.2.74)* jugupsitam dharma-k·πõte’nusasata·∏• svabhava-raktasya mahan vyatikrama·∏• yad-vakyato dharma ititarah sthito na manyate tasya nivƒÅra·πáam janah 3 ≈örila Mukunda DƒÅsa Gosvami 4 guru-padasrayas tasmƒÅt k·πõ·π£·πáa-dik·π£ƒÅdi-sik·π£a·πáam vi≈õrambhena guro·∏• seva sadhu-vartmanuvartanam 1317 II How Aki√±cana-bhakti Is Attained In the past in India, everybody had a guru. A person without a guru was designated as nigurƒÉ or nigora, and this word is still used as an abusive expression, although people have forgotten its original meaning. There were two types of gurus, the family guru and the spiritual guru. They could both be the same person or dif- ferent, depending upon their qualifications. For example, from ≈örimad Bhagavata, we understand that Garga Muni was K·πõ·π£·πáa’s family guru, but His guru in the matter of spiritual education was Sandipani Muni. The family guru was the one who guided the fam- ily members in religious ceremonies related to the var·πáƒÅ≈õrama sys- tem, such as a child’s birth, the name-giving ceremony, the sacred- thread ceremony, marriage, and other conventional duties. ≈örƒ´ Jiva GosvƒÅmi designates the family guru as a vyavahƒÅrika- guru, a “pragmatic teacher,” or one who guides people in the prac- tical matters of daily life. This guru was supposed to be expert in moral law (i.e., the dharma-sastras), astrology (jyotisa), and also Ayurveda. But to attain life’s ultimate goal, one requires a pƒÅramƒÅrthika-guru, or a teacher who guides the aspirant in the matter of spiritual truth. If a conflict should arise between these two teachers, one is advised to give up the vyavahƒÅrika-guru. In this regard, the recommendation to give up the vyavahƒÅrika- guru does not necessarily mean giving up completely, since he may still be respected as a pragmatic guide and engaged in religious cer- emonies and other such material affairs. But for spiritual guidance, one must accept another qualified guru. There is no harm incurred in doing so, because the purpose of life is not just to follow the prin- ciples of dharma but to attain love for Bhagavan. This indeed is the real purpose of dharma (SB 1.2.13, Anuccheda 8). Thus, if conventional dharma, or one’s family guru, is not ori- ented toward the ultimate goal of prema, they should be given up. This is the reason why K·πõ·π£·πáa recommended the abandonment of karma, or dharma, once one has attained ≈õraddha in bhakti, as stated in SB 11.20.9 and Gƒ™TƒÄ 18.66 (see Anuccheda 173). The same instruc- tion is imparted by R·π£abhadeva to His sons. King Bali is a famous example of one who disobeyed his family guru, SukrƒÅcƒÅrya, when 1318 210 The Mantra-guru Is Also Compulsory the latter advised him not to offer three steps of land to Bhaga- v√§n Vamanadeva. Abandoning one’s guru is ordinarily a grievous offense, but in this case, it was commendable on the part of Bali. In the final verse of this anucheda (SB 1.5.15), ≈örƒ´ Narada criti- cized Vyasa because he primarily stressed the path of karma-kanda, which keeps people bound to materialism. Those who are already so inclined would not care to give it up, especially when an author- ity such as Vyasa has prescribed it. This is the primary reason why Buddha had to come and decry the Vedas. 1319Anuccheda 211 Even a VyavahƒÅrika-guru Should Be Respected ‡•®‡•ß‡•ß | ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•å ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ( ‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•ß‡•ß‡•§‡•ß‡•≠‡•§‡•®‡•≠) - OTHERWISE, even those who adhere to the path of karma are meant to uphold the vision that Bhagavan has manifested in and as their own guru, as ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa said: ‡§Ü‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§É ‡•• ‡•¨‡•®‡•≠ ‡•• ·Åã One should know the preceptor to be Myself. One should never disregard or envy him, thinking him to be a common mortal, because the guru is the embodiment of all the gods. (SB 11.17.27)1 ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§™‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•• This verse was spoken in the context of the duties of a student, or brahmacƒÅrƒ´. Commentary IN THIS VERSE, K·πõ·π£·πáa is referring to a vyavahƒÅrika-guru and not to a paramarthika-guru, or spiritual preceptor, because this verse is found in a section describing the duties of a brahmacƒÅrƒ´, which is part of the var·πáƒÅ≈õrama-dharma. This means that even 1 ƒÅcƒÅryam mƒÅm vijƒÅnƒ´yan nƒÅvamanyeta karhicit na martya-buddhyƒÅs√ºyeta sarva-deva-mayo guruh 1320 211 Even a VyavahƒÅrika-guru Should Be Respected a vyavahƒÅrika-guru is to be regarded in the same manner as a p√§ram√§rthika-guru, as long as there is no conflict between them in terms of their respective instructions. It is only if the vyavahƒÅrika-guru becomes an obstacle to the path of bhakti that one can disobey or even abandon him. This is due to the fact that the vyavahƒÅrika-guru generally also facilitates one’s spiritual advancement. It is for this reason that K·πõ·π£·πáa says, “Know the preceptor to be Myself.” Even so, if the very same con- ventional preceptor becomes an obstacle, then he is fit to be given up, because he is then acting contrary to his intended function. See- ing the Divine in one’s elders and teachers and behaving accord- ingly is the appropriate training and preparation for a student who will eventually take a paramarthika-guru. 1321 Anuccheda 212 The Paramarthika-guru Is Directly BhagavƒÅn ‡•®‡•ß‡•® ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•á ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•≠‡•§‡•ß‡•´‡•§‡•®‡•¨-‡•®‡•≠) - SUCH being the case, it is all the more incumbent on those who are intent upon the realization of spiritual truth (paramƒÅrthis) to uphold the vision that Bhagavan has manifested in and as their pƒÅramƒÅrthika-guru, as ≈örƒ´ Narada informed Yudhisthira: 2 ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•å ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§∂‡•å‡§ö‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡•¨‡•®‡•Æ ‡•• ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ‡•¨‡•®‡•Ø ‡•• One who considers the guru, who is directly Bhagavan and who illuminates the heart with the lamp of wisdom, as a mortal being, has a perverted understanding, and all his scriptural study is futile, like the bathing of an elephant. He [the guru] is directly Bhagavan, who is the Regulator of pri- mordial nature and the living beings, and whose feet are sought by great masters of yoga. Yet [out of delusion], worldly people think of him as a human being. (SB 7.15.26-27)2 ≈örƒ´ Jiva’s statement here is syntactically connected to the words bhagavad-drstih kartavya, “the vision of Bhagavan [in and as their guru] is to be had [by them],” from his opening statement to the previous anuccheda. These words are required to complete the sense of what is stated here. yasya sƒÅk·π£ƒÅd bhagavati j√±ƒÅna-dipa-prade gurau martyƒÅsad-dhi·∏• ≈õrutam tasya sarvam kunjara-saucavat 1322 212 The Paramarthika-guru Is Directly Bhagavan ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ- ‡§∞‡§¶‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• He (e·π£a·∏•) [the guru referred to in the previous verse], although characterized as ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa Himself, [is viewed as an ordinary human being]. Therefore, material vision is not a means of valid knowing (pramƒÅ≈Üa) as regards the cognition of the ontological truth of BhagavƒÅn. Commentary BHAGAVAN has appointed various devas to oversee the adminis- tration of universal affairs, but the department of spiritual edu- cation is under His own control. Therefore, He Himself takes the form of the guru to teach conditioned beings the means to attain Him. Uddhava also confirms the same conclusion elsewhere in the BhƒÅgavata (SB 11.29.6). Therefore, ≈örƒ´ NƒÅrada twice affirms that the guru is “directly Bhagavan” (sƒÅk·π£ƒÅd-bhagavan). The modi- fier sƒÅk·π£ƒÅt signifies that the guru should not even be considered a partial manifestation of Bhagavan. In the verse cited in the previous anuccheda (SB 11.17.27), K·πõ·π£·πáa stated that even a vyavahƒÅrika-guru is to be regarded as identical to Him. Thus it is all the more self-evident that a paramarthika-guru is to be regarded as K·πõ·π£·πáa Himself. If one considers the paramarthika- guru to be an ordinary human being, then it will not be possible to obtain spiritual knowledge from him, because spiritual knowledge cannot be disclosed via a material source. The student has to have this faith, otherwise the transfer of knowledge will not take place. As it is said, “One’s attainment is in direct correspondence to his or her faith” (yƒÅd·πõsi bhƒÅvanƒÅ yasya siddhir bhavati tƒÅd·πõ≈õƒ´). One may object that it is impossible to consider the guru as Bha- gavan. He appears and functions like any other human being. The reply is that in this matter, sastra alone is the authority. When K·πõ·π£·πáa appeared on earth, He also looked and acted like other esa vai bhagavan s√§k·π£ƒÅt pradhana-purusesvarah yoge≈õvarair vim·πõgyanghrir loko ya·πÅ manyate naram 1323 II How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained human beings. Though exceptional in many ways, outstandingly beautiful, and immensely qualified, He too ate, slept, felt hungry, and even passed urine (cf. SB 10.8.31). Additionally, He married and produced children. But on the authority of sastra, He is accepted as Svayam Bhagavan. Therefore, the guru should also be recognized as Bhagavan on the same authority. Even K·πõ·π£·πáa Himself accepted S√§ndipani Muni as His guru and served him exactly as He would Bhagavan. 1324 Anuccheda 213 The Guru Is Most Dear to BhagavƒÅn ‡•®‡•ß‡•© | ‡§∂‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ (‡§≠‡§æ‡•¶ ‡•™‡•§‡•©‡•¶‡•ß‡•©‡•Æ)- ON THE other hand, some pure devotees regard ≈öri guru and ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva as nondistinct from Sri Bhagavan, simply on the basis of their being most dear to Him. The Pracetas conveyed this idea to the eight-armed form of Bhagavan [who had appeared before them]: . ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•á‡§® ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ ‡•• ‡•¨‡•©‡•¶ ‡•• O Bhagavan, by a moment’s association with Your dear friend Bhava (≈öiva), we have directly attained You as our ultimate des- tination and as the topmost physician for treating the virtually incurable disease of material existence (bhava)’ in the form of repeated birth and death. (SB 4.30.38)2 ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ö - “‡§§‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ ‡•§ ≈örƒ´dhara SvƒÅmi also comments: “[By the association] of this Bhava (≈öiva), who is Your dear friend, we have attained You Here there is a play on the word bhava, which means “material existence” and is also a name for ≈öiva. So, by the association of “Bhava,” the Pracetas attained Bhagavan as the topmost physician to treat the disease of ‚Äúbhava.” 2 vayam tu sƒÅk·π£ƒÅd bhagavan bhavasya priyasya sakhyuh k·π£ana-sangamena sudu≈õcikitsyasya bhavasya mrtyor bhisaktamam tvadya gatim gata·∏• sma·∏• 1325 II How Akincana-bhakti Is Attained as our ultimate destination (gati) and as the topmost physician (bhi≈üaktama), or expert healer (sad-vaidya), to treat the virtu- ally incurable disease of material existence (bhava) in the form of repeated birth and death.” ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§É ‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•• ≈örƒ´ ≈öiva is the guru of the Pracetas, who spoke this verse. Commentary THE PRESENT VERSE is spoken by the Pracetas, who accepted ≈öiva as their guru, recognizing him as both a great devotee and a dear friend of Bhagavan. Up until now, it has been said that the guru is directly Bhagavan and should be respected accordingly. In fact, one of the most popular verses in India about the guru goes as follows: The guru is Brahma; the guru is Vis≈Üu; the guru is Deva Mahes- vara (≈öiva). Indeed, the guru alone is the Supreme Reality (Param- brahma). I bow down to him, ≈örƒ´ Guru. (Skanda Purana, Guru- gƒ´tƒÅ 1.1)3 Now, ≈öri Jiva reveals a still higher secret, namely, the transra- tional principle of simultaneous distinction and nondistinction (acintya-bheda-abheda). The guru is to be respected as Bhagavan Himself, implying their nondistinction (abheda), yet he is the most dear devotee of Bhagavan, which entails the distinction between lover and beloved (bheda). The guru’s oneness with Bhagavan is due to the totality of his love, yet he is not absolutely one with Him in the ontological sense. This is the understanding of highly realized devotees. In this regard, ≈örƒ´ Vi≈õvanatha Cakravarti has 3 sung: I bow down to the lotus feet of ≈örƒ´ Guru, who is proclaimed by all the scriptures as Hari Himself [≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa] and who is honored gurur brahma gurur visnur guruh devo mahe≈õvara·∏• gurur eva para·πÅ brahma tasmai sri gurave nama·∏• 1326 213 The Guru Is Most Dear to Bhagavan in this manner by saints, yet he indeed is a beloved devotee of Bhagavan. (Gurvastakam 7)^ The relation between Siva and K·πõ·π£·πáa is of the same nature of oneness and distinction. In many places, ≈öiva is depicted as non- different from Krsna or Visnu, yet he is also known as a great devo- tee of Vis≈Üu. The oneness between them is due to love. Therefore, the guru and ≈öiva should be honored as great devotees of Krsna. This attitude is very pleasing to Bhagavan. It is to be noted, how- ever, that to meditate on the guru exclusively as SƒÅk·π£ad Bhagavan runs counter to the mood of practice in rƒÅgƒÅnuga-bhakti, because in this type of devotion, one serves K·πõ·π£·πáa under the guidance of a guru who is himself a devotee. In rƒÅgƒÅnuga, the mood is to be the servant of a servant and not a direct servant of Krsna. If the guru is accepted as Bhagavan directly, there can be no rƒÅgƒÅnugƒÅ, because the latter means to follow the raga of Bhagavan’s associates. HERE ENDS VOLUME I OF SRI BHAKTI SANDARBHA. sƒÅk·π£ƒÅd-dharitvena samasta-sƒÅstrair uktas tatha bhavyata eva sadbhi·∏• kintu prabhor yah priya eva tasya vande guro·∏• ≈õri cara·πáƒÅravindam BHAKTI is a specific functional capacity of Bhagavan’s intrinsic potency, and as such, it belongs to Him alone. By His causeless grace, He invests this potency into His devotees, who can then transmit it to other living beings by the same power of grace. Without the grace of a devotee or Bhagavan, bhakti cannot make its appearance within the atma. In this regard, since Bhagavan is not manifest to people in general except when He descends into the material world as an avatara, His direct grace is scarcely available. Consequently, at all other times, when there is no manifest avatara on earth, bhakti is available only through the grace of a devotee. The devotees’ grace has no specific cause, because they are not in need of anything material. Their grace usually comes about through the medium of hearing their words and rendering some form of personal service to them. This grace is first transmitted in the form of faith, ≈õraddha, appearing in those who receive their grace. Initially, this faith is directed toward the very same devotees whose presence and teachings originally gave birth to it. One is then struck with the feeling that such realized devotees are exceptional human beings, and one is drawn to associate with them, listen to what they say, and render service to them. From the commentary on Anuccheda 11 SJIVA Jiva Institute of Vaishnava Studies Vrindavan
